HEADLINE: Ford Reaches Tentative Pact With Union

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 16

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union reached agreement this evening on a new national labor contract intended to protect the jobs of current and future union workers, while providing wage increases modestly exceeding the inflation rate.
While union and corporate executives refused to discuss the pact's details, Wall Street analysts said the contract would last three years and represented a landmark compromise for Ford's 105,000 U.A.W.-represented workers. Ford guaranteed that the number of U.A.W. workers in its factories would remain at least at 95 percent of the current total, with Ford hiring new workers if necessary to replace retirees, they said. 
 In exchange, analysts said, Ford won the right to pay permanently lower wages in any new auto parts businesses that it might enter, either by building new factories or by buying them.
Both sides said the deal was mutually beneficial. "We're satisfied; I think we've got a good deal," said Alexander Trotman, Ford's chairman, chief executive and president, at a news conference.
Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, said that he hoped to persuade General Motors and Chrysler to accept similar contracts. "We were going after an agreement all the companies could work with, and that's where we are," he said.
Wall Street analysts differed on whether G.M., with its large work force, could afford to guarantee to keep employment at 95 percent of current levels. "If I had to make up something G.M. couldn't accept, that would be it," said David B. Healy, an auto analyst at Burnham Securities.
But Nicholas Lobaccaro, an analyst at Bear, Stearns, thought that G.M. might have little choice about accepting the same terms, given the damage that a U.A.W. strike this autumn could wreak on G.M.'s planned introduction of 15 new models. "If it comes down to a game of chicken, I would have to bet on the union," Mr. Lobaccaro said.
The U.A.W. chose to negotiate first with Ford after the company drafted the innovative deal that was apparently approved today. People close to the Detroit auto makers were already able to describe this compromise in interviews on Sept. 4 and 5, although hard bargaining was needed in the final days to fix the precise level of employment that Ford would guarantee.
The U.A.W. has warm relations with Ford, and never even threatened a strike during the negotiations. By contrast, the union and G.M. have an adversarial relationship that produced a 17-day strike in March at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, that crippled the North American operations of the company, the world's largest industrial enterprise.
The wage and benefit details of today's Ford pact were decided at the last moment, after the expiration of the previous three-year agreement at midnight on Saturday. Wall Street analysts said Ford had agreed to a sharp increase in pension benefits, a $2,000 bonus for all workers and a 3 percent raise in each of the second and third years of the contract. The bonus and raise are in addition to the U.A.W.'s annual cost-of-living adjustments, which the union has had since 1948.
Stephen Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said the settlement was fairly costly. He predicted the higher pension benefits would hurt G.M., which has considerably more pensioners than Ford in proportion to its current workers.
"It looks to me like Ford gave where they could afford to give and where other guys potentially couldn't," Mr. Girsky said.
G.M.'s workers have an average age of 48, and are retiring at a rate of roughly 5 percent a year. The 95 percent employment guarantee, if applied to G.M., would prevent the company. from taking advantage of that reduction in its work force.
The previous three-year labor contract for Ford's 105,000 U.A.W. employees expired at midnight on Saturday, but work continued without any disruption while the negotiators wrapped up their deal.
The union scheduled a board meeting for Tuesday, a meeting of local union presidents on Wednesday and a ratification vote by union members on Sept. 29.
All of the union approvals are nearly automatic because the U.A.W. is a highly centralized bureaucracy and its members, particularly at Ford, traditionally ratify new contracts by margins of 9 to 1 or more.
Mr. Yokich said this evening that the U.A.W. had not made a decision on whether to negotiate next with Chrysler or G.M. He pointed out that he was in close touch with the Canadian Automobile Workers, which is negotiating with Chrysler and is threatening to go on strike at midnight on Tuesday if a deal cannot be reached by then.
The U.A.W. and the Canadian union have a tradition of not negotiating with the same company at the same time.
If the Canadian union does go on strike, it would halve Chrysler's production of highly profitable minivans. Basil E. Hargrove, the Canadian union's president, broke off negotiations with Chrysler early this evening, but resumed them shortly before midnight following more discussions on restrictions on Chrysler's purchase of parts from outside suppliers.
Nicole A. Solomon, a Chrysler spokeswoman, was optimistic that a strike still could be averted. "We believe that we will have an agreement with the C.A.W., hopefully tomorrow," Ms. Solomon said.
Mr. Hargrove was more worried. "The clock is working against us at this point," he said late tonight.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CANDIDATES;
Dole Attacks on Crime, but Clinton Is Ready

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The 1996 Presidential campaign abruptly shifted from the economy to crime today. Bob Dole maintained that President Clinton had presided over an epidemic of juvenile drug use and crime, and Mr. Clinton appeared amid an ocean of blue uniforms to receive the support of the nation's largest police union.
Mr. Dole's tough-worded attack, at Villanova University, was buttressed by a new round of television advertisements devoted to crime and drugs, and signaled that he would play down, at least for the next few days, the tax-cut proposal that has dominated his campaign for more than a month but has yet to show signs of catching on. 
 Instead, he will turn increasingly to the crime issue, which has served Republicans reliably since Richard M. Nixon's election to the Presidency in 1968.
But the endorsement of Mr. Clinton, by the Fraternal Order of Police, a 270,000-member union that had never before supported a Democrat for President, was yet another marker of success in his longstanding effort, dating from his years as Governor of Arkansas, to seize the issue from Republicans.
For the event announcing that endorsement, the President traveled to Cincinnati, where George Bush won the same union's backing four years ago in the race against Mr. Clinton.
The timing of today's event allowed it to compete against Mr. Dole's anti-crime speech at Villanova, a major appearance on the Republican nominee's schedule.
Mr. Dole issued his critique of Mr. Clinton's record on drugs and crime to a cheering, mostly college-age audience in a gymnasium at the university, along Philadelphia's Main Line.
He won a standing ovation as he promised that he would cut drug use among teen-agers in half during his first term in office. His audience cheered again when he promised that as President he would issue an executive order requiring able-bodied Federal convicts to work at least 40 hours a week while in prison, with their pay compensating the victims of their crimes. He also called for cutting back prisoner access to pornography and weight-lifting rooms; urged legislation to treat violent juvenile criminals as adults in sentencing, consideration of prior crimes and public release of their criminal records, and said he would double, to $810 million, the annual Federal contribution to state prison-building programs to make it easier to abolish parole for violent felons.
Mr. Dole has already pledged to cut taxes by $548 billion over six years while concurrently balancing the Federal budget, and his aides were unable to explain today where the increased financing of prison construction would come from.
In any event, his speech was less notable for new proposals than for the implicit acknowledgment that the tax-cut idea that has been a staple of his campaign may not be working, and for his moving aggressively to an alternative theme. Mr. Dole repeatedly suggested that what he described as Mr. Clinton's liberal ways had contributed to a values breakdown that explained a surge in drug use.
"Liberalism keeps showing itself through the Administration's crime policies," he said, speaking forcefully as he stood on a stage filled with the Republican governors of 13 states as well as his running mate, Jack Kemp. "Yes, the President talks about being tough on crime. But, as with so much else that this Administration does, his actions tell a different story than his words. He talks like Dirty Harry, but he acts like Barney Fife."
(Clinton aides later noted that the line contrasting Clint Eastwood's tough San Francisco police officer with the bumbling deputy sheriff on the old "Andy Griffith Show" was originally used by Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia, in referring to President Bush, during a keynote speech at the 1992 Democratic National Convention.)
Mr. Dole blamed the "Administration's old liberal view that law enforcement is less important than social engineering" for drug use among teen-agers. His aides explained later that this was a reference to what they portrayed as Mr. Clinton's emphasis on drug treatment, at the expense of law enforcement.
"This liberal approach failed over and over and over again through the decades," Mr. Dole said, adding, "Americans are tired of being guinea pigs in a discredited liberal-leaning laboratory of leniency."
"What works in combating crime is no mystery," Mr. Dole said. "It begins with the understanding that the cause of crime can be explained with one simple word: Criminals. Criminals. Criminals."
Mr. Dole cited statistics showing a sharp increase in drug use. Most recently, in August, the Government reported that drug use among teen-agers soared 105 percent from 1992 to 1995. Mr. Dole laid the blame for that at the White House steps.
"Thanks to the liberal wink-and-nod policies of this Administration," he said, "drug use among teen-agers has not just started up again, it's skyrocketing upward."
Hours after Mr. Dole had completed his speech, Mr. Clinton offered what amounted to a visual rebuttal. He took the stage at the Cincinnati Music Hall -- rain had forced the event indoors -- surrounded by men and women in blue uniforms, in front of a big blue banner that said, "Law Enforcement Stands Behind President Clinton."
The endorsement announced there by the Fraternal Order of Police was a reward for Mr. Clinton's efforts to court law-enforcement organizations. From his longtime support for the death penalty, to passage of his 1994 crime bill intended to help localities hire 100,000 more police officers, to his successful backing of the Brady Bill and a ban on 19 types of assault weapons, the President has increasingly allied himself with law enforcers, against civil liberties groups and gun rights advocates alike.
Mr. Clinton has already received endorsements from the National Association of Police Organizations and the International Union of Police Associations. Those groups, together with the Fraternal Order, represent about 70 percent of all rank-and-file officers in the nation.
Rattling off a list of his anti-crime measures in Cincinnati today, Mr. Clinton said: "This Administration is not responsible for any of these ideas; we got all these ideas from law-enforcement people themselves. All we did was listen and act. All we did was take what was working and try to go national with it."
The President acknowledged the political difficulty encountered by some members of Congress in voting for two bills he supported that helped lead to today's endorsement: the assault-weapons ban and the Brady Bill, which requires a waiting period for handgun purchases.
"A lot of good people who voted for those bills were defeated in 1994 in their race for Congress," Mr. Clinton said, "because the interest group that was against them went out and told good, God-fearing people from Ohio and Arkansas and other places that the President had gone off the deep end and he and Congress had taken their guns away."
Mr. Clinton was joined on the flight from Washington to Cincinnati by the president of the Fraternal Order, Gilbert G. Gallegos, who told reporters that the endorsement was decided on a vote of 20 to 10 by the organization's board at a meeting in Houston last Friday.
While the Clinton endorsement by the police union, which supported Mr. Bush not only in 1992 but in 1988 as well, was clearly unwelcome news for Mr. Dole, he shrugged it off.
"We knew we wouldn't get the endorsement," he said in one of several interviews with local television stations around the country this afternoon. "He's been wining and dining the union officials. It is a union, so you can expect the union leaders -- not the rank and file, but the union leaders -- to go for the Democrats."

HEADLINE: Wall Streeters Test Water Futures

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

 BODY:
The smartly dressed commuters walked down the gangplank for the East River Express yesterday, clutching newspapers and briefcases, flashing a smile as they boarded the ferry, a far cry from the city's crowded subways, where they jostle every day for a seat.
"I've been waiting for this for a long time," said Stephen P. Brooks, a Wall Street investment banker and a resident of the Upper East Side. "Finally, a pleasant way to commute." 
 And so it was throughout the first day of ferry service for hundreds of East Side commuters. At the 7:05 A.M. departure of the first ferry, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proclaimed that the service would spur the revitalization of the downtown financial district and make it more competitive with midtown.
The 35-minute morning ride on the ferryboat, the Henry Hudson, began at East 90th Street and continued to its final stop at Pier 17, at the South Street Seaport, making one other stop, at East 34th Street. At the 34th Street and Pier 17 stops, red, white and blue New York Waterway buses greeted passengers to take them near their offices without charge.
The ferry service will be free this week, and after that the operators will charge $5. But on Oct. 25, the ferry's operators, New York Waterway, will stop the service and reassess it. It plans to resume full operation by the spring.
During the early-morning ferry ride, which departed from an obscured dock near Carl Schurz Park on East 90th Street, passengers watched with self-satisfaction as thousands of cars remained stuck in traffic on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and the Brooklyn Bridge.
While many Wall Streeters were aboard yesterday, there were also many riders who came to take advantage of the free service, giving the clientele the look of a cruise ship. Tourists, retirees and teen-agers out for a joy ride mixed in with the commuters who operators hope will be the mainstay of the service.
"It's very convenient," said Blair Boardman, an investment banker who lives on East 93d Street and works downtown. "It's nice to wake up on the water as opposed to being slammed against 300 people on the subway."
The ferry service was developed as an alternative for the thousands of Upper East Side commuters who have to fight through crowded subway cars, sit in traffic jams or pay up to $15 for a taxi to work.
But the ferry ride, when it does begin costing money, may not be for those on a tight budget. At $5 a pop, it is considerably more expensive than the $1.50 that the Transit Authority charges for the subways, the $3.50 to take a van or the $4 for an express bus. And Arthur E. Imperatore Jr., the New York Waterway president, said the price would remain at $5.
"If we made the price too low, we'd have too many people," Mr. Imperatore said. "And we'd have to add service, which adds to the cost."
Some passengers took the trip yesterday in part because it was free. They said that while they do not plan to use the ferry to go to work regularly, they plan to use it as a backup.
"It's a little expensive for me," said Martin Schwartzman, a software developer. But he added, "This is probably the nicest trip downtown I've ever had."
For many would-be passengers, however, the ferry arrives in the Wall Street area too late for many of the traders who must get to work bright and early. "I can't believe they did not check this out," said Brian Rieddle, one of the traders.
New York Waterway, which hauls about 25,000 commuters a day between New York and New Jersey across the Hudson, is selling ferry service as more reliable and pleasurable than driving or riding the train.
While the region's train tracks and highways were virtually shut down during the blizzard last January, the ferry sailed on, although with only a handful of passengers, Mr. Imperatore said.
Yesterday, there were a few bumps along the way. Six northbound pleasure boats rushed by, rocking the ferry, with the worst casualties being spilled coffee.

HEADLINE: Clerical Workers' Strike at Barnard Ends in Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
After five months on the picket line, clerical workers at Barnard College yesterday ended one of the longest strikes ever at an American college by ratifying a contract in which Barnard gave in to employee demands on health insurance.
Ending a strike that embarrassed Barnard's administration and strained the strikers' finances, Barnard agreed to pay all of the workers' health insurance premiums and to allow the workers to remain in their old health care plan. 
 "It's a nice victory for labor," said Catherine Cook, one of the 164 strikers and an administrative assistant to Barnard's dean of studies. "It was a long strike, though."
During the emotional confrontation, many professors refused to hold classes on campus, while at commencement, dozens of students who supported the strike sought to pressure and embarrass Barnard's administration by unfurling banners and carrying signs.
While union members hailed the agreement, Barnard officials defended it, saying it achieved important health care savings for the college and contained almost all of Barnard's original pay offer. The strikers, members of Local 2110 of the United Auto Workers, will receive a 9.5 percent raise over three years, considerably more than many other New York unions have won recently, but a shade less than what clerical workers at neighboring Columbia Teachers' College won last year.
Barry Kaufman, Barnard's vice president for finance and administration, said, "While this was a difficult period for all of us, both the college and the union have achieved important economic objectives, and for us, it reverses a five-year trend of increases on health care costs."
Barnard officials said that by instituting such cost-cutting measures as requiring second opinions before medical procedures, the contract would save the school at least $120,000 in the first year. They also said Barnard saved money by rejecting the union's demand for pay increases retroactive to Jan. 1.
"The settlement is tremendously fair to both sides," said Robert Linn, who was brought in as Barnard's chief negotiator in early July after talks soured.
Under the contract, workers with more than five years' experience will receive a $150 lump-sum bonus in each of the next three years, workers with 10 years will receive $250, and those with 15 years, $400.
Among the stumbling blocks was Barnard's insistence that workers switch from a Group Health Inc. plan to Oxford, which the union rejected.

HEADLINE: Inventories Rise as Business Bets on Sales

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Stockpiles of unsold goods at American businesses soared to the highest level in more than a decade in July, suggesting that businesses were betting that a surge in demand would continue.
Their gamble -- which lifted inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent, to more than $1 trillion, for the first time since 1982 -- could still pay off this fall, analysts said, even though the Government reported on Friday that retail sales in August barely budged from a month before. 
 Low joblessness, climbing wages, record consumer confidence and gains in the stock market are giving Americans renewed spending power, said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston in New York. "I don't see any reason to be pessimistic on the sales side," he said.
Still, economists had predicted an increase of only two-tenths of a percent in July business inventories. In June, inventories remained unchanged, according to a revised report from the Government. A month ago, the Commerce Department estimated that June inventories increased by a tenth of a percent.
Because total business sales in July grew by 1.2 percent, to $720.55 billion, the inventory-to-sales ratio -- a measure of how long it would take to sell existing stocks at the current pace -- fell to 1.39 months' worth in July from 1.40 months in June.
 Analysts attributed most of the rise in inventories to optimism about sales prospects. Still, "there seems to be a disconnect between what's happening at retail, manufacturing and wholesale levels," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at the Barnett Banks in Jacksonville, Fla. Indeed, Most of the July increase in inventories came at retailers, whose stockpiles rose 1.1 percent, while wholesale inventories rose only one-tenth of a percent and manufacturers' stocks rose by two-tenths of a percent.
A 1.4 percent rise in auto and truck inventories played a part in the retail buildup. And in the weeks since, Detroit auto makers have cautioned that sales gains will be hard to come by.
A lull in spending when inventory levels are high can force businesses to curtail production or orders while they empty warehouses and store shelves. "If retail sales fail to improve, we will start to see the repercussions throughout the pipeline," Ms. Reaser said.
While the inventory report caused some analysts to increase their third-quarter growth estimates to 2.8 percent or higher, they also said it lended more credence to the notion that the Federal Reserve would leave the Federal funds rate, its target rate for overnight lending between banks, unchanged at 5.25 percent at a policy meeting on Sept. 24.
The Fed "probably won't go until after the elections" in November, said Bill Gamba, a senior vice president at Cowen & Company. Still, investors, Fed policy makers and businesses face the same tough decision: gauging how fast the economy will grow in the months ahead, economists say. "Inventories can be a very big swing factor," Ms. Reaser said. "They can often make or break a quarter's reading on growth."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 20, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article by Bloomberg Business News on Tuesday about a Government report on business inventories in July referred incorrectly to the significance of a figure exceeding $1 trillion. That was the total reached in July for the first time since the Government began collecting inventory data in 1982. It was not the inventory figure for 1982.

HEADLINE: New Republic And Cuban Agree to Settle Libel Lawsuit

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
The leader of the most powerful anti-Castro Cuban exile group in the United States announced yesterday that he had agreed to settle a libel suit against The New Republic for an article in the political weekly magazine that called him a mobster.
The magazine agreed to contribute $100,000 to the Cuban American National Foundation, or C.A.N.F., for a scholarship and to apologize for an article in the issue of Oct. 3, 1994, about the foundation's chairman, Jorge Mas Canosa. The article was headlined "Clinton's Miami Mobster." 
 The foundation and the magazine said in a joint statement, "The New Republic regrets its use of the word 'mobster' on the cover of the magazine and in a headline above the article (both of which were the sole responsibility of the New Republic and not the author) and apologizes for any injury or embarrassment that may have been caused to Mr. Mas Canosa or his family."
Mr. Mas Canosa said at a news conference in Miami, "I accept with much happiness this $100,000 on behalf of the C.A.N.F.," The Associated Press reported. "I believe this represents a victory for the cause of Cuban freedom and for our community."
It was the second legal victory of sorts for Mr. Mas Canosa; in August, Wayne Smith, a former American diplomat in Havana who is now a university professor and a specialist in Cuban affairs, was found to have defamed Mr. Mas Canosa's foundation in a 1992 PBS documentary.
A copy of the correction to be run in the next issue of The New Republic was attached to the joint statement. It read: "The New Republic did not intend to accuse Mr. Mas Canosa of being in any way connected to, or engaged in, criminal activity of any kind, nor was its use of the word based on any evidence of criminal activity on Mr. Mas Canosa'spart."
Floyd Abrams, a lawyer who is an expert on the First Amendment, said on the face of it, the settlement seemed appropriate. "I'm all in favor of magazines apologizing when they're wrong," Mr. Abrams said. "I think we have too little of that, not too much of it. There is nothing intrinsically troubling about it. If they called him that and they had no basis, then an apology is justified."
With the $100,000, the Cuban American foundation said it planned to establish "The New Republic Scholarship," for the education of needy Cuban-American students.
As part of the settlement, Mr. Mas Canosa agreed to dismiss his suit against the New Republic and the article's author, Ann Louise Bardach, a freelance writer. The libel suit was dismissed with prejudice, meaning that it can not be refiled.
"The New Republic and Mr. Mas Canosa are pleased to have resolved their dispute," the statement said, "because, although they may have differences, they both have strongly expressed support for policies aimed at bringing an end to the Communist dictatorship of Fidel Castro and bringing democracy to Cuba."
Mr. Mas Canosa's exile group lobbied successfully this year for passage of the Helms-Burton Act extending the American economic embargo against Cuba, and the organization is widely regarded as a principal architect of American policy toward Cuba.
 The article also misstated the occupation of Ann Louise Bardach, the author of the article. She is a contributing editor at Vanity Fair, not a freelance writer.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 10, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 17 about the settlement of a libel case filed by Jorge Mas Canosa, the leader of a Cuban exile group in the United States, against The New Republic misstated the issue in the lawsuit. It involved wording in the headline and an overline, not in the article itself.

HEADLINE: Misreading the Gender Gap

BYLINE: By Carol Tavris; Carol Tavris, a social psychologist, is the author of "The Mismeasure of Woman."

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Do you know about the gender gap in paranormal beliefs? Women are more likely than men to believe in horoscopes and psychics. People who are unsympathetic to women say it's because women are more gullible or dumber than men; those who are sympathetic to women say it's because women are more open-minded or spiritual than men.
Actually, this gender gap pretty much vanishes when you consider years of education and the number of math and science classes a person has taken. What appears to be a gender gap is in fact a science gap. 
 Do you know about the gender gap in anger? Men are more likely than women to express anger directly and abusively (except maybe in New York, where everyone ventilates). The antiwoman reason is that women are sneakier and more manipulative than men; the pro-woman version is that women are kinder and less aggressive than men.
Actually, the gender gap in expressions of anger pretty much vanishes when you consider the status of the people involved. Both sexes tend to be indirect and manipulative when they are angry at someone who has more power than they have -- say, bosses and police officers. And both sexes are equally likely to lose their tempers with people who have less power than they have -- say, store clerks or children. What appears to be a gender gap is really a power gap.
Now everybody is talking about the gender gap in the current Presidential campaign. Why are women, even suburban women, who lean more Republican, so much more likely than men to support President Clinton than Bob Dole? According to the most recent New York Times/ CBS News poll, women prefer Mr. Clinton over Mr. Dole by 61 percent to 33 percent. Men favor Mr. Clinton, but by a narrower margin: 49 percent to 42 percent.
First, it's interesting that the fluctuating political differences between the sexes, which ranged from trivial in the Nixon-Kennedy election in 1960 to significant today, capture the public imagination in ways that other "gaps" -- like wealth or geography -- do not. (The last time the country became as exercised about opinions divided along other than gender lines was in the days of the "generation gap" during the Vietnam War.)
Men and women, contrary to what those best-selling books say, aren't different species and don't come from different planets. The overlap between them, on voting choices or personality traits, is always greater than the differences that make headlines.
Then why do more women than men support President Clinton? Conservative explanations, such as one recently offered by Irving Kristol in The Wall Street Journal, are that women "tend to be more sentimental, more risk-averse and less competitive than men . . . and therefore are less inclined to be appreciative of free-market economics."
In short, they are by nature soft-headed liberals -- the kind, he adds, who devised and continue to support the American welfare state, which "has had a feminine coloration from the very beginning." (I guess the Depression didn't affect men, who must have stood idly by, cheering for free-market economics, while legions of women instituted the New Deal.)
Fortunately for conservatives, most women marry and have children, a condition that apparently neutralizes their inherent sentimentality and turns many of them into proper tough-minded Republicans.
Conservatives are so worried about all those women supporting the Democrats that they are claiming the Democratic Party itself has become "feminized" -- just about the nastiest charge you could level at an enemy.
The charge not only calls the enemy a wimp; it dismisses as trivial any issues the opposition endorses, such as the right to abortion, government programs for children and the poor, family leave or gun control, because these "feminine" concerns are of no relevance to the standard-issue human being, that is, the male variety.
Your true Masculinized Republican regards government support of just about any kind as crutches for the whiny. ("If terrible things happen to innocent people," Mr. Kristol explains, it's not up to government to help; the poor need only stoicism and prayer.)
The Democratic version of the gender gap is actually not much different from Mr. Kristol's, but with a positive spin. Women are voting Democratic, in this view, not because they are emotional and muddle-headed but because they are more compassionate and less aggressive than men, and thus attracted to the party that will help the weakest members of society.
Of course, the view that women are natural liberals -- whether that's good or bad -- doesn't explain why more than half of all women voted for Eisenhower, Nixon and Ronald Reagan. It doesn't explain why so many men support Mr. Clinton today, and it doesn't explain why gender gaps widen and shrink with the times.
So let's dispense with sentimental explanations based on personality or nature. Bellicosity is by no means a male preserve, nor is compassion a female one. Women, for all their vaunted empathy, have been as willing as men to regard their political and religious enemies as lesser human beings, heathen or vermin. Affluent women have never shown an especially tender-hearted sympathy toward their sisters in poverty.
Today's gender gap, like the race gap or wealth gap, is primarily caused by issues and economics. As Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster, found, given a choice between a candidate they agree with on the issues but who has character flaws and a candidate with a good character with whom they disagree, both sexes choose the candidate they agree with, by a large margin.
And that, I think, is what is happening in this election too, except that women are more likely to agree with Bill Clinton than Bob Dole. Polls show that the gender gap emerged and widened as more women than men rejected the "Reagan Revolution" they once endorsed.
I'd like to think they changed their minds out of compassion, but a more likely motive is experience. A friend told me about a student of hers, an older woman who had returned to college. "I was always against welfare," the woman told my friend. "I thought it coddled the weak. Then my husband divorced me. I was left with nothing. Welfare saved my life until I could get myself together. I learned first-hand how many women are one divorce away from welfare." If a conservative is a liberal man who's been mugged, a liberal is a conservative woman who's been divorced.
The gender gap, then, is largely an experience gap. More women than men today worry that they or their children might need a safety net if they lose a job, lose a partner or lose their health. More women than men are taking care of aging, infirm parents. Many more single mothers than single fathers are raising children on their own. And young women are learning that sex discrimination in the workplace isn't quite the thing of the past they'd been led to believe.
For women to perceive that Democrats will be more responsive than Republicans to these concerns is neither sentimental nor irrational. It stems from self-interest -- surely a motive that conservatives understand. And the many men who share with women concerns about the health of their families, the education of their children and the stability of their jobs know that these issues are not "feminine," but human.

HEADLINE: Rap Star's Death Highlights Harsher Reality

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With the death of the rap performer Tupac Shakur (front page, Sept. 14), the result of a drive-by shooting on a Las Vegas street, observations are being made again about the sometimes violent lyrics in hip-hop music and the sometimes violent lives its practitioners lead.
A harsher reality is more clear: For too many African-American males of the under-35 generation, violence is the rule rather than the exception of their lives. They just don't care. Even more sobering: nobody else does. 
 As we in the hip-hop community brace for some sort of political attack in this election season, I caution the critics of gangsta rap to chill for a second. Though Mr. Shakur's writings include some troubling imagery, his most compelling works have to do with African-American family struggle. He wrote about the hardships of young women who bring into the world children they are not ready to raise, telling those women not to despair. "Dear Mama" -- an open letter to his mother, the 1960's black liberation activist Afeni Shakur, reveals Mr. Shakur's conflict/love regarding their relationship.
Like most rappers who grew up without fathers in the home, he was outspoken on this issue, telling MTV in 1994 that "I didn't have a father and that makes me cold and bitter." So many songs by young African-American male rappers refer to not having a father around, but nobody seems to be listening. Not Democrats. Not Republicans. Not the older African-American political leadership (but they'll all bark like a pit bull over the lyrics they don't like).
Though we may be numb to Tupac Shakur's murder, it cannot be divorced from the numbness we've developed trying to come up with solutions to the larger problems of African-American males in this society. Though the lack of community response should never justify antisocial behavior (black men also have a responsibility to evade the social land mines laid out for them), we've seen these men collectively become the irrelevant other.
Black or white, rich or poor, male or female, conservative or liberal: we are willfully blind to the 700,000 black men incarcerated in 1994 (up from 25,000 in 1960) and to the 11,000 killed as a result of homicide in 1993, both figures from the Bureau of Justice Statistics; to unemployment and life expectancy that lags far behind every other racial and gender classification.
This class of Americans doesn't have think tanks, political parties or lobbyists. To paraphrase the writer Ralph Wiley, that's why black boys tend to shoot.
 
BILL STEPHNEY
New York, Sept. 16, 1996
 
Chief Executive, Stepsun Music

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Slightly Higher On Hints of Higher U.S. Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar made small gains against most leading currencies yesterday after a report that 8 of the 12 Federal Reserve districts favor higher interest rates.
The dollar was also bolstered as France and Germany indicated they were committed to European monetary union, a development that weakened the mark and indirectly helped the dollar. With a unified currency, the mark would give up its role as the dominant European currency. 
 But the dollar's advance was muted as American stock and bond markets were weak for most of the day.
"The gains are still not terribly significant," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, an advisory firm in Essex, Conn. "The move up is cushioned by the fact the market has had plenty of time" to factor in a possible rise in interest rates, he said. "People are cautious of buying the dollar near the highs."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar stood at 1.5136 marks, up from 1.5100 marks on Monday. The dollar traded at 110.24 yen, up from 110.10. The British pound slipped to $1.5560 from $1.5580.
Traders' attention was captured by a Reuters report that an unidentified senior Federal Reserve official had said that the presidents of 8 of the Fed's 12 district banks had requested a quarter-point increase in the largely symbolic discount rate and that a consensus was emerging for a similar increase in the more important Federal funds rate.
"That was enough for the bond market to take a turn and the dollar to push" upward, said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company.
While the bond market does not like higher interest rates because they erode the value of fixed-income investments, traders in the dollar like them because higher rates attract foreign investors to dollar-denominated securities.
In Europe, the mark lost strength, indirectly helping the dollar, as Finance Minister Jean Arthuis of France reiterated that his country would meet its fiscal targets next year in the drive toward monetary union. France is to announce its budget today.
Also, Finance Minister Theo Waigel of Germany said France and Germany were moving toward an accord insuring adherence to the targets for monetary union.

HEADLINE: City Business Districts Are Held to Account

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To contend that New York City business improvement districts function "with virtually no oversight from an outside agency" (letter, Sept. 12) shows lack of knowledge.
Each district has a board of directors whose members must approve the district's annual expenditures. Sitting on each board is the local City Council member, the city comptroller and the commissioner of the Department of Business Services. On some boards the local community board has a representative. 
 Every May, each district must submit a report to the Department of Business Services that details the district's activities for the past year and includes a complete financial statement. The contract between a business improvement district and the city is usually for five years and is not automatically renewed.
All districts are required to hold annual meetings, open to all, where the next year's operating budget, staff salaries and other programs are presented for consideration and approval.
 
MICHAELA. WEISS
Brooklyn, Sept. 16, 1996
 
Director, Metrotech
Business Improvement District

HEADLINE: Personal Health

SERIES: Second of two columns on how to live safely with dogs.

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
MANY dog lovers act on impulse when they acquire canine companions. They may find an appealing stray on the street and take it in "temporarily." Or they may fall in love with an adorable puppy in the local pound or pet store. Either way, little thought is given to the nature of the beast and how well it will fit into the household and lives of its owners.
But experts on canine behavior and the characteristics of the more than 120 different breeds registered with the American Kennel Club say that while some who act on impulse are lucky and end up with a perfect pet, others pay a big price for failing to consider the kind of companion the dog they acquire is likely to be. 
 Is it a highly excitable or very active animal that would quickly wear out an older person? Is it wont to attack any stranger coming to the house? Does it snap at children? Does it attack other dogs? Does it frazzle your nerves with incessant barking at every passerby?
The safety and sanity of dog-loving households may depend on the care taken in choosing dogs wisely and training them properly. It may also depend on prompt recognition of a developing behavioral problem, exploration of its cause and intervention to modify it, if possible, before a disaster ensues.
Dr. Randall Lockwood of the Humane Society of the United States in Washington, who has been studying the dog bite problem for 25 years, said: "Many people have trouble with their dogs because they acquire animals for the wrong reasons and without knowing their special needs. An increasing percentage of people are using dogs essentially as weapons. Your dog should be your friend, not your gun."
Furthermore, Dr. Lockwood pointed out, as certain breeds surge in popularity, careless breeders who pay little or no attention to the quality of the dogs they breed are creating animals with unstable temperaments as well as physical problems that could prove costly economically and emotionally to their owners. For example, he said, "Rottweilers have grown in popularity sevenfold in 10 years, and we're seeing an increasing number of problems now in what was once a trouble-free breed."
 
Selecting Wisely
Whatever characteristics may be attributed to a particular breed of dog may not apply to every individual, since dogs, like people, have their own personalities. Furthermore, dog lovers are often very loyal to a breed, and may choose it despite certain distressing characteristics. So it is often helpful to consult more than one authority before choosing your pet.
Nonetheless, one very balanced and sensible guide is "The Perfect Puppy: How to Choose Your Dog by Its Behavior," by Dr. Benjamin L. Hart and Linette A. Hart of the School of Veterinary Medicine at the University of California at Davis. The book, published in 1988 by W. H. Freeman ($11.95), describes 13 behavioral characteristics that could make or break a successful dog-owner relationship, then rates 56 popular breeds on each trait based on the evaluations of 48 veterinarians and 48 obedience judges.
For example, the Scottish terrier (Scottie), a small dog much admired for its perkiness and spunk, ranks very high on excitability, snapping at children, aggression toward other dogs, watchdog barking, destructiveness and domination of its owner, which may prompt it to snap or growl when told to get off the couch. It is also difficult to train. This is hardly an ideal breed for a family with children, a working person who is away all day or an older couple with grandchildren who are seeking a quiet companion.
On the other hand, the Newfoundland dog, though as big as a small bear, is "a cream puff," the Harts wrote: quiet, nonaggressive, nondestructive, very affectionate and highly tolerant of all sorts of disturbances, including the shenanigans of little children and frisky puppies.
Then there is the matter of the sex of the dog. In general, the Harts say, within a given breed, females are less aggressive than males and less likely to snap at children, but they are no less excitable or less likely to bark excessively. Also, neutered males are less aggressive and spayed females are less nervous than hormonally intact animals of the same breed.
Experts are divided on the relative merits of mutts versus pure-breeds. Many dog owners insist that mutts make nicer, less temperamental and physically healthier pets. If you know the parents of the mutt and consider the characteristics of each, you can get a fair idea of the animal's likely behavior as an adult dog.
But Dr. Katherine A. Houpt, director of the Cornell Animal Behavior Clinic in Ithaca, N.Y., cautioned against adopting mutts of mysterious parentage. "You don't know what you're getting in a mixed breed," she said. "You may wind up with the aggressiveness of one breed and the biting tendency of another."
 
Training Your Dog
A dog must be socialized to other dogs and to people. The dog's mother does the former and the mother's human family and the puppy's adoptive family do the latter. To learn doggie rules, a puppy is best kept with its mother for six to eight weeks. During that time, it should be played with often by its owners. But the bulk of orientation into human households occurs after the puppy is adopted.
It is important for the dog to learn who is boss. It is more important for the dog to learn to come when called than to walk at your heel. Obedience training, which is growing in popularity, can help you avoid disruptive and dangerous behavior problems in your pet.
"Training should be a family affair," Dr. Lockwood said. "You don't send the dog off to school without you. You have to go and learn how to work with the dog, and everyone involved in its care should be consistent in the limits set and the techniques used to reinforce good behavior."
One should never have to hit a dog to get it to behave, Dr. Lockwood insists. "In 20 years of watching wolves, I never saw a wolf hit another wolf with a rolled-up newspaper," he remarked. "Violence begets violence. Praise and harsh reprimands are all that should be needed. Dogs want to please their owners, and animals, like people, respond much faster to rewarded outcomes than to punishment."
Also, training is not a one-time affair. "Like child rearing, it's an ongoing experience as the animal ages and situations change," Dr. Lockwood said. "Good obedience training makes you more observant and teaches you how what you do shapes what the dog does. It focuses on problem avoidance and problem solving. By learning parenting skills, you build a bond with your dog and reinforce behavior that is fun, positive and safe."
To find a good trainer, Dr. Lockwood suggests that you check with your local veterinarian, humane society, dog club (if it is not show-oriented) and dog-owning friends. It is important that you be comfortable with the attitudes and methods the trainer uses. If the trainer is too heavy-handed and does not show proper respect for the animals or the owners, leave and find another.
 
For More Information
The American Dog Trainers Network offers free information on many questions of dog safety and health and can provide referrals.
The network sponsors the Canine Resource and Referral Helpline, (212) 727-7257 (long-distance calls will be returned collect). It can be reached through E-mail at dogs@inch.com, or by regular mail at 161 West Fourth Street, New York, N.Y. 10014. A web site at http:// www.inch.com/dogs/ is also operated by the network.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
'Truth' Is Not Stranger Than Fiction: It Is Fiction

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Who was it who cautioned, believe half of what you see and none of what you hear? If the dispenser of that advice were to see Russ Hexter's "Dadetown," the cynic would be entitled to a good I-told-you-so chortle.
As the final credits roll on this documentary exploration of the forces tearing apart an idyllically picture-perfect small town in upstate New York, it is revealed that the local citizenry was played by actors. A film that has purported to uncover a complex social reality is in fact a brilliant artistic hoax. 
 You might call "Dadetown," which opens today at the Film Forum, a virtual documentary. Some who have been fooled by the film's skillful use of cinema verite techniques to evoke reality have stormed out in a fury of betrayal. After all, isn't it the documentarian's duty to illuminate the historical truths that elude the shallower world of feature films? For those who can't take a joke, Mr. Hexter, who died of an aortic aneurysm in April at the age of 27, may be remembered as an irresponsible prankster or worse, a Judas to his sacred calling.
Beyond the fact that "Dadetown" will instill in anyone who sees it a permanent nagging doubt about the veracity of anything calling itself a documentary, the story it tells is as "real" and compelling as those of many feature films whose audiences eagerly suspend disbelief in the rush to empathize with fictional characters.
The movie, set in the spring of 1994, follows a camera crew that is filming a 20-minute segment for a PBS series called "Small Town America: Where the Heart Was." As unforeseen traumas unravel the town's snug social fabric, the film makers remain in Dadetown to record the damage.
At first Dadetown appears to be a settled, Norman Rockwell-serene community whose economic lifeblood is a metalworking plant that has operated for decades. The local factory workers and their wives proudly reminisce about the glory days of World War II, when the factory produced the fuselage for fighting aircraft. After the war, when it was converted into a metal-bending facility producing staples and paper clips, the plant continued to supply Dadetown with abundant, decent-paying jobs.
But recently, a successful high-tech business, American Peripheral Imaging, has moved its headquarters to the town's outskirts and brought in a new, urban, upscale breed of settler. Eager to ingratiate itself with the longtime residents, American Peripheral has built a children's playground for the community. As the movie begins, there is a peaceful if wary coexistence between the old-timers and the yuppie interlopers in business suits.
When the metal-bending plant begins a series of layoffs, however, some of the unemployed workers irrationally blame American Peripheral. The playground is trashed and the swanky homes of the employees vandalized. When it becomes clear that a cancellation of contracts will force the plant to close, the workers desperately try to organize a union. But after a child is accidentally killed in a shooting accident related to the strike, a deal is made to keep the peace and close the factory.
The gist of "Dadetown" is a chronological series of interviews with longtime residents, factory workers, newcomers and corporate executives, many of them played by nonprofessionals. The film's sense of reality is enhanced by what seem to be spontaneous conversations that allow crucial nuts-and-bolts information about the factory and the town's economy to slip through the cracks. Rapid film editing helps blend the story's disparities and clips off most of the loose ends.
One of the most deceptive (and effective) tricks is to have an actor who is playing a dismissed factory worker lashing out at the camera crew and trying to prevent them from exploiting his private grief. You are reminded that in documentaries as in dramatic films, the cheapest and boldest emotional gestures are the ones paying the highest dividends.
While "Dadetown" succeeds as a fictional film, it also delivers a tough esthetic statement on the artist's relationship to the audience that some will find deeply unsettling. Movies, including documentaries, are, after all, only movies. In compiling and editing their stories, documentarians tend to be as entertainment-driven and manipulative as other film makers. If you've got something that works, you use it.
If "Dadetown" has a storytelling fault, it's that its scenario is too pat, too easy to swallow. We've heard it all in Bruce Springsteen songs. Where the best fiction stretches reality, "Dadetown" merely confirms what passes for it.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Three hotel projects are in the works for downtown Chicago, the first in five years.

BYLINE: By Robert Sharoff 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
AFTER a drought of almost five years in new hotel construction, downtown Chicago now has three projects under way.
The three are a new 800-room Hyatt Regency, a 230-room Hampton Inn and Suites, and a 350-room project that is being carved out of the city's Marina City complex on the Chicago River and will most likely carry the Hilton flag. 
 The three projects will add about 1,380 rooms to the city's current downtown total of about 26,000 hotel rooms.
The new Hyatt Regency is part of the expansion of the city's McCormick Place convention hall complex, which is just south of the Loop along the lakefront. The hotel is costing $108 million, which a Hyatt spokeswoman said was low for a project of that size but attributable to the fact that the hotel -- because of its proximity to the convention center -- will have less than the usual amount of meeting space. In addition to the hotel, the expansion includes a new 850,000-square-foot exhibition hall.
The Hyatt Regency is replacing a smaller hotel, not a Hyatt, that was torn down several years ago. The Hyatt, which will open in the summer of 1998, will be owned by the Metropolitan Pier and Exposition Authority and managed by Hyatt. The architect is Thomas W. Ventulett of Thompson, Ventulett Stainback & Associates. The firm also designed the new exhibition hall.
Hyatt has three other hotels in Chicago, including the city's largest, the 2,000-room Hyatt Regency Chicago.
The other two projects are both in River North, an area north of the Loop, Chicago's central business district. River North has become a tourist destination in recent years. The area is several blocks from the Michigan Avenue shopping district and is also the home of Planet Hollywood, the Hard Rock Cafe and other restaurants and entertainment spots.
"Traditionally, the Chicago hotel market has been based on conventions and business travelers, but the weekend tourist business has really picked up," said Thomas Huffsmith, senior vice president of LaSalle Partners, a downtown commercial real estate company. "There is definitely room for some new middle-market hotel rooms."
According to a recent study LaSalle made of the downtown hotel market, the current occupancy rate is about 70 percent, up from 64 percent last year. During the same period, average room rates climbed 12 percent, to $109.96. "It's a pretty strong market and we think it will continue to grow in 1997," said Todd A. Canter, the author of the study.
The new Hampton Inn and Suites, which will break ground in the next few weeks, will be at Illinois and Dearborn Streets. The 13-story hotel is being developed by Albert Friedman and Stephen L. Schwartz. Mr. Friedman is the president of Friedman Properties Inc. and the largest landlord in River North. Mr. Schwartz is the president of First Hospitality Group Inc., a hotel management company based in the Chicago suburb of Des Plaines.
The hotel, which will have about 100 suites and will be completed late next year, is being aimed at cost-conscious tourists and travelers making extended stays.
"There's a real shortage of extended-stay facilities in Chicago and also a dearth of value-oriented hotels," Mr. Schwartz said. "Most of the hotels that went up in the 80's catered to the upscale market."
According to Arnold Karr, president of the Hotel-Motel Association of Illinois, suite hotels in Chicago "generally do a point or two better than regular hotels" in terms of occupancy and also command a higher average room rate.
The cost of building a hotel in downtown Chicago runs anywhere from $150,000 to $200,000 a room, real estate professionals say. Mr. Friedman said his project would come in at "slightly less" than $150,000 a room.
The third project, as yet unnamed, is under way at the Marina City complex, on the north bank of the Chicago River between State and Dearborn Streets.
The distinctive complex, which was designed by Bertrand Goldberg in the early 1960's, consists of two cylindrical condominium towers, a theater and a 16-story office building. Three years ago, the theater and office building were acquired by John Marks, president of Mark IV Realty, and the NIKI DevelopmentCorporation. The properties are being converted into a hotel and entertainment areas.
The theater, which is to reopen in November, is being taken over by the House of Blues, which will offer live entertainment seven days a week. The 350-room hotel will open next spring. The remaining parts of the project -- a retail and restaurant component -- will be finished in 1998. The total cost of the project is about $75 million.
Mr. Marks is negotiating with the Hilton Hotel Corporation about managing the hotel and he said he was close to a final agreement.
"We're located at the front door of both the financial and entertainment districts," Mr. Marks said. "I think the market for hotels has changed here. The economy is vibrant and people are traveling again. We hope to provide a total urban entertainment experience."

HEADLINE: Somali Gunmen Abduct U.S. Aid Worker

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Gunmen abducted an American aid worker today in Mogadishu, the Somali capital.
Daniel Suther of the United States Agency for International Development was traveling with another American and 3 Britons when their vehicle was surrounded by 10 to 15 gunmen who disarmed their bodyguards and took Mr. Suther away in the car. 
 Mohammed Ali Mahdi, the faction leader who controls north Mogadishu, said he was in contact with the abductors and had demanded that Mr. Suther be released. The American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, confirmed the report.
Kidnappings of aid workers have increased in Mogadishu recently. A Somali working for Unicef and another working for the World Food Program were kidnapped in separate incidents last month. Both were released unharmed.
Chronic unemployment and the lack of commercial activity are blamed for worsening living conditions here. Somalia has had no functioning central Government since the 1991 ouster of dictator Mohammed Siad Barre, when the country disintegrated into warring factions.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Keep It Simple

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
When trying to assess the long-term implications of Saddam Hussein's recent "victory" in northern Iraq, keep in mind the following fact: The Kurds whom Saddam wooed away from the U.S., and forged a partnership with in an effort to reassert his authority in northern Iraq, are the same Kurds whom Saddam bombarded with mustard gas and cyanide in 1988. This is not a relationship with a long future. The relationship between Saddam and the Barzani Kurdish faction has about the same shelf life as an Elizabeth Taylor marriage.
That's why it's actually reassuring to see the Clinton Administration, belatedly, toning down its rhetoric, taking a deep breath and stepping back from the brink of all-out war against Saddam. Yes, the new Kurdish-Saddam alliance is a setback for American policy, but probably only a temporary one and certainly only a limited one. It doesn't change the fact that the U.S. still has Saddam in a strategic box. Washington has no vital interest, no allies and no regional strategy that would justify now trying to break apart Iraq or singlehandedly going to war against it. 
 The vital United States interests are to keep Saddam boxed in, to prevent him from threatening the oilfields in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, to prevent him from savaging the Kurds and to support all reasonable attempts to dispatch him to the next world. All those goals can be accomplished with the current basic U.S. force deployment. Saddam is a chronic rash -- ugly, itchy, occasionally painful, but in his present condition no longer fatal, let alone worth radical, messy surgery with unpredictable results.
The Republicans, desperate to score some points against President Clinton, have been hyperventilating that he squandered the great gulf war coalition. Nonsense. That coalition was held together by two things: oil and nukes. It was not a coalition to protect Kurds. It was not a coalition to take apart Iraq. It was a coalition to protect the oilfields of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia from Iraqi attacks and it was a coalition to prevent Saddam from developing nuclear weapons. That coalition still exists. But a coalition for doing more than that -- like punishing Saddam for maneuvering in northern Iraq -- never existed. The French, the Arabs, the Russians would never sign on to that. So we acted alone. So what? That's the price of leadership. It's also why God created cruise missiles -- for operations without allies.
But the Clinton Administration is also wise to stick to this limited approach because the United States has no larger vision or strategy for the Middle East, and neither does anyone else. There is a strategic vacuum in the Middle East today. In 1991 the end of both the cold war and the gulf war, coupled with a new global emphasis on economic growth, gave the region a new agenda. That new agenda was crystallized in former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres's vision of a "new Middle East," in which Arab-Israeli and Arab-Arab economic development and cooperation would replace confrontation.
Mr. Peres's vision was a romantic one, and everyone liked to poke fun at it. But it actually produced a moderate center in the Middle East and provided a strategic framework for much of what Israel, the Arabs and the U.S. were doing in the region. Everyone reacted to it. Some by opposing it, some by trying to modify it, some by trying to nurture it.
Today the Peres vision is no longer the dominant trend. Yet it has not been replaced by any new vision or agenda. The Arabs have none. The new Israeli Government has none. The new Islamic Government in Turkey has none, and the Clinton Administration has hung an "Out to Lunch, Back on Nov. 6" sign. In this vacuum all the old rivalries and habits are reasserting themselves. There is an all-against-all free-for-all in the Middle East today. Syria and Israel were even reported mobilizing some troops on their common border. We haven't heard that story in years.
When you don't know where you're going, any road will get you there. Right now, no one in the Middle East seems to know where he is going, and everyone is on a different road. In such a moment, the U.S. would be wise to keep its policy toward Iraq simple and tightly focused. It doesn't have the allies, vital interests or road map for anything more.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Drop As Fed Rate Rise Is Feared

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond investors reacted with alarm yesterday to a report that regional officials of the Federal Reserve were pushing for an increase in interest rates.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond dropped a full point, to 96 20/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.02 percent from 6.94 percent. 
 Market participants said the change in market mood was caused by a Reuters report citing an unnamed person at the Fed, who said the Fed consensus supported an increase of one-quarter of a percentage point in the discount rate at the meeting next Tuesday of the Federal Open Market Committee.
The report also said a consensus was forming for a similar increase in the Federal funds rate, which has a greater effect on the economy.
The same person, identified only as a senior Fed spokesman, said that 8 of the 12 Fed district banks had submitted requests for an increase, with three wanting an increase of half a percentage point.
Earlier reports on industrial production and capacity utilization yesterday, which Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said exceeded expectations, had only a mild impact on the bond market by comparison. Even the weekly Johnson Redbook survey of retail sales, which showed that sales were down one-tenth of 1 percent for the first two weeks of September, made little difference.
Industrial production rose five-tenths of 1 percent in August, led by utilities, mining, computers and office equipment. Capacity utilization rose two-tenth of a percentage point, to 83.5 percent.
"The market, of course, is grappling with the issue as to whether or not the Fed will tighten at the F.O.M.C. meeting next Tuesday," Mr. Fine said.
"There is no shortage of data suggesting a quarter-point increase in the Federal funds rate on Sept. 24, but at the same time, three months of lackluster retail sales and the upcoming Presidential election will likely loom large in the Fed's decision," he said.
But Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said, "Having read the Reuters report and reviewed the latest economic evidence, we still do not see the Fed raising short-term interest rates."
Mr. Harris said the requests by the regional Fed banks for rate increases would have been made at various times in recent weeks. That means that some came in before the reports last week of a slight gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in the August Consumer Price Index and soft August retail sales, up two-tenths of 1 percent after a one-tenth of 1 percent gain in July and six-tenths of 1 percent decline in June.
Traders also sold Treasuries yesterday because of worry about getting hurt by hedging activity resulting from the heavy volume of corporate bond issues coming to market.

HEADLINE: Clinton Announces Steps For More Portable Pensions

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Finding campaign fodder in an arcane place, President Clinton today announced steps taken by the Treasury Department to enhance workers' ability to save for retirement even as they move between jobs.
One measure removes barriers to workers rolling retirement savings into the pension plans of new employers. Another allows departing or retiring workers who choose to leave their 401(k) or other savings with the employer to have some investment choice other than money market funds. 
 "What we're doing is to make those retirement plans much, much more portable in ways that benefit both the employees and the employers in the small-business sector of our economy," the President said this morning in an Oval Office ceremony. "When five million workers with pensions change jobs every year, we have to make it easier for them to save."
The initiatives were regarded by pension experts as technical and more or less inevitable but nonetheless of significance as part of a long-running, bipartisan effort to encourage savings and improve job-market mobility by making benefits more portable.
"Both these changes are positive for employees," said Fred Rumack, director of tax and legal issues at Buck Consultants, a New York City-based firm specializing in employee benefits. "They help a lot of people."
Jamie Wickett, tax policy analyst for the National Federation of Independent Business, said, "We're all for pension portability," but reserved judgment on the initiative dealing with investment options for former employees until he had a chance to make sure the Treasury was not imposing new mandates on employers.
The Administration said more than one million workers each year moved to a new employer where rollovers were not accepted and that 50 percent of 401(k) plans did not accept rollovers from new employees. The steps taken today are intended to give employers what the White House called a green light to accept rollovers of retirement savings from people bringing such funds from their preceding jobs.
One reason employers often do not allow such rollovers is fear that their plan may be disqualified or penalized for inadvertently accepting money that proves later to have been ineligible, either because the plan from which it came did not meet the requirements of the tax law or because the rollover was not completed within the required 60 days. One of the Treasury's new guidelines says that a plan that accepts an invalid rollover will be protected against disqualification if there are reasonable grounds for believing that the money was eligible.
Another obstacle is employer worry that rollovers may jeopardize their plan's compliance with rules that bar skewing benefits in favor of the highest-paid employees. The Treasury proposes a regulation declaring that rollovers from new employees, including those not yet eligible to participate in the new employer's plan, will not cause plans to run afoul of the nondiscrimination rules.
Mark Iwry, benefits tax counsel at the Treasury, described today's action as "clarifying the law in areas that had been somewhat uncertain." The uncertainty, it was generally agreed, has inhibited the transfer and therefore the accumulation, of retirement savings.
As for preserving investment options, the Administration offered as an example the case of a woman who worked for many years with a large company and had built up savings of $50,000 in a 401(k) account that was invested in a stock fund returning 7 percent a year over a decade. She then switched to a new employer without any pension plans.
Although the law bars an employer from imposing a "significant detriment" on former employees who keep their savings with their old company, some employers limit their former employees to money-market funds even though active employees have broader choices.
Without the chance to keep investing in, say, stocks, such workers are hurt because they are more likely to "withdraw and dissipate their retirement savings," the Administration said.
The Treasury's new guidance does not bar employers from distinguishing between current and former employees, Mr. Iwry said. Rather, it means that such an extreme position as taking away all the former employee's venturesome investment options is "beyond the pale" if broader alternatives are offered to active employees.
The investment options guidance, Mr. Rumack pointed out, applies only to retirement accounts of more than $3,500. The law allows employers to rid themselves of the chore of administering lesser accounts by having the worker cash out.

HEADLINE: How Schedule Has Worked Elsewhere

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
As he seeks to test a year-round calendar in at least one New York City school district next year, Chancellor Rudy Crew can look to any number of examples nationwide: 2,368 schools, in 39 states, have already adopted a similar schedule, most within the last decade, according to the National Association for Year-Round Education.
For the districts, the allure is twofold. Some, like Trenton, have embraced the idea as a way to shorten the traditional 10-to-12-week summer vacation and extend the school year, giving students more time in school and less to forget what they learned. But others, including Los Angeles, have long used year-round calendars to ease the sort of overcrowding emerging in New York City. Without building a single classroom, a school can expand its capacity a third or more by switching to a year-round calendar. 
 Most schools that have adopted the calendar divide their students into two to five groups and then stagger the groups' schedules so that at least one is out of school at any time. Some students may attend 12 weeks in a row and take off the next 4. Others may attend 9 consecutive weeks and take off the next 3.
About half the schools that have adopted the year-round calendar are in California, with others in Boston, Dallas, Houston and Baltimore. In the Los Angeles Unified School District, second in size only to New York, more than 40 percent of the 660,000 students were on a year-round calendar last year.
Margaret Harrington, the superintendent for high schools in Queens, visited Garfield High School in Los Angeles several years ago and was struck by the school's economic use of space: using a staggered calendar, 4,200 students were taught over the year in a building that had desks for only 3,200.
"I came away impressed," said Dr. Harrington, who at the time was part of a committee studying the issue for Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines. "I thought they were giving the kids a good education."
The calendar also provides schools with some fringe benefits beyond space. In Preston, Idaho, a rural district about 100 miles north of Salt Lake City, students needing remedial education do not have to wait until the summer for a review. They can catch up, on classes they may have failed the first time around, during special makeup sessions held during their vacations.
"The great advantage is learning," said Jerry Waddoups, principal of the Oakwood Elementary School in Preston, which expanded its capacity to 660 students from 530 when it went to a year-round calendar 15 years ago. "These kids do not have a long summer lost to learning."
In many districts, students concerned that taking three weeks off in, say, November, might leave them with little to do are heartened to learn that they can still be involved in after-school sports and clubs.

HEADLINE: After Bitter Debate, Amity on Way to Implement Welfare Law

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
While generally supporting the new welfare law, state officials asked Congress today to give them more latitude and a bit more money to care for poor people and create jobs for welfare recipients.
Whenever Congress debated welfare in the last two years, Republicans and Democrats bitterly denounced each other, and Democrats disagreed among themselves. But today, when a Congressional subcommittee examined efforts to carry out the law signed 26 days ago by President Clinton, the proceedings were notable for the lack of acrimony. 
 Though some had feared that Federal officials might undermine or delay the new law, Republican lawmakers today commended the Administration for being cooperative.
And in brisk, businesslike testimony, Olivia A. Golden, Commissioner of the Federal Administration on Children, Youth and Families, said, "Our job is to implement the legislation as Congress passed it and the President signed it."
Ms. Golden testified in place of Mary Jo Bane, the Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services responsible for welfare programs, who had been scheduled to appear. The Administration pulled Ms. Bane from the lineup of witnesses, fearing that she might be asked to explain why she opposes the welfare law. Ms. Bane said last week that she would step down on Sept. 28 because of "deep concerns" about the law, which ends the 60-year-old Federal guarantee of cash assistance for the nation's poorest children.
At today's hearing, lawmakers focused on the future, not the past. As Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, put it -- with some understatement -- "We've been through stormier times."
"You can't keep fighting the Civil War," he said. "It's over. Now it's time for us to do our job. We set new rules. Now it's time for us to make them work."
Representative Shaw, who presided over the hearing as head of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, said: "Good legislation is about 10 percent of what's required to achieve true welfare reform. The other 90 percent is implementation, and that's going to take a lot of cooperation between Democrats and Republicans in Congress.
"The law is the law. We must join together to make it work. As I've said to the President, we are in this together." Mr. Clinton signed the bill over strenuous objections from liberal Democrats who said the nation had a moral obligation to the poor.
There were at least two reasons for the political amity just seven weeks before Election Day. No state has yet felt any hardship, and Democrats did not want to embarrass Mr. Clinton by criticizing the welfare law he cites as an accomplishment.
The law gives states vast new power to run their own welfare and work programs with lump sums of Federal money. But state officials asked Congress to give them a bit more authority, with easier access to and less restrictions on Federal money.
Under the law, each state will receive a fixed amount of Federal money in each of the next six years. A total of $2 billion is set aside in a contingency fund for states with high unemployment. To use the contingency fund, states must maintain welfare spending at 1994 levels.
Susan Golonka, a policy analyst at the National Governors' Association, urged Congress to relax some of the restrictions on the fund, so the money would be more readily available to states experiencing hard times.
A. Sidney Johnson, executive director of the American Public Welfare Association, asked Congress to repeal a requirement for states to continue extra payments they might be making to disabled people who receive Federal aid under the Supplemental Security Income program.
Mr. Johnson, whose group represents state officials, complained that Congress had imposed the requirement without giving the states additional money to carry it out.
Sheri E. Steisel, a policy analyst at the National Conference of State Legislatures, told Congress that because of the new law, states would lose Federal money that they now receive to help finance welfare payments to families for whom child support is collected.
The loss of this money will be costly, especially the poorer states, she said, and she urged Congress to restore the money.
Under the old law, many states received permission from the Federal Government to conduct experimental welfare programs. On Aug. 19, after Mr. Clinton had announced his intention to sign the welfare bill, the Department of Health and Human Services approved a 10-year waiver for Washington, D.C.
In general, people who go to work need less money for welfare, and Mr. Shaw said that if Washington or any state tried to circumvent the work requirements, it would probably run short of money for public assistance.
"Congress will not be sympathetic to any state that comes in here with a tin cup and says, 'Welfare reform isn't working,' especially if that state has not done anything to make it work," Mr. Shaw said.
