HEADLINE: With Little Fanfare and Facing Crisis, U.N. Starts a New Year

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Its difficult 50th birthday party over, the United Nations opened the 51st session of the General Assembly today without ceremony, in financial crisis and with no idea who its Secretary General will be when this session ends on Dec. 23.
"The United Nations General Assembly begins its 51st session without celebration but amidst criticism of the U.N.'s inability to respond adequately to international crises," the Assembly's new president, Razali Ismail of Malaysia, said in his opening speech. Mr. Razali, an outspoken diplomat who has represented Malaysia here for eight years, said that in this environment, he hoped that the "business as usual" syndrome would go. 
 "Delays and long lunches which lead to more delays, at enormous cost, are over," he said. "So too, I trust, the torture of long, unfocused speeches."
A high point of this annual meeting of leaders of 185 nations will come next Tuesday, when President Clinton plans to be the first to sign a treaty banning all nuclear test explosions. The Clinton Administration has been pressing for the treaty, which was approved by 158 countries a week ago, for the last three years.
Otherwise, it is not such a good time to be an American diplomat or official at the United Nations this year. Washington is responsible for more than half the $2.8 billion debt owed to the organization. Congress has attached conditions to American participation in peacekeeping and other international activities. Republicans and Democrats alike are demanding that Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali step down or be ousted by an American veto.
"It is great to be back from vacation," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said, darkly satirizing his critics at a lunch today. "Frankly, I get bored on vacation. It's much more fun to be at work here blocking reform, flying my black helicopters, imposing global taxes, demoralizing my staff."
When the 50th General Assembly opened a year ago, there were high hopes that the anniversary would spur reform. Working groups representing a range of member states were set up to look at changes in the organization's component parts and how to improve its financial status.
In recent days, however, committee after committee has reported no real progress because of disagreements among member countries. Only the Secretariat, the permanent civil service, has taken steps to cut back on its size and spending.
Changes in the Security Council seem a dead or dying issue because most nations rejected the proposal backed by the Clinton Administration to add Germany and Japan to the Council as permanent members and make room for some major developing nations without the same privileges.
There are no substantive plans for overhauling the General Assembly, now a plodding agglomeration of special interests grown to three times the size it was when the United Nations was founded in 1945. Much of the spending and duplication of efforts for which the United Nations is criticized originates in Assembly resolutions.
"Member states have announced they would reform the organization, but now they must deliver," said Diogo Freitas do Amaral, the Portuguese law professor and political leader who was president of the 50th Assembly. "The world expects this. The issues cannot just be endlessly debated. There must be action. And there must be action soon."
Mr. Razali, the new Assembly president, picked up the theme, saying the "reform process must begin with finding a political consensus on what the U.N. should be and what it can do."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Technology for the Virtual Marketplace

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Electronic commerce on the Internet has not yet reached critical mass, and there is little wonder why. Finding, buying and paying for merchandise on the Internet without having to worry about theft or fraud is a complicated and convoluted process -- one that can sometimes make even the most determined shoppers weep. Some call it "debt by a thousand clicks."
But analysts say a new technology developed by First Virtual Holdings Inc. of San Diego, a leader in digital payment systems, has the potential to transform advertising and simplify the processes of buying and selling on the rapidly growing Internet. First Virtual is supposed to announce details of the system later this week. 
 The First Virtual system, called virtual tags, embeds the transaction process directly into multimedia advertisements that can include animation, sound and even video clips. Consumers can view the sales pitch simply by waving the mouse pointer over the ad. If they like what they see, they can pay for merchandise on the spot, without leaving the World Wide Web page they are viewing. (If it were a newspaper, the system is comparable to being able to touch the ad and buy the leaf blower, without having to stop reading the paper and drive to Wal-Mart.)
The system does not require buyers to install any new software or hardware on their computers, and the process consumes only a few thousand bytes of the computer's memory, only a fraction of the amount used by other systems.
The same technology can also be used to send active advertisements, complete with purchasing options, directly to a customer's electronic mailbox.
"In our opinion, placing the transaction in the ad banner and in the user's electronic mail box will fundamentally change Web economics," said Jack Hidary, president of Earthweb, an Internet software developer and distributor in New York.
To take advantage of the new system, both the buyer and the seller must use First Virtual's transaction system, which currently has only about 175,000 customers and 2,500 merchants -- ranging from virtual shopping malls like Infohaus to the Libertarian Party of Virginia.
To help spread the technology among potentially millions of new electronic consumers, First Virtual has also lined up new financial backers that include the First Data Corporation of Hackensack, N.J., and GE Capital of Stamford, Conn., the finance arm of the General Electric Company. Both are among the leading companies in managing and processing consumer credit systems.
Analysts said that with such backers, along with earlier investors -- First USA Paymentech Inc. and the National Direct Marketing Corporation -- First Virtual now has the potential to distribute the capability to make electronic payments to millions of credit card-wielding computer users.
First Virtual also has technical backing from other computer industry leaders including Sun Microsystems, Electronic Data Systems, Science Applications International and Sybase, which together developed the underlying technical structure needed for handling thousands of transactions simultaneously. Until recently, First Virtual's processing system was unable to process more than a relatively few transactions at once.
The virtual tags developed by First Virtual are extensions of the Java programming language created by Sun Microsystems. Java allows developers to create miniature programs that can be run on any computer that can use the latest Internet Web-browsing software, of which the Netscape Communication Corporation's Navigator and the Microsoft Corporation's Internet Explorer are the most popular. The Java extensions will enable advertisers and merchants to create ads that literally sing and dance on the computer screen -- and then take the customer's money.
In the case of digital products like information, music or news, the merchandise is delivered directly to the consumer after the purchase. In the case of hard goods like shoes or books or leaf blowers, the merchant can ship the merchandise to the buyer's address.
"We're moving the Internet and electronic commerce from buyer pull to seller push -- and doing it in a way that is easy for the customer," said Lee H. Stein, First Virtual's chairman and chief executive.
First Virtual has plenty of competition in the Internet electronic payment arena, ranging from established players like Microsoft, Intuit and Checkfree to such start-ups like Cybercash. But First Virtual's new technology appeared in private demonstrations to offer a combination of security and ease of use that others have not yet introduced.
"First Virtual has a significant technology lead," said Karl Jacob, president and chief executive of Dimension X, an Internet software company in San Francisco that specializes in making tools for Web developers. "From what we've seen, they have a good chance of sweeping the Net with their technology."
In the First Virtual process, unlike other Internet security systems, the consumer's actual financial information and credit card numbers are never transmitted on the public Internet. Instead, the information travels as electronic mail on the existing secure networks that banks and other financial institutions use to exchange data. Only the user's First Virtual code name and "virtual PIN" -- personal identification number, which costs $2 a year -- are transmitted on the Internet.
An intruder hoping to use someone else's First Virtual account information for a fraudulent transaction would have to gain access to the buyer's private electronic mailbox and intercept at least two E-mail messages -- one from First Virtual to the consumer, and a second with the confirmation message to the consumer from the merchant. Such two-step interceptions are highly unlikely, security experts say.
"It is very cool stuff," said John W. Noerenberg, director of engineering for the electronic mail division of Qualcomm Inc. of San Diego, which makes the popular Eudora E-mail program. "I am very impressed with the idea that you have a tag that is not just an advertisement or a link to someplace else, but a call to action. It fundamentally changes the nature of the relationship between the merchant and the customer."
Advertisements employing virtual tags are expected to begin appearing on the Web before the end of the year.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
Dole's Tax Message Heard, Not Heeded, in Midwest City

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SAGINAW, Mich., Sept. 15

 BODY:
Only a day after Bob Dole's "Citizen's Ship" had whisked the Republican Presidential candidate in and out of this once-battered industrial corner of Michigan, it seemed as if everyone in Saginaw had seen the image the Dole campaign wanted them to see: Mr. Dole, in a gesture of Reaganesque simplicity, holding a nickel aloft to symbolize how he would go about cutting the Federal budget.
"Five cents!" he had shouted to the airport crowd, a scene that local television stations in Michigan ran again and again over the weekend. "All I have to do is take 5 cents out of a dollar to pay for this package," he said, insisting that would be enough to pay for a tax cut of 15 percent while paying off the deficit Washington has run up over the last 15 years. Mr. Dole's handlers were delighted with the headline the next morning in The Saginaw News: "Dole Clarifies 15 Percent Solution." 
 But when neighbors in the Heritage Square section of this ethnically and politically mixed city gathered for coffee and muffins one morning this weekend, not one of them, even Republicans who said they liked and trusted Mr. Dole and would probably vote for him, said they found his central message credible.
This isn't the 1980's, they complained. Michigan's economy, fueled by the automobile industry, has roared back. In fact, the survivors of the General Motors downsizing here are now working too much overtime, they assert. As a result, they say Mr. Dole's economic message seems off the point, focusing on taxes rather than on what they want to hear: how to hang onto their jobs in the next recession, how to cope with competition from low-wage labor abroad and how to make sure their children know how to use computers .
In interviews conducted after Mr. Dole's economic tour of Ohio, Michigan and Illinois last week, including talks with workers in factories and offices that the candidate visited, people said they were not surprised that Mr. Dole's carefully targeted message was failing to gain much traction.
"Forget the damn tax cut," was the advice offered by William E. Fentress, a manager in Cincinnati Milacron's purchasing department, after Mr. Dole visited the company last Thursday.
As his co-workers around the fax machine nodded in agreement, Mr. Fentress added, "We should use that money to get rid of the deficit first."
Here in Saginaw, Mr. Dole's effort to reduce his message to a camera-ready scene -- 15 percent -- has yielded more frustration than votes. "It's not that people around here wouldn't vote for a Republican, because there's not much loyalty to any party," said James W. Woolfolk 2d, who has lived here since 1971 and runs a manufacturing services unit at one of the General Motors plants. "But you don't get any details from Dole. Clinton's got problems, but at least he has talked about energizing the economy."
Mr. Dole's campaign aides say it is too early to judge how well his economic ideas are getting through, a process that they hope to accelerate this week with the publication of a book detailing his plans to cut capital gains taxes in half, create "opportunity scholarships" for secondary school students and balance the budget. "We're confident that once the message sinks in, things will turn around," said Dave Doyle, the campaign's senior consultant for the Midwest.
But the growing view that Mr. Dole's tax plan is unworkable, many voters say, has colored their view of their rest of his initiatives.
"Five cents on the dollar does not come out to a 15 percent tax cut," said Gregory Largent, the director of music ministries at a Saginaw church. Mr. Largent's taxes would be reduced by at least $1,000 under Mr. Dole's plan for a family tax credit, but he drew a laugh from his neighbors the other day when he gave an arch description of Mr. Dole's claim that by cutting capital gains taxes the Government would release "$7 trillion in capital that's now tied up."
"It's not like Anna and I sit around every night and say, 'You know, I think we can release our capital gains now,' " Mr. Largent said. "That's not a conversation many people in this city are going to have."
The comments of Mr. Largent and his neighbors make clear that part of Mr. Dole's problem is that he is running a campaign that seems out of tune with the economic mood of industrial states like Michigan. Both here and around the country, the former Senator from Kansas has made the case that the economy is fundamentally on the wrong track. But poll after poll shows that many voters who might have agreed with him a year ago now have a different view.
In a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted earlier this month, 69 percent described the economy as "very" or "fairly" good. The same poll showed 55 percent approving the way President Clinton has handled the economy, the highest rating in his four years in office, and the first time a majority of Americans have given him credit for the turnaround.
If ever there was a state where the tax message should sell, it should be here in Michigan, where a Republican Governor, John Engler, touts his combination of tax-cutting, budget-paring and reduced welfare benefits as spurring the state's phenomenal economic revival. The unemployment rate in Michigan is down to 4.5 percent, and it is increasingly difficult to find factory space.
Michigan's success is almost working against Mr. Dole. In good times, and when inflation is not propelling workers into higher tax brackets, the tax bite is a less compelling issue than it was for Ronald Reagan. And there is an inchoate fear of large Federal budget deficits that did not exist in the 1980's, a fear that Mr. Dole himself fueled as one of the Senate's leading deficit hawks.
Mr. Dole's economic plan goes well beyond the 15 percent tax cut: He talks of the need to boost American economic growth and to cut government bureaucracy.
But Mr. Dole rarely talks long about how to fuel that growth beyond cutting taxes. And even when he has obvious opportunities to talk about worker retraining, or anxieties about jobs headed to Mexico or China, or coping with global competition, he usually passes them by.
Such omissions were particularly evident last Thursday afternoon as the candidate conducted one of his "Listening to America" question-and-answer sessions on the lawn at Cincinnati Milacron, one of the nation's leading makers of machine tools.
The Dole campaign had asked to use the company as a backdrop for the event because of its nearly miraculous rise from the corporate dead to a company that has beaten back some of Japan's fiercest manufacturers, and now exports half of what it makes. He spent 20 minutes touring the plant with the company's chairman, Dan Meyer, who said later that the two "talked about international competition and globalization at length."
But when Mr. Dole emerged for the forum, he never mentioned either subject, and only raised worker retraining to declare that he would "throw out the bad programs" financed by the Federal Government and pass the rest of the money down to the states.
"It was bizarre," a Milacron senior executive said later, asking not be quoted by name because the company's leadership had agreed to act as Mr. Dole's host. "It was as if this was a television stage, not a company that faced real-life problems."
Much the same happened the next morning at Hill Manufacturing, a small truck manufacturer outside Toledo, Ohio, that produces military vehicles and builds part of Volvo's trucks. After Mr. Dole talked for roughly an hour about his economic plan, Dave Abbott, an electrical maintenance worker at the company, said he would "watch Dole a lot more carefully" now that the candidate had stopped by. But in the next breath he worried that Mr. Dole had spent so much time on the tax plan that he had "skimmed right by the problems."
"The economy's going good now and we're working a lot of overtime," said Mr. Abbott, who is 41. "But our factory is full of 30- to 50-year-olds, and most of the workers are scared. They're bringing in all these lasers and robot machines to do the welding, and these young guys who come in here know how to run all the computers."
In Washington, at the Dole campaign headquarters, John Buckley, the communications director, said, "The message of empathy is over what workers are dealing with -- paying more in taxes than our society has ever paid before." He added that Mr. Dole was fully briefed about the companies and communities he visits, but "he is not a retail politican selling the prescription for a particular community."
People here vividly remember the mid-1980's and early 90's, when unemployment ran upwards of 15 percent and ravaged the city's center. But today, with the unemployment rate at 4.5 percent, managers everywhere complain that they cannot find enough skilled workers.
Almost everyone in Heritage Square here says they would welcome a tax cut, but they fear that Mr. Dole's plan is so large that sooner or later they will be paying for it in other taxes. Several people said that is what happened after Michigan cut its income and property taxes, only to raise sales taxes and reassess many houses at a higher value.
"There's an assumption that we're going to have to shell out someplace," said Jon Manning, who works for a not-for-profit human services group and moved here three years ago with his wife, Robin.
Mrs. Manning said she was one of the few in the neighborhood who drove out to the airport the other day to hear Mr. Dole. But she found it "less than convincing," she said, adding, "It would be nice to think that you could balance the budget by cutting 5 cents out of every dollar, but I think we're beyond that."

HEADLINE: Push at Fed For Rate Rise Is Reported

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
A report that inflation hawks within the Federal Reserve are pressing for a rate increase took some of the wind out of the financial markets today and provided more evidence of the conflicting pressures buffeting the Fed as it prepares for a key policy-making meeting next Tuesday.
A report from Chicago by the Reuters news agency quoted a "senior Fed official" as saying that 8 of the 12 Federal Reserve district banks were in favor of raising the largely symbolic discount rate and that a consensus was forming for a quarter-point increase in the more important Federal funds target rate. 
 Fed officials declined to comment on the report. If true, such a disclosure would represent a highly unusual leak of the Fed's thinking just a week before a policy meeting. Still, the report was consistent with the comments in recent weeks by many of the regional Fed bank presidents, who tend to take a hard line on inflation.
Investors, who in recent days had increasingly taken the view that the Fed would leave monetary policy unchanged next week, sold bonds today on resurgent concerns of a rate increase, sending the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond up to 7.02 percent from 6.94 percent. Stocks also faltered after a series of strong performances last week, with the Dow Jones industrial average slipping 40 points during the day then rebounding to close down by 0.37 point at 5,888.83.
The report said that the Minneapolis, Richmond and San Francisco district banks were pushing particularly hard for a tighter policy by calling for a half-point increase in the discount rate, with five others calling for a quarter-point increase. The president of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank, Gary H. Stern, was the lone member of the Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee to favor raising the Fed funds rate at the July meeting.
The likelihood of a Fed tightening appeared decline over the last several days, particularly after a series of economic indicators last week showed almost no sign of renewed inflation despite strong growth rates and low unemployment.
But figures issued today by the Fed on industrial output and capacity use at mines, factories and utilities in August, provided ammunition for those arguing for a rate increase.
Industrial production rose by a larger-than-expected five-tenths of a percent in August, the fifth consecutive monthly increase, even though output of autos and other consumer goods weakened. A rebound in utility and mining output drove the increase, which followed a gain of a tenth of a percent in July. Analysts had expected an increase of three-tenths of a percent for August. The plant-use rate rose to 83.5 percent in August from 83.3 percent in July.
At the very least, today's reports hint that there will be a vigorous debate at next Tuesday's meeting between those who think the Fed should tighten monetary policy to head off inflation before it infects the economy and those who believe the economy is slowing quickly enough to dissipate any inflationary pressures on its own.
Although it left rates unchanged at its July meeting, the Fed voted to lean toward tightening, a signal that it was on heightened inflation alert. It again left rates unchanged at its August meeting after what some officials said was a heated meeting.
"We know that there are a number of F.O.M.C. members -- and we knew this before today's report -- who feel the time has come to be tighter than we have been," said Stuart Hoffman, the chief economist at the PNC Corporation in Pittsburgh. "It's just not clear whether that's a majority opinion. A consensus is forming that the Fed will need to raise the funds rate and do a little light tapping on the monetary brake, and it's just a question of whether it happens at this meeting or takes a couple of months."
Several Fed officials have said in the last week that they are still not certain whether there is an imminent risk of inflation.
With unemployment down to 5.1 percent, its lowest in seven years, and the economy growing at a relatively robust pace, economists have been searching for any sign that recent wage gains are translating into higher prices. So far, there have been none. Those who contend that inflation is just a matter of time once wages start rising, continue to agitate for action now, even as more moderate members remain on the fence, at least publicly.
"We certainly anticipate a slowdown in the second half, but given how low unemployment is, we need to see it happen quickly," Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, said on Friday. "The economy is slowing down, but the jury is still out on whether it is happening with sufficient speed and to a sufficient degree."
The district bank presidents do not get a vote on whether to change the discount rate, which is set by the Federal Reserve Board in Washington. But their reported request is a clear signal that the banks will push hard for an increase in the Federal funds rate, by the open market committee, where they do have votes.
The discount rate, the rate the Fed charges for overnight loans to banks, has remained at 5 percent since Jan. 31, when it was lowered by a quarter- point. The Fed funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for short-term loans, has also been unchanged since Jan. 31, when the Fed lowered it a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent.

(Source: The Commerce Department): "Capacity Utilization" tracks total output as a percentage of capacity, seasonally adjusted, over the same period. (Source: Federal Reserve Board) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Trade Surplus Fell 31% In August From August '95

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus fell 31 percent in August from the monthly level a year earlier, to $3.35 billion, the 21st consecutive month of such declines, the Finance Ministry said today.
A more limited measure, the merchandise surplus with the United States, which has been a source of friction between the two economic powers, declined 16.9 percent, to $2.02 billion in August, from a year earlier. The figures were not adjusted for seasonal factors. 
 Still, the trade surplus was higher than analysts had predicted. But the pace of shrinkage in the surplus is expected to slow toward year's end, reflecting the yen's sharp decline against the dollar from its level a year ago -- something that has helped Japanese manufacturers regain some competitiveness abroad.
The weaker yen, coupled with recent economic data, have convinced many analysts that the Japanese economy was continuing to recover from a prolonged recession.
On Tuesday, Bloomberg Business News quoted Finance Minister Wataru Kubo as saying that the Government was reluctant to provide another supplementary-spending package to stimulate the economy. "The G.D.P. data hasn't changed the Government view that a gradual recovery is continuing," Mr. Kubo said at a news conference.
Officials reported last Friday that the economy shrank seven-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June quarter from the previous three months, the first such quarterly decline since late in 1994. That translates into a 2.9 percent annual contraction.
Mr. Kubo said the decline last quarter was partly due to the first quarter's strong 12.7 percent annual growth, which might have been a result of extra calendar days in a leap year.
Mr. Kubo said he discussed the possibility of a supplementary package with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on their way to Okinawa for a visit. He added that a decision had yet to be made whether to continue two trillion yen in special tax cuts -- $1.8 billion -- in effect since 1994 into the next fiscal year.
Asked about a report in Japan's leading financial newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, on Sunday that the Government planned to schedule one trillion yen in public works spending this year that was originally intended for the next fiscal year, Mr. Kubo said he had not heard of such a plan.
He added, Bloomberg said, that Japanese business was not necessarily in favor of further public works spending. And he said that in the second half of the current fiscal year, there is as much public works spending scheduled as in the comparable period last year.
Many traders and investors seem to have interpreted the recent economic statistics as good news for corporate earnings and a sign that the modest recovery was continuing. Coupled with some record closes in United States equity markets, the news has caused Japanese stocks to surge recently.

HEADLINE: EXISTING LEADERS OF ETHNIC GROUPS WIN BOSNIAN VOTE

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Bosnian voters handed power to the existing leaders of the country's three major ethnic groups, election returns indicated tonight, giving the former enemies the task of cooperating in a three-member presidency to govern a restructured nation.
 According to official but incomplete results, the winner with the most votes is the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, a Muslim, who by virtue of his plurality will be chairman of the presidency for its two-year term. 
Momcilo Krajisnik, a Bosnian Serb separatist, will be the ethnic Serb representative on the presidency, and Kresimir Zubak, an ethnic Croat who promised during the campaign to unite his group's enclave with Croatia, will fill the Croatian seat.
One seat on the presidency was reserved for each ethnic group.
The returns were reported by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Robert Frowick, the head of the organization's mission in Bosnia, said final results for the presidential race would be announced on Wednesday.
Results of the votes for national and regional parliaments, which were held Saturday along with the presidential balloting, are to be announced in the next few days.
Based on the tally available tonight, with 80 percent of the votes counted, Mr. Izetbegovic received 629,439 votes. Mr. Izetbegovic has fought to preserve a unified, multi-ethnic Bosnia but has been criticized for wanting the country to remain under the umbrella of Muslim leadership. His main challenger, former Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic, received 110,845 votes,
Mr. Krajisnik, who during this country's four-year war worked closely with Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader who has been indicted on war-crime charges, received 508,026 votes, officials said. Mr. Krajisnik's chief rival, the moderate Mladen Ivanic, was shown to have mounted a strong challenge as the counting neared its end, receiving 240,000 votes. The fact that Mr. Ivanic did so well prevented Mr. Krajisnik from getting more votes than Mr. Izetbegovic.
Certain powers are reserved for the presidency, which will determine foreign policy and handle issues like foreign trade, transportation and communication links, in what American officials say is an effort to help unify Bosnia.
Duties like defense will be parceled out to the Muslim-Croat federation and the Bosnian Serb republic, and each will have its own army.
In an interview today, Assistant Secretary of State John Kornblum said, "Hundreds of people now have some kind of democratic mandate." He referred not only to the presidency, but also to the legislatures.
"This hasn't existed before," Mr. Kornblum said. "This election will build structures where people not only can but have to work together." He said the vote would transform Bosnia from a "wartime society" to "a normal civil society."
"I am absolutely convinced that a lot of this anger and hatred will be rounded off and fade away as there are more civilian and economic links," he said.
But many Western diplomats say that with the nationalists in charge, it is unlikely that the hundreds of thousands of refugees who were driven from their homes by war will return to those areas.
Critics also questioned whether these bitter enemies would be able to rule by consensus, as is the plan. And they said that with the Croatian and Serbian leaders bent on seceding and Mr. Izetbegovic bent on uniting Bosnia under Muslim control, the governing body might become swiftly paralyzed.
In the next few days, officials expect the tallies for the national Parliament, the two regional parliaments and two regional presidents, one for the Bosnian Serb republic and one for the Muslim-Croat federation.
There was no indication that the various opposition parties, which failed to garner significant votes for the national presidency, fared better in the legislative races.
The presidency will take power the day after the vote count is certified by the European security organization, which could take place as early as Monday. The three members of the presidency are to meet in Sarajevo the day after certification.
But Western diplomats said it was unclear whether Mr. Krajisnik would agree to meet in Sarajevo, his former home. The fact that the city is under Muslim control deeply angers him. He led a campaign by Bosnian Serb leaders to drive 50,000 Serbs out of the city in the days before five neighborhoods and suburbs were handed over to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government last spring as part of the peace agreement reached in Dayton, Ohio.
Mr. Krajisnik has demanded that they meet in the NATO-patrolled zone that separates the Bosnian Serb republic from the Muslim-Croat federation, a request that United States officials have rejected.
The results have also thrown Mr. Izetbegovic's Democratic Action Party into disarray. Some leading members see the vote as solidifying partition.
They are pushing President Izetbegovic to contest the results in the Serbian-held part of Bosnia, where those who carried out the campaigns of ethnic cleansing and were responsible for the murder of thousands of civilians are set to retain power.
Senior officials of Mr. Izetbegovic's party say they are worried that once the Bosnian Serb legislature is in place, it will vote to secede.
"Our biggest concern is how the Republika Srpska will cooperate," said a senior Western diplomat. "There does seem to be this real problem with Krajisnik and his return to Sarajevo. Secondly, we are concerned with the unique decision-making process here. Everything has to be decided six times, with increasing pressure, tension and emotion."
Ten days after the election certification, the United Nations Security Council is permitted to lift economic sanctions on Serbia.
The Bosnian presidency will nominate a cabinet and oversee the seating of the national Parliament and the setting up of the national administration.
American officials are pushing Mr. Izetbegovic to nominate a Serb to a high position in the Government, perhaps to serve as prime minister. After being confirmed by Parliament, the prime minister will nominate the cabinet, which is also subject to Parliament's approval.
All posts are scheduled to be filled by the end of October.
The three presidency members will serve for two years. New elections in two years will choose members who will serve four-year terms.
The structure of the presidency resembles the one that governed Yugoslavia in the years before it broke up. The Yugoslav Presidency proved to be ineffective and ultimately saw the feuding ethnic factions plunge the old Yugoslav federation into war.
If a consensus cannot be reached, Bosnia's new Constitution permits two of the three members to make a decision. But if the third believes that the decision damages the vital interest of his ethnic group, he can appeal to the parliament of the Bosnian Serb republic or the Muslim-Croat federation.
If the objection is upheld by a two-thirds vote in either legislature, the presidency's decision is overturned.
Mr. Krajisnik has little faith in the system he is to join in leading.
"They only way this three-person presidency will work," he said in an interview, "is if it is a thin roof over three enclaves, a roof designed to link our transportation and communication systems and nothing else."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ford Labor Contract Goes Against Big 3 Trend
The new contract between Ford and the United Automobile Workers runs counter to a trend in which Detroit's auto makers have halved their work forces during the last 15 years partly by closing or selling parts factories, while buying more auto parts from nonunion suppliers.
The new contract requires Ford to guarantee a minimum number of union jobs, while adding incentives for the company to produce more auto parts itself. The U.A.W. will let Ford pay lower wages in any new parts businesses it enters. [Page A1.]
 
In an upbeat election-year assessment, U.S. officials said that the Big Three were doing "phenomenally" well and that a trade pact with Japan had been a success. [D6.]
 
Toward More Portable Pensions
President Clinton announced steps taken by the Treasury Department to enhance workers' ability to save for retirement even as they move between jobs. [D2.]
 
Bond Yield Surges on Rate Fears
Bond investors reacted with alarm to a report that regional officials of the Federal Reserve were pushing for an increase in interest rates. The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.02 percent from 6.94 percent. [D18.]
 
The report on the Fed also contributed to a midsession fall in bigger stocks, which recovered most of their losses later. The Dow industrials slipped 0.37 point, to 5,888.83; the Nasdaq pared early gains, but closed up. [D8.]
 
Late Credit Payments Rise
Credit card delinquencies reached a record level in the second quarter. [D4.]
 
Health Systems Seen in Talks
Health Systems International is said to be the company in negotiations to merge with Foundation Health, which had acknowledged that it was considering a business combination but would not name the other party. [D7.]
 
Fund Closed to New Investors
Morgan Stanley is closing to further investment its Princes Gate Investors II, a private equity partnership. [D4.]
 
A Utility's Changing Identity
Brooklyn Union Gas's steady growth and rising dividends have made it a favorite stock of safety-minded investors approaching retirement. But now the utility is embracing a more adventurous strategy that includes a proposed name change and investments outside its field. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Japan's Trade Surplus Shrinks
Japan's trade surplus fell 31 percent in August from a year earlier, to $3.35 billion. [D2.]
 
Turner's New Role With Time Warner
Time Warner said Ted Turner, its new vice chairman, would oversee the company's expanded portfolio of cable networks. Several of those channels, including CNN and TNT, came to Time Warner in its acquisition of Turner Broadcasting System. Time Warner had to accelerate the announcement of Mr. Turner's role after one of his lieutenants said he would depart. [D7.]
 
Back in the Ring
Punch, the weekly magazine of satire, cartoons and reviews that was once a British icon, has been brought back from the dead. Absent for more than four years, it has been revived with an infusion of nearly $5 million by an Egyptian-born businessman. [A4.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton, in Midwest, Takes Page From Reagan's 'Morning in America' Drive

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: FLOSSMOOR, Ill., Sept. 17

 BODY:
Eighteen months ago, President Clinton's election strategists sat down and studied Ronald Reagan's "Morning in America" campaign of 1984 to learn how one of the few recent incumbent Presidents to win a second term had used mood and imagery to sail to a landslide victory.
What the Clinton camp derived from that study has rarely been more evident than it was today, when the President stumped at a vocational education center and a high school in two battleground states of the Midwest. 
 Making no mention of his opponent, Mr. Clinton instead painted a picture of a future America so promising that the young people of today will be doing "jobs that have not been invented yet," in many cases "work that has not been imagined yet."
The appearances marked the beginning of a four-day campaign swing that will carry Mr. Clinton from the bellwether states of the Midwest to Oregon and Washington, both of which he won in 1992 and must capture again. In between, he will take advantage of the most glorious, and quintessentially American, campaign backdrop imaginable, the Grand Canyon.
That will be the second time in two weeks that he has shown up in Arizona, which has voted for Republicans for President for 48 years. Mr. Clinton is trying for a historic upset there, but, even if he ultimately fails to carry the state, his visits have already had one desired effect: Bob Dole campaigned in Arizona today, spending precious time in a place his party has rarely had to contest.
For the cross-country trip from Oregon back to the White House, Mr. Clinton has also tacked on a likely stop in South Dakota, another state where Democrats do not usually bother to tread.
The "Morning in America" approach that was evident in Mr. Clinton's appearances today is not a perfect echo of 1984. The Clinton campaign did not copy everything it learned, and the President, of course, has far different themes to strike. He is running against a Republican Congress full of lawmakers who consider themselves Reagan heirs. And when he campaigns against Mr. Dole's $548 billion tax-cut plan, he is in essence on the stump against Reaganism reborn: the Dole plan was intended to recapture the excitement that Mr. Reagan's call for tax cuts once generated.
Still, to see clearly how Mr. Clinton's technique owes a large debt to Mr. Reagan, one has only to read the memorandum that months ago caught the eye of Ann F. Lewis, the President's deputy campaign manager. It is a plan written in 1984 by a Republican strategist, Stuart Spencer, and later republished in campaign tomes.
"The tone of the campaign should be upbeat, but not so confidently optimistic that we are vulnerable to the charge we believe things are better than facts warrant," Mr. Spencer wrote in the "Proposed Plan to Re-elect the President."
"The future vision the President establishes should include challenges," Mr. Spencer advised, "but reaffirm our faith in the country's ability to progress and meet those challenges."
Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message in January was in fact made up of "challenges" to America, which have been spoken about throughout his whole campaign.
That theme, aides say, was not directly inspired by Mr. Spencer's 1984 plan. But early this year Mr. Clinton also chose to put more emphasis on the nation's good economic statistics than on growing income disparities, adopting a "Morning in America"-type message of economic resurgence instead of attacking corporate greed as some in his White House had recommended.
And today, in search of the Reagan Democrats who deserted the party in the 1980's, Mr. Clinton fairly bubbled over with the kind of optimism that was a trademark of the Republican who made America feel good about itself. In appearances on school grounds here in the Chicago suburbs and in Westland, Mich., near Ypsilanti, he mixed one of his favored themes, education, with those of patriotism, optimism and healthy economic data.
"I can tell you, I'm more optimistic today than the day I took the oath of office," the President told a boisterous crowd of thousands on the football field of John Glenn High School in Westland. "I am more idealistic today than I was when I took the oath of office, because I know today from seeing what has happened in the last four years that there is nothing you cannot do if you are given the tools to do the job."

HEADLINE: Chrysler Averts a Walkout by Canadian Union

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Chrysler Canada Ltd. averted a strike tonight when it reached a tentative agreement with the Canadian Auto Workers union about 90 minutes before workers were set to walk off their jobs.
"Who says you can't move mountains?" Basil E. Hargrove, the union's president, said. The talks had stalled earlier over the issue of outsourcing, or relying on outside nonunion suppliers for parts. 
 A strike would have cut the Chrysler Corporation's North American supply of its minivans and full-size cars. Chrysler Canada operates three assembly plants and two parts plants. About 60 percent of Chrysler's popular Dodge and Plymouth minivans are made in Windsor, Ontario. The rest are built in St. Louis.
The agreement includes a two percent wage increase for Chrysler's workers in each year of the three-year contract. The tentative deal will also give workers an additional 10 paid days off over the life of the three-year agreement. Mr. Hargrove estimated that Chrysler would have to hire as many as 300 people to make up for that time.
The 12,600 union members are expected to ratify the deal on Sunday.
The agreement comes after the Ford Motor Company and the United Auto Workers agreed to a new three-year contract in the United States.
Outsourcing to suppliers that pay far lower wages than the auto makers was a key issue in both countries.
Chrysler Canada and the C.A.W. agreed on outsourcing earlier today. Chrysler Canada said it would not cut job levels if it contracts out work as long as the company makes a profit, Mr. Hargrove said.
Negotiators had not even begun bargaining on the economic package until Tuesday.
"Everything was like pulling teeth out of tigers," Mr. Hargrove said.
The Canadian union's strategy is to use the Chrysler Canada contract as a blueprint for deals with Ford Canada and the General Motors Corporation.

HEADLINE: U.A.W.'s Pact At Ford Aims At Downsizing

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company's new three-year labor contract with the United Automobile Workers union addresses two issues that have haunted organized labor for more than a decade: layoffs and moves by companies to rely more on outside suppliers.
The new contract, reached Monday evening, requires Ford to guarantee a minimum number of union jobs, while adding incentives for the company to produce more auto parts itself. 
 Interestingly, the agreement comes at a time when many large companies, including auto makers, are downsizing their work forces to try to cut costs and deliver more value to shareholders. Detroit's auto makers have halved their work forces over the last 15 years partly by closing or selling parts factories, while buying more parts from nonunion suppliers.
In exchange for the employment guarantee, the U.A.W. will let Ford pay permanently lower wages in any new auto parts businesses it enters.
What remains unclear is whether the Ford deal will set a precedent for other companies, inside and outside the industry. Only a tenth of the nation's private-sector work force is unionized and there are few other unions that are so powerful.
The first test for the union will come quickly as it tries to impose similar settlements on the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation. Analysts said G.M. in particular would be hard pressed to accept such a deal because the company was trying to cut its work force and rely less on its own auto parts manufacturing operations.
And beyond the auto makers, the Ford contract might have much weaker influence, even in those industries in which the U.A.W. represents workers. For example, Caterpillar Inc., a maker of heavy equipment, was able to hire replacement workers and continue doing business last year despite a U.A.W. strike.
"I think that may be the model to look at, rather than Ford," said Sharon F. Canner, the vice president for human resources policy at the National Association of Manufacturers.
Under the new contract, Ford has guaranteed that for the next three years, the number of U.A.W.-represented workers in each factory will stay at 95 percent or more of current levels. With Ford's 105,000 U.A.W. workers retiring at a rate of 5 to 6 percent a year, the pact will force Ford to hire thousands of workers to replace the retirees and will keep overall employment high.
The new rules guaranteeing minimum employment make it much less attractive for Ford to continue farming out the manufacture of parts to outside suppliers, Wall Street analysts said. Ford would still have to employ just as many workers even if there was no work for them to do.
Indeed, the new contract may have its greatest impact on the immense auto parts industry that has grown up to supply the growing needs of auto makers. According to the Commerce Department, there were 711,000 Americans working in the industry last year producing $131 billion worth of parts, although the auto makers' own remaining parts factories accounted for about a quarter of these totals.
When a dozen senior executives from auto parts suppliers met over coffee and danishes at a riverfront hotel here this morning, they were upset about the new rules at Ford, said Donna L. Parolini, a consultant who attended the monthly gathering. "If they can't lay off any people, what does that do for us? Nothing -- that's what they were saying," Ms. Parolini said later.
The new arrangement could still run into problems. The U.A.W. long resisted lower wages for auto parts workers, fearing friction between low-wage and high-wage workers in the same union. But that friction could now be limited given that the low-wage workers will be mainly in new Ford factories and may seldom meet high-wage workers.
In an interview on Sept. 5, Alexander Trotman, Ford's chairman, chief executive and president, said Ford would be more interested in entering new parts businesses if the union allowed lower wages. "To the degree that we can figure out how to make widgets much more effectively than we do today, it increases the likelihood we're going to make more of those widgets and even make widgets we're not making today."
G.M. already makes many of its own parts, and so has fewer opportunities to move into new parts operations at lower wages. Thus, it has less incentive to sign such a contract.
In addition, G.M. uses more workers to produce each vehicle than its rivals do, and it wants to pare its work force sharply through attrition. So guaranteed job levels will be a tougher sell to G.M. executives.
The union may respond by showing some flexibility in negotiating with G.M. on the definition of new auto parts, people close to the union said today. That would allow G.M. to call a product new and move production to lower-wage factories.
The new Ford pact has a complex clause giving Ford an extra incentive to increase its overall work force quickly by moving into auto parts businesses, people with a detailed knowledge of the contract said. For every three low-wage workers Ford hires in the new parts factories, the company will be allowed to let two high-wage workers retire without replacing them, even if this means going below the 95 percent floor on employment levels at existing assembly plants and parts factories.
The contract also allows Ford to negotiate a breach in the 95 percent threshold if a recession badly hurts the company. Previous labor pacts have required auto makers to continue paying most of the wages of laid off workers, but have not guaranteed levels of employment.
Detroit's auto makers currently pay about $19 an hour to assembly workers and parts workers alike. Outside parts companies pay $8 to $17 an hour, depending on the product. The Ford pact would let it pay the same wage in its new parts factories as the better-paying outside makers of the same product.
The U.A.W. has a long history of seeking innovations in industry pattern-setting deals with Ford. Henry Ford 2d, who ran the company from 1945 to 1980, agreed to many new fringe benefits, like fully financed pensions, first granted in 1949.
Peter J. Pestillo, an executive vice president at Ford, has shaped the labor policies of Ford and the entire auto industry since 1980. People close to the U.A.W. said that Mr. Pestillo and Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, drafted this year's innovative contract.
The many provisions in Ford's contract to discourage corporate downsizing and outsourcing, or the use of outside suppliers, come at a time when both practices have become buzzwords for politicians and some business leaders critical of numerous layoffs in the last decade.
While G.M. is still moving to buy more parts from outside vendors, Ford and Chrysler have found some of these suppliers to be unreliable.
Chrysler lost millions of dollars last year when it had to delay the introduction of a new line of mini-vans because a 16-employee company in Toledo, Ohio, fell behind on orders for a machine vital to the production of front suspensions.
Ford has closed one of its most profitable factories for all of this week because the Dana Corporation, a large parts supplier, could not make enough metal underbody frames to keep up with a surge in demand for F-150 pickup trucks with four-wheel drive.
Gary Corrigan, a spokesman for Dana, said it was working quickly to make more frames. He predicted that even with the new labor contract, auto makers would buy more and more parts from suppliers like Dana.
But Ms. Parolini said that other auto suppliers were more worried.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 19, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday listing some provisions of the tentative labor contract between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union misstated the sources of the information. They were people close to the union and other sources, not company officials.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A New Approach to Corporate Downsizing"
The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union reached a three-year agreement on Monday evening that provides the company with incentives to stop shrinking its work force and begin hiring more workers. The pact is subject to ratfication, considered virtually certain, by union members. Here are some of the provisions.
 
Ford's overall employment of U.A.W. members will stay at or above 95 percent of current levels. There are 105,000 U.A.W. workers in Ford now.
 
If Ford begins manufacturing auto parts that it previously purchased from outside suppliers, Ford can pay much lower wages to the extra workers hired.
 
Each low-wage worker hired in a new auto parts business counts as two-thirds of a worker for calculating compliance with the 95 percent minimum. So Ford has incentive to hire many low-wage workers so as to let more high-wage workers retire without replacing them.
 
Ford will raise pensions by an much as 11 percent over three years, partly as an incentive to encourage the retirement of high-wage workers.
 
Each Ford worker will receive a $2,000 bonus this year followed by a three percent bonus or wage increase in each of the second and third years. These are in addition to annual cost-of-living raises, which have been paid since 1948.
 
(Source: Company interviews)(pg. D6)

HEADLINE: WHEN MONEY COUNTS;
... And a New House Bends to a Family's Needs

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
IF design awards were given for political correctness, "The Next Home," an experimental four-story house designed to be affordable for nontraditional families, could be a contender.
In this United States election year, as candidates again tout home ownership as part of the American dream, the $27-a-square-foot prototype home on view here at McGill University may represent the trenches of affordable design. 
 It also mirrors a broad swath of society. This new type of housing, built by McGill's Affordable Homes program, the first of its kind at a North American school of architecture, takes on the conventional wisdom of the homebuilding industry that bigger is better.
The "Next Home" offers a camera-ready vision of ourselves: adaptable at practically a moment's notice to non-Ozzie and Harriet family groups of every description: divorced parents, empty nesters, widowers working at home. Varied families need a variety of rooms, and the "Next Home" gives them the power to configure their own layouts and architectural details.
"The way we work, live and entertain is changing," said Prof. Avi Friedman, who designed the house.
"The landscape of the house needs to change along with it."
The prototype "Next Home," which is on display until Sept. 27, was built with a pollster's -- or a television sitcom writer's -- instinct for social and demographic trends, from the rise of the single-parent family to buying in bulk from shopping clubs.
Conceived as a triplex, the prototype has fictional occupants: Claude, 57, a widower who was downsized from his job; Marc and Julie, a young childless couple struggling to afford a starter home, and Susie, a single mother with two teen-age children.
In contrast to conventional housing, in which costly remodeling is often done after the fact, the "Next Home" lets residents create their own solutions -- say, buying as many floors as they want and personalizing them as their means allow. Homeowners, not builders or architects, decide whether to splurge on bay windows -- and where to put them -- and whether to go for a flat or a pitched roof.
Claude lives in the 750-square-foot ground-floor apartment, which includes a home office 15 feet by 12 feet, to accommodate the consulting firm he is starting: cost, about $40,000. It has its own wheelchair-accessible entrance (the layout easily lends itself also to a granny flat). Marc and Julie inhabit the second floor, an 800-square-foot space (about $40,000), which includes an unfinished porch that could eventually be turned into a baby's room. Susie, the divorced single mother, who supplements her income as a health-care worker by freelancing from home, bought the 1,150-square-foot two-story upper unit for about $53,000. She chose a two-tier loftlike space with a cathedral ceiling and dormer bedroom suite to give her and her children privacy.
The flexible design, in which "many things that today happen by accident will be planned for," in Professor Friedman's words, also allows homeowners or builders to alter the position of walls and stairways, which could easily allow a triplex, for example, to convert to a duplex. Rooms contain minimum walls, with the idea that homeowners can add them if they need them. (In the demonstration home, curtains and storage units function as room dividers, prompting some visitors to mutter that it was designed with the young in mind.)
Homeowners can also change the position of water pipes, heating and cooling ducts, drain pipes and electrical wiring without costly construction work, thanks to open-web joists, the structural members that make up ceilings and floors.
For better or worse, residents could also largely decree the look of the house. One novel concept of the "Next Home" is to let homeowners choose from a menu of architectural options. For an extra cost, for example, they could add a bay window, for extra seating in the living room or a pergola to the outdoor porch. The owner of the upper floors could turn the attic into a livable dormer mezzanine, which would determine if the building had a flat or gable roof.
The flexibility of the house symbolizes economic and social changes that have occurred over the last decade, including the unstable job market, in which, Professor Friedman said, "many people between the ages of 25 and 44 are not in a position to carry a mortgage over $100,000." The home is designed a la Gail Sheehy's "Passages," to parallel the changes in its occupants' lives.
To cut costs, Professor Friedman and his colleagues streamlined the construction, using prefabricated elements and relying on a simple no-frills floor plan requiring minimal mainenance. Its low cost and adaptability are attempts to translate into home design such issues as job insecurity (reflected in both the house costs and home offices); shrinking family size; working parents, and the growing numbers of empty-nesters, single parents and childless families. The goal, he said, is a house that "doesn't make assumptions on likely or projected household types" but "can evolve, like society."
Professor Friedman would like to do for housing what Steve Jobs did for computers, comparing the "Next Home" to a Honda versus a Cadillac. "We're offering the same cake, just smaller slices," he said.
Paradoxically, the idea of downsized houses, or smaller slices, flies in the face of United States homebuilding trends. Gopal Ahluwala, director of research for the National Association of Home Builders, says that though family size has decreased, the size of the average American house has increased to a whopping 2,100-square-feet, compared with 1,520 in 1971.
Mr. Ahluwala said that consumer studies indicate buyers want even more space, including two and a half baths or more. He attributed the escalating size to baby-boomer demand. "They want everything, whether they can afford it or not." He said that schemes like the "Next Home" were "a good idea, but not a national idea."
Professor Friedman argues that builders are designing outmoded gas guzzlers and that the lack of small units creates serious affordability problems. "Consumers respond to what's available," he said.
Gwendolyn Wright, a professor of architecture at Columbia University and author of "Building the Dream: A Social History of Housing in America," believes that "the market needs to be more flexible." She said: "Like a thermostat, it responds to climatic shifts, but it can also be adjusted. There needs to be more pluralism and experimentation."
Professor Friedman's commitment to affordable housing stems in part from experience. His parents are Holocaust survivors who immigrated to Israel from Poland in the 1940's. They lived in abandoned army barracks outside Tel Aviv before moving into a 350-square-foot home of cinder blocks. He and his sister shared the small bedroom while his parents slept on a pull-out bed in the living room. Professor Friedman vividly remembers the luxuriousness of 350 square feet. "Being able for the first time to have a shower indoors, the fortune of not hearing the rain zipping through the roof. It was wonderful to have that comfort."
In designing the "Next Home," he and his colleagues took cues from the postwar houses of the 1940's, including the 800-square-foot Levittown, L.I., houses. It was an era, Professor Friedman explained, in which small, modest homes were within reach of the average family, and government policies forced architects and builders to come up with innovative low-cost solutions.
For a year they interviewed occupants of postwar houses in and around Montreal, to learn if and how they modified their spaces. The conversations affirmed their hunches. "They showed us how versatile people could be at finding solutions internally," Professor Friedman said.
The form of the home was also inspired by the narrow-front Montreal duplexes and triplexes of the 1920's and 30's, which still punctuate the city's landscape with a latticework of external stairways.
The "Next Home" builds on the success of the "Grow Home," an affordable, 14-foot-wide single-family home Professor Friedman designed six years ago with the author Witold Rybczynski, now a professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
Much to Professor Friedman's continued amazement, the "Grow Home," which also began as a prototype plunked into the middle of the campus, took off commercially; there are more than 5,000 of them in and around Montreal.
The success of the "Grow Home" has spawned its own problems, chief among them quality control. There can be a big difference between a model home at a university and a developer's interpretation.
Garry Garbarino, a Montreal developer who built 350 "Grow Homes," said such housing needs good planning to succeed, including access to schools and shopping. Many of the "Grow Homes" have been built on urban fringes, far from city services, where land is cheap. He said the projects also need scrutiny from local planning boards. "Many builders took advantage of the 'Grow Home' and put out a shoddy product," he said.
"Affordable housing is a hot political issue in the United States," Professor Rybczynski pointed out, citing resistance of municipalities to anything that might lower property values. Ours, he added, is a "more contentious culture" than Canada's. Philadelphia and other American cities have a long tradition of small row houses, but the "Next Home" and "Grow Homes," he said,"would be more difficult to build here."
A recent visit to "Grow Homes" in Montreal found the owners generally happy with their houses, which though somewhat stark outside felt comfortable and roomy inside.
Andree Tardif, 49, a municipal employee who lives on her own in Laval, a Montreal suburb, added extras to her "Grow Home": an angled fireplace, suspended cupboards in the kitchen, a whirlpool bath to ease apres-ski aches. She would like to add a fireplace mantel, but "my wallet can't go as fast as I want to," she said.
Living in a "Grow Home" that cost her about $70,000, including the frills, has changed her idea of luxury, she said. "I used to want to live in a big house. Now I wonder, how do they manage to heat it? They feel so big. If you're two people, you're not close to each other."
They've plumbed the plusses. "It's a little house," Lise Languein, another "Grow" homeowner, said. "So it's no problem to cut the grass."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Narrow Range For Bonds On Rate Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed but stayed in a narrow range yesterday, as the market continued to be weighed down by concerns of an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.
Market participants remained wary that short-term rates may be increased at next Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, particularly in light of a news article this past Tuesday that said some Fed district bank presidents had officially submitted requests for rate rises. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 5/32, to 96 25/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.01 percent, from 7.02 percent on Tuesday.
Among the data ignored yesterday was the July international trade report by the Commerce Department, which showed the trade gap widening, to $11.68 billion, the biggest gap since $12.9 million in the fourth quarter of 1987.
The National Association of Home Builders monthly index of single-family housing market conditions fell for the fourth consecutive month in early September to a reading of 56 from 57 in August. For some economists, this is a sign that the interest-rate-sensitive housing sector can slow without the Fed having to start raising rates. The index's peak this year was 63 in May.
Several Fed officials were scheduled to speak this week and market participants were actively interested in what they had to say. Some analysts noted that Fed officials usually refrained from saying anything about economic conditions and monetary policy in the week before a policy meeting.
Among the officials speaking yesterday was a Fed governor, Susan M. Phillips, who was in Washington appearing before the House Banking Committee. She spoke about the impact on the banking system of the Sumitomo copper trading scandal, and did not discuss the state of the economy or Fed monetary policy.
The Fed vice chairman, Alice Rivlin, speaking in New York at an Institute of International Bankers meeting, told reporters that the economy was healthy and that it had made progress toward growth with little inflation in the past few years.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, sees the market being treated to a battle royal between the opposing hawkish and dovish forces at the Fed, with the outcome still murky. Mr. Delaney says steady and impressive growth on the employment front has many experienced and supposedly savvy policy makers convinced that the time to act pre-emptively to nip inflation is now. On the other side, the argument goes, "Give growth a chance."
"Our own feeling," Mr. Delaney said, "is that the Fed chairman's influence in this conflict will be utilized to negotiate a compromise, resulting in a 25-basis-point hike in both the Fed Funds and discount rate next week." And there could be additional tightening should developments warrant, he added. "But, should housing starts drop off a cliff," Mr. Delaney added, "the doves may prevail at least until the next F.O.M.C. meeting."
Nationsbank, Ford Motor Credit Company and Daimler-Benz A.G. led a crush of companies wanting to borrow before the Fed meets next Tuesday. Nationsbank, sold $1.45 billion of debt in three parts with $500 million of senior notes due in 2001 priced to yield 7.034 percent, $500 million of subordinated notes due in 2006 priced to yield 7.500 percent and $450 million of subordinated notes due in 2016 priced to yield 7.862 percent.
The senior debt is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's, while the subordinated debt is rated A-3 and A minus, respectively.
The Treasury yesterday also announced the size of its note auctions for next week. It plans to borrow $18.25 billion by selling two-year notes on Wednesday and $12.5 billion of five-year notes on Thursday, down about $500 million. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.25 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 6.61 percent.

HEADLINE: Photo Error Is Blamed For Defeat In Primary

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
All newspapers make mistakes at times, and apologize for them, but the correction and apology that The Star Tribune of Minneapolis put out after a computer glitch placed a picture of John Derus in the wrong article last week on the day of a primary election is not good enough for Gov. Arne Carlson of Minnesota. He thinks The Star Tribune should pay for a new election.
That is because Mr. Derus was a candidate in a State Senate primary that day, and the article with which his picture was accidentally printed, but with which he had nothing to do, was about charity fraud. "Charity Fraud," the headline said, right above Mr. Derus's photograph in the Sept. 10 issue, and when the ballots were counted, Mr. Derus had lost his race in the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party primary by 104 votes, out of more than 6,000 cast. 
 Since Mr. Derus would have won if just 53 of those 104 votes had gone to him, he and Governor Carlson say the election results were wrongly corrupted when enough headline-skimming readers got the impression from page B3 of The Star Tribune that morning that the candidate was some kind of crook.
Human error and a quirk of The Star Tribune's pagination process, which composes complete newspaper pages for the printing press, caused the mistake, said Tim J. McGuire, editor of The Star Tribune.
Mr. Derus wants a new election and the Governor agrees, adding that the newspaper, not the taxpayers, should pay the bill.
"It is my opinion that the Sept. 10 primary election should be declared null and void, and a new election should be held, and The Star Tribune should be accountable for election costs," Mr. Carlson wrote the Hennepin County Canvassing Board, the local election agency, on Monday.
Absolutely no, Mr. McGuire replied to the Governor's demand.
"We certainly take the mistake seriously," Mr. McGuire said. "It was the wrong picture in the wrong place on the wrong day, and we have apologized to Mr. Derus. But we have no intention of getting involved in the electoral process economically."
The fact that Mr. Carlson is a Republican and Mr. Derus is a Democrat does not appear to be enough of a difference to overcome what unites them: a shared dislike for Minnesota's biggest and most influential daily, with a weekday circulation of nearly 400,000.
The newspaper has frequently criticized Mr. Carlson in his six years as Governor, and a 1993 investigation by The Star Tribune reported that Mr. Carlson had ignored racketeering in the Minneapolis Employee Retirement Fund when he was State Auditor, an accusation the Governor denies.
Meanwhile, the words the newspaper has used to describe Mr. Derus, for 19 years a Hennepin County Commissioner and a former Minneapolis Alderman, are mostly of the blunt-object variety, like "bully."
Patrick H. O'Connor, the chairman of the canvassing board, wrote back to Governor Carlson on Monday that the case of the mixed-up photograph was not the board's problem.
"Any action sought by Mr. Derus regarding the actions of The Minneapolis Star Tribune must go through the courts," Mr. O'Connor said.
Mr. Derus has accordingly hired lawyers, who have until Friday, the day the canvassing board is to announce the winner, to challenge the outcome. But First Amendment experts said the idea of making a newspaper pay for anything as a result of a mistake did not pass legal muster.
Yet the Governor is sticking to his demands.
"The Governor certainly believes -- he is more convinced than I am -- that the election was affected by the mistake," said Cyndy Brucato, Mr. Carlson's deputy chief of staff.
Ms. Brucato estimated that a new primary election for the 58th District, which covers Minneapolis's north side, would cost about $2,000.
The newspaper had run the same picture of Mr. Derus in a voters guide on page B3 the week before the election ("a long history of cronyism, bullying and abuse of co-workers and subordinates," an editorial said of him that week), but technicians afterward neglected to remove the picture from the computer.
On the next Tuesday, the page-making machine placed Mr. Derus's picture back onto page B-3, this time in the charity fraud article.
Brian Rice, Mr. Derus's lawyer, conceded that state law generally required proof of fraud committed by one of the candidates, like a false claim of party endorsement, to void an election. But the law also cites the use of fraud by others to prevent the free exercise of the vote, Mr. Rice said, and the newspaper's past criticism of Mr. Derus may add to his case. But he stopped short of calling the photograph mix-up deliberate.
David Anderson, a professor of law at the Universityof Texas, said the Governor and the candidate had little chance of succeeding under current First Amendment doctrine of the Supreme Court.
"If the candidate sued for libel, he would lose because the United Supreme Court would say the newspaper is protected from liability for inadvertent error," he said. "For the very same reason that it is impermissible for the law to give a libel remedy, it is impermissible for the law to require a newspaper to pay for an election."

HEADLINE: Export Data Nudge Dow 11.47 Lower

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday for a second day as computer issues like Intel and Microsoft again reached record highs, helping offset weakness in machinery and retail shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.47 points, to 5,877.36, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.47, to 681.47. The Nasdaq composite index, home to both Intel and Microsoft, climbed 2.40, to 1,205.71. 
 Declining stocks outnumbered advancing issues by about 7 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, where 396.6 million shares changed hands, below the average for the last three days.
Stocks suffered after a report of unexpectedly weak United States exports in July damaged machinery companies and other companies that have large sales abroad.
The trade report also suggested that economic growth might not be as robust as expected in the third quarter. Total United States exports fell 3.6 percent in July, to $67.2 billion, prompting some leading economists to consider lowering their third-quarter growth forecasts for the entire economy.
As a result, among the biggest percentage decliners in the S.& P. 500 were the farm and construction-equipment makers Deere, down 1 1/8, to 41 7/8, and Case, off 1, to 47 5/8. Cincinnati Milacron, a maker of machine tools, fell 5/8, to 21 1/4.
Gillette, which got 70 percent of its sales last year overseas. fell 5/8, to 67 5/8. Gillette, the razor maker, recently agreed to buy Duracell International, which gets half its sales abroad. Duracell slipped 7/8, to 59 3/4.
"I don't think the foreign markets, especially the European markets, are recovering the way people thought," said Gil Knight, director of research at Allied Investment Advisors, who helps oversee $4 billion in assets. "There doesn't seem to be any great economic advance in Europe, so who's going to have the money to buy?"
Concern about the pace of economic growth in the United States and questions about the strength of Christmas sales hurt retail stocks. Sears, Roebuck fell 1/2, to 44 7/8; Wal-Mart Stores slipped 1/2, to 26 5/8, and Dayton Hudson declined 1, to 34 1/4.
The advance in computer-related shares showed that some investors believed these companies would do well even in the sixth year of the economic expansion, Graham Tanaka, president of Tanaka Capital Management, said. "There are some very healthy parts of the technology sector, and the companies that have proprietary positions are going to do very well," he added.
Microsoft rose 2 5/8, to 136 1/2. And Intel soared 1 3/8, to a record 95 5/8. Earlier this week, the chip maker said sales had been unexpectedly strong in the current quarter.
The feeling among many investors was that because of their dominance of the computer market, Intel and Microsoft were more likely to benefit from improved personal computer sales than any of their rivals.
Not all computer-related issues did well. Netscape Communications slumped 3 3/8, to 42 5/8, in trading of more than 3.8 million shares after Merrill Lynch cut its investment opinion to "neutral." Merrill said the Internet pioneer's window of opportunity against Microsoft, the country's leading software publisher, was shrinking fast.
Zenith Electronics climbed 2, to 16 5/8. Its chairman denied speculation that the company, a maker of consumer electronics, was in talks to be sold.
Trading in options to buy Zenith's shares soared as well. Options to buy stock at 15 a share in October vaulted 1 3/8, or 110 percent, to 2 5/8, as 1,618 contracts changed hands.
 Trans World Airlines retreated 1/8, to 10 1/2. The airline said cancellations in the wake of the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 in July and higher fuel costs would reduce profits below the levels of a year earlier.
