HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Drop in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday after a strong housing report alarmed investors and a Government report on manufacturing sent mixed signals to a market already sharply divided over the possibility of a rise in interest rates.
The 30-year bond fell 13/32 , to a price of 9613/32 , to yield 7.04 percent, up from 7.01 percent on Wednesday. 
 Analysts said the Philadephia Federal Reserve Bank's regional business survey for September sent mixed signals to a market that was looking for something more definitive, as it tried to figure out whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates next week.
The overall business outlook index fell to 13.9, which was encouraging for those who believe the Fed will refrain from raising rates because inflation was under control. But the prices-paid index was up to 18.0 in September and, in the minds of market participants, higher prices in the mind of market participants means a higher probability of inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments like Treasury securities.
Also a stronger-than-expected August housing starts report, released by the Commerce Department, raised expectations of an interest rate rise scenario next Tuesday.
"Today's report, which showed starts up 4.5 percent last month, reinforces the view that this sector is indeed strong, despite high mortgage interest rates," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "These data are more ammunition for those policy makers wanting to raise interest rates and reinforces our view that the Fed will implement a 25-basis-point hike in rates in next week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting."
The weekly jobless claims report for the week ended last Saturday showed a decline of 2,000 from the previous week, to 329,000. Ms. Schaja believed it confirmed perceptions of a strong labor market.
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International, San Francisco, said yesterday morning's Philadelphia Fed report did not clarify Fed policy uncertainties. She said, "The moderation in the Philly Fed index, the slowdown in orders, the drop in delivery times, and the decline in building permits helped support the slowdown scenario."
"However," she added, "the rise in the Philly price paid and prices received components, the rise in employment, and the resilience in the housing sector could argue for a 25- basis-point rate hike." But she says the Fed has been patient, and with retail sales and consumer credit showing signs of weakness, and still benign readings on many of the inflation indicators, her firm's assumption is that the Fed will choose to wait.
But no doubt it was the jump in the housing report that sent up the warning flag yesterday. Joseph Battipaglia, chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company, said, "Everyone knows these numbers are volatile, but it's hard for the bond market to shake the thought that the economy is still strong."
He said there was some anticipatory positioning going on ahead of a Fed announcement next week. "My suspicion is that dealers would want to be light inventory-wise going into the F.O.M.C. meeting next week," he said. His reference was to the Federal Open Market Committee.
Elsewhere, corporate borrowing slowed yesterday as yields on Treasury securities rose. Still, there were some companies looking to sell securities in case rates rise in the coming weeks.
The Philip Morris Companies priced $650 million of five-year bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Given a coupon of 7.25 percent, the notes were priced at 99.67, to yield 7.33 percent, or about 67 basis points more than the when-issued Treasury note at the time of pricing. Noncallable, the notes are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the two-year note to be sold next week was being offered at a price to yield 6.28 percent and the five-year, 6.63 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Changes Policy on Polio Inoculation, Recommending Salk Vaccine for First Doses

 BODY:
Inactivated polio vaccine, familiar to millions in the 1950's and 60's as the Salk vaccine, was reinstated on Wednesday as part of the Federal Government's recommended schedule of childhood immunizations.
After two years of study, the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta formally recommended a change from four doses of oral polio vaccine, which uses the live but "attenuated" virus, to two doses of inactivated polio vaccine, given as an injection, followed by two doses of the oral vaccine. 
 The transmission of polio from person to person -- "wild" polio in medical terms -- has been eradicated in the Western Hemisphere since 1991. But 8 to 10 cases of polio are diagnosed in the United States each year as a result of the oral polio vaccine itself. Virtually no cases of vaccine-associated polio have been attributed to the inactivated vaccine.
Under the new recommendation, by taking the inactivated vaccine first an infant would gain protection against the tiny risk of contracting polio from the oral vaccine.
The disease-control centers estimated that providing the polio shots would add as much as $6.50 to the cost of immunizing each child who visited a public health clinic and $1.00 to $1.50 more for children who receive their immunizations at offices of private physicians. Over all, the change would cost the health care system $15 million to $16 million a year.
The centers said it would be acceptable for infants still to receive either four doses of oral vaccine or to take all four doses in the form of the Salk shots, since both types of vaccinations appear to protect against polio.
A coalition of minority health care organizations said yesterday in a conference call with reporters that it would petition President Clinton to delay the policy change because of concern that it could result in a lower overall rate of immunization for all childhood diseases among inner city and rural children.
The coalition said that adding two polio injections to the 13 shots already recommended for measles, diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough, hepatitis B and other diseases would discourage some parents from bringing their children back repeatedly to doctors to complete the entire series of immunizations or increase the number of shots in a single visit.
"In underserved communities, this change would have an impact not only on the rates of immunization for polio but would jeopardize the whole immunization schedule and put children at risk for other vaccine-preventable diseases," said Dr. Jane Delgado, president of the National Coalition of Hispanic Health and Human Services Organizations.
Proponents of the change disagree. "I don't know of one parent who would forego a vaccination because it is given by shot," said John Salamone, of Oakton, Va., whose son, David, now 6, contracted polio from an infant immunization with the oral vaccine.
"Every other immunization is given by shot," Mr. Salamone said in a telephone interview. "This is the exception."
Mr. Salamone said that at the time of his son's vaccination "we really had no idea that there was any risk at all and, in fact, we had no idea that there were choices." The policy change is "a no-brainer and should have been made years ago," he said.
Dr. Walter A. Orenstein, director of C.D.C.'s national immunization program, said the agency had discussed the issue with groups of minority parents. "Once they understood the issue, about 80 percent of the economically disadvantaged parents said they would prefer inactivated vaccine," Dr. Orenstein said.
Members of the minority coalition said the change would pose dangers to far more people than the small number who might be spared polio infection.
"According to the best data we have, there are only 5 to 10 cases of vaccine-associated polio every year," said Dr. Norma J. Goodwin, president of Health Watch, an organization that promotes minority health improvement. "While that is extremely regrettable, public health policy is supposed to be about what is good for the public at large. This change is being made to prevent one case of vaccine-associated polio for every 2.5 million vaccinations."
The minority health coalition said there were no data to support the contention that the changed schedule would reduce vaccine-associated polio. But the centers estimates it would cut the number of cases by 75 percent to 80 percent, or down to two or three cases per year.
The change in policy could create a potential windfall for Connaught Laboratories of Swiftwater, Pa., currently the world's only maker of inactivated polio vaccine, and could cost millions of dollars for Wyeth Lederle Vaccines and Pediatrics, of Radnor, Pa., currently the only maker of the oral polio vaccine.
Connaught will sell about 500,000 doses of the inactivated vaccine this year, said a company spokeswoman, Chris Grant. If only half of next year's four million newborns are given the inactivated vaccine, the number of doses would rise to about four million, she said. Connaught could sell as manyas eight million doses a year if the recommendations are universally adopted.

HEADLINE: Semiconductor Issues Rally in Mixed Day as Dow Dips 9.62

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Semiconductor shares rallied again, but stocks were mixed yesterday as interest rates rose once more in the bond market after a strong reading on housing construction aggravated inflation worries.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.62, to 5,867.74, its third straight losing session after two record highs. The total retreat has amounted to less than 22 points, with many investors remaining optimistic for a run at 6,000. 
 Most broad market measures turned positive after a weak start with bonds. The Nasdaq market rose for the 10th straight session, continuing its gradual crawl back toward record levels amid renewed investor interest in computer-industry shares.
Stocks initially followed bonds lower after the Government reported that construction of new homes and apartments unexpectedly shot up in August to the highest level in nearly two and a half years.
The report was the last major economic reading before Tuesday's Federal Reserve meeting on interest-rate policy. It spurred worries that rising demand for building materials and home furnishings will pressure an already tight labor market, forcing higher payroll costs that might be passed on to consumers.
So far, there has been little evidence that retail prices are rising. But analysts have been divided over whether economic growth is slowing enough to contain wage and other production cost pressures without the central bank's intervention. Higher Fed lending rates would help contain inflation by slowing spending and demand, but that could hurt corporate profits.
As bond prices fell, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond a key determinant of corporate and consumer borrowing costs rose to 7.04 percent from Wednesday's 7.01 percent.
Despite the higher rates, stocks started rebounding in the late morning and early afternoon on optimism that the signs of economic growth could translate into better earnings, analysts said.
"What's happened this afternoon is the realization that the economy is rocking right along," said Jim Weiss, deputy chief investment officer for equities at State Street Research and Management Company in Boston.
"There's no evidence that inflation is flaring up, so the market is looking through the news of the day to the underlying conditions," Mr. Weiss said.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers by an 13-to-11 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 398.6 million shares, about even with Wednesday's pace.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.53, to 683.00, and the Big Board's composite index rose 0.50, to 363.94, but the American Stock Exchange's market value index fell 1.21, to 565.44.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 6.38, to 1,212.09.
Semiconductor shares were among the session's strongest issues, with Intel continuing this week's rally on news of its surprisingly strong third-quarter sales.
Intel rose 1 3/8, to 97, in active Nasdaq trading. Among chip makers on the Big Board, Micron Technology rose 2, to 27 3/8; Texas Instruments rose 2 1/4, to 52 1/4; LSI Logic rose 1 1/8, to 23 3/4, and Cypress Semiconductor rose 7/8, to 12 3/8.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
In His Own Words

 BODY:

BILL CLINTON
 
Speaking yesterday in Centralia, Wash., about House Republicans:
"I remember well in 1994 when they went across the country and they won the Congress back. 
 "They won as many seats in the state of Washington, including this one, as in any state in the country, and they said a few clear things.
"They said we have this 'Contract With America' and it will move American forward.
"And they neglected to say they wanted to cut education. They wanted to weaken the environment. They wanted to raise taxes on the poorest working people. They wanted to permit people to raid their workers' pension funds.
"They wanted to abolish Americorps, abolish our student loan program, abolish the safe and drug-free schools program. They wanted to turn Medicare into a two-tier system. They wanted to stop Medicaid's guarantee of health care to poor children, to pregnant women, to families with people with disabilities, to the elderly in our nursing homes.
"They left out all that fine print in 1994, but when they took office, we saw what they wanted. They also attacked us for two things. They said the economic program which passed in 1993 raised the taxes of ordinary Americans -- their income taxes. It wasn't true."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Dole Inside Out

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Bob Dole had one main thing going for him as a candidate for President: He was a man of steadiness, of responsibility, of character. With him, there would not be the flip-flops of Bill Clinton's White House. You might not share his ideology, but you knew where you stood with Bob Dole. You could trust him.
How bizarre it is to say that now. For, one month into the campaign, Senator Dole has become the flip-flop candidate. He has allowed himself to be manipulated into abandoning one after another of his established beliefs for the hope of short-term political advantage. 
It began at the Republican Convention, when he raised the banner of supply-side economics that he had always mocked as self-delusion. He told the country with a straight face that he would cut taxes by $550 billion and balance the budget at the same time -- without touching the biggest spending items: defense, Social Security and Medicare.
The economic irresponsibility has got worse since then. The other week he was in New Mexico, and he promised that while he would abolish the Energy Department he would preserve two of its costliest enterprises -- the weapons laboratories at Los Alamos and Sandia in that state. If there is any more ludicrous duplication in the Federal budget than those two laboratories, it is a secret.
In San Diego, Senator Dole said his tax-cut plan included "a $500 per child tax credit for low- and middle-income families." Analysis since then, by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, has shown that 28 million children of low-income parents who work would get nothing from the Dole plan. That is because it would give the credit only to those whose Federal income tax exceeds the earned-income tax credit already available to the working poor.
Immediately after the San Diego convention, Senator Dole flatly repudiated one plank in the Republican platform. It called for a constitutional amendment to repeal the 14th Amendment's provision that everyone born in this country is a United States citizen. A sponsor of the plank said women were "coming across the border just to have babies."
Mr. Dole's rejection of that radical plank seemed to put him among opponents of extreme measures against illegal immigrants. But now he is using his still-strong influence in Congress on behalf of another harsh idea, to bar the children of undocumented aliens from public schools -- a step that the Supreme Court in 1982 held unconstitutional.
The schooling ban was added to a pending immigration bill in the House. Last week Mr. Dole sent word that he wanted Republicans to insist on keeping it in the final bill. He hopes thereby to win votes in California -- and to kill the bill in the Senate, thus denying President Clinton credit for signing an immigration-reform measure.
The rawness of those tactics outraged Mr. Dole's old friend Senator Alan Simpson of Wyoming. He said Mr. Dole was being "ill served on the issue" by advisers, and the national interest was being "subverted by Machiavellian mumbo-jumbo."
The most surprising of the Dole flip-flops was on the treaty to prohibit the production, sale or use of chemical weapons. Negotiation of the treaty was started by the Republican Administrations of Presidents Reagan and Bush, with Senator Dole's support.
The Senate was to debate the treaty last week. But at the last minute right-wing opponents of this and other arms control measures produced a letter from Senator Dole saying that he had changed his mind and joined the opposition. Faced with defeat, sponsors canceled Senate consideration.
The reasons given by Mr. Dole for his switch were embarrassingly contradictory. He said that the ban on poison gas would be too easy to avoid -- and that the provisions of the treaty for inspection of suspect sites were too intrusive.
Bob Dole has above all been responsible on issues of foreign policy, repeatedly putting the national interest ahead of politics. That is why his political turnabout on the chemical weapons treaty was so troubling. It will be harder, from now on, to say what many did: We may disagree with him on this or that, but Bob Dole is a serious man.

HEADLINE: Elizabeth B. Noyce, 65, Benefactor of Maine With Vast Settlement From Her Divorce

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Elizabeth Bottomley Noyce, a microchip millionaire's scorned first wife who showed as much imagination and verve in deploying her half of his Silicon Valley fortune as he had in making it, died on Tuesday at her seaside home in Bremen, Me. She was 65 and had been the state's premier philanthropist and most innovative investor for two decades.
Her lawyer, Owen Wells, noting that Mrs. Noyce had long suffered from emphysema, said the cause was a heart attack. 
 The daughter of a blue-collar worker from Auburn, Mass., who had to hold two jobs to support his family in the Depression, Mrs. Noyce was majoring in English at Tufts University in the early 1950's and dreaming of becoming a writer when she signed on as costume director of a summer theatrical production and caught the eye of one of the cast members, a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology named Robert N. Noyce.
The couple were married in 1953, and Mrs. Noyce, who had dreamed of writing novels and short stories, became the most dutiful of corporate wives, bearing four children and following her husband from job to job, including a somewhat reluctant move to California for a woman who never felt comfortable away from her beloved New England.
"We were under the distinct impression that we would try it for a year and if I didn't like it we wouldn't stay," she recalled years later, suggesting that her husband had forgotten the bargain: "We stayed 19 years."
By then the life of the blue-collar worker's daughter had changed considerably, largely because her husband had become a co-inventor of the microchip, which laid the foundation for the vast personal computer industry, and had helped found three of the industry's premier companies, including the giant Intel Corporation.
Her life changed even more in 1975 when Mr. Noyce left her to marry an Intel executive. Although bitter over the circumstances of the breakup of her marriage, Mrs. Noyce, whose husband died in 1990, managed to console herself somewhat in the divorce. Under California's community property laws she claimed half his Intel stock and all his other assets, including full title to their 50-acre Maine estate, where Mrs. Noyce had been spending summers.
How much she received from the divorce could not be determined yesterday, and a spokesman for Intel, which has a market capitalization of $86 billion, could not say how much stock she owned at the time of her death. Mr. Wells, her lawyer, said, however, that after all her charitable donations, her estate was worth $100 million to $1 billion.
Putting her husband and California behind her, Mrs. Noyce did not so much move to Maine as adopt the state.
In a whirlwind of philanthropy that began almost as soon as she settled into her house on Muscongus Bay and continued the rest of her life, she systematically gave away some $75 million, primarily to Maine charities.
Oh, there would be the occasional out-of-state donation -- a million to Tufts here, a half-million to Harvard there -- but for the most part Mrs. Noyce, whose donations covered the gamut of public causes including education, medicine, the arts and the environment, concentrated her giving in Maine, responding to virtually any cause, charity or public institution in the state that needed money.
Among other things, she built a golf course for the town of Bremen, gave lavishly to the Portland Museum of Art, the Maine Maritime Museum and the University of Maine. When the Cumberland County Civic Center was so pressed for cash that it was looking for a corporate sponsor that would give it money in exchange for the right to give the center its name, Mrs. Noyce came through with a $1.3 million donation that allowed the center to retain its identity.
But for all the acclaim Mrs. Noyce received for her direct philanthropy, including the $15 million in endowments for charitable trusts that make independent grants to Maine charities, Mrs. Noyce gained even more applause when she began pioneering what she called "catalytic philanthropy," investments designed to bolster the state's economy.
In 1991, for example, when out-of-state financial institutions were picking off Maine's banks one by one and it appeared that Maine businesses and other borrowers would soon be at the mercy of distant lenders, Mrs. Noyce blithely created a brand new bank, the Maine Bank and Trust Company with an initial $7.7 million investment that eventually grew to some $14 million.
What made such "philanthropy," especially appealing became apparent when the bank prospered. Mr. Wells, who advised Mrs. Noyce on her investments, estimated yesterday that the bank was now worth at least twice what she paid for it.
During a lull in Maine's construction industry, Mrs. Noyce built five homes to provide jobs for construction workers, and when Maine's leading bakery was threatened with a takeover by a company that intended to move it out of state, Mrs. Noyce came to the rescue, buying the bakery and saving its 1,200 jobs.
Recently Mrs. Noyce had turned her attention to Portland's deteriorating downtown, going on a buying spree in which she acquired about 10 percent of the city's office and retail space. The rehabilitation effort attracted L. L. Bean and other tenants.
Although her efforts won wide praise, there were some rumblings that Mrs. Noyce was becoming too big a factor in the Portland economy and she had recently announced that she had no further designs on downtown property.
For all her wealth, Mrs. Noyce lived fairly simply, shunning the usual trappings of wealth and even driving her own car, most recently a Cadillac, to be sure, but only, she told her friends, because after a wreck in her smaller Oldsmobile, she felt more secure in a larger car.
Although she was always appropriately dressed, Mrs. Noyce had no interest in fashion and even less in travel, preferring to stay in Maine rather than visit the world's resorts.
Not that she was above the occasional indulgence. When she found that the steep driveway to her house became dangerously slick with wintertime ice, she built a more accessible winter home a thousand feet away.
Her only real material weakness stemmed from her love of the water, but it was a tribute to her reputation for innovative "catalytic philanthropy," that when she indulged her passion by commissioning a multimillion-dollar 60-foot yacht a few years ago, the acquisition was not viewed in Maine as an example of conspicuous consumption. Instead the purchase was trumpeted in the Maine press as a rescue of Maine's boat-building industry.
In recent months Mrs. Noyce had apparently developed renewed concern about the state's beleaguered boat builders. She had commissioned a 90-foot yacht.
Mrs. Noyce is survived by a son, William, of Hollis, N.H.; three daughters, Pendred of Weston, Mass.; Priscilla, of Kenya and Margaret, of Montana; two brothers, Frank Bottomley of Ohio and Bruce, of New Hampshire; a sister, Frances Broomhead of Rhode Island, and 13 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Simpson-Case Fatigue Mixes With Obsession

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19

 BODY:
As jury selection began this week in the civil-suit sequel to the murder trial of the decade, the prospect of another national spell of obsession with O. J. Simpson was bringing a sigh from many a resistant viewer, reader and coffee-shop debater across the nation: "Not again."
"It should have been over the first time," said Richard Hahn, who owns the Animal Kingdom pet shop just around the corner from the Santa Monica courthouse where the trial of wrongful-death lawsuits against Mr. Simpson is expected to last at least four months. 
 Penny Jeffries, a retail clerk in Nashville, protested: "We are O.J.'d out."
Even Mary Stanley of the Los Angeles-area town of Downey, a supporter of Mr. Simpson who attended his criminal trial regularly, said that as she got up to catch the 5 A.M. bus to Santa Monica on Tuesday, she found herself muttering: "Oh, God, here it is again. I went through this for over a year. Can I do this again?"
Still, like reluctant soap-opera addicts, people in interviews around the nation said by and large that they would follow the case, particularly the testimony of Mr. Simpson himself, who never took the witness stand at the criminal trial. That trial ended last October in his acquittal of the murders of his former wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald L. Goldman, both of whose families have brought the civil suits.
"I'm interested in the trial, because what wasn't said in the criminal hearing may be said this time when O. J. takes the stand," said Ronald Fisher, a 33-year-old resident of the Bronx. "I'm a black American, but I think he was guilty. I think his money acquitted him."
Outside the Santa Monica courthouse, the great white mushrooms of television-truck satellite dishes have sprouted, and the reporters conduct their lawn interviews. But a been-here, done-this kind of of enervating deja vu seems to have taken hold, the enthusiasm among the news-media representatives not nearly what it was the first time around. (Jamie DeMatoff, a T-shirt entrepreneur, said sales to the press of his "Camp O. J. II -- The Sequel" edition were not going well at all.)
To a large extent, of course, it was live television coverage that drove public interest in the first trial. That is absent this time, cameras barred from the courtroom by the judge in the civil case, Hiroshi Fujisaki. And Jerianne Hayslett, the spokeswoman for the Los Angeles County Superior Court, confirmed that media interest this time was not "as rabid" as it was during the criminal trial and certainly nothing like the peak of last Oct. 3, when some 2,000 members of news organizations were on hand at the courthouse in downtown Los Angeles for the verdicts.
For all of that, the American news media, like Americans as a whole, have hardly abandoned the O. J. case.
Ms. Hayslett, for instance, said news organizations' interest in the civil trial was certainly far higher than run of the mill, with 72 of them having applied for seats in the courtroom.
And those networks that went all out in their coverage of the criminal trial, like CNN and Court TV, are ready to respond this time as well to a public fascination that just will not die. Both those networks will provide frequent updates throughout the day, and Court TV will feature a daily half-hour report called "Families v. Simpson."
Steven Brill, the founder and chief executive of Court TV, compared interest in the Simpson case to rubbernecking at a car accident. "You watch it," he said, "but you don't feel great about yourself about watching it."
Americans tend to be in denial about their interest in the case, said Jeffrey Toobin, the author of the latest Simpson-trial book, "The Run of His Life," which, in the week after its release on Sept. 9 by Random House, climbed immediately to No. 2 on the New York Times best-seller list. As he travels the country on his book tour, Mr. Toobin said, he has found that "the passions have only grown more intense."
"What people would always say to me -- and still do, to a certain extent -- is, 'Oh, I don't follow it anymore,' " he said. "And then they'd cite an extremely recent fact that shows they've been following it very closely. It just combines everything that obsesses the American people: sex, race, violence, celebrity, sports."
Those elements have inspired an assortment of professional and amateur authors to create more than 50 books and audiotapes about the murders. Still more are expected, with the planned publication of books by some of the principals in the criminal trial, including the chief defense lawyer, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., and the lead prosecutor, Marcia Clark, who has been attacked by many authors, Mr. Toobin among them, for poor prosecutorial judgment but who obtained the highest advance, more than $4 million.
Mr. Simpson would seem to be the most likely author to cash in on the cottage industry. And indeed his "I Want to Tell You" (Little, Brown), written while he was jailed during the criminal trial, earned him hundreds of thousands of dollars.
But his efforts to win a contract for a follow-up book failed to attract a publisher, partly because his popularity was so low, partly because his asking price was more than $2 million. "That was a very strong investment for something that people felt was of very dubious commercial value," said one publishing executive, who insisted on anonymity.
There was little news emerging from the courthouse in the last two days, as the first group of potential jurors were questioned as to whether serving on the case would pose a special hardship.
But in some last pretrial rulings, Judge Fujisaki ordered a special hearing on whether evidence of blood on Mr. Simpson's shower and air-conditioner could be admitted. The judge also decreed that grisly autopsy photographs of the murder victims would remain sealed but that other photographs, of the crime scene itself, could be introduced.
Jury selection is expected to take several days. Mr. Simpson wanted to be present for it but will now apparently be preoccupied at a courthouse in nearby Orange County, where he is battling with the parents of his late wife for custody of their two children.
Around the nation, people who watched the criminal trial and said they would be following the civil proceedings closely also said they were hoping it would yield new clues that would answer questions left unresolved.
Jerry Flores, a parking valet in downtown Los Angeles, said he was waiting to find out "why did O. J. run during the car chase."
"If he is not guilty," Mr. Flores said, "why didn't he stay?"
John L. Adams, a motor-pool manager who works nearby, said he wanted to know how Mr. Simpson cut his finger, and what was in the bag that he carried to the airport on his way to Chicago the night of the murders.
In many cases, however, it is anger, not curiosity, that seems to be driving interest.
As she sat on a bench on Broadway in New York City, Elsa Acosta, 23 and unemployed, said she would read all about the civil trial for just one reason: "I want to see him made guilty, because I think he did it. He's aggressive, and he took it out on his wife. He has to face it."
Equally vehement were those who believe Mr. Simpson innocent: "They just need to leave him alone," said Gregory Davis, 19, a student at Tennessee State University in Nashville. "He's already been tried."
Even people who said they would not follow the proceedings expressed strongly held opinions about the case. Kent Wood, a securities analyst in Wichita, Kan., who said he was far more interested in the Presidential campaign than in Mr. Simpson's travails, could not resist adding: "O. J. Simpson should be in jail. Period."

On Wednesday morning, prospective jurors stood in line outside the court building. The trial is expected to last at least four months. (Associated Press)

Sumitomo Estimate of Loss Grows in Copper Scandal
Sumitomo said the losses incurred by Yasuo Hamanaka, its former chief copper trader, had increased to $2.6 billion, $800 million higher than earlier, and that it would request that criminal charges be filed against him.
Much uncertainty remained, but Sumitomo seemed to be trying to put the scandal behind it, giving few details of how the trader could have hidden such losses or whether others might have cooperated with him. [Page D3.]
 
Showdown Over Wireless Taps
The wireless communications industry voted to reject Government-backed technology that would make it possible for law enforcement agencies to keep closer tabs on cellular telephone users. [A1.]
 
Fraud Charges Against Merrill Seen
Merrill Lynch has been told by regulators that they intend to charge it with disclosure fraud in connection with the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., lawyers said. [D2.]

A Big Gain In Construction
Builders broke ground on new homes and apartments at the fastest rate in nearly two and a half years during August. Housing starts, which were predicted to decline modestly, instead increased 4.5 percent. [D2.]
 
After the housing report, bond yields rose because of fears of rising inflation and an increase in interest rates by the Fed. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was 7.04 percent, up from 7.01 percent on Wednesday. [D13.]

2 Big Ad-Agency Companies to Join
The stampede of acquisitions involving advertising-agency companies continued, but with a twist: the buyer is smaller than the seller. BDDP in Paris, the 15th-largest agency company in the world, agreed to be acquired by GGT in London, the 22d largest. [D5.]
 
Settlement in Comparator Case
The S.E.C. settled cases against Comparator Systems, a company that had no successful products but that somehow became valued at a billion dollars, and two officials who had been accused of issuing financial reports that overstated the company's assets.
Floyd Norris: Market Place.[D6.]

Group to Buy Ryder Rental Unit
Questor Partners Fund and a group of other investors plan to buy Ryder System's rental truck division for about $575 million. [D16.]
 
Olivetti's New Chief
Carlo de Benedetti may no longer be the chairman of Olivetti, the computer maker, but he remains a powerful shareholder. With this leverage, his representatives on the board ousted the company's chief executive and installed Roberto Colaninno, above, who headed an auto parts company controlled by Mr. de Benedetti. [D3.]
 
Insurance Accord In Congress
House and Senate leaders agreed on two major health insurance proposals, directing insurance companies to offer comparable coverage for mental and physical illnesses and to guarantee mothers coverage for at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth. [A20.]
 
I.B.M. said it would provide benefits to the partners of lesbian and gay employees. It is the largest employer yet to extend health care coverage to couples of the same sex. [A18.]
 
Barneys Parent Seeks to End Deal
The parent company of Barneys New York, which filed for bankruptcy protection last January, said it was seeking to end a licensing agreement with its partner, Isetan. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Clinton Errs in Designating Utah Monument

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Clinton's unilateral action to designate 1.8 million acres in Utah as a new national monument can only be viewed as election-year politics (editorial, Sept. 18, and news article, Sept. 19). In creating the Canyons of the Escalante National Monument, he ignored the professional input of the Bureau of Land Management, which is charged with evaluating wilderness suitability, and he has withdrawn a significant domestic reserve of high-quality coal.
The Kaiparowits Plateau, part of the land included in the President's designation, is among the nation's richest coal fields, with an estimated 65 billion tons of high-quality coal. Currently, two-thirds of the nation's 640 million acres of public lands are off-limits to mining. This means that the mineral potential of this land will never be realized. 
 President Clinton is adding to this unrealized mineral potential, apparently without concern for the economic health of the local, state and Federal governments that would benefit from the development of the plateau.
His action comes as renewed tension in the Middle East highlights the importance of scarce and dependable American energy supplies. From the oil embargo of the early 1970's through the Persian Gulf war, Americans have learned what happens when our nation becomes dependent upon a foreign source of energy. We should not permit politics to create future gulf wars for the young men and women of our armed forces.
 
RICHARD L. LAWSON
Washington, Sept. 19, 1996
 
President and Chief Executive
National Mining Association

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RUNNING MATE;
Kemp Accuses the President of Lacking Strategy to Deal With Inner City

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Trying to undercut one of the Democrats' political pillars, Jack Kemp today attacked President Clinton's urban policies.
At the same time Mr. Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, released a confidential Clinton Administration memorandum in which the Housing Secretary pleaded with the White House for action on inner-city problems and warned of potentially dire political consequences if they were not addressed. 
 "Everywhere I go, I hear the same thing: Bill Clinton has abandoned the inner cities," Mr. Kemp told a sparsely attended rally at a public housing complex near downtown Memphis. "He has no urban strategy."
Memphis was the first stop on Mr. Kemp's two-day swing through Tennessee, one of the make-or-break Southern states for the Republican Presidential ticket and the home of Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Kemp appeared to have both factors on his mind in his appearance here.
"Bill Clinton's plan for the urban poor is to continue to promote dependence on a failed welfare system," Mr. Kemp said. "He does not have faith in their potential to do better than welfare; therefore, he has not worked to provide opportunities for the poor to rise from poverty. The Republican Party forced him to sign a welfare bill he did not believe in, and he has already pledged to dismantle the reforms if he is re-elected."
After Mr. Kemp spoke, his aides gave reporters copies of a year-old confidential Administration memorandum from Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
In the memorandum to Mr. Clinton, dated Aug. 9, 1995, Mr. Cisneros asked the President to develop immediately a cohesive "Presidential strategy" to deal with urban problems.
"The cities are hurting badly," Mr. Cisneros wrote, "and as a nation we'll pay the consequences for many years; we are running out of time; there is always room in the budget for Presidential priorities of reasonable size, and we do not have enough to stand on in the cities."
In his direst advice, the Secretary wrote, "We can be caught flat-footed by the violent outbreaks which will stem from the anger in the cities."
Mr. Cisneros noted that in the summer of 1995 there had already been "contained outbreaks of civil unrest" in Indianapolis, in the Coconut Grove area of Miami and in Los Angeles.
Mr. Cisneros recommended a number of strategies, including public and private investment in cities, community development banks and a network of "empowerment" schools.
In a telephone conference call with reporters, Mr. Cisneros dismissed Mr. Kemp's release of the memo as politically motivated. But more to the point, he added, virtually all of the ideas he proposed to the President have since been pursued by the Administration, from Mr. Clinton's proposal for new tax credits for employers who hire former welfare recipients, to a cleanup of polluted sites in urban areas to the expansion of community development banks.
"Most of the pieces have been addressed in one form or another," Mr. Cisneros said. "His implication is that we've not done enough. The story of the last several years has been our effort to address problems in communities across America."
Mr. Kemp's campaign aides would not say how they obtained the memorandum, only that they had had it for "some time" and had waited for an opportune moment to use it.
They saw that chance today as Mr. Kemp visited the public housing development. Not many development residents attended the rally, but the site served the Republican campaign's purpose of throwing down a new challenge to the Democrats on their own turf.
"The timing was to come to Al Gore's home state and talk about the status quo two days after he did," said Wayne Berman, the political director for Mr. Kemp.
In his speech, Mr. Kemp pledged that Bob Dole as President would drop all capital gains taxes on investments in inner cities and promote private ownership of public housing units.
"We need a radical, audacious, positive, constructive, bleeding-heart war against poverty and unemployment," Mr. Kemp said.
He did not mention the 15 percent across-the-board tax cut that is at the center of the Republican ticket's economic program, nor did he dwell long on crime and drugs, the issue the ticket began emphasizing this week.
Mr. Cisneros accused Mr. Kemp of "running from his own record and the Bush Administration's record in the four years that they had a chance to do these jobs," and failed to deliver on Mr. Kemp's ideas for creating so-called "enterprise zones" in which Federal tax incentives would be used to spur urban investment. He noted that it was left for Mr. Clinton to successfully press in 1993 for passage of a program to create "empowerment zones" along the same lines in cities and rural areas, and the President has now proposed expanding that program.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, talked yesterday to residents of the Hurt Village housing project in Memphis. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Little Changed Ahead of Fed Policy Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly higher yesterday as dealers and traders squared positions ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting next week to consider interest rates.
The 30-year bond rose 1/32 , to a price of 9613/32 to yield 7.04 percent, unchanged from Thursday. In the bond futures market the limited activity yesterday was mostly driven by the expiration of the October options contracts. 
 The credit market remained focused on next week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making panel. Since the market is deeply divided on what the policy decision will be, prices of government securities stayed in a narrow trading range for most of the day and are expected to do so until the panel meets on Tuesday.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, said the market was definitely waiting on the Fed. "While I think it will be a close call," he said, "we expect they will hold monetary policy steady. With inflation very low and economic signals showing the economy is moderating, the Fed can afford to wait to see if their expectations of slower growth materialize."
Mr. Palash said market prices improved in the afternoon, after the expiration of options.
In when-issued trading for notes to be auctioned next week, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.25 percent and the five-year note at 6.61 percent.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said that after reviewing most of the August economic data, he was trimming his estimate of third-quarter growth in gross domestic product to 2.3 percent from 3 percent.
"These slow-growth forecasts," he said, "follow the rapid 4.8 percent real growth in the second quarter and are critical to our thinking that the Federal Reserve System should not be raising short-term interest rates at any of the F.O.M.C. meetings this year."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Seemly Vs. Sexy On Screen

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"Sex and the Silver Screen" is a six-hour account of the decades-long battle between permissiveness and censuriousness, or between prurience and primness, or between the artist and the bluestocking, or between the exploiter and the upholder of standards. However described, it is generous with flesh-and-frolic scenes from movies that were greeted with finger-shaking by some and lip-licking by others.
The hourlong segments are presented backward in time, permitting the producers to lead off with the most explicit excerpts and the most recognizable stars. Since the doings on screen are connected to changes in society at large, going in reverse seems perverse, which is not altogether inappropriate. 
 Anyhow, the somewhat simplistic theme is the conflict between movie makers intent on opening things up and censors determined to shut them down. From the beginning, of course, Hollywood has been driven less by such edifying concepts as free speech or art than by good old box-office considerations. As in some of the movies on show, the focus has always been on the bottom line.
In Sunday's two-hour opener, you can see excerpts from such works as "Last Tango in Paris," "Deep Throat," "Basic Instinct," "Blow Up," "Lolita" and "Beyond the Valley of the Dolls," which was directed by Russ Meyer, that pioneer of the flesh flick who declared, "I deal in big bosoms and square jaws." The series continues its backward journey weekly on Fridays until it reaches pre-talkie times.
The courts, as noted here, have upheld the cause of screen sex despite pressures to suppress, and Frank Martin, the series writer and director, is on the side of the First Amendment. Raquel Welch, our host, may be forgiven for her stiff delivery of such vapidities as, "The most satisfying form of creative stimulation begins first in the heart and finds its way from there." But she looks good enough to stimulate at least half the audience, which is what "Sex and the Silver Screen" is mainly about.
 
'Democracy in America '96'
'Downsizing the Dream?'
CNN, Sunday night at 9
This well-reported look at the nation's economic condition contrasts cutbacks by A.T. & T. and the hard times of union workers locked out of a trailer factory in Charleston, Ill., with the high times of the growing information industry in lower Manhattan and the resurgence of Pittsburgh from rust-belt blues to high-tech hopefulness.
 
'Jobs'
'The Class of 2000'
PBS, Sunday night at 7
(Channel 13 in New York)
And speaking of the up side of downsizing, this documentary, which is as boring as it is worthy, tells of community programs that are readying young men and women for solid jobs. A 20-year-old man in Tulsa, Okla., is on his way to becoming a machinist; a single mother in Boston will soon be a radiation therapist, and an apprentice journalist in Pittsburgh just got her first byline. We know what that feels like, Joanna.

Showtime, Sunday night at 8
 
First of a six-part series, created, written and directed by Frank Martin. Produced by Martin and Rudy Poe. With Raquel Welch, host. An Eleventh Day Entertainment Production, in association with ZM Productions.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Modestly in Advance Of European and Fed Meetings

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was moderately higher against major currencies yesterday as traders squared their books before the European finance ministers meeting this weekend in Dublin and the Federal Reserve's session on Tuesday.
The talks at Dublin Castle, which start in earnest today, were seen as essential for keeping considerable political momentum behind starting a single European currency in January 1999. 
 The meeting comes amid an intense scramble by European Union Governments led by Germany and France to bring their 1997 budget deficits in line with the Maastricht Treaty criteria for economic and monetary union.
Some currency traders were optimistic that the talks would yield progress. As a result, the German mark weakened against the dollar and other European currencies because the mark would become less important as a safe-haven currency if monetary union came into being.
"As time goes on, it seems like the countries seem to be determined to try and get their budgetary matters in accord with Maastricht targets," Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange at Bank of Montreal, said.
"So people feel the convergence is going to happen eventually. So that's why the mark was sold off in overnight trading." The French franc had soared to a two-month high against the mark yesterday, but the German currency cut its losses against the franc and other currencies in New York.
In late New York trading, the dollar stood at 1.5155 marks, up from 1.5132 late on Thursday. The dollar traded at 109.80 Japanese yen, up from 109.40.
Speculation about whether the Fed would raise interest rates Tuesday to head off any inflationary pressures has also preoccupied the foreign exchange market. Higher rates tend to help the dollar by making dollar-denominated assets more attractive to foreign investors.
By yesterday, currency traders had largely priced into dollar exchange rates the possibility that the Fed may increase rates by one-quarter percentage point, traders said.
In other trading, the British pound rose moderately to $1.5550 yesterday from $1.5520 on Thursday. The dollar fell to $1.3668 (Canadian) from $1.3704.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Deal on Mental Health May Affect Employers
Experts on employee benefits said Congress's decision to expand health insurance coverage for the mentally ill would prompt tens of thousands of businesses to redesign their employee health benefits in ways that go far beyond what is required by Congress. Employers, even big companies like Xerox and Hewlett-Packard, said they feared that the new requirements would substantially increase their costs. [Page 1.]
 
Stocks Rise But Dow Misses Record
Stocks were mostly higher, lifting some measures to record highs, but the buying was restrained with many investors awaiting next week's Federal Reserve policy meeting on interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.72 points, to 5,888.46, closing less than a point from Monday's record close of 5,889.20. The Nasdaq composite index rose for the 11th consecutive session, led again by technology issues. [34.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose as dealers and traders squared positions ahead of the Fed's meeting. The yield on the 30-year bond was unchanged at 7.04 percent. [34.]
 
Archer Daniels Sues Executive Archer Daniels Midland has sued Mark E. Whitacre, the former company executive who served as an informant for the Government, accusing him of embezzling millions of dollars from the company over several years. Mr. Whitacre, who secretly tape-recorded meetings as part of a price-fixing investigation of Archer Daniels, was dismissed from the company last year amid allegations of embezzlement. He has acknowledged obtaining the money in overseas bank accounts. But he has said that he obtained it as part of a secret plan intended to allow executives to avoid taxes; Archer Daniels denies that allegation. [43.]
 
Blue Cross Questions Deal
The national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association suggested that Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield was not getting full value for the main business lines that it has agreed to sell to the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation for $299.5 million. [43.]
 
Time Warner in Feud With Fox
Time Warner's cable television company has decided to offer NBC's new news channel and not one being started by Rupert Murdoch's Fox Inc., enraging Fox executives, who accused the Time Warner chairman, Gerald Levin, of breaking a fully negotiated agreement. One Fox executive said that Mr. Murdoch was so angry over the decision that Fox may retaliate. [21.]
 
F.T.C. Drops Publishing Case
Seventeen years after starting an antitrust investigation, the Federal Trade Commission quietly closed a case involving six of the largest book publishers without deciding if they ever discriminated against independent bookstores by selling discounted books to major chains. Voting 3 to 1 to end the antitrust review, the commission released a statement explaining that it was better to terminate the case because it did not appear to be a "prudent use of scarce public resources." [32.]
 
Funeral Home Rivals Fight
The shooting began between the two largest funeral home chains in the country after the Service Corporation, which is seeking to buy the Loewen Group, said its rival had overpaid when it spent $240 million to buy the nation's largest cemetery and funeral home. [32.]
 
Dollar Rises Slightly
The dollar was moderately higher against major currencies as traders squared their books before the European finance ministers' meeting this weekend in Dublin and the Fed's session on Tuesday. In late New York trading, the dollar stood at 1.5155 marks, up from 1.5132 on Thursday. The dollar traded at 109.80 Japanese yen, up from 109.40. [33.]

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Off on Possible I.M.F. Sale Of Supply to Aid Poor Countries

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gold prices fell yesterday on the Comex Division of the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concern that the International Monetary Fund would officially announce a plan to sell five million ounces of gold to help pay debts of the world's poorest countries.
On other markets, copper fell while soybeans rose. 
 "There is some concern over a possible announcement from the I.M.F. on their proposed sale," said Don Tierney, analyst with Pell Brothers Trading. "They're meeting today and again tomorrow."
Gold for December delivery fell $1.70, to $383.90 an ounce. December silver plunged 7.7 cents, to $4.863 an ounce, dropping 4.6 percent in two days.
Gold's failure to respond to the conflict in Iraq and the surge in oil prices past $25 a barrel to a five-month high is reducing demand from investors.
"It doesn't look good," said Jeff Singer, gold trader with Imperial Bank in Los Angeles. "We've just been through a mini oil crisis. If gold can't respond to that, what is it going to take?"
Copper fell 2.6 percent after stockpiles did not fall enough to offset concern over rising mine output.
While the London Metal Exchange said its copper inventories fell by 2,900 tons since Tuesday to 265,450 tons, dropping 3.5 percent so far this month, traders were focusing on increased supply next year from new mines in Chile. December copper fell 2.4 cents, to 87.80 cents a pound, on the Comex.
Soybeans rose for the first time in three days amid forecasts that cold temperatures could damage crops. The Weather Services Corporation said temperatures were likely to drop as low as 30 degrees Fahrenheit early next week in Minnesota and northern Iowa.
The crop, which was delayed in planting this year by heavy rains, is about two weeks behind development, with most areas harvested during October. A freeze now would be just 10 days ahead of normal.
"The ongoing fear of frost is going to be supportive for prices whether it materializes or not," said Dale Durchholz, analyst at Agrivisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill.
November soybeans rose 6 cents, to $7.9525 a bushel, at the Chicago Board of Trade.

HEADLINE: Lewis Replaces Primis as President of Times Co.

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company announced yesterday that its 50-year-old president and chief operating officer, Lance R. Primis, had resigned. He will be replaced by Russell T. Lewis, the president and general manager of The New York Times newspaper.
Industry analysts and one executive of the Times Company said that Mr. Primis's unexpected resignation was prompted by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman and chief executive of the company. The chairman, they say, was apparently unwilling to offer Mr. Primis any assurances that he might one day succeed Mr. Sulzberger as chief executive. 
 Clearly, they added, the relationship between the two men was not working as smoothly as Mr. Sulzberger had hoped when Mr. Primis became president four years ago.
"Punch Sulzberger is chairman of this company, and he is going to be for some time -- and it's years, though I don't know if it's 2, 5 or 10" years, said Diane Baker, the company's chief financial officer. "Lance did a terrific job. But the partnership between them did not jell in a way that Punch felt was going to work in the long term."
Ms. Baker insisted that the departure of Mr. Primis would not alter the business strategy of the company.
In a statement, Mr. Sulzberger said, "The addition of Russ Lewis to the corporate team will assist the company in achieving its current strategy, which is to invest in its core businesses, increase holdings in traditional and new media and focus on both re-engineering and revenue building."
Most Wall Street analysts said they expected the company's strategy to remain intact. Douglas Arthur of Morgan Stanley & Company said that he expected the company's share price to drop somewhat because of the surprise resignation.
But Mr. Arthur said he was continuing to recommend the company's stock because of signs that the New York City economy was coming out of a seven-year slump and because the Times management had done a good job in controlling costs, which should allow profits to rise as advertising picks up. Mr. Primis's departure, he said, "doesn't change the story."
Class A shares of the Times Company fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $32.
Like other analysts, John Reidy of Smith Barney Inc. noted that control of the company had rested with the Sulzberger and Ochs families for a century. "This is a 100-year-old, family-run franchise, and it just isn't going to revolve around one person, especially someone from outside the family," Mr. Reidy said.
In his statement, Mr. Sulzberger said, "Lance wanted to be free to seek a more certain opportunity to run an enterprise and thought it would be appropriate to relinquish his responsibilities."
Mr. Primis, who started at the company in 1969 answering telephones in the paper's classified advertising department and rose through the ranks, will remain as a consultant until the end of the year.
Mr. Primis did not answer telephone calls and electronic mail messages seeking comment yesterday.
Analysts said the resignation appeared to increase the likelihood that Mr. Sulzberger would someday be succeeded by his son, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the 44-year-old publisher of The New York Times.
"Arthur Jr. is now more clearly the heir apparent to be the chairman of the company as a whole," said John Morton, an analyst with Lynch Jones & Ryan Inc. in Washington.
But there is no timetable for any succession. Mr. Sulzberger, the 70-year-old chairman, has "no plans to retire," said Nancy Nielsen, a company spokeswoman.
As the new president of the company, Mr. Lewis, 49, will oversee the operations of not only its flagship newspaper, but also The Boston Globe, 21 smaller newspapers, 9 magazines including Golf Digest and Tennis, 8 television stations and 2 radio stations.
Mr. Lewis joined The Times as a copy boy in 1966 while attending the State University of New York at Stony Brook. He became a news clerk and then a news assistant, a role that included handling local reporting assignments. After earning a law degree, he became a lawyer for Cahill, Gordon & Reindel, before rejoining The Times as a staff lawyer in 1977. During his years as the head of production, from 1988 to 1992, he streamlined the operations to curb labor costs significantly, analysts said.
Since 1993, Mr. Lewis has been president and general manager of The Times newspaper. Analysts say he has helped lead the effort to raise advertising and circulation revenues with aggressive pricing, while curbing costs. In the first six months of 1996, they note, advertising revenue increased 8 percent and circulation revenues rose nearly 15 percent.
"They are getting decent numbers despite a sluggish advertising environment in New York City and the Northeast in general," Mr. Reidy of Smith Barney said.
Mr. Lewis helped plan and manage the construction of a new color printing plant in College Point, Queens, which is expected to open in mid-1997. Once the plant is in operation, The Times will be able to print in color and place advertising inserts in its daily editions, which should increase advertising revenue.
In his statement, Mr. Sulzberger praised the performance of the newspaper's management team, his son and Mr. Lewis. "Under Arthur's and Russ's leadership," Mr. Sulzberger said, "The Times has significantly increased its operating revenues, national circulation and profitability while the paper has continued to maintain the highest journalistic standards."
At the newspaper, Mr. Lewis will be replaced as president by Janet L. Robinson, who has been senior vice president for advertising. Ms. Robinson, 46, had previously been senior vice president for sales and marketing of the company's women's magazine group, which was sold in 1994. Before joining the company, Ms. Robinson was a public school teacher and reading specialist for 11 years.
She will be succeeded as senior vice president for advertising by Daniel H. Cohen, who had been vice president for advertising. Mr. Cohen, who is 44, had previously held a variety of positions in corporate planning, circulation and advertising. Before joining The Times, he was a program director for Warner Amex Cable in Dallas and had worked as a television cameraman in Orlando, Fla. He is the son of the company chairman's sister, Judith P. Sulzberger, a director of the company.
Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said of Ms. Robinson: "Under her skillful leadership, advertising revenues have increased significantly in a challenging market. Since joining the company, she has demonstrated a strong commitment to our financial success, and I know she will bring that same energy and drive to her new position."

HEADLINE: EXPERTS FORESEE HEALTH PLAN SHIFT FOR MENTAL CARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Experts on employee benefits said today that Congress's decision to expand health insurance coverage for the mentally ill would prompt tens of thousands of businesses to revise their health plans in ways that go far beyond what is required by Congress.
Employers, including big companies like Xerox and Hewlett-Packard, said they feared that the new requirements would substantially increase their costs. But others said the costs would be manageable. 
 James A. Klein, the executive director of the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, a trade group of mostly Fortune 500 companies, said: "Employers are likely to reduce other valuable benefits in order to accommodate the cost of the new mandates. If some specific benefits are required, different benefits valued by other workers will be sacrificed to pay for them."
Martha Priddy Patterson, the director of employee-benefits policy at KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm, said, "Some employers will look at these requirements and decide that it's too expensive for them to begin or continue providing health benefits."
Congressional leaders announced on Thursday that they had agreed on legislation to curb disparities in insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses. Under the proposal, if a group health plan offers any mental health benefits, it may not impose more restrictive annual or lifetime limits on spending for mental illness than on coverage of physical ailments.
All group health plans offering mental health benefits and serving more than 50 employees would be subject to these requirements in January 1998. In later years, a health plan may obtain an exemption if it can prove that its premiums increased by 1 percent or more as a result of the mandate.
Employee-benefits experts said many companies would re-evaluate their benefit programs in the light of the legislation. Employers could drop mental health coverage altogether, set higher co-payments or deductibles or make other changes to control or offset the new costs.
"Employers will take a new and fresh look at mental health benefits," said Ronald E. Bachman of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm. "They won't just say, 'Let me tinker with my benefits to be sure I'm in compliance with the new law.' "
The new costs, Mr. Bachman said, "will be insignificant," well under 1 percent of premiums.
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that premiums in a typical fee-for-service plan would rise four-tenths of 1 percent. But the agency said employers, over all, would offset more than half of this cost by dropping health insurance coverage altogether, by dropping or reducing coverage for mental health services or by dropping other benefits.
Advocates for the mentally ill said few companies would experience an increase in costs of more than 1 percent. But Susan D. Moriconi, health benefits manager for Hewlett-Packard, said: "They're absolutely, positively wrong on that. A large number of employers and plans will have an increase of more than 1 percent."
Mr. Klein, of the pension trade group, predicted that some employers would increase co-payments and deductibles, for all services or just for mental health services, to offset the new costs.
"The vast majority of employees who have mental health services," he said, "will pay more to help the very few who would otherwise hit the annual limit."
The requirements for mental health coverage were added to an appropriations bill that will probably be approved by Congress next week. President Clinton strongly supports the requirements, so they are expected to become law.
The requirements will probably increase the demand for health maintenance organizations and other health plans that control costs by managing care, especially mental health care. In the last few years, an industry has sprung up to provide mental health services at predictable costs, by monitoring the work of psychiatrists and psychologists and other mental health professionals.
James E. Buckley, senior partner in charge of health care consulting at KPMG Peat Marwick, said: "The impact of this legislation will be to encourage employers to make greater use of managed care. It becomes more of an economic necessity. Otherwise, it's difficult to control inpatient mental health expenditures."
Mr. Bachman, an actuary at Coopers & Lybrand, said, "The market will respond in new and creative ways to provide flexibility in plan design and to meet employees' needs while making sure that mental health costs don't get out of hand."
Employers will still be allowed to set limits on the number of outpatient visits or hospital days for which they will pay. Mr. Bachman said employers might revise mental health benefits to create options for employees, giving them more visits with psychotherapists if they accepted fewer days of hospital care.
Hewlett-Packard now has a lifetime limit of $1 million on health benefits for any employee or dependent, with a separate limit of $300,000 on mental health care.
Ms. Moriconi said she did not know how the company would revise its plan to comply with the Federal requirements. But she said: "I can't imagine proposing any reduction in the $1 million lifetime limit. That would send a very negative message to employees." At the same time, she said, it will be difficult to increase monthly premiums or co-payments because employees are "very sensitive" to such costs.
Many companies have a lifetime limit of $50,000 on mental health coverage, with a much higher limit of $750,000 to $1 million on coverage of physical ailments. Mr. Bachman said these companies could comply with the new requirements by setting a single lifetime limit of $1 million for medical, surgical and mental health benefits combined.
E. Clarke Ross, the executive director of the American Managed Behavioral Healthcare Association, a trade group, said few people used more than $50,000 of mental health benefits in a lifetime. Thus, Mr. Ross said, the precedent of the new legislation will be more important than its direct, immediate effects.
"A precedent has been established that you cannot discriminate on the basis of mental illness," he said, and that precedent can be used to eliminate other disparities in the coverage of mental and physical illness.
Helen Darling, manager of health programs at Xerox, said: "Xerox and the business community have strongly resisted mandated benefits of this type. Congress, as usual, is heavily regulating the good guys, the people who voluntarily provide benefits, even as millions of Americans still get no health benefits from their employers."
Ms. Darling said she feared that the new requirements would lead to "an explosion of costs" like the one Xerox experienced several years ago when it increased coverage of outpatient mental health care.
Xerox later imposed limits on mental health benefits to control such costs, Ms. Darling said.

HEADLINE: Honesty in Banking

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators will decide soon whether to gut an important protection for bank customers. The 1991 Truth in Savings Act requires banks to advertise yields on deposit accounts in identical fashion so that customers can instantly compare one bank's offering with another. The provision forces banks to compete honestly for customers by offering attractive interest rates. Consumers Union estimates that the law will be worth $300 million this year to depositors.
The proposed rollback is part of a larger bank bill designed to shore up the fund that insures deposits at savings and loan institutions. The fund is in trouble because it began charging savings institutions very high premiums after the huge bankruptcies of the 1980's. The high premiums, in turn, are driving many savings institutions to turn themselves into commercial banks, sapping the fund of cash. The bill would call on banks to help stabilize the fund -- a sensible first step in bringing savings institutions and banks, which are economically indistinguishable, under the same regulations. 
 To get banks to go along, however, politicians had to offer the sweetener of eliminating some regulations. Some rules are needlessly costly and deserve to be discarded. Truth in Savings is not one of them. Banks offer customers a bewildering variety of deposits. Few customers can easily calculate whether they would be better off with an account that pays 5 percent compounded each day or one that pays 5.4 percent compounded each month. The law requires banks to provide consumers with a simple yardstick called the "annual percentage yield," which takes account of both the interest rate and the formula the bank uses to compute interest payments.
Alfonse D'Amato, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and his Republican colleagues are debating whether to include the Truth in Savings rollback in the omnibus budget bill. Before they make that mistake, the White House should make clear that President Clinton will sign no spending bill that strips consumers of well-designed protections that keep banks honest.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Turks, Opposing U.S., Urge Iraq To Take Control of Kurdish Area

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Determined to crack down on Turkish Kurds who are waging a guerrilla war from camps in northern Iraq, Turkey is urging President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to impose his authority there.
This Turkish policy, which Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller described in an interview here today, marks a departure from the policy of the United States, which seeks to limit Mr. Hussein's power. 
 Mrs. Ciller insisted that Turkey, a NATO ally, would continue allowing American planes enforcing the "no flight" zone in northern Iraq to operate from a base in Turkey. But the emerging policy differences suggest that relations between the two nations may be entering a new and possibly difficult phase in the wake of the power shifts in northern Iraq.
Mrs. Ciller's remarks were greeted with dismay by senior Administration officials, who said they did not reflect what Turkey has told the United States in recent meetings.
Mr. Hussein's last attempt to assert authority in northern Iraq, which came three weeks ago when he sent troops there to support a local Kurdish faction's takeover of the region, led the United States to stage cruise missile attacks on military installations in southern Iraq.
Mrs. Ciller did not say whether Turkey wants Mr. Hussein to send his own troops into northern Iraq to crush Turkish Kurds who are fighting a separatist war from bases there. No other force in Iraq, however, including Mr. Hussein's new Kurdish allies, appears to have the military power to conduct such an operation.
If Mr. Hussein's army or another powerful military force were to conduct a major strike against Turkish separatist guerrillas in Iraq, the guerrillas would probably be forced to flee either into Turkey, where they would have to face the Turkish Army, or into neighboring Syria, where their leaders are based.
Mrs. Ciller said that if Mr. Hussein's army or some other force could chase the separatist guerrillas out of northern Iraq, Turkey would drop its plan to create a "security zone" inside Iraq.
"We have the problem that a terrorist group, the P.K.K., is operating from camps in northern Iraq," she said, referring to the separatist Kurdistan Workers Party. "An average of three Turkish soldiers are being killed every day by these terrorists. That is something we cannot tolerate, and to stop this infiltration, we proposed establishing a security zone in the border area."
"We have sent a delegation to Saddam to tell him that if he can impose central authority there, O.K.," she said in the interview, speaking in English.
"We are still talking to him, and we are interested to see what he can do or is prepared to do," she continued. "If he can establish a degree of rule there that puts an end to terrorist infiltration, that would be fine with us. If not, we will take measures to see that terrorists do not continue to operate on our borders. We defend the territorial integrity of Iraq, but the lack of authority there has been tragic for us."
Washington was clearly unhappy about Mrs. Ciller's comments.
"I have to say I'm a little surprised by those statements," a senior State Department official said. "This does not accord with the discussions the United States has had with Turkey. Perhaps it is Turkey's way of signaling to the United States that it has alternatives."
The official added that if it was true that Turkey was inviting Mr. Hussein to re-establish control over northern Iraq, "it would not be a welcome development -- it would obviously make our cooperation with the Turks more difficult."
But the official also said, "There is room to be uncertain about what different officials in Turkey really think."
Secretary of Defense William J. Perry met with Mrs. Ciller during his recent swing through the region, and she did not tell him of Turkey's intention to urge Mr. Hussein to re-assert his authority over the north. Secretary of State Warren Christopher is to meet with her next week when they both attend the United Nations General Assembly.
For the last five years, Iraqi forces have been barred from the northern part of the country, where the United States and its allies established a haven for Kurds after the Persian Gulf war. But the Kurdish authorities in the enclave have proven unwilling or unable to close Kurdistan Workers Party camps there.
Last month one group of Iraqi Kurds formed an alliance with Mr. Hussein, and for the first time since 1991 Iraqi troops entered the Kurdish enclave. It is still unclear whether Mr. Hussein will assume full control of the region, but that prospect, while troubling to the United States, is encouraging to Turkey.
Mrs. Ciller's comments today underlined a fundamental difference between Turkish and American goals in Iraq. The United States seeks to limit Mr. Hussein's power and prevent him from disrupting the flow of oil from the Middle East to Western industrial nations.
Turkey's principal goals are to close Kurdistan Workers Party bases in Iraq by whatever means necessary and, if possible, to end the American-led economic boycott of Iraq, which has cost Turkey billions of dollars in lost trade.
On Thursday, the new Turkish Prime Minister, Necmettin Erbakan, broke three weeks of silence on the Iraqi crisis by asserting that he would be very happy if Kurds in northern Iraq were to reach an accord with Mr. Hussein.
"If this happens, the area would be cleared of the P.K.K.," Mr. Erbakan told reporters in Ankara. "It would be great."
Asked if he thought the United States would be pleased with a solution that would increase Mr. Hussein's power, Mr. Erbakan replied: "This is not our problem. We have no quarrel with any person in Baghdad. That is only the concern of the United States."
Mr. Erbakan is the first Turkish Prime Minister from an Islamic-based political movement, but his comments and those of Mrs. Ciller reflect a strong political consensus that reaches across the Turkish political spectrum. All mainstream political leaders here, evidently supported by public opinion, are eager to crush the Kurdish separatists and to rebuild Turkey's once-lucrative trading links with Iraq.
The leader of the Iraqi Kurdish faction that is now allied with Mr. Hussein, Massoud Barzani, visited Turkey this week for talks with Foreign Minister Ciller. She said today that Mr. Barzani was sympathetic to Turkey's demand for a crackdown on the Kurdistan Workers Party, which is known as the P.K.K.
"We told him that he would never get what he wants from Turkey if this situation continues," Mrs. Ciller said. "He said he and his people were against terrorism and against the P.K.K., and that P.K.K. operations against us from his territory were something he does not want."
Mrs. Ciller also said she was pleased at a crackdown on organizations in Western Europe that support the Kurdistan Workers Party this week. In an operation coordinated with Germany, Britain, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, more than 200 police officers in Belgium swooped down on the offices of a Kurdish-language television station that officials described as a "propaganda mouthpiece" of the Kurdistan Workers Party. More than 60 Kurds were reportedly detained for questioning.
Newspapers in Belgium reported that the police there believe that the Kurdish Workers Party is engaged in drug and arms smuggling, extortion and other crimes in Europe.

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New Jersey remained at 6.1 percent in August for the fourth straight month, but still remained one percentage point above the national rate, the state Department of Labor said yesterday.
