HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Offering Book on His Economic Plan

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 20

 BODY:
Hoping to jump-start public interest in the centerpiece issue of their campaign, Bob Dole and Jack Kemp today released a book on their economic plan.
The book, entitled "Trusting the People," bills itself as "the Dole-Kemp plan to free the economy and create a better America." 
 Mr. Dole, the Republican Presidential candidate, and his running mate, Mr. Kemp, handed out the books today to reporters traveling with their campaigns and planned to mail hundreds more free copies.
Charles Black, a senior adviser to Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp, said he did not expect the book, which costs $15 and is published by HarperCollins, to produce brisk sales among the public. But he said, "We're going to get them out to opinion leaders."
Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp are listed as the authors of the book, and the cover features a picture of the smiling candidates that was taken the day Mr. Dole introduced Mr. Kemp as his running mate.
Campaign aides said they did not know how many books had been printed, and they could not say immediately how much the project had cost the campaign.
The flyleaf of the book touts it as "more than vague election-year promises."
"In common-sense, jargon-free language, Bob Dole and Jack Kemp walk you through the details of their plan to unshackle the American economy," the book promises.
In the book, the candidates use charts and graphs and large type to explain what their economic plan would mean to families and how they hoped to achieve their goals.
Mr. Dole has promised that if he is elected President, he will push for a 15 percent across-the-board tax cut for every taxpayer, a tax credit of $500 per child for "working families," a 50 percent cut in the tax rate for capital gains, an end to "overbearing" Federal regulations and an overhaul of the legal system.
He has also promised to balance the Federal budget by 2002, although the flyleaf of his book, in an apparent error, lists the target date as two years earlier.
The Republican economic plan has come under a withering attack from President Clinton and other Democrats and has been met by rampant skepticism by much of the public. So far, it has failed to take hold with voters.
Dole-Kemp campaign staff members acknowledged that they were borrowing an idea that their rival, Mr. Clinton, used in his 1992 run for the Presidency, when he summed up his main campaign themes in a book entitled, "Putting People First."
The Republicans released their book in advance of a countrywide push next week to put their economic plan back at the forefront of their campaign, which has focused on crime and drugs in the last week.
"It'll help us get the Dole plan out," said Mr. Black, the political adviser. "We have to defend our plan against the Democratic fog machine."

PUB-DATE: September 22, 1996

SECTION: Section 6; Page 68; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3401 words

HEADLINE: THE FOREIGN POLICY RACE;
Bob Dole's Calculated Pragmatism

BYLINE: By Owen Harries; Owen Harries is the editor of The National Interest.

 BODY:
Until a few weeks ago, the vital question in this Presidential election campaign seemed to be whether it took a village to raise a child. Now we have another question: Why did it take Saddam Hussein to make American foreign policy an issue worthy of discussion in the campaign? Until he sent his troops north against the Kurds, the subject was being comprehensively ignored, and how the strongest country on earth should comport itself abroad was a nonissue.
To be fair to Bob Dole, this is not the way he had wanted it to be. Earlier this year, he was predicting that "America's global future will soon be an important issue in this election" and he went to the trouble of creating an elaborate network of consultants on foreign policy. So elaborate and inclusive is the network, indeed, that when Senator John McCain says that he is one of Bob Dole's 200 closest advisers, it appears less a joke than a simple statement of fact. McCain himself, Jeane Kirkpatrick, Donald Rumsfeld, Robert Ellsworth, Brent Scowcroft, Richard Lugar, Paul Wolfowitz, Richard Armitage, Peter Rodman, Richard Perle, Robert Zoellick . . . and, it sometimes seems, virtually every Republican and conservative in Washington with any foreign policy credentials. 
 Dole also delivered a series of strong speeches on foreign policy in which he insisted that there are "vast and fundamental" differences between him and President Clinton. He relentlessly criticized the Administration's performance as incoherent, vacillating, scattershot, posturing and self-contradictory, and he found no difficulty providing examples to support his charges.
In the case of China, he assailed the Administration's inability to coordinate and prioritize policies on trade, human rights and geopolitics. In the case of Bosnia, he bemoaned the endless prevarication over intervention, the smoke and mirror "solution" at Dayton and the President's failure to keep a direct promise ("I give you my word") to arm and train the Bosnians. In the case of North Korea, he pointed to the President's solemn declaration that such a rogue state could not be allowed to develop a nuclear bomb, followed by an admission that it probably already possessed one, followed in turn by a generous grant of aid to an unrepentant Pyongyang. And so on.
These attacks clearly signaled Dole's desire to make foreign policy a campaign issue. But it soon became equally clear that the Clinton Administration was determined to decline the invitation. After every Dole speech, the White House immediately insisted that, rhetoric apart, there was really no significant difference between the two sides. This "smother defense" seems to have worked. In July, The New York Times editorialized that Dole was "finding it hard to pick a foreign policy fight" and perceived convergence between the two candidates on the subject.
Say such a thing to a Dole adviser and you get an indignant denial, but it is half true. No, there is not genuine convergence, but neither is there enough clear daylight between the two positions to make foreign policy contentious. In part, this is because the post-cold-war world is not amenable to the kind of grand, overarching ideas that simplify and give a sharp definition to events.
Dole's problem is compounded by what one may term either Clinton's skill at "triangulation" or his incredible policy promiscuity. President Clinton does not have a foreign policy. Rather, he has multiple and conflicting foreign policies, sometimes pursued in sequence, sometimes simultaneously. While this is not very good for the country, it makes it extremely hard for an opponent to find a fixed target or to come up with a policy to which Clinton cannot lay some claim. Is Dole for granting most-favored-nation status to China? Well, so in the end and after some bewildering wobbles and wanderings, is Clinton. Does Dole want a missile defense system? Well, so does Clinton sort of, sometime, to some extent.
Faced with such quick-change artistry, Dole is reduced to trying to differentiate himself convincingly from Clinton by focusing on general qualities like coherence, clarity and consistency. These are vitally important in a foreign policy but they lack political sex appeal. Whatever the combination of reasons, by August it looked as though Dole had bowed to the conventional wisdom that, barring some major international crisis, foreign policy does not count for much in Presidential elections. Now, events in Iraq, together with the farcical election in Bosnia, may help force the subject onto the campaign agenda.
If that happens, it will be long overdue. The seven-year failure by both parties to put together anything approximating a coherent post-cold-war foreign policy represents an extraordinary and unsatisfactory state of affairs. And on the evidence of his first four years on the job, there is every reason to doubt that a second-term President Clinton would, or could, do anything much to repair the omission. (To believe otherwise -- that with no more elections to contest he would suddenly put politics aside and start "playing it for history" -- is to ignore the compulsive behavior pattern of a lifetime.)
 WHAT, THEN, OF A PRESIDENT DOLE? WOULD he do any better? What would he bring to the shaping and running of American foreign policy?
Bob Dole is quintessentially a party man -- the Mr. Republican of his generation -- so it makes sense to consider his views in the context of the party he now leads. Republicans are as deeply divided on foreign policy as on domestic "values." Since the fall of the Soviet Union deprived them of an overriding unifying cause, two distinct and sharply opposing wings have emerged: the neoisolationists and the global crusaders.
The neoisolationists argue that the level of global involvement and commitment sustained during the cold war was abnormal and that it should now be reduced drastically and rapidly. Commitments abroad should be subject to the stringent test of national interest and priority should be given to urgent, long-neglected domestic matters. The main political support for this position comes from the party's right, and Patrick Buchanan has been its most forceful spokesman.
The global crusaders insist that, as the sole remaining superpower, the United States must now assume a "proactive," interventionist but benevolent leadership in world affairs. Both its power and its ideals demand that it maintain global order, oppose and end oppression and energetically promote democracy and human rights. American foreign policy must be informed by an inspiring vision, one that will serve not only to reshape the world but also to remoralize America itself. This position is advanced forcefully by neoconservatives like Joshua Muravchik, William Kristol and Robert Kagan.
Dole subscribes to neither of these limiting positions. He berates isolationists -- along with "declinists," multilateralists and protectionists -- as people who would "make a dangerous world even more so." That said, it is worth recalling that he spent his first 20 years growing up in Kansas, then a bastion of isolationism.
Thus, it is not entirely surprising that Dole now believes that "our cold war victory allows the United States to be more selective in its involvement around the world," that "hopes and desires should not be confused with United States interests, which are paramount," that the promotion of democracy abroad should not be seen as an absolute goal and that America's freedom of action must never be circumscribed by the need for multilateral consent.
While Dole clearly rejects the minimalism of the neoisolationists, he does share their concern with discrimination and imposing limits and their insistence that self-interest should provide the criterion for doing so. His relationship with the global crusaders is the other way around: he agrees with their central contention that the United States must play a leading role in world affairs but disagrees with virtually everything else they say and the tone in which they say it.
For someone of Dole's ironic and skeptical disposition, that tone tends to be excessively pretentious. Dole is not a vision man. He once told his friend Warren Rudman that he thought the whole vision thing "a phony," and on another occasion he commented disparagingly that "you can have all the vision you want, but you have to translate that into real laws and real programs. I know how to get things done. It's what I do."
There is much to be said for such skepticism. Scrutinized closely, the demand for vision usually amounts either simply to a desire for a more uplifting class of rhetoric or to a determination to impose America's will on the world. While the first is merely pretentious, the latter can be dangerously arrogant. Thus, Kristol and Kagan maintain that the proper course for the United States, in its pursuit of "benevolent hegemony," is to ignore the well-known advice of John Quincy Adams and go "abroad in search of monsters to destroy." They insist that anyone who would argue for less would be settling for "a policy of cowardice and dishonor."
Such hyperactive interventionism is bound to be uncongenial to Dole. It offends his sense of limits, imposed by the test of national interest. It violates his sense of prudence -- for however cloaked in good intentions, it is a reckless and dangerous policy, likely ultimately to unite other countries against the United States. And perhaps most important, it is alien to his sense of propriety. I once asked the man closest to Dole, Robert Ellsworth, which trait in his friend's character was most relevant to understanding his approach to foreign policy. Ellsworth is a subtle and sophisticated man, and he could have given an elaborate answer. Instead, he simply said, "He hates bullies." Now, to hate bullies is not only to hate being bullied or to see others being bullied; it is also to be averse to being a bully.
Questions of temperament and disposition aside, there are also compelling political reasons why Bob Dole cannot countenance global crusading. Most Republicans assign very high priority to downsizing the Federal Government, yet an ambitious, interventionist foreign policy is incompatible with that goal. Most Republicans give a high priority to balancing the budget, but a "proactive" foreign policy is very expensive. (Kristol and Kagan glibly propose adding up to $80 billion a year to the defense budget.) Many Republicans would agree with Edwin Feulner, the president of the Heritage Foundation, that "something is terribly wrong with America" and would therefore conclude that the biblical injunction, "Physician, heal thyself," should take precedence over any impulse to instruct and correct the world. America's capital city -- the very symbol of its power and authority -- is currently failing to supply safe drinking water to its inhabitants.
Dole certainly does believe in American leadership, but in a focused leadership meant to achieve specific goals, not an open-ended, diffuse one. Its coherence and purpose would come not from a sense of some grand mission but, more mundanely, from a clear definition of interests, the establishing of firm priorities among them and consistency and determination in their pursuit.
This very deliberate and pragmatic approach characterizes Dole's response to what he nominates, justifiably, as the most important challenge America faces: the rising power of China. First, strategic goals are set out clearly: "A China which does not threaten its neighbors and a China which plays by the rules of the international system of nonproliferation and trade, a China which is peaceful, prosperous and free." Then the steps necessary to advance toward these goals are itemized: "Prioritize our interests, communicate our priorities to the Chinese leadership and implement a policy in a confident and a consistent manner."
Dole realistically recognizes that "trade is not a panacea, and freer trade does not always lead to democracy," but rightly urges it as the best option for China. Capitalism has already "corroded central government control" in China, and Dole properly emphasizes the enormously significant move toward democratic elections at the municipal and village levels that is taking place there.
Always a results-oriented politician, Dole is dismissive of gestures: "Denying M.F.N. would not free a single dissident, halt a single missile sale, prevent a single threat to Taiwan or save a single innocent Chinese." But he insists with equal firmness that engagement should not mean acquiescence in Chinese misbehavior. Clear markers should be laid down -- on weapons proliferation ("top priority"), on the security of Taiwan -- and if these are violated, appropriate steps must be taken. If that means economic sanctions, they must be applied, but with intelligent discrimination -- thus, in responding to unacceptable weapons sales, their specific targets should be "enterprises controlled by the People's Liberation Army involved in proliferation -- not every American business in China."
If what Dole has to say about coping with the rising power of China demonstrates his strengths, what he has to say about the other great geopolitical problem facing Washington -- a Russia coping with the rapid decline of its power and status, while simultaneously undertaking a transition to democracy -- is much less impressive and exposes some of his weaknesses.
They are weaknesses that result largely from the grip of habit, and at the age of 73, acquiring the habit of breaking habits may be Bob Dole's hardest task. His instruction in foreign policy took place entirely during the cold war, when Moscow was the enemy. In Dole's mind, it often seems, it still is. He sees today's Russia as "all too willing to repeat old patterns, challenging the interest of America and the West," without elaborating quite what he has in mind. He draws a sharp distinction between "the Russia we hope to see" and "the Russia that truly exists," and he sees the latter as characterized by neoimperial policies. He accuses the Clinton Administration of "misguided romanticism" toward Russia.
On the crucial question of the expansion of NATO, Dole takes a tough line. He berates Clinton for deferring and delaying in the face of Russian pressure and pledges that he would move rapidly to bring Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into NATO by 1998. But he would not stop there, for other states "from Slovenia to the Baltics rightly aspire to this goal." Even Ukraine, "despite the great pressures of its geography," should be regarded as eligible for "cooperative activities" with NATO. All this should proceed regardless of Russia's views. Moscow would simply "be told" that NATO is a defensive alliance and that it therefore has no cause for complaint.
There is no evidence in all this that Dole accords validity to any of the strong arguments against NATO expansion. He hasn't explained how to justify, in the absence of any credible threat, advancing a military alliance several hundred miles closer to the borders of another great power. Nor has he said why we should trust countries that have recently failed miserably with the modest problem of Bosnia to shoulder vast new commitments -- especially as they have all reduced their defense budgets substantially. He hasn't realistically faced the constraints imposed by the American people's aversion to taking casualties. Finally, he has ignored Winston Churchill's advice that, in victory, magnanimity to the defeated is usually the best policy -- advice that served America well with respect to Germany and Japan after Dole's "good war."
It has sometimes been suggested that Dole's strong views on Russia reflect the personal connections some of his closest advisers have with Central and Eastern Europe. It is more likely that they are shaped by 30 years of experience as a cold warrior and his hatred of "bullies," the latter activated by events in Chechnya.
On the whole, Dole's advisers reflect his own pragmatism and have been chosen for their experience and competence. If he wins, I would expect Dole to draw his major foreign policy and national security players from Rumsfeld, Kirkpatrick, Ellsworth, Colin Powell, McCain and Wolfowitz, and any combination from that list would constitute an impressive team. (With Madeleine Albright being touted if Clinton wins, for the first time in American history a woman is a very strong candidate for Secretary of State in both parties.)
How, in the meantime, can Bob Dole present his views on foreign policy so that they resonate more effectively with an American people who are largely indifferent to the outside world? Here are some suggestions:
First, insist that the United States must perform its vital role as world leader in ways consistent with its own nature and core values. America is not an imperial power but a republic, and it must lead as a republic -- not through command and force majeure but by cooperation, example, persuasion and encouragement. Its aim should not be to create a hierarchical world of leaders and followers but to create one in which responsibility, initiative and enterprise are widely dispersed.
Second, as the American people today wish to downsize government and revitalize civil society, Candidate Dole could stress that the real source of America's global leadership is not the power of its government but the energy, inventiveness and initiative of its society. Its great economic companies, its universities, its silicon valleys and (for better and for worse) its cultural and mass-entertainment industry -- it is these that will insure America's global leadership into the 21st century, not the State Department, the U.S. Information Agency or even the Pentagon. America's real foreign policy is itself.
Third, that said, he would acknowledge that in a dangerous world of competing states, military power remains indispensable. But in deciding when to deploy it, Washington should practice the sound federal principle of subsidiarity -- that is, allowing problems to be handled at the level closest to the problem. This way, a sense of responsibility can be developed throughout the international system and the United States can reserve its own interventions for the great issues involving its vital interests, acting as a balancer of last resort rather than a busybody and bully.
Fourth, when it does decide to intervene, the United States should not feel bound by the largely phony universalism of the United Nations. But its unilateralism should be tempered by a readiness to cooperate with like-minded states through ad hoc "coalitions of the willing," flexible arrangements that are better attuned to the fragmented nature of the new era than standing alliances.
Fifth, emphasize missile defense. Apart from satisfying a general desire for greater security, this appeals to two opposing constituencies: those who favor minimal international involvement (since viewed from one angle, it is the modern equivalent of raising the drawbridge) and those who favor an activist policy (since viewed from another, it reduces the inhibitions imposed by vulnerability).
Sixth, make character a foreign policy issue. When serious foreign policy crises occur, the country needs a President with a strong character. Clinton does not have one. At best, he fakes firmness and resolution, as with the Dayton accords or the recent responses to Saddam Hussein. Dole does have a strong character, tested by adversity. He has shown a willingness to adopt and stay with unpopular positions and to support Presidential policies even at a political cost. The worst that he is accused of is having a mean streak. But meanness, properly controlled and directed ("this dog is dangerous, when attacked it defends itself") is a strength in foreign policy.
Combined with the specifics that Dole has already spelled out, an approach to foreign policy along these lines would satisfy the wish that America should lead the world, reflect the concern to keep costs of blood and treasure low, harmonize with the prevailing Republican philosophy of limited government, meet the conservative concern for prudence and discrimination and reflect the nationalist concern with preserving freedom of action. And it would serve America's national interest well.

PUB-DATE: September 22, 1996

SECTION: Section 6; Page 82; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2178 words

HEADLINE: PEROT, ALONE

BYLINE: By Gerald Posner; Gerald Posner is the author of "Citizen Perot." He last wrote about the Perot campaign for the Magazine in March.

 BODY:
INVITED ONLY A WEEK EARLIER BY THE LEADERS OF ROSS PEROT'S fledgling Reform Party, Richard Lamm received a rousing reception for his June 1 speech at the California State party gathering. Afterward, a reporter asked the former three-term Colorado governor if he had thought of running for President. He hesitated, then said he would consider it "under the right circumstances."
"I didn't think about it," says Lamm. "It just came out." 
 "We almost all had a heart attack," says Tom, his brother, who was standing nearby.
Lamm, of course, had no way of knowing that Perot had been desperately hoping to lure someone with Lamm's political credentials into the race. Perot, who had been claiming for months that the Reform Party was "not about me," fretted that if he did not have believable competition for the nomination, he would be roundly criticized for indulging in vanity politics.
Perot's party was at a crossroads. This election would tell whether it would be a movement or a monument to himself, and the decision -- like all decisions in the Reform Party -- was up to Perot. In the end, Perot toyed with Lamm, and the consequences of that dalliance could well affect more than Lamm's career. The Reform Party was America's best chance to sustain a real third party in decades. Its moment may have passed, and if it has, much of the reason can be traced to the strange dance between Lamm and Perot this summer.
 LAMM'S IMPULSIVE ANSWER ABOUT RUNNING FOR PRESIDENT caught the attention of Russell Verney, then the Reform Party's national coordinator, who asked the Lamms to meet with Perot after his speech at the California gathering. Verney wanted to join Perot at the meeting, but the Texan was adamant he wanted to see the Lamm contingent alone.
Since his 1992 campaign, when he had hired, clashed with and then fired political professionals, Perot has relished his role as campaign manager, strategist and media adviser. The only people capable of standing up to him -- his business partner, Mort Meyerson, and his estranged attorney, Tom Luce -- are long gone. Perot's new, small group consisted of Verney, a former executive director of the Democratic Party in New Hampshire; Sharon Holman, his press spokeswoman and a former personal secretary, and Clay Mulford, his son-in-law and an attorney at a Dallas firm that grew fat on Perot business.
After Perot's talk, Dick and Tom Lamm passed Perot's security guards and entered a small, cramped room. Perot had briefly met Lamm before but now stepped forward as if they were old friends, vigorously shaking his hand. Then, sitting back in a folding chair and kicking his feet onto a table, Perot startled them. "Governor, I hope that you will be a Reform Party candidate," he said. "Your speech was well received, and you are one of the kind of guys we want. It's going to be a democratic process, and we'd like you to be part of it."
Tom Lamm, an attorney, asked who the other candidates would be and, more important, if Perot intended to run.
"Well, I certainly hope I don't have to be that candidate," said Perot in his most gracious tone.
"In my profession, that is nonresponsive," Tom Lamm said politely. "We don't want to run against you. It's your party; if you want it, you should run."
"I hope I don't have to," Perot assured them. "I would like to go back to work."
On several occasions, Perot leaned forward and looked Dick Lamm intensely in the eyes: "I want you in this race. We want you in this process." By the end, Tom Lamm decided Perot was not going to reveal his intentions. "I have cross-examined thousands of witnesses," he says, "and none were tougher than Ross Perot."
During the next few weeks, Perot made several encouraging calls to Lamm. By late June, Lamm thought that "Perot was testing me, waiting to see if I would have the courage to enter the race" and that if he ran, Perot would not. When he called Perot on Monday, July 8, to say he had decided to join the Reform race, Perot abruptly told him: "Do what you need to do. Godspeed and good luck."
Lamm was annoyed by Perot's response but quickly overlooked it as he booked an appearance on "Larry King Live" for Tuesday, July 9. Within hours Perot reserved an appearance on "King" for the following night. The Lamm brothers watched in anger as Perot, on July 10, eclipsed Lamm's entry. "I knew he was unpredictable," says Dick Lamm, "but this was not exactly welcoming me to the party."
Once Lamm entered the race, Perot himself made several decisions that tilted the race in his favor. One was his refusal to turn over the list of 1.3 million party members; the Perot camp claimed it was worth $4 million and that giving it to Lamm would be an illegal campaign contribution. Actually, Perot was concerned he could not control the solicitations Lamm would make to party members and feared if he gave the list to Lamm, "it could leak into the hands of one of the parties."
By mid-July, Lamm took his complaint about the list to the press. Perot was infuriated, privately protesting that he had gone out of his way to help Lamm. Their relationship was further strained when Perot could not stop Lamm from speaking to the press -- about the name of the accounting firm selected to tabulate the party's nominating ballots and about the number of votes each candidate received. On the second occasion, Perot called Lamm, curtly demanded an explanation and ordered him to "work on keeping this from happening in the future."
The final straw for Perot was learning of Lamm's desire for a debate from the press instead of from Lamm himself. The two men had shared Perot's private plane between two campaign stops. "He never brought it up a single time," Perot complains. He then ignored advisers who told him to maintain a cordial if distant relationship with Lamm and instead insisted he did not want to "talk to that guy anymore." When some suggested a debate could boost both his profile and that of the Reform Party, Perot vetoed the idea. Without any debates, there was little press or public interest in the race, and Perot started slipping in public-opinion polls, dropping five to six points by late July.
All of this contributed to very low television ratings at the dual Reform Party conventions in Long Beach, Calif., and Valley Forge, Pa., in August. By that time, the Lamm and Perot camps were completely estranged.
At Long Beach, when Russ Verney finished the only scheduled briefing session, Eric Anderson, Lamm's press spokesman, jumped to the podium and started listing complaints. Sharon Holman stopped chatting and walked nearer the lectern. Clay Mulford stiffened, his face flushed red with anger and he kept biting his lower lip. When Anderson stopped, the Perot cadre huddled in the rear of the room, clearly distressed over the public airing of the party's dirty laundry.
In the week before the second and final phase of the convention at Valley Forge, Lamm unleashed his harshest criticism of Perot, saying that his qualities as a businessman would not transfer well to politics and that unless Perot loosened his grip on the Reform Party, it would not survive.
The underlying differences that had caused friction between them were emphasized in the politicking at the conventions. Lamm arrived early, mingled with the crowds and made himself available to the press. But Perot flew in on his private jet just before his speeches, rejecting suggestions he energize Reform Party loyalists by mixing with them. He merely waved to the crowd from the stage after each of his talks before quickly departing. He did not field a single question from the press corps except for the "Larry King" interview after his acceptance speech. (During the speech, he looked at his watch several times, insuring he would not be late for the live show.)
The contrast between the candidates was never clearer than in the minibiographical films that introduced them. Lamm's film focused on his political experience and the issues. Perot's consisted of a barrage of stories about his saving people in distress, from a woman with an aneurysm to a member of the Paralympics to his own employees jailed in Iran. The message: If Ross Perot can do this for regular people, imagine what he can do for the country. It seemed more fitting for a run for head of the Red Cross than for the Presidency.
When the winning candidate was finally announced, with less than 5 percent of the Reform Party members voting, there was little suspense. Even Lamm seemed relieved it was over. Apparently exhausted, in his rambling final speech he compared his 78-day campaign to "drinking from a fire hose" and almost walked away from the podium before offering halfhearted congratulations to Perot.
 BY REFUSING TO PLAY BY ANY RULES BUT HIS OWN, ROSS Perot bypassed a unique opportunity to have real competition build the reputation of his embryonic party. Now that he has prevented Dick Lamm from mounting a genuine challenge, he has a much harder job running an effective campaign, much less building a third party. If he is to succeed at either, he must let others in -- and not just candidates but advisers.
For instance, one of his first post-nomination decisions (actually announced on "Larry King" within minutes of his convention speech) was to accept the nearly $30 million in Federal funds available as a result of his strong 1992 showing. Perot, known for his parsimony, ignored advisers who thought not only that it looked ungainly for a billionaire to take Government money but also that it was not enough to run his television campaign. Perot was seemingly not bothered by the apparent hypocrisy that in 1992 he had adamantly rejected the idea of running for office on public funds. The day after Perot's "King" appearance, Verney tried to backpedal, saying the decision was not final, but Perot refused to reconsider.
Perot overrode his advisers once again in their desire to start the campaign in mid-August and to hold more campaign rallies before Reform Party loyalists and friendly groups. (His choice for Vice President, Pat Choate, a maverick political economist whose controversial book "Agents of Influence" was seen by many as xenophobic, will have the role of attending more traditional campaign rallies.) They argued that Perot needed an early bounce in the polls, where he had languished in single digits. Yet except for a single August appearance at the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention -- in which he refused to stay to mix with the crowd after his speech -- Perot single-handedly vetoed the idea of an August kickoff; he believes that a late television blitz will dramatically lift him. While he did start his infomercial assault on Sept. 1, he agreed to only a few public appearances for the remainder of the month.
Since the political press will not play by Perot's rules -- that is, ask easy questions about his core issues as opposed to aggressive ones about his character -- he intends to get millions of dollars of free publicity with soft interviews only. While his aides know that putting their boss in close proximity to the press is often a sure-fire recipe for combustion, they believe it is a mistake to bypass the political press. Voters want a President who is tough, and ducking hard questions does not bode well for someone who could eventually deal with world leaders much tougher than the Washington press corps. Perot directed his own campaign against Lamm, and he intends to play the same role this fall. He has personally devised a battle plan to boost his standings in the polls, assuming that he would be in each of several Presidential debates. Whether he's included or not in each of the debates, he intends to go after both Clinton and Dole vigorously.
Whom does Perot hurt with this solo campaign? Ultimately Dole, because Perot prevents the Republican candidate from focusing just on catching Clinton. Also, in half a dozen states including Florida and Georgia, Dole and Clinton are almost even in the polls. Perot's good showing in those states could push them to Clinton and all but eliminate Dole's chances.
Perot's isolation in Dallas and his decision to run only a television campaign will make it difficult to ignite the enthusiasm his campaign needs. Pat Choate may be a forceful advocate for trade restrictions and campaign-finance reform, but he will do little to energize the Perot effort. For Perot to catch fire, he must listen to his Dallas advisers and develop a more personable side by attending campaign rallies, pressing the flesh with voters and standing up to the political press without losing his temper. Without a strong finish on Election Day, he will further hurt his new party's chances for long-term survival.
One thing is certain: on election night, whatever his final vote tally, Perot will have only himself to credit or blame. In 1992 he finished his election-night festivities by dancing with his wife, Margot, to Patsy Cline's "Crazy." This year Frank Sinatra's "My Way" would seem more appropriate.

HEADLINE: THE FOREIGN POLICY RACE;
Madeleine Albright's Audition

BYLINE: By Elaine Sciolino; Elaine Sciolino, a senior writer in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, has also served as The Times's chief diplomatic correspondent and United Nations bureau chief.

 BODY:
Under a warm late-afternoon sun, two middle-aged American women in smart pants suits slip out of their Prague hotel and stroll across Old Town Square. Trailed at a discreet distance by Secret Service agents, they study the clock on the 15th-century Town Hall, do some window shopping and walk into Wenceslas Square, where a protest rally in 1989 sparked the country's Velvet Revolution and the fall of Communism. They talk about their children, the professors they had at Wellesley College, walking, eating and vitamins. Madeleine Korbel Albright and Hillary Rodham Clinton are clearly having a good time.
It is four days of fun and diplomacy, captured in a few snapshots: Albright, the Czech-born American delegate to the United Nations, showing off the yellow house in which she once lived . . . the two women laughing uncontrollably when their umbrellas turn inside out in a driving rainstorm . . . sitting in a Prague cafe, editing their talking points over dumplings and cabbage for meetings in Slovakia the next day . . . singing "Good King Wenceslas" with a dear friend, President Vaclav Havel, as their Chevrolet Suburban pulls into Wenceslas Square. 
 Why is Albright playing tour guide in Prague for the First Lady? "Mostly because it's friendship," says Albright. "And it just seemed like a natural thing to do."
It may also have been an expedient thing to do. Should Clinton win another term and the Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, decide to leave, Albright would be a contender for his position. And one of the people likely to decide whether the time is right for a female Secretary of State is Hillary Clinton. In some quarters in the Administration, Albright's trip with the First Lady is viewed as so blatantly political that it is dismissed in just two words: the audition.
The 59-year-old Albright is certainly well positioned for a bigger role should there be a Clinton II. She is the first American delegate to the United Nations who is both a member of the Cabinet and a full-fledged participant in the National Security Council. She has moved into the vacuum left by an uneven foreign policy team and defined her role broadly, doing the speeches-and-talk-show circuit, visiting American troops to boost her standing with the military and subbing for the Secretary of State whenever necessary. She has embraced her job with the same energy that in an earlier life drove her to knit sweaters at the movies and take a crash course in Russian while her premature twins were isolated in incubators.
Her extracurricular activities leave only about half her time for the United Nations, prompting criticism there that she does not take her job seriously enough. Around Washington, her diverse schedule is seen as evidence of an ambition that has taken her from early marriage and motherhood, through a devastating divorce, to a professorship at Georgetown University and finally to being a key member of the President's foreign policy team, one who has a shot at becoming the most senior female official in United States history.
Perhaps the single biggest surprise about Albright -- and what has catapulted her into prominence -- is that's she's so good in public, particularly on television. "CNN is the 16th member of the Security Council," she likes to say. The President wants her in front of the cameras, and largely by default she has earned a reputation as the most passionate and articulate defender of Clinton's foreign policy.
"I hate to sound this way because it makes me sound so conceited," she says, "but I do think I'm playing a larger role than any U.N. ambassador ever."
Like Pamela Harriman, Clinton's Ambassador to France, Albright has made it in a world dominated by men, because of men. Both women used their wealth and their Georgetown homes as meeting places for rich, important and potentially important Democrats. Harriman made her way because of her personal relationships with men; Albright moved up because she worked hard for men, made them look good and believed in them. "I was the world's perfect staffer," she says. Or the ultimate good daughter.
What she may lack in innate brilliance, she makes up for in dedication. Her critics whisper that she hasn't written a serious work in 25 years of studying foreign policy and that she lacks strategic vision. None of this fazes Albright, whose importance is beginning to transcend that of the men she works for. Sitting in an armchair in the peach-and-yellow living room of her Georgetown town house, Albright talks straight. "I'm not that smart," she says. "I work very hard."
It would be hard for most men in public life to be so self-deprecating, or so honest.
ON A COOL SATURDAY afternoon at the Orange Bowl, 60,000 Cuban-Americans are on their feet cheering wildly, not for the Miami Dolphins but for Madeleine Albright. "Madeleine, libertad! Madeleine, libertad!" they cry over and over. She waves, campaign-style. The applause is so overwhelming she can barely get through her speech.
"We thought she was running for mayor of Miami down there," Clinton joked afterward. Albright, he added, "has a great political feel."
In a Presidential election year in which Florida's 25 electoral votes are up for grabs, a little Cuba-bashing can go a long way. Only weeks before that March rally, Cuban-American leaders had been complaining loudly that Clinton was too easy on Fidel Castro, and the leading Republican Presidential candidate, Bob Dole, was scoring easy political points.
But that all changed when Cuban jet fighters downed two unarmed civilian planes from Miami and Albright went on the offensive in the Security Council. Sneering at the worst impulses of men, she said something no male diplomat would dare say in polite company: the Spanish curse word for testicles. "Frankly, this is not cojones, this is cowardice," she sputtered, echoing the very word the Cuban pilots had used as they boasted about their attack.
Diplomatically, it may have been her worst moment at the United Nations, where the remark was greeted with outrage. "She tried to say a man's word, and it was uncalled for," says Diego Arria, a former Venezuelan representative. "I wouldn't even say that word, not even on my farm."
Politically, though, it was clearly her best moment. And it pleased the President. "Probably the most effective one-liner in the whole Administration's foreign policy," Clinton called it. "The Cuban-Americans loved it so much they had bumper stickers made up. I have a bumper sticker with Madeleine's quote on it."
Political sense, the ability to project passion and energy -- these are the keys to campaigns and to people's souls, and they have set Albright apart from colleagues in the Administration who measure their words but fail to connect. They also explain why Albright is considered a valuable weapon against the Republicans and why Clinton likes her so much. "I am not a diplomat," she likes to say. "I am such a political person."
She has taken her campaign to sell Clinton's foreign policy around the world, to obscure capitals like Tblisi and Baku that normally wouldn't make a Secretary of State's itinerary. And she rarely passes up an opportunity to charm the military. Dressed in an orange life vest, a helmet and goggles on the deck of the aircraft carrier Constellation, a big grin on her face, her striped pants flapping in the wind, she looks much more comfortable than did her former boss, Michael Dukakis, when he peeked out of a tank during the 1988 Presidential campaign.
Her solid relationship with President Clinton assures her a seat at the policy-making table. They first got to know each other when he, as Governor of Arkansas, went to Boston to help prepare Dukakis for the 1988 Presidential debate. After Dukakis lost the election, Clinton and Albright stayed in touch. When Clinton wanted to get into the Council on Foreign Relations in 1989, he turned to Albright for a recommendation. "He has an active mind and an excellent background," she wrote. (He got in.) Albright also derives power from her lofty place in the State Department. George Bush's Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d -- fearing competition from one of the nation's most talented diplomats -- banished his envoy, Thomas Pickering, from the building. But Christopher doesn't feel threatened by Albright, who keeps disputes inside the Administration. He has rewarded that loyalty with a large suite of offices on the floor just below his.
IN AN ADMINISTRATION THAT WAFFLED on China, retreated from Somalia and procrastinated before making peace in Bosnia, she stands out as always wanting to do more. More than many of her foreign policy colleagues, Albright is comfortable with the projection of American power, a view that flows from her experiences growing up in Europe during World War II and fleeing as a refugee to America. Whether or not an intervention meets the test of a "vital national interest" is less important for her than whether the United States can do good in the world, using military power if necessary.
"My mind-set is Munich; most of my generation's is Vietnam," she says. "I saw what happened when a dictator was allowed to take over a piece of a country and the country went down the tubes. And I saw the opposite during the war when America joined the fight. For me, America is really, truly the indispensable nation. I've never seen America as an imperialist or colonialist or meddling country."
The lesson of Munich is to get in; that of Vietnam is to stay out. And it is that difference that set her apart from her colleagues early on in the Administration, particularly from Colin Powell, then the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Fresh off his victory in the Persian Gulf war, Powell had little trouble convincing Clinton and his team to abstain from using force in Bosnia.
Except for Albright. Haunted by parallels to the dissolution of Czechoslovakia in 1938, she argued in a memo to the President in April 1993 for punitive NATO air strikes to destroy the tanks and heavy weapons of the Bosnian Serbs and to demolish the bridges and transit points used to ship weapons from Serbia.
In his memoir, "My American Journey," Powell recalls a discussion with Albright on Bosnia. "What's the point of having this superb military you're always talking about if we can't use it?" she asked him.
"I thought I would have an aneurysm," wrote the originator of the Powell doctrine, the idea that the United States should intervene militarily -- and with overwhelming force -- only when its vital interests are threatened. "American G.I.'s were not toy soldiers to be moved around on some sort of global game board." Powell had a close ally in Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, who lectured Albright that the kinds of issues the general was raising "are exactly the ones the military never asked during Vietnam."
Albright now delights in telling people that NATO conducted its first serious air strikes against the Bosnian Serbs the week Powell's book came out. Even better, they worked, driving the Bosnian Serbs to the bargaining table. "I felt some vindication," she says. "It wasn't easy being a civilian woman having a disagreement with the hero of the Western world. But maybe he'd want to rewrite that page now."
A week touring the country with Albright is studded with examples of her plain-spoken, sound-bite approach to foreign policy. On why the United States engages with China but isolates Cuba: "We do not have a cookie cutter approach to policy. China is a world power. . . . Cuba is an embarrassment to the Western Hemisphere."
On whether a Communist-dominated Soviet Union could come back: "I do not see it coming back. What is always possible . . . is for things to be chaotic in a way where there will be a turning to more authoritarian ways."
On NATO expansion: "We're not out there trolling for new alliances."
On the Middle East: "The peace process there is not reversible."
On land mines: "I've never seen so many one-legged people as I have in Angola."
On arms sales: "The trading of arms is disgusting and contributes to horrors around the world. With the breakup of the Soviet Union, it's a bazaar out there."
Within the Administration, she has a close ally in Gen. John Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The general was raised in Poland and, like Albright, sees the world through the lens of Munich. He too believes that the Powell doctrine is a cold war relic, ill suited to today's more fluid world system. But others remain closer to Powell's view: Lake, who has advocated greater involvement, but episodically; Christopher, who is always cautious and deliberate, and the Secretary of Defense, William Perry, who is the most reluctant to commit American forces.
Christopher often disagrees with Albright's brand of activism, but always politely and usually in private. By contrast, Lake demonstrates his exasperation with her long, impassioned digressions by drumming his fingers, gazing around the room or cutting her off in meetings. "Madeleine sometimes likes to free-form think," says a senior White House official who is a fan of Lake's. "Tony doesn't."
A senior State Department official in Albright's camp sees it differently. "There's not any yelling and screaming, but there are unmistakable signs of impatience when Madeleine challenges Tony's views." For that reason, the official adds, Albright sometimes has more impact if she participates from New York through a secure television system, so she can interrupt when she wants to.
But even Lake found a willing teammate in Albright in August 1995, when he undertook a new peace initiative for Bosnia. Albright's memo attacking the status quo and laying out a plan for action, including the use of American military force, helped establish the groundwork for the Dayton accords. Although Clinton said afterward that Albright's arguments were the most compelling ones he heard, she has received little credit. "Someday it shall be known," she says wistfully, sitting in a Prague cafe. "The meek shall inherit the earth."
Albright's thinking on the use of force has evolved in recent years. Like many mainstream Democrats, she initially opposed going to war against Iraq. Just weeks before President Bush sent American troops to battle, she was still saying that sanctions should be given more of a chance to work. She has since called her view "a mistake."
She would be the first to admit that she has become harder-edged since the beginning of the Administration. The most prominent example is the abandonment of her crusade for what in 1993 she called "assertive multilateralism." She argued that the United States could not afford, financially or politically, to play global Lone Ranger, and that international coalitions should be put together when force is needed. But she was savaged by Republicans on Capitol Hill and by the foreign policy establishment for what was perceived as relinquishing American sovereignty to the United Nations. "It didn't catch on," she says now. "People thought it didn't work. I got tired of having to explain it. So I just let it go."
Now she is plugging a more modest slogan, what she calls "the doability doctrine": that America should use its military power in flexible ways to achieve practical, if sometimes limited, goals. "You deal with the pragmatic situation you have," she says. "You may have to scale back your objectives and decide that just because you cannot do everything does not mean you should do nothing."
For Albright, Bosnia is one example of the Administration's committing American troops in a mission with limited -- if imperfect -- goals. "In the best of all possible worlds it would have been great to eradicate the power of those determined to undermine the multi-ethnic state of Bosnia," she says. Nevertheless, she considers a deeply flawed peace better than war.
The recent military attacks on Iraq are another example. In her view, the operation was a practical solution that served American interests but avoided the choice between sending American ground forces into a full-fledged war or doing nothing. "Those who say America has to dominate the world, and that you have to either control everything or go home," she says, "don't understand the way power is projected at the end of this century."
In some cases, however, "doability" means doing nothing. Back in 1993, Albright called Somalia a "failed state" that the international community must help by disarming all its warlords. But after 18 American soldiers were killed and the United States withdrew, she pulled back as well. So today, while she calls Burundi "a country on the verge of national suicide," she does not propose sending in troops to rescue it. The average American, she tells audiences, "wouldn't know where Burundi is."
 ALL THE POPPING off to obscure capitals and war zones, all the road shows and campaign appearances and all the television talk shows don't leave a lot of time for the day job: chief American representative at the United Nations. Even if the post lacks automatic Cabinet rank, the public nature of the job, the proximity to Washington and the need to deal with every member country of the United Nations makes it much more important than a mere ambassadorial post. It also comes with a staff of more than 100 and a $27,000-a-month suite at the top of the Waldorf Towers.
During the cold war, when the United Nations was paralyzed by superpower rivalry, American envoys more often than not were verbal crusaders struggling to extend America's sphere of influence. Their styles and strategies and mandates varied. Adlai Stevenson got the appointment because President Kennedy wanted him in a dignified setting away from Washington. George Bush had little input into policy but charmed his colleagues with his impeccable manners. Andrew Young lent sex appeal to the normally staid post by roaming around Africa, where he was treated like a rock star. Daniel Patrick Moynihan said the job all depended on when you were there; his bashing of the United Nations as anti-American and anti-Israeli helped him in his subsequent race for the Senate.
Jeane Kirkpatrick spent as little time as she could inside the United Nations and never hid her contempt for the place. "I'd rather be in Philadelphia," she once said. Her successor, Vernon Walters, loved it there; he ate his way through the reception lines and told funny stories in several languages. By most accounts, the best-liked American envoy was Thomas Pickering, President Bush's choice and now Ambassador to Russia. Frozen out of Bush's policy-making circle, he was nevertheless a diplomat's diplomat, resolving numerous disputes with creative formulas that countries could not refuse.
Unlike Pickering, Albright doesn't spend much time working the hallways; the way her foreign colleagues see it, she doesn't spend much time there at all. When she does show up, they complain, she seeks out the television cameras more than them.
And her combative style rankles. While Pickering was known as "the magician," Albright is called "the queen of mean." When the Chinese representative couldn't vote on an anti-Cuba statement because he didn't have instructions, she kept the Security Council in session until 4 A.M. until he got them. When the British representative tried to finesse a resolution partly lifting sanctions on Serbia, Albright concluded that compromise was impossible and walked out of the room.
"Abrasive? In the U.N. they'd call her worse than that," says Arria, who considers her a friend. "She projects a tough, cold image. I know her as the opposite of that, but even I don't recognize her sometimes when she speaks."
Never has the job of American representative been so easy -- or so difficult. In the post-cold-war world, it usually doesn't take much arm-twisting for the United States to get its way. The Russians won't challenge the United States as long as they are left alone in the countries that were once part of the Soviet empire; the Chinese won't veto any resolution that doesn't directly affect their own security.
Thus, Albright has managed to pull off some surprising successes. Take the American-led invasion of Haiti. In July 1994, a State Department memo said it would be "folly" to ask the Security Council to authorize the invasion; Christopher and Perry were also skeptical. But Albright told Clinton, "If I have the authority, I think I can do it." She did.
But the refusal of Congress to pay its back dues -- more than $1.1 billion worth -- has enraged other member states, including America's closest allies, and undercut American authority. That bad feeling has hurt the United States in its campaign to deny Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali a second five-year term.
From the start, there was never any love lost between Albright and the Egyptian-born career diplomat. She felt he went beyond his authority and was ineffective in reforming the institution -- although he has presided over the largest staff reductions and budget cuts in the organization's history. "People are concerned when Boutros-Ghali seems to overstep and believes he's in charge of everything," she once said.
So early this year, Albright urged the Administration to dump Boutros-Ghali when his term expires in December. After he resisted, Christopher stepped in and -- ignoring Albright's reservations -- offered a compromise that would extend the Secretary General's term a year. When the negotiations later blew up, Albright was on the road. Working the phones from Bubba's Hundred Sandwiches on the highway between San Diego and Los Angeles, she tried to head off trouble. But lacking the authority to inform United Nations officials and diplomats ahead of time, her hands were tied. Most of them learned of the decision in the newspaper the next morning and blamed her for the mess.
Since then, the Security Council has refused Albright's pleas to begin the process of choosing a new candidate before the American Presidential election. The United States does not have its own candidate, which may be just as well. There is still enough anti-Americanism in the U.N. and so much ill feeling about the clumsy way the matter has been handled that any "American" candidate would automatically lose.
"The decision to dump Boutros-Ghali is dumb foreign policy and it doesn't move us anywhere at the U.N.," says Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a former Secretary of State in the Bush Administration. "But I'm probably one of the few people who thinks he's done a good job."
 IT IS 10:30 P.M. IN LOS Angeles and Albright, dressed in a taupe dress and shawl, is off to dinner with Barbra Streisand. Since the representative awoke in her quarters on the Constellation in the Pacific this morning, she has had breakfast with the officers, flown back to San Diego in a tiny C-2 prop plane, given a speech at a luncheon in her honor, worked her cell phone on the Boutros-Ghali embroglio, driven to Los Angeles, attended a reception with Korean-Americans and given two interviews and a news conference. Most people would call it a day.
But not Albright. Streisand wants to show off her new house, so Albright shoehorns in another event. The women, who met at a Hollywood Women's Political Caucus function in early 1993, go antiquing together, talk often on the phone and try to get together whenever they're in the same city.
"You know, you meet certain people and you have a rapport or you don't," Streisand says. "You share the same kind of feelings about life and politics and whatever. And we just became instant friends. We talk about everything. We talk about love, relationships, a lot of politics."
They also talk a lot about the difficulties of being powerful women in men's worlds. "We're vulnerable women in powerful positions," says Streisand. "We're not toughies. And yet we are tough in some ways. I mean we're multifaceted. We're little girls at moments, we're teen-agers and we're grown-ups. And we'd like to be accepted for all those qualities. And the rare person sees through the powerful position and sees you as a woman."
Tough or sweet, hard or soft. The tension is always there for Albright and it is sometimes difficult to find the right balance.
In a way, she is the ultimate independent woman, a mother of three grown daughters with careers and a grandmother of two, who expresses no need or even desire for a man in her life. "There's no way, unless I were married to some truly unusual man who had a whole life of his own, that I could possibly be married," she says. "And there are not a lot of them around."
She resents being asked about it. "There are lots of questions about women that don't come up for men, like 'How do you stand being alone?' " she says, the anger rising in her voice. Albright also feels she is held to a higher standard because she is a woman, a standard that dictates nurturing and soft-edged behavior. "There is this slight sense that women have to be saints or Joan of Arc and it's not always possible," she says.
Albright is particularly thin-skinned when journalists write about how she looks. In the same breath, she says it doesn't matter, but the frustration pours out. "When I work I really work," she says. "I rub my eyes and my makeup comes off and I stick pencils in my hair. So I've given up. If some days my hair doesn't look great or some days I look overdone, so be it. Or if I wear a red suit and one of the female reporters says I look like a fat little red ball, that's her problem."
But in the waiting room at a local television studio in Cleveland, where she is svelte compared with the plus-size models for Liz Claiborne, she pulls the skirt of her red suit away from her hips to show how loose it is. "Twenty pounds since February and still counting." She insists she "wears whatever fits." What fits that day is Givenchy.
It's a long way from Prague, and from her diplomat father, Josef Korbel, who taught her how to think and encouraged her to push herself beyond her limits. When Albright tells the story of her childhood as Marie Jana Korbel, it is her father's story as well: how as a junior officer in the diplomatic corps he watched in horror as the Nazis invaded Czechoslovakia in 1938; how the family survived World War II in Britain; how he went to Belgrade as the Czech Ambassador after the war; how he and his wife, Anna, insisted that Marie Jana leave home at age 10 for a boarding school in Switzerland (where she acquired the name Madeleine); how he might have become foreign minister if the Communists had not seized power.
But the Communists did seize power, in a coup in 1948. Korbel was forced to start over. He and his wife and three children arrived in the United States in 1949 and were eventually granted asylum as displaced persons. He later became dean of the School of International Affairs at the University of Denver and wrote books; Anna worked odd clerical jobs to earn extra money.
Even as a teen-ager, Albright by her own admission was the kind of hard worker who used "colored folders and 13 different colored pens." She won the Rocky Mountain Empire United Nations Contest by reciting all the member countries in alphabetical order and went to Wellesley College on a scholarship.
"Madeleine was the responsible one," says her younger sister, Kathy Silva, a special assistant in the Department of Education. "She was very serious. She's a lot more fun now."
Albright graduated from college with honors in 1959 and three days later married her college sweetheart, Joseph Medill Patterson Albright, the scion of a wealthy newspaper family. He became an important journalist; she became a mother. But that was not enough. Over the next decade, while raising three daughters, she took graduate courses at Columbia University, getting up at 4:30 every morning to work on her doctoral dissertation.
"Daddy reincarnate," Silva calls her.
Some people make their way through bureaucratic thickets by force of intellect. Others bully their way through. Albright builds friendships with the right people. She has played both protegee to powerful men and mentor to younger men and women. She met Senator Edmund S. Muskie, the Maine Democrat, when she worked on his 1972 Presidential campaign, and went on to become his chief legislative assistant. Two years later she went to work in the White House as Congressional liaison for a former professor, the national security adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski. It was a job for someone a decade younger, but Albright had a lot of catching up to do.
In Albright's view, the greatest setback in her life was her divorce. Banished to a "think tank" after the Democrats were ousted from the White House in 1980, her world fell apart after her husband told her that the marriage she thought was perfect was fatally flawed. Even today, she wears the mantle of the spurned woman.
Sitting on an upholstered armchair in the living room of her Georgetown town house, she tells the story as straight and raw as if it just happened: "It was Jan. 13, 1982, the day of the Air Florida crash and a massive snowstorm. At 8 o'clock in the morning and sitting on this very chair was Joe Albright, who said to me, 'This marriage is dead and I'm in love with somebody else.' "
Joe Albright says only: "Madeleine has worked very hard to get where she is and I wish her well. She and I are on cordial terms."
When Albright walked out, he left behind the townhouse, the 370-acre farm in Virginia and a generous investment portfolio. Madeleine Albright was rich but restless. Until Bill Clinton's victory in 1992, she waited in the wings, teaching international relations at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service.
Her students elected her best professor four years in a row; her colleagues regarded her as a capable synthesizer whose passion was politics more than scholarship. "I never thought of myself -- or I was never allowed to think of myself -- as a serious academic," she says. "I came into academia late. I'm not one of the people who wrote great tomes."
Albright made up for that by throwing herself into Democratic politics, decorating her Georgetown salon with the best Democratic thinkers and building up connections along the way. She served as foreign policy adviser to Geraldine Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee in 1984, so it was natural that she became chief foreign policy adviser to Michael Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential nominee four years later. Her later work as president of the Center for National Policy, a nonpartisan research organization, prevented her from working directly for the Clinton campaign. But she had paid her dues. When Clinton promised a Cabinet of diversity that would "look like America," she was ready.
AT THE AIRPORT IN THE Slovak capital of Bratislava, Albright bids a fond farewell to Hillary Clinton. The First Lady goes on to Budapest; Albright plans to drive to Vienna to catch a flight to New York the next morning.
But not before one final news conference. As soon as the First Lady's plane takes off, Albright strides back into the V.I.P. lounge to tell reporters how tough she had been with Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar. It is clearly not an anonymous approach to diplomacy. It is also Secretary of State work.
Clinton has not even been re-elected but Albright and numerous other figures are already jockeying for Christopher's job, should he decide to step down. There is no clear favorite in the Secretary of State sweepstakes; Clinton is likely to choose the person he thinks will help him the most, not necessarily the one he likes the best. And he may decide against making any changes, having told aides recently that he is comfortable with his current team. "It's a jinx to talk about it," he has said.
When Christopher was thinking of leaving nearly two years ago, Clinton sounded out both Colin Powell and Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat, neither of whom was interested. Despite Powell's sharp criticism of Clinton in his memoirs and his endorsement of Dole for President, Clinton is said to consider him a first-rate strategic thinker. Even his views on the use of force are not enough to turn Clinton off. Still, Powell has made clear in private conversations that he is no more interested in the job in a Democratic Administration than he ever was.
Clinton forgave Nunn long ago for opposing his plan to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military, and Nunn has already decided not to run again for the Senate. A centrist who commands respect among Democrats and Republicans on the Hill, Nunn would bring a command of both foreign policy and defense issues and strong views on how to deal with both Russia and China. Then again, Nunn would make an equally attractive candidate as Defense Secretary, a position that some Clinton Administration officials say has been promised to the Director of Central Intelligence, John Deutch, should Perry leave the post.
Of course, Clinton could cast a wider net. In a meeting with the President in December 1994, when Christopher discussed the possibility of resigning, the Secretary brought along a list of possible successors. Powell and Nunn were on the list, along with several others, including George Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader; Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, and one woman -- Albright.
Mitchell had little foreign policy experience in his years in the Senate but is making up for lost time. He spends much of his time as a special negotiator on Northern Ireland and a year ago became chairman of the International Crisis Group, a privately financed organization that works to help prevent conflict around the world.
Talbott has been close to Clinton since they were roommates as Rhodes scholars, but he suffered through a bruising Senate confirmation in 1993 because of columns he wrote for Time magazine. He is more likely to be considered for national security adviser, which does not require Senate confirmation, should Lake move on.
Richard C. Holbrooke, the former Assistant Secretary of State for Europe, was widely touted in the media as a possible successor to Christopher or even Albright after he successfully negotiated the peace settlement in Bosnia. He would bring a Kissingerian toughness to either job and an ability to get things done. But in the Clinton Administration he is considered a bureaucratic bully whose priority is too often to make himself look good at others' expense. Moreover, he and Lake do not get along.
Walter Mondale, the Ambassador to Japan and former Vice President, knows trade issues and Asia policy and would bring major stature to the job. Secretary of Commerce Mickey Kantor is a long shot because of his shallow grounding in national security issues; but he is a friend of the President and would put global economics at the top of his foreign policy agenda.
Then there's Anthony Lake, who is increasingly active in making the Administration's foreign policy and who is also said to covet Christopher's job. Lake's strengths are his intellect and relationship with Clinton. His weaknesses, say friends and critics who work with him, are his penchant for secrecy and his reluctance to delegate authority. As a result, they say, it takes forever to get decisions made.
Curiously, Albright's future may depend almost as much on the Attorney General, Janet Reno, as it does on Warren Christopher. If Reno, who has Parkinson's disease, should leave, and if Clinton decides he needs a woman in a serious, front-line Cabinet post, Albright would have a clear shot at Secretary of State. Besides her reputation as a loyal, energetic and telegenic defender of the faith, she now has the experience of an insider.
On the other hand, many in Washington believe that Clinton could decide to promote Reno's deputy, Jamie Gorelick, to Attorney General and leave Albright at the United Nations.
Albright doesn't deny her interest in becoming Secretary of State; given the public nature of the competition, that would be foolish. "There isn't anybody, I would be willing to say, who has been involved in foreign policy who hasn't thought about the concept," she says over breakfast at the American Ambassador's residence in Vienna. "I always did think it was something that was totally impossible. But I have found it interesting that people at least consider it possible that a woman might be Secretary of State."
Her most obvious weakness is her lack of knowledge or interest in global economic issues. The passion she shows for banning land mines or labeling Saddam Hussein a war criminal deserts her in debates on stealing intellectual property or eliminating tariffs on flat glass.
In addition, she is regarded as a good firefighter who deals capably with individual crises but has yet to prove herself as a broad strategic thinker. But policy is made in the doing, not the thinking. And even some Republicans admit that she might make a pretty good Secretary of State.
"She represents the best instincts of this Administration on foreign policy," says Paul Wolfowitz, dean of the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University, an adviser to the Dole campaign and a contender for Secretary of State in a Dole administration. "Unfortunately she often doesn't get the support she should. I think good solid instincts would go a long way in improving the performance of this Administration. Clinton could do a lot worse than make Madeleine Secretary of State."
Albright has another surprising ally -- Jeane Kirkpatrick. As a chairwoman of Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, Kirkpatrick also has a chance to become the first female Secretary of State. "I never thought there would be two women even remotely being mentioned as Secretary of State," Kirkpatrick says. "I hope if Bill Clinton is re-elected, he'll appoint Madeleine. I'd like to see a woman in the job."
But if the President is re-elected and asks Albright to stay just where she is, she promises she will, no complaints. "It is way beyond any of my dreams," she says about her place in life. "God willing, it will all go on."
