HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Asian Investment Is on the Rise in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
JAPANESE investment in the top hotels and office towers in Los Angeles soared during the 1980's and then crashed with the real estate market in the early 1990's. Now, Asian investment is once again increasing, mainly from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Indonesia, driven partly by bargain real estate prices here and political uncertainty at home.
In the last three years, Asian-based companies have bought at least 15 buildings in the Los Angeles area, each priced at more than $10 million, according to the Financial Capital Investment Company, which helps Asians buy American property. Analysts and Asian buyers say these transactions -- which the company says total nearly $450 million -- reflect Asia's growing prosperity and a belief that Southern California's struggling commercial property market has hit bottom. 
 For instance, a Hong Kong-based syndicate, B. W. Hotels, bought the luxury Regent Beverly Wilshire in February for a reported $100 million. The landmark 275-room, 12-story Beverly Hills hotel, featured in the film "Pretty Woman," is near the chic shopping street Rodeo Drive.
"We think Los Angeles has turned around in hospitality," said Ambrose Cheung, president of B. W. Hotels. "It is now on the upswing. We think the real estate situation is positive. It's about coming in at the right time."
For years, Taiwanese entrepreneurs have been major investors in small-scale projects like shopping centers, warehouses and apartment buildings in the Los Angeles area, and they typically have focused on those communities with a large Asian presence. But Randall J. Lee, an Asian economic consultant with Lilly Enterprises here, said the new wave of Asian investment was increasingly of a larger scale.
"We are going to continue to see the mom-and-pop guys buying the small shopping centers," Mr. Lee said. "But we are beginning to see the bigger players, their equivalent of Goldman Sachs."
In the Chinese style, many investors are low profile, which makes tracking sales difficult, said Richard Alter, managing director of Financial Investment Capital. He said investors typically formed a syndicate, paid in cash and focused on second-tier properties like midsize office towers and business-class hotels that do not draw as much attention or attract as much competitive bidding.
"We try to go after some properties that the big Wall Street firms would not go after," Mr. Alter said. "Size makes a difference. We go for commercially viable properties, but not the Statue of Liberty. We don't want to pay for the marquee value."
Real estate brokers and Asian investors here say the recent interest in Los Angeles real estate is partly a product of confidence in Southern California's improving economy and partly an example of bottom fishing. Investors are capitalizing on real estate values that are down nearly 50 percent from their peak in the late 1980's after years of recession coupled with cutbacks in the defense sector.
Despite the city's budding recovery, downtown is suffering from a glut of office space and hotel rooms. Office vacancy rates downtown have hovered near 20 percent for some time, according to the Los Angeles County Economic Development office, while the area's hotel occupancy is 59.9 percent for the year through June, according to PKF Consulting, a hotel industry advisory service.
ON the other hand, downtown is regarded as having a solid market base since there are only a few convention-sized hotels. And the city's center is being considered as a site for a new sports arena, which could help revitalize the area.
"Asian buyers are getting great bargains on all these properties and they sense that there is great economic potential here," said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the county's economic development office.
Those companies selling big properties bought during the boom years are generally losing millions of dollars in the process. In a few cases, the losers are Japanese companies, part of a multibillion-dollar divestment of their American assets.
For example, TAT Los Angeles Ltd., one such Japanese company, bought the ornate, 11-story, 683-room Biltmore Hotel and its adjoining 22-story office tower for a reported $219 million in 1989 and then sold it in June to Hong Kong-based Regal Hotels at a 70 percent loss. Many Japanese companies bought American property with borrowed money, and now their banks are demanding payment.
Peter Zen, a director of the Taiwan-based Forward Time Corporation, which paid nearly $50 million last year for Los Angeles' largest hotel, the 1,368-room, glass-faced Westin Bonaventure Hotel and Suites, said property in Los Angeles is relatively inexpensive compared with many Asian cities. He said land in Los Angeles could cost only $300 a square foot, versus $2,000 a square foot in Taipei.
Moreover, he said, many Asian investors regarded the United States as a safe haven for capital, especially in light of recent events in their home countries. For instance, Indonesian protesters clashed with the police in Jakarta in July. At the same time, Taiwan is frequently swept by fears of invasion from China and the British colony of Hong Kong is 10 months from reintegration with mainland China.
"The United States is a country where you don't have to worry about expropriation, or that the government is going to topple every day," Mr. Zen said.
But, he added, there is a trade-off to investing in Los Angeles versus Bangkok or Kuala Lumpur. Profits are generally lower in Los Angeles, and its land values are expected to increase much more slowly than in Asia's prospering cities.
"You can't compare Los Angeles to the Far East, where you have a lot of upside," Mr. Zen said. "Here, it's very stable. You turn out some earnings every year."
Asian companies often do not get involved with the demands of owning industrial space, and instead focus on office towers and hotels, which are considered to be easier to operate. Frequently, Asians hire an American company to manage the property.
Since profiting from significant short-term property appreciation in Los Angeles is unlikely, many Asian buyers say they have a longer-term commitment to their acquisitions, at least for the near future. As a result, many investors plan property improvements to attract business.
FOR example, the Biltmore Hotel, built in 1922, will get a $10 million to $20 million renovation. The Regent Beverly Wilshire will get 100 new suites on five vacant floors in roughly 18 months.
"Suites, bungalows and villas are in very high demand," Mr. Cheung said. "These are the rooms that can command a very high rate from the entertainment, performing arts, and fashion industries."
Asian real estate buyers generally cited an increasing familiarity with the United States, either through their own education here or that of their children, as a major investment factor. Asian companies are focusing most of their purchases on New York and North America's major Pacific cities, all of which are easily reached from Asia and have large Asian communities. Los Angeles County's Asian population in 1995 was estimated at 907,000 by the state Department of Finance.
"These investors go where there are more Asians and more infrastructure," Mr. Alter said. "That makes them more comfortable than in Salt Lake City or Cleveland."
Mr. Lee said investment in Los Angeles real estate should increase as wealth spreads to more Asian countries. In particular, he said companies from mainland China, some of which have already participated in a few medium-sized deals in Los Angeles, should be a growing source of capital.
"A lot of people don't realize that there is a lot of wealth being created in China," Mr. Lee said. "Before it was the government people, now it's the entrepreneurs."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1080 words

HEADLINE: Why Are We in Korea?

BYLINE: By Frank Gibney; Frank Gibney is the president of the Pacific Basin Institute. His most recent books on Asia are "Korea's Quiet Revolution" and "Senso: The Japanese Remember the Pacific War."

 BODY:

TRIPWIRE
Korea and U.S. Foreign Policy in a Changed World.
By Doug Bandow.
255 pp. Washington:
Cato Institute. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.
Through all the public soul searching about America's post-cold-war security responsibilities, one commitment has gone generally unchallenged: to maintain a United States military presence on the Korean peninsula. At the moment this presence amounts to 37,000 troops on the ground in the Republic of Korea, along with air and naval support. The troops are there, as they have been since the 1953 Korean War armistice, for both real and symbolic purposes. Any attack by North Korea on the South will automatically engage the United States. 
 The reasoning behind this commitment is straightforward enough. The so-called People's Republic of Korea, even shorn of its former Russian and Chinese allies, and even with its economy disintegrating, remains a rogue country, a danger to peace in the region. At least a portion of Pyongyang's Stalinist high command seems interested in working out some kind of peaceful coexistence with its neighbors, but the next moves of the militarist clique that probably runs the country remain unpredictable. And the military card is all that they have left to play.
Worst of all, Seoul, the capital and nerve center of the Republic of Korea, with a population of 12 million, is a hostage to geography. Barely 30 miles from the border, it sits almost within artillery range of the North Koreans. In the last analysis the prospect of immediate American retaliation is probably the one factor that the isolated satraps in Pyongyang -- when they think of a military gamble -- cannot ignore.
Not so, writes Doug Bandow in "Tripwire." A senior fellow at the aggressively libertarian Cato Institute, Mr. Bandow has visited both North and South Korea and obviously spent a great deal of time studying fact and opinion on the subject. The American military presence below the 38th-parallel boundary, he argues, "provides a dramatic example of an antiquated commitment kept alive only by the artificial life support of political elites in their respective nations' capitals." With its high-growth gross national product, an estimated 18 times larger than the North's, South Korea should be big and strong enough to handle the North Koreans on its own.
Cold war conditions may once have justified a strong American security presence in Korea, Japan and elsewhere in the region, but the world has changed, Mr. Bandow insists, and yesterday's security assets are today's "fiscal black holes." Military outlays in Asia cost Americans $40 billion annually, while saving defense money for Asian allies who are also our economic competitors. Even if Kim Jong Il's troops invaded the South, they would pose "no credible military threat" to the United States.
But withdrawal from Korea -- and then Japan -- is only the beginning for Mr. Bandow. With the Soviet threat gone, he advocates abandoning a "globalist foreign policy" that badly distorts the American political system by "encouraging the growth of a large, expensive, repressive, secretive and often uncontrolled state." Instead, he wants a new military strategy of what he calls "benign detachment."
"Lace-curtain Buchananism" might be a better phrase for it. Like the redoubtable Pat, Mr. Bandow wants to build up Fortress America now that the Russians (maybe) are gone. Yet in treating our military role in Asia as a transitory cold war phenomenon, he overlooks the fact that the United States has been a Pacific power since the days of Commodore Perry and Admiral Dewey. However much we may talk about the primacy of economics, American power remains the ultimate guarantor of Pacific Basin prosperity.
In discussing Korea, for example, Mr. Bandow hugely underestimates the catastrophe for the region that would result from a North Korean attack on Seoul, even assuming that the good guys win in the end. He also neglects to inform us that Seoul's exposed border location resulted from an American -- not a Korean -- political decision to refrain from pushing the cease-fire line another 40 or 50 miles up to the narrow waist of the peninsula. This the United Nations forces could have accomplished in 1951 or 1952, after the Chinese advance had been turned back. But that was before the Republican Presidential candidate, Dwight D. Eisenhower, told the voters that a Republican Administration would make peace in Korea, come what may, after the 1952 election. (George Bush's failure to press the gulf war advantage had ample precedent.)
Mr. Bandow may trip over his own wire on the here and now of Korea, but he makes a great many other points worthy of attention. He rightly reminds us that despite sweeping changes in East Asia's economy and politics, "America's troop deployments . . . seem set in concrete." Asian countries are not American military protectorates. They make up their own minds, and their voters can get quite angry. Fifty years after the end of World War II, almost half of Okinawa's land is still an off-limits preserve of the American military -- and one bitterly resented. For their part, Seoul residents have long tired of the booze-and-bar-girl resorts of the Eighth Army in Itaewon.
CHANGES in Asia over the past half-century surely require a rethinking of our security needs. Sadly, this has yet to be done. Any new appraisal would no doubt be far from Mr. Bandow's total disengagement policy, but would certainly include drastic American troop redeployments, joint use of bases and a sharp reduction in exclusive military preserves. The antiquated cold war security treaties with both Japan and Korea would be replaced by the beginnings of a new regional security pact in which each country (Japan notably included) provides its share of the military muscle. Other countries might be invited to join -- including China, despite its current truculence. (After all, we once asked the Russians to join the Marshall Plan.) Yet a visible American presence must remain if we expect any such pact to work.
In Korea, the chances for an ultimate peaceful settlement, if not reunification of the sundered peninsula, are probably better now than they ever were, thanks to the near-bankrupt condition of the North, politically and economically. Pyongyang has few options left. When and if an agreement is reached, the great majority of the Eighth Army's troops in Korea should start packing. But not a moment before.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: TRIPWIRE (BOOK)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 35; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1099 words

HEADLINE: The 40 Years' War

BYLINE: By Stephen Kotkin; Stephen Kotkin, the director of Russian studies at Princeton University, is the author of "Magnetic Mountain: Stalinism as a Civilization."

 BODY:

INSIDE THE KREMLIN'S COLD WAR
From Stalin to Khrushchev.
By Vladislav Zubok and Constantine Pleshakov.
Illustrated. 346 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $29.95.
For 40-odd years the cold war shaped American life. Then came Chernobyl, the breach in the Berlin wall and, in December 1991, the lowering of the hammer and sickle from the Kremlin. As Americans witnessed the other side's capitulation, hopes were kindled that newly released Soviet documents might finally resolve the nagging riddle of what had brought about the costly confrontation. Vladislav Zubok and Constantine Pleshakov have made one of the long-awaited forays into the Soviet archives. They emerge with "Inside the Kremlin's Cold War," an analysis that is constructed around a series of biographies and that hints at possible missed opportunities. 
 Mr. Zubok, a senior fellow at the National Security Archive in Washington, and Mr. Pleshakov, the director of the Pacific Studies Center at the Institute of U.S. and Canada Studies in Moscow, describe tantalizing memorandums prepared for Stalin during World War II by high-level Soviet diplomats. Internally, these specialists advocated not world conquest but a partnership with the United States and Britain to prevent Germany's resurgence and to assist in the Soviet Union's reconstruction. They also recommended exploiting the differences between the two capitalist powers. Examining Stalin's statements at Yalta and his subsequent actions in Turkey, Greece, Iran, China and Japan against the diplomats' memorandums, the authors surmise that the Soviet leader heeded his minions' advice. Stalin "wanted to avoid confrontation with the West," they suggest, because he "believed in the inevitability of a postwar economic crisis of the capitalist economy and of clashes within the capitalist camp that would provide him with a lot of space for geopolitical maneuvering in Europe and Asia -- all within the framework of general cooperation."
But in a belligerent speech in February 1946, Stalin seemed to reverse himself. With the death of Franklin Roosevelt and the stunning (for Stalin) election defeat of Winston Churchill, the Soviet leader had lost the partners whose company made him feel respected. Even then, documents indicate, Stalin almost reached a modus vivendi with Harry Truman at Potsdam. Between deliberations, however, Truman dropped word about the successful test of a new bomb, which he soon exploded at Hiroshima, aggravating the suspicious Stalin's fears of a double-cross.
Could the whole mess have been America's fault? It would seem that whatever its implications for the war with Japan, the bomb was used "at the worst possible moment" for relations with the Soviet Union. But the authors also assert that Russian imperialism and Marxist globalism "predestined" Soviet expansionism. They contend that Stalin's obsession with Alexander I's prominence during and after the Congress of Vienna in 1815, following the defeat of Napoleon by a coalition of nations, goaded him to preserve the coalition that subdued Hitler; at the same time they argue that Stalin's distrustfulness predestined him to a fallout with his capitalist confederates. No wonder American officials had trouble reading the situation. A declaration of cold war imposed a certain clarity and sense of mission, yet uncertainties persisted.
After Stalin died in 1953, two aspirants, Lavrenti Beria and Georgi Malenkov, favored moving away from ideology and global confrontation, according to Mr. Zubok and Mr. Pleshakov, precisely because, as overseers of the military-industrial complex, they understood the Soviet Union's vulnerabilities and the suicidal dangers of nuclear war. But Beria faced a firing squad and Malenkov lost a power struggle to Nikita Khrushchev, a romantic revolutionary who could not resist the summons to third-world liberation -- manifest in his attachment to Castro's Cuba. Khrushchev viewed this attachment as a revival of the promise of the Russian Revolution rather than an overreaching that sacrificed relations with the West and billions of rubles in exchange for grapefruit, beach vacations and elan. For Khrushchev much more than for Stalin, the authors say, Communist ideology proved to be a delusion.
Sketches of Vyacheslav Molotov, a ruthless defender of Soviet interests, and Andrei Zhdanov, a brutal ideologue out of the loop, fill in the book's focus on personalities. But readers may wonder whether individuals, even in a dictatorship, determine and implement policy as they see fit. Moreover, in puzzling through the minds behind the Kremlin's volatile mix of ideological proselytism and geopolitical pragmatism, the authors have relied at least as much on intuition as on new sources. That is because except for a few episodes -- the onset of the Korean War, revolts in Eastern Europe -- the decisive documents, including the working papers of the Politburo and Stalin's immense personal archive, remain under lock and key. Declassified second-tier materials illuminate policy making inside the Foreign Ministry, but cast predominantly indirect light on the Soviet leadership's aims and motivations.
A mostly engaging pastiche, this book can perhaps best be appreciated as unwitting testimony on Communism's collapse. When Mr. Zubok and Mr. Pleshakov observe that "the gallery of portraits of Soviet 'statesmen' in the cold war pales in comparison with the one of American and West European 'wise men,' " and that "there is no one on the Soviet side to praise," they betray the despair that gripped the former Soviet Union's educated elites. Both authors, baby boomers far removed from the Revolution, rose to coveted posts at a prestigious yet "infinitely cynical think tank." Serving a system their superiors scorned, both defected intellectually before the final crisis struck. Now they are exorcising demons.
Mr. Zubok and Mr. Pleshakov topple Stalin from his statesman's pedestal. "Stalin's postwar foreign policy was more defensive, reactive and prudent than it was the fulfillment of a master plan," they conclude. "Yet instead of postponing a confrontation with the United States . . . he managed to draw closer to it with every step," bequeathing an unbearable burden. In the book's last line, the authors proclaim that the nightmare has ended, that Stalin and his followers are dead and that the Kremlin will never again pursue revolutionary imperialism. But if the still-enigmatic cold war has taught anything, it is that the course of Russian foreign policy does not depend on Russia alone.

HEADLINE: Grandchildren of the New Deal

BYLINE: By James M. McPherson; James M. McPherson's most recent books are "What They Fought For, 1861-1865" and "Drawn With the Sword: Reflections on the American Civil War."

 BODY:

THE INHERITANCE
How Three Families and America Moved From Roosevelt to Reagan and Beyond.
By Samuel G. Freedman.
Illustrated. 464 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $27.50.
IN his State of the Union address on Jan. 23, President Clinton proclaimed, "The era of big government is over." This announcement, according to Samuel G. Freedman, acknowledged "the profound political transformation wrought by conservative Republicans. So drastically have politicians from Goldwater to Reagan to Gingrich shifted the electoral center to the right that in both of Clinton's Presidential campaigns the Democrat has sought to appropriate traditionally Republican issues and rhetoric." Mr. Freedman's purpose in "The Inheritance: How Three Families and America Moved From Roosevelt to Reagan and Beyond," a fascinating and occasionally frustrating book, is to explain how and why this "rise and fall" of the "New Deal dynasty" occurred. 
 The New Deal coalition that dominated American politics for nearly half a century fused the one-party white-supremacist South awkwardly and incongruously with a Northern blend of patrician elites, labor unions, Roman Catholics, Jews and African-Americans. The coalition's downfall resulted from the mass exodus of Southern whites and Catholics from Irish, Italian and Polish backgrounds. It is the Catholic defection that most interests Mr. Freedman, whose last book was "Upon This Rock: The Miracles of a Black Church." In 1980, a majority of Catholic voters cast Republican Presidential ballots. And in 1994, a majority of Catholics voted Republican in a Congressional election for the first time. Catholics accounted for one-third of the total vote in 1994 while constituting less than one-quarter of the population. "The Catholic exodus from the New Deal coalition," Mr. Freedman writes, "has now reshaped Congress."
The author's vehicle for tracing this transformation is a narrative of three families over three generations, from the time Al Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt were prominent in New York State politics to the time of Alfonse D'Amato and George Pataki. Each family -- one Irish, one Italian and one Polish -- clawed its way up from immigrant tenements in New York and Baltimore or wrong-side-of-the tracks cottages in New Rochelle and Ossining to suburbs, college and respectability by the third generation. The first-generation progenitors were a plumber, a domestic and a numbers runner. Three of their grandchildren met in the 1970's at the State University of New York, Albany, where they were active in Republican politics, heading for careers as a campaign manager, election lawyer and fund-raiser. With parents and grandparents of unshakable Democratic loyalty, these three -- Tim Carey, Frank Trotta and Leslie Maeby (whose grandfather was named Joseph Obrycki) -- became part of the New Right of the 70's.
Mr. Freedman interweaves their stories with incisive analyses of political campaigns, mainly in New York State. The reader follows the first two generations through the precarious prosperity of the 20's and the devastating poverty of the 30's, when emergency relief, the W.P.A. and Franklin Roosevelt were the only things that warded off starvation and despair. World War II, the G.I. Bill and the postwar economic boom set them back on their feet, still loyal Democrats. But by the 60's and 70's the third generation had broken the mold.
What happened? In a few words: a backlash against the extremes of the civil rights movement and against the countercultural opposition to the Vietnam War. Brought up in families that professed a strong work ethic, self-help, sexual restraint and marital responsibility, and a meritocracy of achievement, these third-generation white Americans reacted in shock and anger to race riots, black power, affirmative action, "welfare queens," limousine liberals who supported busing to achieve racial balance and sent their own children to private schools, antiwar protesters safe in their college exemptions from the draft who burned the American flag that had meant freedom and opportunity to their grandparents.
Frank Trotta worked part time all through high school, where he graduated as valedictorian, and worked to put himself through college at SUNY Albany, where he saw minority students on full scholarship who seemed to have more money and leisure time than he did. He wondered, Mr. Freedman writes: "In a college devoted to meritocracy, why did his own merit languish unrewarded?" In 1967, as a 20-year-old draftee, Tim Carey helped guard the Pentagon against assaults by antiwar protesters from Yale, Amherst and other bastions of privilege. "He could barely contain the disbelief, the near hatred, that those fortunate sons should attack American soldiers, should attack him, for bearing the burden they shirked." When they looked at the political system, these young people perceived the Democrats as coddling blacks and hippie anarchists. America had made a wrong turn. So they became Republicans.
Much of this is a well-known tale. But Mr. Freedman gives it a human face in richly detailed life stories with empathy for all sides in this complex human and political drama. There is no cheap condemnation of "racism" here; there is a sympathetic understanding of the social forces that drove the civil rights and antiwar movements to excess. There is also a finely honed sense of irony. Many of those who turned against welfare in the 70's had parents or grandparents who got through the Depression only with the help of relief and the W.P.A. Those in the third generation who deplored "big government" and voted for Ronald Reagan came from families that could not have moved to the suburbs and bought a house without the Federal highway program, the G.I. Bill and Veterans Administration mortgages.
The very richness of detail in "The Inheritance," however, carries some liabilities. The narrative is often disjointed, jumping from one family to another and backward or forward in time by a decade or more. So many uncles, aunts, siblings, cousins and in-laws enter the story by the second and third generations that the cast resembles the Admiralty in "H.M.S. Pinafore." The reader needs a scorecard to tell the players; indeed, a scorecard in the form of genealogical tables or family trees would have been a valuable addition.
One substantive omission from "The Inheritance" is any discussion of the gender gap. The existence of such a gap is implicit in Mr. Freedman's narrative. Although one of these third-generation new Republicans (Leslie Maeby) is a woman, the female relatives in the story are more likely than the men to remain Democrats. White male anger clearly played an important part in the transition analyzed here, while women were less affected by events that caused this anger. Yet there is no discussion -- indeed not even a mention -- of this significant distinction.
Another omission is perhaps equally important. In his foreword, Mr. Freedman promises to show how the Catholics represented by these three families "made and unmade the Democratic majority." He has fulfilled that promise -- for the suburbs and urban neighborhoods in the North where these groups mostly live and vote. But what of the South? The book contains two or three passing references to the Sun Belt but virtually nothing about the Old South. Yet that region is the main locus of Reagan Democrats and the Gingrich revolution. For three-quarters of a century the South was solid for the Democrats. Now it is almost as solid for the Republicans. That is the real story of the making and unmaking of the Democratic majority.
Samuel Freedman would probably acknowledge as much, but would insist that a reviewer should review the book he wrote, not a book he didn't write. I agree, and I salute the timely, incisive and engrossing book he has written. But the reader should be aware that in this account of three emblematic families and "their estrangement from the welfare state that once had sustained them," "The Inheritance" does not tell the whole story of how "America moved from Roosevelt to Reagan and beyond."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1259 words

HEADLINE: An Ordinary Bigot

BYLINE: By Phyllis Rose; Phyllis Rose has completed a memoir, "The Year of Reading Proust."

 BODY:

ABOUT SCHMIDT
By Louis Begley.
274 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $23.
Some of Western literature's most resonant works, including "King Lear" and Henry James's novel "The Spoils of Poynton," concern the transfer of property from one generation to the next. The issues raised by inheritance -- the limits to love between parents and children, the fading but still formidable power of the parents, the almost inevitable ingratitude of the children as they pursue their own goals, the new alliances and potential betrayals involved in any marriage -- touch all of us, whether we have a kingdom or splendid British country house to pass on or only some precious, albeit worthless, family tchotchkes. In Louis Begley's fine new novel, "About Schmidt," the property at issue is a house in the Hamptons, and although most readers might salivate at the prospect of owning such a house, inherited by Albert Schmidt from his wife's maiden aunt, his daughter -- wouldn't you know? -- would rather spend her weekends upstate, and her fiance worries about the upkeep. Schmidt is a buttoned-up, emotionally deprived man who has recently lost his wife, Mary, on whom he depended for his social life. A meticulous corporate lawyer, known for drafting elegant contracts, he retired early in order to care for her in her final illness. Now he is lonely, adrift and at odds with his only child, Charlotte, who, in addition to having bewilderingly turned into a yuppie he can't completely like (she does public relations on behalf of tobacco companies), has announced that she will marry a man he completely dislikes, a partner in Schmidt's firm -- a nerd, a bankruptcy maven, a Jew. For yes, even though his best friend is Jewish and considers his anti-Semitism "innocuous, one might almost say irrelevant," "Schmidtie" is an anti-Semite. 
 Mr. Begley is too fastidious to make Schmidt likable, as though to elicit sympathy for him would then be too easy. How much greater the literary accomplishment to make us pity, understand, even identify with someone we have permission to write off.
 Mr. Begley, who is a lawyer as well as a novelist, made his stunning literary debut with "Wartime Lies," a novel about a Jewish boy hiding from the Nazis, passing for Christian. This new novel could be called "Peacetime Truths," not only for the way it touches on "innocuous" anti-Semitism but because its protagonist is "an odd stickler for the truth," who, for example, feeling no affection for his prospective son-in-law, makes no pretense of affection in the slightest degree, even to the young man's mother. Whereas "Wartime Lies" explored duplicity and imposture, "About Schmidt" presents a determined search for accuracy in emotion, as the widower and retiree moves into a new phase of life, the last.
 Much as he wants to think that he is acting out of generosity in transferring his life interest in the Bridgehampton house to his daughter as a wedding present, Schmidt has to admit to himself that it is done partly "to avoid the duty I would feel to treat my married daughter and her husband as co-owners." So: the selfishness within generosity, the distaste mingled with parental love, the promiscuity that coexists with the deepest marital devotion. "About Schmidt" gets at them all.
 Sometimes the truth-telling can be hard to take, like this, on women's aging: "It seemed to Schmidt that loss of the ability to attract was an affliction as generalized among his female coevals as thinness of hair, the sclera and teeth turned yellow, sour breath, flaccidity or gigantism of breasts, midriffs gone soft and distended by wind, brown blotches and deltas of minute angry veins around the knee and on the calf, disastrous, swollen toes verging on deformity displayed in sandals or throbbing in the prison of black pumps. To tease Mary, he used to tell her what, in fact, he thought was the truth: that his own loss of libido, from the effects of which she was exempt . . . had less to do with his own aging than with the aging of the women around him."
 (It's a minor flaw in the novel that Schmidt, at 60, seems too young to be carrying on so about age, and too old -- the same goes for his Jewish film-maker pal and quondam college roommate -- to be so attractive to women in their 20's. If their young girlfriends exist to prove these men aren't as old as they think, it doesn't work. One geriophilic young woman per novel might be credible. Not two.)
 Whatever you think of him, Schmidt is remarkable for his clarity of mind. Why, he asks himself, should he give up alcohol, tobacco, cheese, red meat and eggs, for the sake of a longevity whose pleasures were unknown? As it was, "it seemed reasonable to stick to his agreeable, life-shortening habits, perhaps even to acquire new ones." In a crucial scene, Charlotte, on the telephone, distressed at feeling she has to reject both the wedding party and the house her father has been offering, attacks him, saying that according to her fiance, Schmidt's whole firm had considered him an anti-Semite. In a peacemaking effort, her mother-in-law-to-be, a psychiatrist, calls Schmidt to explain that Charlotte's inappropriate aggressive behavior had been caused by her guilt. But Schmidt only wants to know: did her aggressiveness consist of telling the truth or telling a lie? Did his partners really consider him anti-Semitic?
 This book exists at a point where the dry probity of a certain high-WASP temperament and the dry secular spirit in Judaism meet. It resolutely refuses transcendence. The temperature never goes up. The pitch never varies. You never feel you are being manipulated into a falsely emotional response. You can trust it as you trust a well-wrought contract: it keeps its affect entirely under control. It never tries to mean more than it says -- in fact, tries strenuously not to. This, to me, is the great pleasure of reading Louis Begley. His exceptional literary intelligence is always in control, making me wonder if more novelists shouldn't develop the virtues of lawyers as writers: accuracy, economy, abjuring the language of emotion.
 Quietly, the novel gains power as it continues. A deep underlying pessimism comes more often to the surface. "All lives end badly," Schmidt believes, and if a certain couple seems happy, it's because their lives "had not yet been broken. Their time would come." Ultimately, all books about inheritance are about Heraclitean flow. The river of life moves on. Things change. Poynton burns. The Hamptons aren't what they used to be. People we expect to die don't, and those we don't expect to die do. Wills reveal intentions we never suspected. Schmidt's new woman is a Puerto Rican waitress younger than his daughter. And so unpredictable is the current that things end well for him. The final events of the novel remind us, cleverly and wisely, that every older generation was once a younger generation, that every generation, no matter how loving or beloved, by its very existence poses problems for the generation, parental or filial, with which it is inextricably linked.
 Consistently subtle and intelligent, this novel ends by getting under your skin despite the unlikability of its protagonist. You are left with the feeling of having found out the complex truth behind the impeccable facade of someone you might never notice if you met him at a party -- someone, on the other hand, you might just know or be, an ordinary person with ordinary problems, even if he does have a retirement income of some $330,000 a year.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1902 words

HEADLINE: Balloons and Baskets, Riders on the Wind

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
IT was another miserable morning in Plainville. The fog was thick and close to the ground. At Norton Park, several hundred sleepy-eyed spectators watched anxiously as a score of gaudily-colored canvas mastodons stood motionless, waiting for the sky to clear.
Robert Zirpolo had waited long enough. The morning before, just like this day, he had awakened before dawn and driven from his home in Cheshire in his van, the one with the license plate reading "AIRHED," only to have an unseasonable drizzle ruin his plans. There was no precipitation this time, just the mist, spread out in all directions as far as the eye could see. The flight ceiling was estimated at 200 feet. 
 That would have to do. Mr. Zirpolo beckoned his passengers into the basket where he stood, while he pumped hundreds of B.T.U.'s worth of energy into the balloon, a canvas envelope above him, by tugging on twin propane-fueled burners just above his head. Huge jets of flame shot into the mouth of the envelope until the basket began to rise.
The flight lasted 15 minutes, and the craft ascended a mere 600 feet. That was sufficient to get above the fog, but also to lose sight of all land features save the ridgeline of Meriden Mountain, poking out of the cottony vapor like Everest's peak. "It's all mashed potatoes up here," Mr. Zirpolo grumbled before making a landing near an empty parking lot. As soon as the basket was back on its trailer and the canvas envelope bound up inside the van, Mr. Zirpolo was zooming off, in search of propane fuel for another run. Like politicians, balloonists make a living riding ever-shifting winds and making a lot of hot air. Occasionally they too can get lost in the clouds. Finally, inevitably, they come to earth, except in the case of balloonists, this is done intentionally, at least most of the time.
Ballooning is a tough avocation in Connecticut. The long coastline, rolling hills, and woodland expanses all play havoc with the plans of even the best pilots, as does the sprawl of urbanization. Finding a safe place to land amid power lines and condominium complexes can be tricky.
Then there's Mother Nature. Mark Twain once observed that "one of the brightest gems in the New England weather is the dazzling uncertainty of it." Leo Tetreault, a balloonist from Manchester, concurs: "You have a hundred percent chance of weather every day."
That may be one reason why there are not a lot of balloonists in Connecticut. A definitive count is hard to get, but estimates vary between three to five dozen. Many of them are concentrated in central part of the state.
Despite their often competing to sell "champagne flights" -- aerial tours to paying customers that are the balloonist's main objective -- Connecticut balloon pilots seem a tight-knit group in settings like a rally. It is a brotherhood and sisterhood of rising before the sun, hunting down propane tankers, and savoring the exhilaration that arrives with watching the shadow of one's own craft blot the landscape 2,000 feet below.
This year has been a particularly good example of how a balloonist's life can be made miserable by the weather. A long, snowy winter belatedly gave way to a brief spring, and then a stormy summer. Balloonists console themselves by noting there is still fall, which while traditionally rainy is also the peak period for champagne flights. People come from other states to take in the majesty of Connecticut's foliage change from above.
"It's especially marvelous in a slow-moving craft, where you can get down in those leaves in a basket," said Kathy Wadsworth, a commercial pilot from Farmington. "Weatherwise, it's very tricky, but visually, it's spectacular."
Balloons are normally kept airborne for only an hour, and fly only several miles, so it's neither speed nor distance that the pilot is after. "It's the esthetics," said Mike Kirkwood, a pilot from Plainville. "They are colorful, and still mysterious to a lot of people." Flying them also carries its share of mystery. "You don't know where you're going to land, or who you're going to meet," he continued. "If you land on a street, the whole neighborhood might come out to greet you. It's a great way to meet people."
Balloons are at the mercy of the winds, which is one reason pre-dawn and late-afternoon launches are the rule. In the middle of the day, the sun heats up the ground and creates dangerous thermal pressures. The ideal balloon flight is a slow one, with plenty of time for sightseeing and a soft landing.
Tolerant landowners are also a boon. Most people in Connecticut tend to enjoy the spectacle of a balloon, even as it sets down on their property. Dale Martin, one of the Plainville firefighters who puts on the hot-air balloon festival there, said people in the area are receptive to balloons most of the time, even though they are a fairly common sight during weekends. "If a balloon lands in your backyard, it's an event."
Steve Ushchak, a carpenter and farmer from Cheshire who heads Mr. Zirpolo's chase crew, carries a map with him that delineates all the properties within a several-mile radius of a given spot. A few of these properties are marked in red, meaning their owners are known not to want balloons landing there.
He notes stories of landowners threatening balloonists with shotguns and even siccing a dog on an earthbound aviator, but he insists that is far from common. "One in a hundred will give you a hard time, and usually that guy is mad at the world."
While some might see ballooning as more spectacle than sport, those associated with the activity say there are actually two tests of ability going on simultaneously in a flight. There is the balloonist, who shifts altitudes seeking the right winds and, finally, a good landing site. Then there is the balloonist's chase crew, on the ground riding a van, trying to keep pace and trying to be where the balloon lands, when it lands.
Mr. Kirkwood got his start crewing for Mr. Zirpolo. "It's a good feeling when you get there ahead of the balloon," he said. "The sport is to get there at the same time without breaking any speed limits. You need to have knowledge of where the winds are going."
Most balloonists use special radios to keep in touch with their chase crews, although Mr. Tetreault said his own crew chief is so accustomed to his ways that radio contact is sometimes not necessary. "He thinks like me," Mr. Tetreault said.
Mr. Tetreault outfits his crew with attention-getting T-shirts emblazoned with the name of his balloon: "Yo Baby." Other crews are less conspicuous but just as dedicated. Like most crewpeople, Mr. Ushchak and his wife, Judith, are not paid for their work. Instead, Mr. Zirpolo is teaching Mr. Ushchak how to fly. "He also helps us with the hay in the spring," Mr. Ushchak said. "All the balloonists help, because we let them land in our field."
There are such things as balloon competitions. Each year, the Balloon Federation of America puts together a series of contests, mostly involving precision flying exercises like getting the closest to a standing pole or chasing another balloon. They culminate in the National Hot Air Balloon Championship, currently held in Missouri.
Other favored sites for B.F.A.-sanctioned competitions include Colorado and the West Coast, which helps explain why not many Connecticut balloonists are to be found there. Sharon Ripperger, a federation official, said she could find only eight balloonists from Connecticut registered with their competition division.
One of the few Connecticut balloonists who does actively compete is Paul Morlock of Newtown, a regular in the Nationals from 1984 to 1992 who once ranked among the top 100 balloonists in the nation. While he still managed a respectable showing earlier this year in Battle Creek, Mr. Morlock no longer competes regularly.
"I'd love to, but you have to have the money," he said. "Most of the biggest ones have sponsorships."
Another Connecticut balloonist who has received national recognition is Ms. Wadsworth. In the 1970's, she and her then-husband, Brian Boland, set several altitude and endurance records with the AX-1, the smallest balloon model with only 9,000 square feet of envelope capacity. While those records have since been broken, she notes they were among the first to experiment with the design, building a craft that, among other things, is easier to pack and unpack.
Like many other champagne flight providers in Connecticut, Ms. Wadsworth owns her own company, KAT Balloons, Inc. She has been doing it longer than most, however, 22 years.
"I like the idea of being able to get up in the sky from my backyard," she said. "It's the simplest form of flying. You can't want to go anywhere. You just got to accept the conditions. There are different elements that you are dealing with, and you've got to use them to your advantage. It's like a chess game."
There is little good money to be made in ballooning, its practitioners say. Economic and meteorological reasons are partially to blame, but so too is a glut in the market. Mike Bollea of Farmington noted there are 10 balloonists within a five-mile radius of him, and that most of them, like himself, are commercial.
"People price around," he said. "They might ask you 'How come this guy charges so much less than you?' You might say: 'I wouldn't go up with him, he's not safe.' "
Most commercial pilots tend to have second careers. Mr. Morlock is a builder, for example, while Mr. Tetreault works at the Post Office's vehicle maintenance center in Hartford.
Mr. Kirkwood is in video production. He used to work for ESPN, but quit in 1992 to fly across the United States in a balloon. An acrophobe who still gets uneasy climbing tall ladders, Mr. Kirkwood has soared as high as 18,000 feet in a balloon.
Bruce Byberg is a full-time commercial balloonist who is prospering. One reason is that he has the northeastern corner of the state, Tolland and Windham counties, virtually to himself. Another is that he has commercial sponsors. At Plainville, for example, he was on hand to give tethered rides to children in a balloon bearing the logo of the ReMax real estate agency.
The ReMax balloon is a familiar sight at balloon fairs and other state events, sort of Connecticut's poorer cousin to the Goodyear blimp. Mr. Byberg said as advertising, a balloon can be quite effective. "It's a very friendly way to get your name out there."
There are four major balloon fairs in the state. Next month, Mr. Byberg will be the balloonmeister at the last of them, the Windham Lighter Than Air Festival at Jillison Square in Windham, Oct. 18-20. Admittance is free, but donations will be solicited for the Hole in the Wall Gang camp in Ashford.
Mr. Byberg touted the Windham area as offering the best flying conditions in the state. Not only is there plenty of open farmland available for landings, he said, but the people there still get excited by balloons.
The people at Plainville seemed turned on, too, as the morning wore on and the heavy fog suddenly lifted. In a single moment, 20 balloons filled a blue sky, going toward all points of the compass as they hovered over the craning necks of adults and children alike.
"It's an amusement," Mr. Zirpolo said. "That's all it is. It's not of any use to anyone, except as an amusement. Hopefully it's as much for your amusement as for those you take up."

HEADLINE: Purchase College, the 25-Year-Old Experiment

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
TWENTY-FIVE years ago this month, Purchase College officially opened during a downpour. The rain prevented 10 portable classrooms from being delivered to the unfinished campus, and the first entering class -- 170 third-year students who had transferred from other schools -- met under a tent.
Such plucky coping has been the school's chief mode of operation since 1973, when Nelson A. Rockefeller, whose vision of public higher education is embodied in this arts-oriented branch of the State University, left the Governor's office to become Vice President of the United States. State support dwindled almost immediately, and the college, like other branches of the university, is now struggling to fulfill its mission as a public-private hybrid. 
 Rockefeller was not only personally passionate about the arts -- serving as a trustee of both the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- but he also dared to establish a public college devoted to cultivating arts education at the highest level. He and the administrators he recruited went further than establishing performing arts conservatories and a visual arts faculty, to be buttressed in 1972 by the opening on campus of the Neuberger Museum of Art. They believed aspiring artists should be nurtured by the broad study of science and the humanities, and thus liberal arts became equally important at the school.
Ever since, debate has raged here about how truly to connect the various disciplines, so that economists might comfortably quote from Euripides and painters might find inspiration in Plato's cave. "If we could pull it off, it would be unique in higher education in the public sector, and maybe even in the private," said Bill Lacy, the college's current president. He added that the issue was constantly under discussion.
If Rockefeller did not draw up the marriage contract in detail, he did lay the groundwork for such fertile intermingling, said former college officials involved in the early planning stages of the school. "There's no question that it was his dream, but he had some real help," said John W. Straus, the first dean for administration and the arts. The person primarily responsible for carrying out the dream was the late Dr. Abbott Kaplan, who was recruited from his position as associate dean of the College of Fine Arts of the University of California at Los Angeles to become the first president of Purchase College. Dr. Kaplan also served as chairman of the California Arts Commission.
Dr. Frank W. Wadsworth, a literary scholar who was the first vice president for academic affairs, recently recalled what Dr. Kaplan asked of him in developing a liberal arts curriculum. "The goal," Dr. Wadsworth said, "was a first-rate college experience on a public campus, so people who couldn't go to the Harvards and Wellesleys could get a personalized and independent education. It was an innovative program with an emphasis on independent study in the broadest, most philosophical sense, so that students would take more responsibility for their education than in the usual undergraduate school."
Dr. Wadsworth, who also taught literature here until 1990, recalled the "wild-eyed, anti-everything" students of the early 1970's, whose generation lent spice to Rockefeller's remarks at a ground-breaking ceremony here in 1969: he applauded Dr. Kaplan's courage in taking on the job "at the regular salary, no combat pay."
Those living in the area were at first wary at the prospect of any wild-eyed rebels in their leafy neighborhood, given the roiling passions of antiwar demonstrators and student activists nationwide. Mr. Straus, who was also one of the first members of the Purchase College Foundation, recently recalled that people "were unhappy with the concept that we'd bring these 'crazy' students into the community."
But Strathglass Farm, a 500-acre farm devoted to raising prize-winning Ayrshire cattle, among other things, was being sold by its owner, the paper-manufacturing magnate Hugh Chisholm, and the neighbors decided that a college on the site would be preferable to a housing development, Mr. Straus recalled.
"People began to realize that it was a great opportunity, because there was so much open space left," Mr. Straus said. As designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes, master architect of a team that also included Philip Johnson, Robert Venturi and others, the campus sprawls out of sight of Anderson Hill Road in angular patterns worthy of the painter Chirico.
Students strolling to class on a recent sunny afternoon softened the sharp-edged center mall, which is lined with maple trees and banners heralding the school's 25th anniversary.
The student body of 2,200 matriculating students is comprised of diverse ethnic groups, and faculty members say the racial mixture is one of the school's strong points. A continuing challenge, however, is the recruiting and retaining of students, Mr. Lacy said.
"We need to be a college of 6,000 students, and that's part of the growth plan for over the next five years," he said. "That's the number the academic planners built and designed the school for."
Students pay $10,400 a year in tuition, room and board if they are New York residents, and $15,300 a year if they are not.
In addition to its undergraduates, the college can also be measured by the strength of its contributions to the community. The place is a cultural magnet, drawing thousands a year to its four-theater complex, the Performing Arts Center; its division of Continuing Education and the Neuberger Museum.
Many travel weekly to events and classes on the campus, where Eugene McCarthy taught a history course in 1975, James Baldwin lectured in 1986 and young artists are forging paths to follow some of the school's stellar graduates. These include Wesley Snipes and Stanley Tucci, who graduated from the theater division in 1984 and 1982 respectively; Dwayne Croft of the Metropolitan Opera, who graduated from the music division in 1983 and Terese Capucilli, a 1978 graduate who was a principal dancer with the Martha Graham Company.
The college plans a series of celebratory events through next spring that will "cut across every academic program," said Margaret M. Sullivan, vice president for external affairs and development. She said all are free to the public, except lectures about Kykuit on Oct. 8 and Nov. 7 and a benefit performance and dinner to be held Nov. 18. The performance, which will take place at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, will feature Mr. Tucci, Ms. Capucilli and other well-known graduates. The dinner will be held at Tavern on the Green. For ticket information, call (212) 935-1840.
Two exhibitions in honor of the anniversary will open today at the Neuberger Museum. These are "Urban Suburban: The Architecture of Purchase College," curated by Mr. Lacy and Susan de Menil, which runs through Jan. 19, and "25 Years of Visual Arts at Purchase," an alumni exhibition continuing through Jan. 5.
Two more events are planned next Sunday. The television personality Charlie Rose will lead a panel discussion at 1:30 P.M. in the Performing Arts Center called "The Vision of Nelson Rockefeller: A Multifaceted Perspective." Panelists will include Kitty Carlisle Hart, a former chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts, who was appointed by Rockefeller; Dr. Clifton Wharton Jr., former Chancellor of the State University of New York; Mr. Barnes, the architect; Joseph Persico, author of "The Imperial Rockefeller"; and Gerald Benjamin, director of the Center for New York State and Local Government Studies at the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government. Tickets are free, but reservations are required. The number to call is 251-6200.
In addition, the exhibition "A Tribute to Nelson A. Rockefeller" will open next Sunday at 5 P.M. at the museum. Dr. Lisa Keller, an assistant professor of history here and director of the Institute for Westchester and Local History, said the exhibition, which she curated with the archivist Harold Oakhill, includes documents and photographs from the Rockefeller Archives, as well as selected paintings and sculptures from Rockefeller's art collection. This show also runs through Jan. 5.
In researching Rockefeller, Dr. Keller said, "I was surprised by the degree to which he was driven by the altruistic desire to do good regardless of the political ramifications."

HEADLINE: What's on the Internet? Here's a Start

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN 

 BODY:
DEBORAH GILBERT, the host of The Emerging Society, a call-in talk show simulcast on the Fairfield County News Radio, AM 1350, and on the Internet, speaks about cyberspace with sheer reverence. A seasoned talk-show host, she started using the communication tool last fall before starting her program, the first of its kind in Connecticut.
To prepare, she spent hours in chat rooms and in moderated chats from CNN, meeting people from all over the world and discussing everything from international politics to trivia. 
 What touched her more than anything else, she said, was the camaraderie on line. One man from Oklahoma she met during a chat session told her he was nervous because he'd accepted a job in New York City and had few contacts. Ms. Gilbert invited the man into a chat room with people from the New York area, who offered him housing leads and contacts, easing his anxiety about moving to the city.
Ms. Gilbert also recalled how last New Year's Eve, she stayed home nursing the flu, yet spent the evening on line hypertextlinking all over the world to wish people a happy New Year.
"That's one of the glories of chat and of the Internet," Ms. Gilbert said. "It's bringing people and information together in a democratic form. It's absolutely mindboggling."
Once a small society of computer wizards and academics, the Internet population has soared into the millions, as more and more people abandon their televisions and radios to seek entertainment, business and educational opportunities on line. Ms. Gilbert's talk program, which can be heard by downloading audio software (http://www.clubnetct.com) features local and national Internet experts whose range of topics include web site design, new on-line technology and Internet advertising.
The program illustrates both the technological advances of the Internet and the new wave of excitement over the medium's potential. Though observers note that Connecticut has not embraced the technology as vigorously as other states, particularly those in the West, signs of its steady growth are evident in the number of Connecticut-based web sites, Internet-related businesses, the popularity of chat services and on-line videoconferencing.
Next Saturday, Connecticut will also become one of the first states to connect hundreds of its schools and libraries to the Internet, in a project called Connect T96. The program enables schools and libraries to get high-speed wiring at a discount, modems to send and receive data via phone lines as well as access to Internet provider services.
The integration of the medium into more and more facets of American life, say observers, indicates that the ambivalence or dread of the last few years over the Internet's impact has to some degree subsided.
"The Internet mirrors and magnifies life around us in all of its diverse and perverse forms, which is why people react fearfully," says Terence Rogers, an Internet consultant from Greenwich, who has worked in the computer industry for 25 years. "Yet it is crystal clear that the Internet is important and is here to stay," he said.
Gloria Brown, a fourth and fifth grade teacher at Wakelee Elementary School in Wolcott, already uses the Internet in her classroom for student research projects and to communicate with other schools. Micro-Net, an Internet service provider in Waterbury, offers Wakelee and some 130 other schools in the state free access as well as a chat area and videoconferencing program for student use only. Ms. Brown says she leaves the computer on all day, allowing students to work on papers and E-mail pen pals in other states. "It's like having a library in the classroom," she said.
Despite its educational advantages, she said, she remains mindful of the dark side of the Internet and must emphasize to students to use the medium responsibly. "I still have my reservations about using it," she said. "With children you have to be so careful. You never know who you'll find out there."
Educators, or just the curious who want information about the state, will find thousands of Connecticut-based web sites on line. Probably the best places to start are with the so-called gateway web sites, which offer links to hundreds of other sites.
The State of Connecticut web site (http://www.state.ct.us/) provides access to information created by government agencies, with categories in the economy, environment, health, transportation and municipalities.
The Connecticut Guide site, supported by Atlantic Computing Technology Corporation in Newington (http://ctguide.atlantic.com/sites/ index.html), provides a link to 709 Connecticut sites from CERN, the particle laboratory in Geneva that created the World Wide Web. Listing a site is free. Visitors to CERN's collection can find everything from businesses and associations, to events, advice on automotive problems, kayak kits, head lice solutions and a medical information retrieval service.
The Connecticut Guide site also links visitors to the Connecticut Tourism Guide and to the Connecticut Library Home Page, which began as a senior project in computer science at Southern Connecticut State University. The site is an excellent launchpad to the state's educational, political, artistic and recreational resources.
Social contact and self-expression is another prevalent theme, as the graphics and text of many of Connecticut-based home pages illustrate. At the Ranting with Kenny site, visitors encounter an odyssey of doom and purple prose. "Outside the world screamed and splintered, and animals cooked to the bone in the incredible meltdown," the site's author says in a fictional diary excerpt. "Fortunately or not, I was less than an animal. I thrived on the ghastly heat, thrashing in the boiling muck."
On the lighter side, the Hauserman family's home page includes click-on's to Paul's, Patti's, Amanda's and Gregory's pages plus family news and the Hauserman's favorite recipes.
Jason M. Card tells visitors to his site that he is 24 and works in the marketing department of a "big-time" health insurance company. Just as most web sites do, Mr. Card's displays a few of his favorite links like the Mutant Page, the Looney Tunes page, and the Ozzy Osborne page.
At Kerry Lynn Torello's web site (http://www.connix.com/Kerry/ #index) browsers discover she's a veteran Internet user and enthusiast, that she loves rock and roll, shooting pool, taking shots of Tequila and riding Harley-Davidson motorcycles topless. In real life, Ms. Torello is a telecommuter for Digital Equipment Corporation headquartered in Maynard, Mass., where she is a software support specialist.
In a recent telephone interview, Ms. Torello said she designed her own web page for fun and for business. The site provides a link to her husband's company, Quality Graphics and Marketing, which maintains the web site for the Connecticut Lottery (http://www.qqm.com/ ctlott.html).
Ms. Torello began using the Internet as a social tool in 1993, while living in Colorado Springs. During an encounter inside an America Online chat room, she met her future husband, Gary, who lived in Connecticut. Through their conversations, Ms. Torello said, they drew closer and eventually met. In February of last year she moved to Haddam to live with Mr. Torello. The couple married later that spring.
Somewhat of a chat specialist, Ms. Torello warns that finding love on the Internet isn't for everybody, and that weboholics are plentiful. "It's very easy to get sucked in because a relationship on the Internet becomes so intense and heartfelt," she said. "Unlike day to day encounters you can be as uninhibited as you want, which can give you a false since of intimacy. It may be a fascinating communication tool, but people have to remember it doesn't reflect real life."
She added that for many, the Internet fills a void in their lives, particularly in an era where work and family demands overshadow social relationships. "People are aching to socialize," she said. "And the Internet is easily accessible. You don't have to brush your teeth or even get dressed to participate."
The visual equivalent of the Internet chat rooms, CU-SeeME, allows video conferences over the Internet. The set-up combines CU-SeeME software, which can be downloaded at no cost from Cornell University and a black and white digital camera for about $100. Once in place, users can communicate with other people anywhere in the world. The software supports up to eight windows to other parties on a computer screen. A version that includes audio was released last year. Transmissions occur out of reflector sites, computer servers that act as small digital television stations.
Kevin Wolfthal, who coordinates photographic services at Fairfield University, has used the Internet for cultivating professional and social contacts. He started using CU-SeeME at home earlier this year after several years of communicating with friends and colleagues through chat rooms and newsgroups.
"The difference was amazing," he said, about the first time he used the program. "All of the sudden these images started coming up on my computer screen. It was really wonderful to see people's gestures and expressions."
Since then, Mr. Wolfthal has met people across the country, from graphic designers and researchers to schoolteachers and college students. One of the more famous personalities is named Batwoman, an Internet socialite who throws get-togethers for CU-SeeME users around the country. Another user named Jae is from Portland, Ore. where she's planning on opening an Internet cafe.
The CU-SeeME culture comes with its own slang. For example, lurkers are users who don't show themselves on camera, yet watch everyone else. DC-ing is when two people break away from the pack to have a one-to-one conference.
In many ways, Mr. Wolfthal said, CU-SeeME enhances the quality of on-line communication because it takes away some of the wariness a user might have with text-only meetings. "With CU-SeeME it's easier to establish trust," he said. "Whereas on commercial services there's a lot of flaming. You never know who's getting on or what his or her agenda is." (Flaming is communication perceived as hostile or rude.)
Nevertheless, video conferencing breeds its share of bad taste. Users have been known to expose themselves on camera and to make obscene gestures. "It's unbelievable what people will do," Mr. Wolfthal said.
Much of the on-line video conferencing is taking place on college campuses and in the swell of Internet cafes. Charles Wilhelm, the owner of the Online Cafe in Norwalk, which became the first of its kind to open in the state to open last fall, said the cafe attracts business people, researchers and those who use the Internet for entertainment and recreation. The cafe sells coffee and pastry and supports its own T-1 reflector site for CU-SeeME, allowing users to get images faster and sharper than with a personal modem.
A former publisher, Mr. Wilhelm said the Internet's advances in the realm of audio and video pose a serious threat to television and even the telephone, yet the medium will not become a household staple until it expands its local information capabilities. "One day soon," he said, "you're going to wake up and be able to check your local weather, see the school lunch menu, check the time of the P.T.O. meeting and even see if the local hardware store carries a certain product. People will cozy up to the Internet even more when they see how it can improve their lives and their communities."
Mr. Rogers, the Greenwich Internet consultant, agrees, pointing out the already growing number of web sites supported by towns and cities around the state and others that offer links to several communities. He added that once the Internet develops a financial approach, where information is perhaps supported either through donations or through advertising, the on-line content will improve as will the medium's overall usefulness.
"Right now you're either astonished or disappointed when you use the Internet, which is a sign of its immaturity," he said. "But once an economic plan is applied, the boring and faddish stuff should fade and the more interesting and important information will grow and grow."

HEADLINE: Another View Of a Store's Fate

 BODY:
In reference to your article, ("Pride in State and Family, Trying for a Sound Economic Base," Aug. 11):
As a person who grew up in the Waterbury area, I have fond memories of shopping with my mother at Howland-Hughes. But as a young reporter at The Waterbury Republican in the late 1960's, I was shocked, disheartened and then outraged when the late Morris Paine was successful as the prime force behind the demolition of the Buckley Building, a magnificent structure designed by Stanford White, so that a downtown parking garage could be built to accommodate shoppers at Howland-Hughes. 
 Mr. Paine accomplished this in his capacity as chairman of Waterbury's Parking Authority over the objections of people who tried to save the building by promoting alternative ways to provide additional parking.
Mr. Paine was concerned only with the short-sighted interest of his own store, with no consideration for the preservation and potential adaptive re-use of what was undoubtedly the most beautiful building in all of Waterbury.
The parking garage that was built on that site is absolutely soul-less, one of the ugliest buildings I've ever seen.
It's ironic that business declined at Howland-Hughes in the decades after the garage was built and equally ironic that Mr. Paine's son, Hank Paine, is now promoting Connecticut's heritage.

JANE ANDERSON VERCELLI
Thompson

HEADLINE: SCHOLARSHIPS FOR THE RICH

 BODY:
The two cases Andrew Delbanco uses to illustrate the impact of financial aid in college admissions oversimplify a complex process ("Scholarships for the Rich," Sept. 1). 
 Attractive scholarships notwithstanding, might not Kevin Seal have chosen Indiana over Columbia because he wanted to cheer for Bobby Knight's Hoosiers as well as receive a high-quality education? Might not Nikia Scott have found at a historically black institution like Howard a campus environment that Columbia could not provide? Such subjective factors enter into the decisions 18-year-olds make when they select colleges. And for many, the presumed reputation and influence of the Ivy League may be far less important than Delbanco thinks.
 
JAMES W. SCHMOTTER
Bethlehem, Pa.
 
Dean, College of Business
and Economics
Lehigh University
