HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Home Buyers Move Cautiously Back Into the Market

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AS the economy and job market improve so does New Jersey's housing outlook as once-hesitant buyers tiptoe back into the residential market, which had fallen into the doldrums last winter.
Sales of existing homes are better than they were this time last year and new home purchases are holding their own even though new construction remains sluggish. And the impact of last year's corporate downsizings, especially AT&T's announcement that it would lay off 7,000 employees in New Jersey, turned out to be less harsh than expected. As a result a sense of relief has returned to the market, real estate professionals said. 
 But what makes the market's improvement exceptional, they add, is that it came despite the fact that mortgage interest rates are higher than they were at the start of the year.
Assessing the situation, James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, said: "For consumers the tug of war has been mortgage interest rates versus the health of the economy, and so far the economy has won out."
Projections are that the market will continue its modest rebound through the end of the year.
At the same time, new-home construction remains on a "declining path," said Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association in Plainsboro.
Overall demand "is not explosive, but it is trucking along and prices are stable," said Niels Guldbjerg, vice president at the Otteau Appraisal Group, a real estate consulting firm in East Brunswick. David Schoner, vice president of the New Homes Division, New York metropolitan region, at Coldwell Banker, a real estate brokerage with national headquarters in Short Hills, called demand "spotty."
Despite the market's new optimism, buyers remain cautious. People will buy if they perceive value and realistically priced houses will sell, said Michael Ford, president-elect of the New Jersey Association of Realtors in Edison.
The active markets were, and will be, communities that offer good schools and hold their appreciation, said Mr. Schoner, noting that the appeal was still location,
As sales of existing homes in the first half of this year rose 8.8 percent from the same period in 1995 -- from 67,800 to 73,800, said the realtors' group -- so did the median home price, which rose to $152,100 from $146,500. The state's median household income also increased -- from $54,000 to $57,400.
About 22 percent of the sales were for homes priced from $100,000 to $140,000 and 19.8 percent were for homes costing $200,000 to $300,000, indicating that the sales activity had spread from first-time purchasers to move-up buyers, said Peter Mosca, spokesman for the realtors' association.
THOUGH the market for resale homes priced above $300,000 was weak, developers of new homes in that category report good sales. One is Toll Brothers of Huntington Valley Pa., which has 34 communities ticketed for a total of 3,822 homes in various stages of construction. Most are in the $300,000 to $500,000 range.
In the first half of this year 379 homes were sold at an average price of $387,000, compared with 215 homes at an average price of $361,00 in the first six months of 1995.
But move-up buyers like Steven and Mary Cooper predominate. After holding off buying a home because of concerns over job security the couple, both in their 30's and the parents of two children, decided last fall to move from their town house in Tinton Falls to a $260,000 four-bedroom house at a subdivision being built in Howell Township.
"We ran out of space, were finally in a position to afford a larger home and reached a point that we couldn't live our lives being afraid," said Mr. Cooper. He is a sales manager working from his home for Timberland, the New-Hampshire-based footwear and clothing company; she is a part-time dental assistant.
So with mortgage rates higher but still reasonable "we felt buying a home was a chance worth taking," said Mr. Cooper. He said he and his wife chose a corner lot and worked with the developer, Christopher Stephen Homes, of Wall Township, to keep the cost of the house within their reach. The couple sold their town house for $126,000, $14,000 less than they had paid, and moved into the bigger house this month.
In terms of demographics, move-up buyers, mostly maturing baby boomers with children -- which Dean Hughes said represented one of every three New Jerseyans -- will continue to be a market focus. And industry professionals are betting that more of them will react as the Coopers did and buy.
The professionals feel that this will keep sales moving through the fall and winter, enabling the market not only to finish the year ahead of 1995 but to match 1994, when the state reached its highest level of sales since 1987.
What will keep the market on a steady course, most experts agree, is job growth. Dean Hughes said the state was expected to gain 46,000 jobs in 1996, against the 33,000 it added last year. As long as mortgage rates stay reasonable (they went from a low of 7.24 percent in February to 8.5 percent earlier this month) the market should come close to 1994 levels, said Dean Hughes.
Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president at HSH Associates, a Butler firm that tracks mortgage activity, said he expected rates "to hover around the 8.5 percent mark through year's end." He said the higher rate was mitigated by the wide variety of mortgages lenders are offering, such as the assortment of adjustable-rate loans and those with 3 percent down.
BUT concern persists over new-home construction. Through June the state issued 8,558 building permits, down from 9,705 the same time last year. Mr. O'Keefe of the Builders Association said that the decline would accelerate in the second half of this year and beyond as developers run out of approved projects.
Mr. Mosca said his group estimated that 146,000 existing homes would be sold in 1996, compared with 138,300 in 1995 and 145,400 in 1994.
"Attendance at our open houses is up 30 percent, indicating a strong finish to 1996," said Jacelyn L. Botti, regional vice president at Weichert Realtors, the state's largest broker. She said her company had 18 percent more signed contracts for new and resale homes in the first half of the year than the 14,379 signed in the same period last year.
While Mr. O'Keefe said demand for homes priced from $100,000 to $150,000 was strong, the state's long approval process and limited land for small lots makes building them difficult.
But Continental Properties of Brick has been able to respond. It is building detached homes on small lots at the Estates at Sailor's Quay, an 81-home project in Brick Township in Ocean County, where land is available at reasonable costs.
The homes range in size from 1,500 to 2,100 square feet and in price from $125,000 to $165,000. Sales opened earlier this month and 150 people showed up, said Steven Fisch, a principal at Continental. "I'm optimistic," he added.
So is Gabriel M. Pasquale, director of marketing for K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, the state's largest developer, which continues to focus on town houses and detached single-family homes for entry-level and move-up buyers.
He said while sales were down 3 percent the first half of this year against the same time last year "traffic is significantly up, showing strong interest."
As proof he pointed to Woodcliff at Marlboro, containing 286 homes ranging in size from 1,860 square feet to just under 3,000. The community opened two weeks ago in Marlboro and 35 homes priced in the $190,000 to mid-$200,000's range were sold, he said.
Toll, which saw success with projects this year aimed at second- and third-time move-up buyers also sees the activity continuing, said Douglas C. Yearley Jr., a vice president. "For these buyers it is not an affordability issue, but a matter of confidence, which is returning," he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Perseverance Pays Off for Developer in Mamaroneck

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: MAMARONECK

 BODY:
THE Westchester County landscape is littered with the detritus of failed development projects, both residential and commercial. Some have fallen due to the financial collapse, for whatever reason, of the developer. But several have never gotten off the ground due to vociferous local opposition.
It is not uncommon these days for an approval process to take the better part of a decade. During that time, a project can change hands several times. And it is rare that a developer is able to hang in and fight City Hall, as it were, for that length of time. 
 But that is what happened to Howard Loewentheil, who on Wednesday will celebrate the opening of a 39-unit moderate-income condominium project that had its beginnings almost exactly nine years ago.
The finished product, called Continental View, is not exactly what Mr. Loewentheil envisioned when he purchased 50,000 square feet of property on East Boston Post Road on Oct. 25, 1987.
At the time he foresaw a luxury townhouse condominium development with a swimming pool, where the units would cost $400,000 to $500,000. But it wasn't meant to be.
His property happens to border a neighborhood of turn-of-the-century homes and a prewar apartment building, and the residents there vigorously opposed the proposed development from the start.
"When we heard about it, we said no way this is going to happen," said Morton Heilman, past president of the Stuart Avenue Association. The neighborhood group took the village to court, charging that it had improperly granted a variance to build a town-house complex in a zone where only single-family homes were permitted. And it won.
"For the next four to five years, it was like the Israelis and the Iraqis," Mr. Loewentheil said. "No matter what we proposed they didn't want it. Something was always wrong. Basically they wanted to turn it into a park. But when you spend over $1 million for a piece of property, that's not going to happen."
For his part, Mr. Heilman doesn't really dispute the developer's characterization of the opposition. "I guess the best thing that could have happened is if he walked away," he said. "We just didn't want a residential project there with 100 more people in the neighborhood all walking their dogs on Stuart Avenue."
Eventually, "after about seven or eight years, it became clear that something was going to go in there," Mr. Heilman said, "so a compromise was in order."
THE intervening years changed the nature of the development considerably. The market for luxury condominiums had dried up and Mr. Loewentheil opted instead for moderate-income units.
The units range in size from two-bedroom, two-bath condominiums that also have a den to a single one-bedroom unit. "The village made us include a one-bedroom," Mr. Loewentheil said. Prices range from $139,900 for the one-bedroom unit to $152,000 to $179,000 for the two-bedroom ones.
So far, 37 units have sold, Mr. Loewentheil said, mostly to people who already live or work in Mamaroneck. "We have an agreement with the village to sell to village residents and employees first," Mr. Loewentheil said.
Ann Worthy, one of the buyers, was ecstatic about the project finally being completed. "This past winter, I shoveled out my last driveway," she said. "I needed to be released from the responsibilities of a house."
She and her elderly father will soon move into a large two-bedroom apartment at Continental View. "If this hadn't happened, I probably would have had to leave the village to find something affordable," Ms. Worthy said.
The project's shift to moderate-income helped it gain credibility with the community, according to Peter J. Murray, one of Mr. Loewentheil's development partners. "There's such a need for housing in this price range," Mr. Murray said. "It helped us get financing and some government funding."
County Legislator Paul Noto, who had been mayor of Mamaroneck when Mr. Loewentheil bought the property, was instrumental in pushing through financing in the form of a $424,000 infrastructure grant to provide parking both for projects residents and the general public.
"It was a loose end I really wanted to tie up," Mr. Noto said. "I was never happy about what happened to the project. So when I had an opportunity to help I did."
By then, the developer had been able to broker a deal with the residents and the village. "Getting the money just helped move things along," Mr. Loewentheil said.
Mr. Noto sees the Continental View story as a cautionary tale to developers, who could face increasing difficulty trying to get projects built in the future.
"It requires patience and persistence," he said. "A developer must be willing to be flexible and work with the neighbors. Once they feel they're involved in the process, it gets a little easier."
One Mamaroneck Village trustee, Martha Sokol McCarty, points out that two other pending projects are now experiencing opposition that could threaten or delay construction.
Avalon Properties, of Wilton, Conn., wants to build 227 luxury rentals on Mamaroneck Avenue just north of the village's downtown. "After undergoing two or three incarnations where they addressed previous concerns in the design of the project, I got a call recently from someone in the village asking when public hearings are scheduled," Ms. McCarty said.
The project has received final approvals and Avalon expects to begin construction by the end of the year, she said. "But people are still complaining," she added. "The person on the phone said that a lot of people in the village don't want a project of that size. It never ends."
SIMILARLY, a proposal for a 114-unit moderate-income condominium on Mamaroneck Avenue at East Boston Post Road, which has been on the drawing board for years, has also drawn negative reaction.
A local developer, the Mamaroneck Affordable Condominium Corporation, has already sold 95 of the units, according to Ms. McCarty. "Basically people were buying a hole in the ground," she said. "But this kind of housing is so needed in the village."
The project has had a lengthy gestation period, Ms. McCarty said. "There have been a number of proposals and owners," she said.
The two proposed projects and Continental View are all on land that had previously been used for commercial or industrial purposes, Ms. McCarty said.
"If they're not developed in some useful way, they become these vacant eyesores that do no good for anyone," she said. "But sometimes I think people get used to seeing them that way and don't want them to change no matter what is proposed for them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Howard Loewentheil, left, and Peter J. Murray, development partner, at Continental View in Mamaroneck. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Habitats/220 East 65th Street;
Pink Walls, Greenbacks

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
WHEN Erik Grossman bought his condominium on East 65th Street, it had pink walls.
"It was all original -- from 16 years ago, when the building was built," Mr. Grossman said. The floors were drab. The doors, he said, were "cheesy." "It was a rental," he said, "and looked like it." 
 So Mr. Grossman, who was born in the United States but had lived 23 of his 28 years abroad because his father was in the Foreign Service, negotiated a deal: He would pay $370,000 for the large one-bedroom with a dining ell -- called a "convertible two" in real estate parlance -- but the landlord would include some renovations in the price.
"I bought the apartment from the sponsor," Mr. Grossman explained, "and I asked him to build a wall, sand the floors and paint the apartment. He threw in the cornice moldings. I paid for new brass handles, for built-in shelves and nicer doors, and I paid a differential to use really good paint."
Now, freshly painted white, with basket-weave wood floors the color of a lion's mane and a second bedroom created by the addition of a wall and French doors, the apartment at 220 East 65th Street has already risen in value to about $425,000, Mr. Grossman said.
"I got that appraisal from my agent, Caroline Brown of William B. May, and from Barbara Russo, the sales representative that handles the building -- who sent me a letter the other day telling me the building was now 80 percent sold -- and just from my own familiarity with the market," he said.
Mr. Grossman, who closed on his apartment in late June, pointed out that the building, known as the Concorde, is currently undergoing major renovations in the lobby. The front of the building is blocked off, and visitors must walk down a ramp, through a parking garage, and to the service entrance on 64th Street to see a doorman. But there are glimpses of what is to come: elaborate cherry-toned floor-to-ceiling paneling is partly installed.
"And obviously, that, too, will contribute to an increase of apartment values here," said the young investment banker, who said he began work at Schroder Wertheim and Company as a trainee right out of the City University, London, and has risen to vice president, specializing in Asian currencies.
MOST recently, his company stationed him in Hong Kong, after a stint in Seoul, and his collecting testifies to his love of things Asian: a marble sculpture of two Buddhas from the Wei Dynasty, circa 200 A.D., sits overlooking the balcony; two 150-year-old black chairs from Beijing flank the French doors; tea baskets and antique boxes and bamboo chests are placed around the living room, and a 1,400-year-old statue of an ox and cart sit under glass on the floor next to the bamboo chest, waiting for a place to be shown off.
After coming from Hong Kong, where he said rents were at least double those in New York City, he thought he could find an incredible apartment here for $400,000. "I expected a river or a park view," he said.
Looking out over his balcony, to distant views of another new apartment building and, immediately, over the street and traffic, he said ruefully: "I had to compromise on the view, but I refused to compromise on location." For his money, he also got two full bathrooms.
In his search, he said, he almost bought an apartment in the Parc Vendome, at 340 West 57th Street. But that apartment was a one-bedroom, albeit an 1,100-square-foot one-bedroom with a fireplace, which would have cost him $360,000 -- only $10,000 less than the one he bought.
According to his calculations, the rent on the one-bedroom -- should he have to leave town for an extended period -- would be only $2,400. He figured the apartment he bought could rent for $3,200 to $3,400.
"It's pure economics," he said.

HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
All-Day Kindergarten Makes Inroads but Has Far to Go

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
In the early afternoon, the 5-year-olds at the Ridge Street Early Childhood Center haul out soft blue mats and doze for a spell. Napping, it seems, remains as essential to the kindergarten experience as singing, painting and story time.
But unlike past generations, the Ridge Street kindergartners stay in class from 8:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. For the first time, the school system here is providing a daylong program for all kindergartners, part of a plan to improve early-childhood education in one of New Jersey's poorest cities. The school district is joining thousands around the country that view full-day kindergarten as crucial in preparing children, especially those from low-income families, for the intellectual and emotional challenges of elementary school. 
 The Newark district, which the State Department of Education has operated since last year because of corruption and poor student performance, has abolished half-day kindergarten and added 42 full-day classes, bringing the total to 170. It has hired 29 new teachers and reassigned others to the program, which was serving 2,500 children in the first week of school. But it has been able to afford full-day kindergarten only by making significant cuts elsewhere and seeking corporate donations.
Dr. Beverly Hall, the state-appointed superintendent, is paying for new early-childhood programs, including full-day kindergarten, with $3.6 million saved through recent layoffs. The Prudential Insurance Company, which has its headquarters here, donated $250,000 for furniture, supplies and teacher training.
But most of New Jersey's 600 school districts have not been able to start full-day kindergarten. During the 1995-96 school year, 61 percent of the state's 94,500 kindergartners were still enrolled in half-day programs, said Jennifer Seeland of the Education Department. Of 536 districts that offered kindergarten, 211 provided full-day programs for at least some pupils, she said. The other 325 had only half-day programs. Some districts did not offer any kindergarten at all because New Jersey is among 15 states that do not require it.
More than ever, though, early childhood experts believe that 5-year-olds can not only handle a full day of class but also flourish in it. The program also makes economic sense, they say, because it allows working parents to save on child-care expenses.
"It's absolutely absurd that kindergarten is half-day in any district at this point," said Lesley Mandel Morrow, an education professor at Rutgers University who has studied half- and full-day programs in New Brunswick. "The public sector has got to come into sync with economic realities."
Some states now require full-day kindergarten for every pupil and provide money to support it. But for the most part, New Jersey has left the decision to individual districts, most of which pay for full-day programs with tax money. The school financing plan that Governor Whitman proposed in May provides $288 million for early-childhood programs in districts like Newark, where at least 20 percent of the pupils are poor. But the plan does not provide any such aid for most districts.
"Our concern is that districts will either have to take full-day kindergarten to the voters or go backward to half-day," said Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association.
In some cases, districts are doing that already. West Paterson eliminated full-day kindergarten this year because it was taking up too much space in the cramped elementary schools. River Edge and Plainfield are hoping to raise money for full-day programs through bond referendums this fall. Voters in Little Ferry recently defeated a similar referendum.
Although poor districts in New Jersey receive more state aid and qualify for Federal grants to help establish full-day kindergarten, few of those districts provide it for every student. Paterson, another state-operated district, actually has fewer children enrolled in full-day kindergarten than it did in 1991-92, the year the state took control. Last year, 567 of the district's 2,252 kindergartners were enrolled in full-day programs, said Joy Friedman, a district spokeswoman.
In 1991-92, Paterson had 661 pupils in full-day kindergarten, according to Education Department figures.
Early-childhood experts stress that full-day programs should not have a more intensive academic curriculum than half-day programs. Lydia Silva, the assistant superintendent overseeing the Ridge Street Early Childhood Center, said kindergartners there will learn colors, shapes, letters and some numbers this year. But they will learn through games, music and stories instead of workbooks and tests.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pupils gather in a circle in Sylvia Gregory's class at the Arlington Avenue school in Newark, which has established a systemwide all-day kindergarten program this year. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Party Faces For a Spandex A-List

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
THEY aren't all household names yet. But you can tell they've arrived because they're now hot guests at splashy parties. These new party faces (some from New York, some not) are achieving recognition in the media-driven meritocracy that is New York society. Like money, their names are used as currency on invitations and in gossip columns.
It's a long list (almost as long as the list of new cable TV-channels and on-line magazines), but that doesn't necessarily mean you can forget the names from last year. The A-list universe in New York, after all, isn't like the Midtown Tunnel, which brings in fresh air and forces out the stale every 90 seconds. It's more like a middle-aged paunch or the Blob, absorbing more and more weight with each year.
 
ONE-NAMED POP WONDERS
 
BECK, the new Michael Stipe, who just won an MTV video music award for best male vocalist of the year. BUSH, the new Pearl Jam. OASIS, not the new Beatles, but British, so they're being compared to them. PHISH, the new Grateful Dead. NAS, the new Coolio.
 
NEW BAD KIDS ON THE BLOCK
 
JOHN GALLIANO, French enfant terrible. BIJOU PHILLIPS, model daughter (not as in paradigm, but runway) of John Phillips of the Mamas and the Papas. The Courtney Love of models.
 
SOCIAL LIGHTS
 
MOUNA AYOUB, jewelry-laden, recently divorced and a "Middle Eastern Ivana Trump," according to New York magazine. PATRICIA KLUGE, who divorced the billionaire John Kluge, 82, and got her own apartment in the Waldorf Towers. MARIE-JOSEE KRAVIS, couture-wearing Canadian economist who married Henry Kravis and who (in an intellectually symbolic gesture) has been converting the ballroom in their new Park Avenue apartment into a library. NINA BAUER, 25, who has a broken engagement to Steven Perelman (son of Ron) and an unbroken one to Charles de Gunzburg (whose mother was a Bronfman) on her social bio.
 
STAGEY TYPES
 
THE 'RENT' CAST, because it's nice to have actors at a swank party who play East Village junkies and squatters, not real ones. SAVION GLOVER, who, on Broadway, is no longer just a tap-dancing kid in the shadow of Gregory Hines. JOAQUIN CORTES, a heartthrob flamenco dancer getting an armada-like public-relations send-off.
 
THIS YEAR'S MODELS
 
VENDELA, who just signed to represent Almay cosmetics and married a Swiss millionaire. WILLEM DAFOE, old film and experimental theater actor; new Prada model.
 
TV TYPES
 
JENNY McCARTHY, hostess of MTV's "Singled Out" dating-game show, who was Playboy's July centerfold. ROSIE O'DONNELL (nice suddenly sells.)
 
LETTERS SET
 
KATRINA VANDEN HEUVEL, editor in chief of The Nation. DOMINIQUE BROWNING, editor of House and Garden redux. FRANK McCOURT, former schoolteacher whose memoir about growing up poor and Irish is making him less poor.
 
AVAILABLE ATHLETES
 
LISA LESLIE, Olympics basketball star recently spotted sipping Champagne through a straw at the Bubble Lounge. KEYSHAWN JOHNSON, the Jets' rookie wide receiver with a poster-boy smile. ANYBODY INTO EXTREME SPORTS except Sandy Pittman, the media-loving mountaineering socialite who was shoved off her cliff by an expose in the August issue of Vanity Fair.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
In the Heat of Passion, What Will the Fed Do With Rates on Tuesday?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
IN Tuesday, the seven governors of the Federal Reserve and the presidents of the Fed's 12 regional banks will gather in the board room at the central bank's Washington headquarters.
Sitting around the oval conference table, the 15 men and 4 women will debate whether to tighten the economic reins a bit by raising short-term interest rates. But there will probably be more passion than normal, given recent public comments by Fed members, and the unusual leak of a request by 8 of the 12 presidents for a hike in the discount rate, the second of the Fed's two interest-rate levers. 
 Feelings about the meeting are running strong outside the board room, too. Investors and market analysts appear to be as divided as the Fed policy makers, and the myopic focus on the event has resulted in incredible volatility in both the bond and stock markets. The yield on the 30-year bond has moved from 6.69 percent on Aug. 9, to 7.15 percent on Sept. 5, to 6.95 percent on Sept. 13, and to 7.04 percent on Friday.
The mood swings have come with each new round of economic data that changes the bet on what the Fed will do with its No. 1 interest-rate lever, the Federal funds rate. The fearful predictions range from an increase of one-half of a percentage point to no increase at all.
The problem for investors is that no matter what happens on Tuesday, speculation about what the Fed will do next will still roil the markets.
No action on Tuesday means the recent market volatility is likely to continue as each new economic report -- beginning on Oct. 4 with the September employment data -- affects the predictions of what the Fed will do when it gathers again on Nov. 13, after the election.
In addition, there could be a chorus of "the Fed is not being tough enough on inflation" from many market analysts. That sentiment would be bad for long-term interest rates, which are sensitive to inflation fears. And if they move up enough, the stock market could take a hit.
The combination of no action on Tuesday and a strong employment report for September could fuel pressure for a one-half point increase in the Fed funds rate in November. Forecasters would probably say that the Fed needs to be tougher, having passed up a rate increase on Tuesday.
Moreover, "If you go a week or two without the data showing a slowdown in the economy, you would see a large rise in bond yields and probably a small correction in the stock market," said David Hale, chief economist at Zurich Kemper Investments in Chicago.
If the Fed does act, long-term rates should rise but short-term rates could fall because they have already risen in anticipation of an increase. This is the bet of Barbara Kenworthy, a fixed-income portfolio manager at Prudential Mutual Funds. She has taken cash and bought shorter-term securities in anticipation of a bounce from a rate increase.
But even if the rate climbs, analysts will begin speculating on when the Fed might move again, based both on the size of the increase and on their own economic projections.
Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research in Princeton, N.J., believes that the economy is already slowing down. So he concludes that any Fed move would be modest, maybe just a quarter of a percentage point, and another quarter-point later.
But others see inflation just beneath the surface. "The Federal Reserve is right on the edge of a potential upsurge in inflation," said John R. Williams, chief global-markets economist at the Bankers Trust Company. If this is the case, the Fed might have to move more strongly on raising interest rates. And that uncertainty could keep the bond and stock markets churning.
There is a longer-term view of a rate increase on Tuesday, one that sees it as bolstering the confidence of the markets that the Fed will do the right thing: slow down growth to prevent inflation from rising above the 3 percent level at which it has been contained since 1992.
In this view, a Tuesday increase and maybe one more would help assure the slowing of the economy that the Fed itself has predicted, relieving inflationary pressure. And as soon as that slowdown is confirmed in the monthly data, long-term interest rates should fall.
Slower growth is not great for earnings and stocks. But moderate growth with contained inflation would probably not sharply undermine the stock market if long-term interest rates are falling.
Yet, given the recent sharp swings in market anxieties, this view might be shunned for one focusing on a danger of Fed rate increases: that the economy will fall into a recession. In its perverse way, the bond market would be happy with this perspective, but stocks could falter.
No matter how things turn out on Tuesday, then, uncertainties will live on. But some portfolio managers seem less bothered than others by Tuesday's meeting and its consequences.
"If you sit and dwell on what the Fed will do, you will spend your time second-guessing and not focus of the big picture," said Ole Dial, chief investment officer of the $500 million Northstar Total Return fund in Greenwich, Conn.
Charles P. Smith, president of the New Income Fund at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, said of Tuesday's meeting: "I don't think it's terribly significant to how you stand now. It is not as important as your guess about the how strong the economy is or what inflation will be."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
New Life Insurance Isn't Always the Best Policy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
IN a small auditorium in lower Manhattan last week, the New York State Insurance Department held its final hearing on a new regulation intended to combat deceptive practices in the selling of life insurance policies, a longstanding problem that has cost consumers millions of dollars.
At the same time, insurance regulators from a dozen other states have been drafting similar standards, which are expected to be endorsed later this month by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. They would become a model for regulation throughout the country. 
 "Initially, everyone thought there were isolated cases of this just in their backyards," said Brian Atchinson, the president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and the superintendent of insurance in Maine. "Then we realized all of our backyards looked a lot alike. This was a problem clearly of national scope."
The practice, referred to as "twisting" or "churning" by unhappy customers, and by the less colorful term of "replacement" by the industry, has been a problem in New York, one of the biggest insurance markets in the country and the home of scores of insurance companies.
Churning became widespread in the 1980's when interest rates were climbing. Some insurance agents persuaded customers to trade in their old policies for new ones at higher prices with no advantage to anyone but the agent, who received a commission, and his company, which increased its sales. The lure to the customer was higher returns on the new policies.
Customers were often offered whole-life and universal life policies -- which pay a death benefit and offer an investment feature -- that could match the yields of 12 percent and higher that investors were getting from mutual funds and virtually risk-free money markets. For the many people who were holding old policies paying interest of, say, 6 percent, the new policies sounded attractive.
But in many cases, zealous agents showed projections of the phenomenally high interest rates continuing for 20 or 30 years. They did not explain that what goes up most often comes down. Customers also say they did not realize they would lose some critical benefits provided in their original policies. When interest rates eventually fell, many policyholders were left worse off than when they started.
"In fairness," Mr. Atchinson said, "during the booming 80's a lot of very intelligent people lost sight of cyclical turns and didn't seem to realize that interest rates weren't going to stay high forever."
Some of the largest insurance companies in the country have settled disputes over churning. The Prudential Insurance Company of America agreed in July to pay a $35 million fine and to query 10.7 million policyholders for possible claims of improper sales practices that investigators say could cost the company up to $1 billion in compensation. (If all the policyholders file valid claims -- which is considered unlikely -- the average payout would be about $90.) The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and New York Life have agreed to compensate some policyholders.
Churning has been an embarrassment to an industry that sells itself on trust, and many insurance executives say they believe it has also hurt sales. In Washington last week, the American Council of Life Insurance, a group of 580 life and health insurance companies, announced the creation of the Insurance Marketplace Standards Association to write a code of conduct for the companies.
In New York, hearings on regulations to aid consumers began last fall, and with the final hearing on Tuesday, Edward J. Muhl, the state Insurance Superintendent, said the new rules should be in place by the end of the year. They still must be reviewed by the office of Gov. George E. Pataki and posted publicly before taking effect.
"The root of the churning and twisting problem is that policyholders often lack crucial information," Mr. Muhl said.
One of the most significant of Mr. Muhl's proposals would require an agent who is selling a replacement policy to notify the company that issued the original policy so it can make a counter sales pitch, arguing why the original policy is better than the replacement. Agents would also be required to explain in writing why a replacement would be an improvement for the customer.
In addition, the new regulation would give customers up to 60 days to change their minds after agreeing to a replacement. It would also require companies to appoint a senior executive to monitor the compliance of the company and its agents, although some companies are doing that voluntarily. New York Life, for example, has created a compliance group of 110 employees to guard against improper sales. Prudential follows up on new life insurance sales by an employee outside the sales force.
In the Prudential case, investigators from state insurance departments around the country found that the company had provided agents with misleading sales materials and had failed to monitor sales practices. It not only failed to discipline agents who were reported to have relied on deceptive tactics, but repeatedly promoted many of them, sending a bold wink of the eye to its agents while maintaining a public policy of adherence to the highest standards of integrity.
Robert DeFillipo, the company's director of public relations, said that while Prudential had accepted the findings of the investigation, it believes "the vast majority of the 10.7 million policyholders were treated fairly."
He added, "We are absolutely committed to resolving every legitimate customer complaint."
NEW YORK State Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, the chairman of the Assembly's committee on insurance, says the commission system gives agents the incentive to churn. At the close of a sale in New York, agents receive up to 55 percent of the first year's premium; in some states the commission is more than the total first-year premium. This keeps agents hungrier to find new business than to preserve old policies, even though the economics of life insurance make long-term arrangements best for most customers.
Mr. Grannis, who will hold a hearing on Oct. 10 in Manhattan on pending legislation concerning agent compensation, says one solution might be to reduce the commission in the first year and extend the payout to agents over a longer period, giving them a greater interest in keeping a policy in force. Another proposal by Mr. Grannis is to require agents to explain their pay system to customers, so they can see the agent's financial interest.
In the insurance department hearing, Nathan M. Perlmutter, an insurance agent and son of an agent speaking on behalf of the National Association of Life Underwriters, an agents' group, argued that compensation is not a primary motive for churning. Even so, he said, as a gesture of good will, the organization proposed that the new regulation stipulate that no commissions be paid until after the 60-day period in which the customer may reject the replacement policy.
Speaking in support of the proposed changes, Albert R. Dawson, a senior lawyer for the American Council of Life Insurance, said that "few subjects arouse as much passion and anxiety in our business as does replacement."
In some cases, he said, it makes sense to replace an existing policy. But with churning and twisting, he said, a "salesperson puts personal gain first and the client interest second."
"Invariably," he added, "the client loses."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Managers May Change; What About Principles?

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
THE founders and managers of the Pax World fund, the country's oldest and largest socially responsible mutual fund, have decided to cash out, selling the company that manages the fund's $500 million of assets.
But some shareholders, who were notified only late last month of the proposed sale, are feeling little peace. They complain that they have been left in the dark about the buyers, and how the sale would affect both the fund's performance and its practice of investing according to moral as well as financial tenets, a practice that Pax World pioneered a quarter century ago. 
 "The fact that shareholders were never informed of the possible sale until the last minute bespeaks an attitude of ignoring our interests," said Milton Feinberg, a retired social worker in Hamilton, N.J., who owns shares in the fund. Mr. Feinberg, 85, said that he was angry that a group that advocates good corporate behavior would not be more open with the fund's own investors.
At a time when fund deals make headlines nearly every week, the sale of Pax World Management, founded in 1971 by a group including two Methodist ministers, Luther E. Tyson and J. Elliott Corbett, has attracted little attention. One reason is that both the sellers and the buyers have avoided any but the most necessary public disclosure.
In proxy materials, shareholders received this assurance from Mr. Tyson, president of the fund and the management company: "From the perspective of the fund's shareholders, most things will not immediately change." Nothing will be altered in the social criteria of the fund, he said, and the current portfolio manager will stay at least a year to insure a smooth transition. And in an interview, Mr. Tyson said "we had the best interests of shareholders in mind" every step of the way.
But some shareholders say they have not been given adequate information about the four siblings who are buying the management firm for $15 million, or about their investment record.
No member of the family group, led by Laurence A. Shadek, an executive vice president at H. G. Wellington & Company, a New York brokerage firm, has ever managed a mutual fund. Instead, Mr. Shadek, his sister and two brothers have mainly been active managing the family's assets, which include investments made early this century in the predecessor company to I.B.M.
Mr. Feinberg said he objected to a statement in the proxy materials that "there is no guarantee that the adviser will be able to attract any other purchasers who are as committed to the fund's policies as is the Shadek family."
"That is an implied threat," he said, "that either we vote for it or we will lose this great opportunity."
The frustrations are likely to be voiced at a meeting on Friday in Boston, where fund investors are to vote on a crucial part of the deal: a new contract with Pax World Management, under new ownership, to manage the fund's portfolio. Despite the concerns of some shareholders, the new contract is likely to be approved.
A mutual fund is owned by its investors, not by the company that markets the fund and manages the portfolio, much as a mutual insurance company is owned by policy holders. Thus, a change in control of the management company voids the contract to oversee the fund's investments and to charge management fees.
The Shadek family has a business pedigree of some renown. In the early 1900's, Mr. Shadek's great-uncle, a Wall Street financier named Charles R. Flint, combined a hodgepodge of floundering ventures into a small conglomerate called the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company. In 1914, he hired Thomas Watson, an unemployed young salesman, to run the company.
That company is now International Business Machines, and Mr. Watson became one of America's most successful industrialists. Members of the Flint family, including Mr. Shadek's grandfather, Wallace Flint, were significant shareholders.
In an interview, Mr. Shadek, who is 46, said his family had long been active in venture capital. He entered the investment business after finishing the Graduate School of Business Administration at New York University. He worked for the brokerage firm of Moore & Schley and then for H. G. Wellington.
His brother, James M. Shadek, 44, is a stockbroker at H. G. Wellington. Another brother, Thomas M. Shadek, 45, runs a direct-marketing business in San Diego. A sister, Katherine Shadek Boyle, 36, formerly worked as a stockbroker.
Until now, the family has rarely been involved in the daily operation of the businesses it buys, although it will be active in marketing the Pax fund. Thomas Shadek has run the direct-marketing business for eight years, and he is an officer and director of Wildlife Education Ltd., a San Diego publisher of educational wildlife books. The family owns both businesses.
Though the family does not have experience in socially reponsible investments per se, Laurence Shadek said: "We've always had a belief in investing according to certain criteria and disciplines. We want to be involved in companies that are good corporate citizens, and we've always believed that good corporate governance is part of the picture in long-term investing.
"Certainly we have some things to learn about the mutual fund industry specifically, but we have been managing our family's money for years," he said.
While Mr. Shadek is quick to say that nothing will change with the Pax World fund, the family has plenty of other plans, including starting other socially responsible Pax funds. Pax World is the only fund now managed by Pax World Management.
He says there are plans to start an equity growth fund. The Pax World fund, as a balanced fund, holds both stocks and bonds.
The goal of any new funds will be similar to that of the current one, which, according to its charter, seeks "investments in companies producing life-supportive goods and services and that are not to any degree engaged in manufacturing defense or weapons-related products."
As such, the fund, whose largest holdings at the end of June were Merck, Peoples Energy and Campbell Soup, excludes companies that derive at least 5 percent of gross sales from military contracts. In addition, it shuns tobacco, alcohol and gambling stocks.
Future funds, however, might employ slightly different social criteria to screen potential investments. For example, Mr. Shadek said the 100 largest contractors of the Defense Department included companies like Procter & Gamble and Gillette.
"We don't want to invest in makers of weapons," he said, "but if a company is selling soap or razor blades to the Army, I don't necessarily think they should be excluded from the fund."
Mr. Tyson, who is 73, said the fund's founders had been seeking a buyer for several years, in part because they knew they could not run the fund forever. Of the other co-founders, Mr. Corbett is 74, and Anthony S. Brown, a former stockbroker, is 61. Each owns 29 percent of the management company. The remaining 13 percent is held by Paul V. Brown Jr., a brother of Anthony.
The potential purchase came to the Shadeks' attention through Thomas W. Grant, president of H. G. Wellington, who before joining that firm in 1991 was a managing director at Fahnestock & Company, where Anthony Brown worked as a broker from 1982 to 1990.
"We set up criteria we wanted a buyer to meet before we would consider any kind of negotiation," Mr. Tyson said. "The Shadek family was a good fit. There were other offers that were more remunerative. But we decided based on the deep belief that the standards we set for the last 26 years will be met and exceeded" by the new owners.
LITTLE is known about the investment record of the Shadek family, which has never courted publicity. That is often the case with a family managing private investments, but less so for a group trying to sell mutual fund investments to the public. Mr. Shadek declined to make any family members available for a photograph to accompany this article.
"From a family standpoint, that is always the way we have conducted ourselves," he said. "It is not meant to be secretive. But we'd rather not have the publicity as a family. We'd rather focus on the management of the fund and growth of the business."
What is unclear for investors is how their returns will be affected. Under Anthony Brown, who has managed the portfolio for six years and would stay at least one more, the fund has outperformed its peers over the last year and three years. But its performance has been uneven over a longer period.
Mr. Shadek said shareholders should take comfort from the fact that the fund's six independent directors had reviewed his family's investment record and recommended unanimously that shareholders approve the new management contract. After the transaction, the board would have eight members (down from nine), including the six independent directors.
"I think that's the protection and due diligence shareholders should rely on," he said. "I hope and trust that over a number of years their confidence will be proved true."

HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
Looking at Voters' Wallets, and the Candidates' Fingers

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
IF the polls are any indication, the old saw that people vote their pocketbooks remains valid. To help such readers, the October issues of three personal-finance magazines -- Money, Worth and Mutual Funds -- have articles examining the stances of Bob Dole and President Clinton on the economy.
The package in Money is by far the most comprehensive and rewarding. It includes an "In Your Interest" column by Frank Lalli, the magazine's managing editor, in which he compares the candidates' economic rhetoric with reality. 
 Mr. Lalli offers some interesting conclusions:
* The details of Mr. Dole's tax plan aren't quite as sweet as his "I'm going to cut your taxes by 15 percent and balance the budget" promise.
* The President's contention that "our targeted tax cuts are paid for" is based on assumptions that may not pan out.
* The line-item veto will give the next President far less power than most people have been led to believe.
* It was Mr. Dole, not the President, who championed (in 1982) the biggest tax increase, when adjusted for inflation, in United States history.
* Mr. Clinton's assertion that "we saved Medicare" when the Republicans tried to destroy it doesn't jibe with a projection that the program's trust fund will become insolvent in 2001.
The main article -- "The Candidates and Your Wallet," by Ann Reilly Dowd, a Washington correspondent for the magazine -- includes an interview with Mr. Clinton in which some of his most interesting comments are about the need for changes in Social Security.
Mr. Dole and Ross Perot, the candidate of the Reform Party, declined to be interviewed.
The package, which is buttressed by the results of a Money poll, covers just about every pocketbook issue on the table and is an excellent primer for anyone trying to get beyond daily sound bites and headlines.
The article in Worth is laudable, but not as comprehensive as those in Money. It is based on questions that the magazine submitted to Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton.
The article winds up with a telling point, however: "As the election picks up steam, remember this: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's policies will have more impact on the economy, and thus on voters' pocketbooks, than a President of either party."
The contribution by Mutual Funds simply presents the contrasting opinions of two fund managers.
 
A WARNING SIGN? A thoughtful, and troubling, article by Jim Rogers, a finance professor at Columbia University, in Worth examines some signs that foreign investors may be pulling back from financing America's national debt by buying its Treasury bonds, notes and bills.
The ramifications of this could be shattering for the economy, Mr. Rogers writes. He advises American investors to keep some assets out of the country, in a safe currency like German marks or Swiss francs, as an insurance policy.
 
THINK SMALL The October issue of Kiplinger's Personal Finance recommends buying stocks in seven small companies whose profits are growing at least 20 percent a year and which haven't been "discovered" by the market. The seven dwarfs are: Avondale Industries, a shipbuilder; Consolidated Products, a restaurant chain; Friedman's, a jewelry retailer; Horizon Mental Health Management, which provides mental health services in general acute-care hospitals; Lumisys, a medical-equipment company; Nobel Education Dynamics, a for-profit operator of schools, and SEI, a financial-services concern.
To minimize risk, it is recommended that all seven be bought as a package.
 
TAKE CREDIT Smart Money's October issue examines the frustrating problem of inaccurate credit reports. Devin Leonard's "Garbage In. Garbage Out." describes the workings of TRW, Equifax and Trans Union -- the Big Three in the credit-reporting business -- as well as what causes mistakes and what a consumer can do about them.
The problem appears to be widespread. The author says that of the 2.5 million people who request copies of their credit reports each year from Trans Union, 50 percent have questions or disputes about their credit histories. TRW says it handles 360,000 complaints a month.
 
YOUR POCKETBOOK Kiplinger's has a good rundown of 34 World Wide Web sites that can help consumers manage their finances, from investing to buying a car to selling a house. The magazine also recommends that it might be time to look at investing in Eastern Europe, with a list of some mutual funds that do just that.
And in case you didn't already know it, Kiplinger's points out that the nation's banks are on a rampage of imposing fees and surcharges. Last year, the banks raked in $16 billion from such charges.
 
BITS AND PIECES Worth and Kiplinger's both examine the merits of P.I.M., or personal information manager, computer programs; Smart Money gives some excellent pointers on buying an Oriental rug; Kiplinger's presents its "stinky fish" awards to nine mutual fund flops, and Andrew Tobias beats up on Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate and Presidential candidate, in a cover article in Worth.
