SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2662 words

HEADLINE: Aging World, New Wrinkles

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
A CHARACTER in the comic strip Doonesbury once declared: "This generation is like a great comet, blazing through the firmament, carrying with it a dream as boundless as the universe itself."
"Whew," another figure responds. "How will we know when it's over?" 
 "Esquire will run a piece on the hot new funeral homes."
Keep an eye out for that Esquire issue soon. Worldwide, the great comet of boomers is beginning to cross the 50-year milestone, as President Clinton did last month, and the result will be to create a global society that is by far the oldest in the history of the world. This aging process will be one of the dominant trends over the coming decades in the industrialized world -- and, for different reasons, in the third world as well -- reshaping societies across the globe.

 
 
Old vs. Young
 Scholars point tentatively to several trends:
*Growing political clashes between the generations. The future political battlegrounds may have less to do with the tug between left and right, and more with a new buzzword, "inter-generational conflict."
*Increasing immigration. One way of avoiding labor shortages as baby boomers retire would be to admit more foreign workers, especially young ones.
*Changing attitudes toward infirmity and death. As they progressed through the life cycle, boomers made society less squeamish about sex and menopause. With the same elan, they may now bring more openness to discussions of incontinence, loneliness and suicide, making euthanasia as furious a political and moral debate as abortion is now.
Although this is more debatable, some experts also worry that aging will mean less creative and entrepreneurial societies. Would Bill Gates have founded Microsoft if he had been a septuagenarian? Would he even have used Windows? More broadly, will society be as receptive to new ideas when it is disproportionately hard of hearing?
"We're afraid that as we get an older society, we will lose our innovative capacity, our adaptability to a changing world," said Makoto Atoh, director-general of the Japanese Government's Institute of Population Problems.

 
 
Japan Frets
 Still, there are plenty of people throughout history, from Socrates on, whose creativity and brilliance ripened with age. If Benjamin Franklin or Thomas Edison or Madame Curie had not proved the point, then Virginia Hamilton Adair, a spirited Californian blinded by glaucoma, underscored it earlier this year when she published her first book of poetry at the age of 83, to wide critical acclaim. In addition, the needs of an older society could trigger a new wave of entrepreneurs and inventors.
Whatever the verdict on creativity, though, Japan is particularly concerned because it may be the world's fastest-aging country. Like most nations, Japan had a baby boom after World War II, for the upheaval of war delayed child-bearing across most of the globe, and the postwar years also saw worldwide strides in health care that meant more babies could survive to swell the ranks of the boomers. Japan is also special because it now enjoys (and frets about the consequences of) one of the longest life expectancies in the world -- 76 for men and 83 for women. By 2025 it is expected to be one of the oldest societies on the globe, with more than one-quarter of its population over 65.
The United States will not be that gray, but a virtual demographic revolution appears under way. In 1790, half the American people were under 16. It took two centuries, until 1990, for the median age to rise to 33. But by the middle of the next century, it will be over 40 and could approach 50.
It makes sense that the heroes and heroines in an older society are not the likes of youthful rock stars or 20-something movie actors, and indeed Japan may be a step ahead of other countries by hailing geriatric celebrities, like a pair of 104-year-old twins, Gin-san and Kin-san, two women all smiles and wrinkles, each everyone's idea of a great great-great grandmother. When someone asked them what they were doing with the money from all their public appearances, Gin-san smiled and explained, "We're saving it for our old age."
Gin-san and Kin-san offer a typical face of old age in part because they are women. In 1850, a newborn white baby girl in America could expect to live to 40, two years longer than a white baby boy. That gap has steadily grown, and today a white newborn girl can expect to live past 79, more than six years longer than a boy. The fastest-growing sector in the industrialized world is the "oldest old," meaning those over 80, and there are more than twice as many women in this group as men. The result is that the industrial countries will have a growing number of white-haired widows living for years on their own.
Moreover, while Gin-san and Kin-san are doing just fine financially, many who today are showing their first few gray hairs will not. By some estimates, American baby boomers on average are setting aside only a bit more than one-third what they need for retirement. In almost all industrial countries, social-security schemes are unsustainable: they are mostly "pay as you go" programs of the kind founded by the German statesman Otto von Bismarck a century ago. These plans do not involve real savings, and instead they borrow from today's workers to pay for today's retirees. This means that they rely on a huge excess of workers over retirees. When the baby boomers retire, the system will go bust -- or at least will require adjustments such as later retirement, higher taxes, or cutbacks in benefits. Already, the retirement age to receive social security benefits has been raised in the United States, and more increases are likely.
Later retirement makes eminent economic sense, and not only to avoid pension catastrophes. When most jobs were the likes of hauling hay bales or hoisting steel beams, physical limits forced many people to stop working early, but that is not so much of an issue in an economy where the great majority of people can work without perspiring.
Yet later retirement is not the trend -- just the reverse: people around the world are taking advantage of pensions and social security schemes and quitting earlier and earlier. This combination of earlier retirement and longer lives is leading to a boom in leisure for the elderly. In 1960, an American man could expect only three years of retirement; now he can enjoy almost 10. This is the statistic that, coupled with the advent of air conditioning, has revolutionized Arizona and Florida. It also means that, relatively speaking, fewer people are on the job.
"Now in Japan there are six workers for every retired person," said Yasuhiro Yokota, the director of the International Longevity Center in Tokyo. "But in 2025, there will be just two productive workers for every retired worker. This burden will be huge, and younger people will wonder why they should bear it. I think this may lead to great conflict."
Lester C. Thurow, the American economist, argues in a book published this year that "in the years ahead, class warfare is apt to be redefined to mean not the poor against the rich but the young against the old." In the book, "The Future of Capitalism," Professor Thurow cites the example of Kalkaska, Mich., which he describes as a retirement haven where elderly voters effectively used the school budget to pay for snow plowing and other expenses. These voters then refused to approve further money for the cash-strapped schools, forcing them to close months early.

 
 
Geezer Power
 This perception of "greedy geezers" may grow, partly because elderly voters wield disproportionate political influence, a tribute to their likeliness to vote and their passion about specific issues like social security. The elderly are no longer relatively poor in America, but because of their political influence -- since their feelings of vulnerability propel them to political involvement -- there is still a Government reallocation of resources to their pockets. For all the talk of educating children to secure the nation's future, for all the knowledge that children are the sector of the population most likely to live in poverty, the United States Government spends nine times as much on each elderly person as on each child.
Similar issues are being debated in capitals and dusty villages around the globe, for the aging of the population is a trend everywhere. Indeed, some of the countries that are aging most rapidly are in the statistically younger third world. The reason for aging there has less to do with baby boomers, and more to do with two other demographic factors. Vaccinations and other public health programs are leading to significantly longer lives, while at the same time the expectation that children will survive leads parents to choose smaller families. The average Indian woman today may still have three children, a bundle by American standards, but that is down from five in 1980, and life expectancy has risen from 52 to 60 in the same period.

 
 
The Respect Factor
 "A lot of countries are going to be caught unaware, because they are going to have a big boom in the elderly," said Kevin Kinsella, chief of the aging studies branch at the United States Census Bureau. Governments think that families will be able to look after the aged, Mr. Kinsella said, but he doubts they can handle the task on their own.
Andre Malraux once said that "youth is a religion from which one always ends up being converted." It will be fascinating to watch whether the baby boomers -- who in their youth led a fairly successful rebellion against the moral authority of the elderly -- will in the end be converted as well. It is easy to imagine graying boomers supporting moves to raise the legal ages for drinking or driving, conceivably even for voting. More fundamentally, they may try to restore the mantle of authority that as youngsters they had ripped down. All the current Bob Dole jokes notwithstanding, a recent survey of Americans found that the single value that parents most want to pass on to younger generations is not diligence or patriotism or consideration for others, but "respect for the aged," chosen by 91 percent of those surveyed. That is some distance to come for a generation that, in the 1960's, was famous for Jerry Rubin's dictum: "Never trust anyone over 30."
In this respect, Asian countries may be a bit better able than others to handle the aging of the population: the elderly are respected and the extended family still lingers. The Confucian world has always emphasized respect for the aged, and in Chinese to call an old man "lao" or "old" -- as when Mr. Xu becomes Xu Lao -- is to present him a great compliment, rendered by the standard Beijing Chinese-English dictionary as "our revered Comrade Xu." Children in East Asia were traditionally taught tales of filial piety, like the Chinese one about the old man who dressed up in a diaper and crawled around on the floor like a little baby, so that his even more aged and doddering parents would feel young again.

 
 
Dementia
 Not all children in East Asia were so filial, and Japan used to have ubasuteyama -- literally, "mountains to dump a granny" -- where elderly and unwanted women were left alone to die of hunger or cold. But in Japan today 57 percent of people over the age of 65 still live with their children. The result is, perhaps, not just happier grandparents but also better-supervised grandchildren.
"Here in Japan people live with their parents and grandparents, and the elderly have a role in the family," said Yukiko Kudo, a researcher at the longevity center in Tokyo. "In Japan, they know this role and they are not afraid of it. They feel that as they age they can do some good."
To be sure, as Mrs. Kudo knows -- her parents-in-law live in her home -- many Japanese no longer want to share their homes with their parents. And with so many single children, it often happens that a couple faces the prospect of looking after both sets of parents, creating an inverted pyramid: four grandparents, two parents, and one (incredibly spoiled) grandchild.
The aging of the boomers is vested with great significance in part because they are associated with major social changes over their life cycle. Beginning as teen-agers in the late 1950's, boomers transformed music, politics, hair styles and social mores. More recently, as the boomers have aged and grown pot bellies, they have stoked the fitness and diet boom; with well-paying jobs, they have triggered the surge in mutual funds and a long bull market that has been built on boomer savings and investments.
So what comes next? The graying of the boomers will focus growing attention on the problems of the elderly, from gums to prostates. If herpes was the disease of the 1970's, then dementia and depression among the elderly may capture the imagination in the 2010's. Suicide is disproportionately common among the elderly, as people face loneliness, infirmity, and the prospect of a mental slide into oblivion. Alzheimer's disease was identified only in 1906, when a neurologist named Alois Alzheimer studied a woman suffering from it, and already some 22 million people around the world are believed to have Alzheimer's and other forms of dementia. The number is soaring with the aging of the population, for in the 1990's alone, the number of people over age 65 in the world is set to rise by 30 percent.
An American gerontologist, Dr. Robert N. Butler, wrote of dementia in a recently published academic paper: "We will be confronted, indeed, with the 'disease of the 20th century' being transformed into the epidemic of the 21st."
Economists are also exploring the implications of the demographic trends. "As the population ages, the savings rate will decline," said Charles Y. Horioka, an American economist at Osaka University. This is because elderly people, instead of saving, often dip into past savings to pay for retirement. Less savings could lead to shortages of capital and higher interest rates, and also to changes in trade patterns.
Professor Horioka argues that the reduced savings will lead to sharp declines in Japan's capital exports and in the Japanese trade surplus. That process may already be beginning, for Japan's surplus has been tumbling for 20 consecutive months, and it could end up with something that a few years ago would have been regarded as more fanciful than a unicorn, a Japanese trade deficit.
Anticipating the demographic changes, companies are beginning to pour resources into industries that will cater to the elderly. A major Japanese conglomerate, Hankyu, which is mostly involved in railroads and retailing, announced recently that it would prepare for the future by entering the mortuary business. Investors are already looking for hot stocks as demographic plays.
Some brokerages are recommending nursing home companies; others favor golf courses, vitamin manufacturers or investment brokerages. Among the technologies to watch are home monitoring devices: bed sheets that automatically take electrocardiograms and toilet seats that automatically measure one's blood pressure.
Some investment strategists say the stock market should continue to benefit from a net inflow of cash as the baby boomers -- those born from 1946 to 1963, accounting for 31 percent of the American population -- reach their peak earning years in the next couple of decades. The problem is that the boomers would then be expected to pull money out of the market to finance their retirement, triggering a crash that could make 1929 seem tame.
While the consequences of global aging are hard to predict, the one point experts agree on is that the implications are enormous. And while there will be tremendous difficulties paying for the boomers' retirement, there is a bright side to all this. Aging may be a problem, but think of the alternative.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Parochial School Mystique

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
IN the 1950's and 60's, Roman Catholic schools were known as places where all students had to wear uniforms and bad students got their knuckles rapped or their ears pulled by nuns. Except for a handful of institutions, particularly Jesuit schools, they were not regarded as academically superior to public schools.
Suddenly, though, Catholic schools are being held up as a paragon of excellence by, among others, New York City's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who wants to send some of the city's worst students to them. Studies by the Rand Corporation and others support the Mayor, showing that Catholic school students -- especially the poorest -- have lower dropout rates, higher test scores and a better chance of going to college than their public school counterparts. 
 The new regard for Catholic schools has a lot to do with the falling status of public schools. Twenty years ago, there weren't as many poor students pulling down public schools' averages. And there wasn't as much of a need to start looking for alternatives.
But Mr. Giuliani's plan has people worried that if the city embraces parochial education, it will give up on the public schools. So what is the magic of parochial schools? And, why can't the public schools replicate it?

 
 
No More Rulers
 The magic is not in nuns' knuckle rapping. Corporal punishment is no longer practiced in most Catholic schools, and nuns have largely been replaced by lay teachers. (In most Catholic schools only about 10 percent of the teachers are nuns.)
It is certainly not the resources. Catholic schools are generally low-budget operations, with smaller expenditures per pupil than the public schools. Often they have no fancy gyms or laboratories. And their teaching methods typically are not on the cutting edge.
Maybe it's the uniforms then. Catholic schools still require those, and there are some people who think they engender the right attitude. President Clinton has even recommended bringing uniforms to public schools.
But many educators say more intangible factors set Catholic schools apart: the high standards they set for all their pupils and the close community feeling they engender. Since Catholic schools are smaller, with minimal bureaucracy, there is more interaction between students and teachers.
Perhaps the crucial element is the families' commitment. Indeed, some researchers say this is the factor that makes most of the difference. Catholic schools draw students from homes that value education highly, support their children's efforts in school, financially and otherwise, and often get involved with the schools.
Leonard DeFiore, president of the National Catholic Educational Association in Washington, says self-selection undoubtedly plays a role. But he believes the schools themselves are responsible too.
Catholic schools, some say, are working because they endorse certain values. "Old math, new math. Phonetics, whole language. It didn't matter," said Jacqueline Jordon Irvine, co-editor of "Growing Up African American in Catholic Schools" (Teachers College Press). "There was nothing remarkable about the curriculum or the instruction. What mattered was the people, the purpose, the values, the mission."
That theme is often sounded by those who have studied the schools. Paul T. Hill, the lead author of the Rand study, comparing public and parochial schools in New York City in the late 1980's, said initially he doubted the strength of parochial schools.
"As far as teaching techniques and command of the material, on the whole the public schools were better," said Mr. Hill, now a research professor at the University of Washington. "But the Catholic schools were highly motivational. And if a kid had a bad teacher, the Catholic schools took the responsibility and worked to make sure he caught up."
Most Catholic schools have a strict academic curriculum for all students, not just the strongest ones. It typically includes four years of high school English and math and three years of social studies, science and foreign language, well beyond public school requirements.
"In public schools, you can predict that it is largely African-American and Hispanic students who will end up in the lower track," said Janine Bempechat, an assistant professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. "At the Catholic schools, that is not the case. Even the lowest-track students are required to take one and a half or two years more of English and math than they would in the public schools. The standards are higher." And, Dr. Bempechat said, Catholic school students are less likely to blame external factors for their failure and more likely to believe in the value of effort.

 
 
Crosses and Prayers
 But what about the religious requirements? Parochial high school students typically have to take a religion course every year they are in school (covering scripture, church doctrine and practices and moral instruction), and elementary school students have formal religious teaching every day. These requirements would hold even for the public school students who transfer to parochial schools. What's more, signs of religious faith abound in Catholic schools: There are crucifixes on classroom walls, prayers at the beginning of class, and religious issues raised in history or English classes.
Still, some educators think this is a useful thing. "Even where children are not Catholic, there are retreats and liturgy requirements and a sense of spirituality that pervades the schools," said Peter B. Holland, a co-author of "Catholic Schools and the Common Good" (Harvard University Press, 1993). "This makes it clear that the schools are there not just for academic gains but for a broader purpose. It provides a social context."
Do the strengths of a Catholic education depend on a religious atmosphere? Not everyone thinks so. Dr. Holland, who is superintendent of schools in Belmont, Mass., and a former teacher and administrator in Catholic schools, said, "The kind of things Catholic schools talk about and do are the kinds of things we want in our public school systems -- things like deeper relationships between the adults and kids that extend beyond the school day and a greater focus on the academic curriculum."
Some public schools are moving in this direction, putting more emphasis on a core academic curriculum and trying to enrich student-teacher relationships through sports and other after-school programs. Chicago's public schools recently struck up a partnership with local Catholic schools with the aim of learning from each other.
But, asked Dr. Holland, "How do you create an inspirational ideology in a pluralistic society that is comparable to the sacramental rites and saints in the Catholic schools? The private schools try to do it through inspirational leadership. How you do it in a large urban system, I am not sure."

HEADLINE: The Fed Can Wait

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve is coming under enormous pressure, from inside and out, to raise interest rates when it meets Tuesday. It should resist. The economy is performing better than nearly any economist, until recently, would have predicted. Yet there is barely a whiff of the dreaded monster, inflation, that the Fed is responsible for slaying. The only supposedly "troubling" sign is that wages have begun to outstrip prices -- but that is actually a wondrous turnaround after decades of wage stagnation. Before the Fed clamps down, it ought to have a better reason than the fact that workers are, finally, enjoying fatter paychecks.
Many on Wall Street, and most of the presidents of the regional Federal Reserve banks, are pushing for a rate hike as a preventive strike against inflation. But the wiser course is to watch and wait. If, over the next few months, unemployment continues to fall without triggering inflation, then the Fed would have learned an invaluable lesson about how good this economy can get. If, however, prices begin to creep up, then the Fed can clamp down and prove yet again, as if anyone were in doubt, that Mr. Greenspan will not tarnish his successful nine-year reign by permitting higher inflation to grab hold. 
 Tuesday's meeting has drawn exaggerated attention, especially by Clinton supporters, because it is the last before elections. But even if the Fed were to raise interest rates by modest amounts, the economy would barely slow and even that would not happen for six months or more, well beyond November. The feared impact of a Fed hike of short-term rates -- the only ones it controls -- on mortgage and other important long-term rates is also misplaced. A Fed decision to raise short-term rates would signal Wall Street that it intends to bring inflation lower. An expectation of lower inflation could bring long-term rates -- a portion of which compensates lenders for future inflation -- down.
The Greenspan-led Fed has steered the economy to its best combination of unemployment and inflation in decades. A legitimate issue is whether the economy is overachieving. Unemployment is down to nearly 5 percent, the lowest rate in seven years and about a full percentage point below what economists used to think was the rate that could be sustained. Wages are rising slightly faster than prices and much faster than productivity. If those trends continue, profits will fall and companies will react by further pushing up prices. However, profits have plenty of room to fall from their high levels. Besides, workers are hardly flourishing. Total compensation -- benefits plus wages -- has been barely keeping pace with inflation.
The old wisdom -- that a 5 percent unemployment rate puts too heavy a strain on labor markets, driving up wages and then prices -- may yet prove accurate. What makes matters hard is that the Fed cannot wait long enough to find out for sure. It must anticipate problems months in advance or else find that inflation has already spiked and it must crack down hard, creating a recession. Yet there is no reason that the Fed must react before there is any inflationary sign even on a distant horizon.
The Fed would be not be acting irresponsibly if it raised rates on Tuesday. A rate hike might not even be wrong. But it is surely unnecessary.

HEADLINE: John W. Tuthill, 85, Career Envoy for U.S.

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

 BODY:
John W. Tuthill, who served as United States Ambassador to the European Economic Community and to Brazil, died on Sept. 9 in a Washington hospital. He was 85 and lived in Washington.
The cause was cancer, said Frances Miller, who helped him write his memoirs. 
 Mr. Tuthill, a highly regarded career diplomat, was Ambassador to the European Economic Community from 1962 to 1966. In 1964 he issued a warning in a speech to American businessmen visiting Brussels.
Europeans, Mr. Tuthill told them, feared that American business was so powerful that it would eventually change Europe's way of life.
That fear, he said, "is a factor which you and the United States Government must bear in mind." He added, "We must be especially regardful of local problems, local traditions and local pride."
Born in Montclair, N.J., he graduated from the College of William and Mary and received graduate degrees from Harvard and New York University. His diplomatic career extended from 1940 to 1969.
His memoir, "Some Things to Some Men: Serving in the Foreign Service," is to be published by Minerva Press.
He is survived by his wife, Erna; a son, David, of Redondo Beach, Calif.; and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
Crime Rates May Be Down, but the Problem Stays Hot With Politicians, and Voters

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 18

 BODY:
There is nothing unusual in Tampa about Ed W. Block's belief that crime is just about the biggest problem around.
On local television stations, car-jackings and murders are reported breathlessly on the evening news. In a recent survey taken in Hillsborough County, which includes Tampa, people ranked crime far ahead of their other concerns. Such polls are sheet music for politicians, and their drumbeat crosses party lines: Tough on crime, tough on crime. 
 The only thing odd about all this is that the crime rate has been falling in Tampa, as it has in many other cities around the country. On a day this week when Bob Dole was doggedly pushing crime to the center of the Presidential campaign and President Clinton seemed just as eager to engage the voters' concerns over the issue, the Justice Department reported that violent crime dropped by 9 percent last year.
"That's what the paper says," Mr. Block, 62, said, waving the statistics away as he sat while on a break from his job managing a cigar store in downtown Tampa. "But all I hear about are these car thefts, the rapes, holdups, stickups. In May, I bought a new Honda Accord. Went to this pizza place. When we came back, someone had already screwed around with the lock on the driver's side. Cost me 500 bucks."
With precious few Communists left to stand up to, almost no good trade fights and the economy gurgling along, it is all a politician can do these days to draw up an enemies' list. As Mr. Dole seemed to have concluded this week, there may be no political staple quite like crime. Not even, perhaps, taxes.
"Drugs and crime are sort of good-weather concerns in American politics," said Franklin E. Zimring, the director of the Earl Warren Legal Institute at the University of California at Berkeley. "Violence around the corner is something we always have to worry about when we don't have more pressing problems in the immediate vicinity."
Couched in the falling rates for all crimes are numbers that may explain some part of the continuing public concern: From 1985 to 1994, a period when murders by adults were generally in decline, the rate of murders by people from 14 to 17 years old jumped 172 percent, according to research by James Alan Fox, dean of the College of Criminal Justice at Northeastern University.
But criminologists, political scientists and sociologists who have studied public opinion about crime say politicians' stubborn focus on the issue in recent years also reflects the fact that Americans' fears of crime have rarely followed the crime rate, and that the extent to which people see crime as a problem has even less to do with the statistical rise and fall.
Nor does people's sense of crime in their own neighborhoods necessarily have much to do with how they see the nation's crime problem.
People's views on the issue, the experts say, appear to be shaped much more by what they see on their local television news and at the movies, by the talk at their workplaces and by the politicians.
"One good solid murder of a baby or a rape-murder of a 7-year-old girl will outweigh a ton of statistics," said Lawrence M. Friedman, a professor of law at Stanford University.
After several years in which reported crime was relatively stable, the proportion of people who thought crime was the country's most serious problem rocketed to 37 percent in 1994, from 9 percent the previous year, according to a Gallup survey.
The source of the public's reassessment is still debated. But some analysts point to a string of lurid incidents that drew extraordinary attention from the news media: the kidnapping and slaying of 12-year-old Polly H. Klaas in California, the cold-blooded shootings by a gunman on a Long Island Rail Road train, the Menendez brothers' slayings of their parents and the assault on the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan.
However vulnerable people may have been last year or a few years ago, said E. Mark Warr, a sociologist at the University of Texas, Americans generally contrast the latest brutal events with the warm, idealized images of "the good old days," when everyone knew their neighbors, left their doors unlocked and did not worry about their children being shot by young gangsters driving by.
In Wichita, Kan., where the police reported that overall crime dropped 12 percent in 1995 and is down 7 percent so far this year, Mayor Bob Knight said there was no question but that crime was the central issue of the campaign in which he won election last year. Whatever the real odds that someone in the city might be the victim of a violent crime, he and others suggested, people's impressions of the problem seem to be shaped more by occasional incidents that reinforce the notion of a place where killers keep getting younger, the street gangs more violent and the courts less effective.
June Hargrove, a 72-year-old widow who lives in a condominium in northwest Wichita, described her neighborhood as "pretty safe," but said she was unnerved by what she saw on the local television news. Beyond Wichita, she said of crime, "It's definitely worse elsewhere."
A survey conducted for the National Law Journal in 1989 -- after a decade in which the murder rate generally fell -- found many people like Mrs. Hargrove. More than 80 percent of those questioned said they thought crime was worsening in the United States. Another 34 percent of the sample described themselves as feeling "truly desperate" about the situation. But in the same poll, almost two-thirds of the people surveyed said the crime problem in their own neighborhood was either improving or staying the same.
Such sentiment has been good political news for Republicans since the crime rate started a long rise in the mid-1960's.
Richard M. Nixon made crime a central theme of both of his successful runs for the Presidency, even at a time when most Americans opposed the death penalty. In 1980, even though the country's homicide rate was hitting a post-World War II peak, the issue was for the most part overshadowed by those of the ailing economy and the hostages in Iran.
But in 1988, George Bush's landslide Presidential victory over Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts owed a debt to a widely criticized television commercial featuring a convicted murderer, Willie Horton, who attacked a couple and raped the woman after being furloughed from a Massachusetts prison.
Mr. Dole turned to the crime issue in part out of a confidence that the rate at which people are actually victimized might be of less political importance than their fears. "Regardless of what statistics say, ordinary Americans suffer acute anxiety when it comes to their safety," said Mr. Dole's campaign press secretary, Nelson Warfield.
The Republican portrayal of Mr. Clinton as tolerant of crime and unperturbed about rising drug use among teen-agers also serves one of Mr. Dole's broader strategic goals, one of his advisers said -- to paint the President as a closet liberal.
The crime issue, the aide said, "speaks to the weaknesses of liberals on a number of different levels -- a lenient attitude toward personal responsibility, a willingness to blame society's ills on some sort of anti-social behavior and not on the ills of the individual."
Mr. Clinton's enthusiasm for the fight over crime has only partly to do with figures from the Federal Bureau of Investigation showing that the overall crime rate has dropped steadily since 1991. Since his tenure as Arkansas's Attorney General and Governor, Mr. Clinton has sought to steel himself against the historical Republican attacks, by supporting the death penalty, backing a ban on assault weapons and seeking money for the hiring of more police officers.
The President's aides seemed barely able to contain their glee at having Mr. Clinton endorsed by the nation's biggest police union just as Mr. Dole began on Monday to focus his campaign on crime. In a telephone interview on Thursday, one of Mr. Clinton's political advisers, Rahm Emanuel, characterized the President at least nine times as standing "shoulder to shoulder" with law-enforcement officers.
"I think the Republicans are in a time warp on this," Mr. Emanuel said. "They have tried to use it over the past 25 years against Democrats. But against President Clinton, with his record, it is not an effective tool."
Pollsters tend to agree. In a telephone survey of 1,020 people on Sept. 3 and 4 by ABC News and The Washington Post, 46 percent of those questioned said they trusted Mr. Clinton to do a better job fighting crime, as against 40 percent for Mr. Dole. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Mr. Clinton may also be the beneficiary of another gap between numbers and perceptions, one in which some of those who sense that crime is getting worse still believe he can better solve the problem.
"They say it's gone down, but I really haven't seen the change," said Will Williams, 21, a bus company maintenance worker in Tampa. "It's like Bill Clinton cutting the budget. I haven't seen any cuts yet."
Mr. Williams added that he would vote for the President nonetheless. "Bob Dole says a lot of things that don't add up for me," he said.

HEADLINE: A 7th Ave. Campaign Goes to Washington

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
All week, trunks arrived from New York slated for unpacking at the National Building Museum. Tissue and tape, gaggles of models like Kate Moss and Amber Valetta, mounds of accessories and setup crews were a thunderous advance for the arrival of designers like Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan, Calvin Klein, Isaac Mizrahi, Linda Allard and Oscar de la Renta.
More than $1 million in clothing was shipped from Seventh Avenue in Manhattan to a city not usually known for its fashion acumen. 
 Washington deals in faux a lot, rarely faux crocodile. But in an unusual alliance of fashion and politics, Seventh Avenue has moved off its usual turf and embraced the rubber-chicken crowd here in a push to give breast cancer a profile that rivals that reserved for AIDS.
Come Tuesday, the elegant but cavernous museum will be transformed into "Super Sale 1996," a shopaholic extravaganza-cum-gala dinner to benefit breast cancer research. Diana, the Princess of Wales, is honorary chairwoman for the evening; Hillary Rodham Clinton will be the host of a breakfast that morning.
More than 1,100 guests, including Gen. Colin L. Powell; Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, President Clinton's top economic adviser, and Elizabeth Dole are expected for the gala and shopping on Tuesday night.
About 800 people paid $500 each for the dinner, while an additional 300 paid $150 to join them for dessert. The cable network VH-1, in broadcasts before and after the event, will be promoting T-shirts designed by Mr. Lauren as part of the fund-raising effort. On Friday and Saturday, the general public, for $15 a person, can have a crack at purchasing the clothing, which was donated by designers for the occasion.
"Nothing this major has ever been done for breast cancer here before so we think it will raise awareness," said Mr. Lauren, who organized the event with Anna Wintour, editor in chief of Vogue magazine; the Council of Fashion Designers of America, and The Washington Post. All proceeds will benefit Georgetown University's Nina Hyde Center for Breast Cancer Research, which will present its first humanitarian award to Mr. Lauren.
Mrs. Hyde, a fashion writer for The Washington Post who died of breast cancer in 1990, was a friend of Mr. Lauren. "I made a commitment to her," said Mr. Lauren, who began his personal fund-raising efforts in 1989 with a cocktail party at Washington's Carlyle Hotel and raised nearly $1 million.
"That was the beginning," he said. "Then six months ago, Anna said she'd like to do something really big in Washington and get the whole fashion world in on it. Since this is home base for the center, we thought the exposure would be really great and special."
Initially, there was skepticism about holding a fashion fund-raiser here.
"We thought at first that you couldn't do things here the way you do things in New York," said Katharine Graham, the former publisher of The Washington Post. "But Anna said, 'Let's try.' And she just did it."
Ms. Wintour said they had faced some resistance. "Maybe in New York we get jaded," she said. "Some people said, 'You're never going to raise any money down there.' But across the board, everyone has completely responded, and we're completely sold out. We've got celebrities coming down. Designers have been extraordinarily generous."
The opening night gala, "A Salute to American Fashion," is being underwritten by Mr. Lauren and Vogue, and tables are selling for $10,000 to $25,000 each, which is in addition to the individual's cost.
"We've all written big checks," said Paul Wilmot, vice president of public relations for Conde Nast. "But what starts with the bank account ends with personal involvement."
Ms. Karan, for example, who has been in Europe on business, was expected to return for the gala.
"This isn't about clothes for Donna, but about creative people coming together to do some great things," said Patty Cohen, the senior vice president of public relations for the designer. In the last year, breast cancer has been gradually emerging on a par with AIDS in the fashion industry's charitable hierarchy.
A community that poured out its sorrow over AIDS in high-profile charity events like "Seventh on Sale," the fashion industry's shopping bonanza and fund raiser, in part because many of its creative talents have been stricken by the disease, has increasingly turned its attention to breast cancer.
Women are a natural constituency of the fashion industry so breast cancer awareness has grown out of the lessons learned from the effectiveness of advocates for people with AIDS.
"Ten years ago, breast cancer was just as important an issue, but people wouldn't talk about it," said Fern Mallis, executive director of the New York-based Council of Fashion Designers. "The breast cancer lobby took a lot of cues and learned a lot from the AIDS messengers and fund-raisers."
Beginning with the "Fashion Targets Breast Cancer" T-shirts produced by Mr. Lauren in 1994, the fashion industry has increasingly expressed its support for breast cancer research. Revlon has established a foundation, and Avon Products sponsors a program called the Breast Cancer Awareness Campaign.
In Times Square, Linda Evangelista looms large on a billboard advertisement for Kenar sportswear seeking public support for the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. The foundation was established by Evelyn H. Lauder, senior corporate vice president of the Estee Lauder Companies, to raise money for clinical research at 10 medical centers around the country.
Next month, five General Motors cars, each customized by the designers Richard Tyler, Nicole Miller, Todd Oldham, Anna Sui and Mark Eisen, will be auctioned in New York at another benefit as part of National Breast Cancer Awareness Month.
"A lot of folks are realizing that breast cancer is an important issue for women and women are their main customers," said Jane Reese-Coulbourne, vice president of the National Breast Cancer Coalition, which includes 270 organizations. The coalition is working with designers to create a piece of jewelry that could be sold to raise money and increase public awareness of the disease.
But nothing except "Seventh on Sale," on which it is patterned, is likely to rival this week's fund-raising efforts.
"Super Sale was very low-key and fairly small the first year, and it was profitable and good last year," Mrs. Graham said. "But with this nucleus of fine fashion designers, the whole thing has just escalated."
AIDS, Ms. Mallis said, has been the "big galvanizing force" for the fashion industry, teaching it that "we had the ability to raise enormous amounts of money."
Some observers, however, are concerned that expanding the altruistic tent to breast cancer might dilute support for AIDS.
"Sometimes people try to bring that up," Ms. Reese-Coulbourne said. "But this is not the disease Olympics. They're both horrible diseases, and what we really want is not take a piece of the pie from somebody else, but make the pie bigger."

HEADLINE: A Portrait of the City, Painted by the Numbers

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The numbers that are the life force of New York City government are born anew each year in the Mayor's Management Report, required by law each September. The reports always draw political fire, and the one that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani issued last week came under particular criticism for its sunny spin on the state of city services.
 But the report is much more than a political document. Its gray columns of figures create a snapshot of New York at this moment: how sick or well its residents are, how slowly cars move through midtown Manhattan, how many people skated at a public rink, how many died. These highlights are a small fraction of the complete urban almanac. DAVID FIRESTONE

HEADLINE: Jackson Journal;
As Snow Falls in Tetons, Elk Temperatures Rise

BYLINE: By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 20

 BODY:
The first snows of the year have fallen in the mountains that dramatically surround this luxury resort town, bringing summer to an abrupt halt and signaling the onset of autumn.
The snow, which has dusted the craggy peaks of the Tetons with a coat of white halfway down, is also a harbinger of the beginning of the season of the elk, as herds of thousands begin their ancient seasonal migration from the high country to lower altitudes, where traces of summer can still be found. 
 Elk are a totem animal in Jackson. The town square is decorated with four large arches made entirely from thousands of bleached white elk antlers, and the only National Elk Refuge in the nation is a five-minute walk from downtown. Elk meat is on some restaurant menus.
In the meadows and pine forests of nearby Grand Teton National Park and on national forest land, branch-antlered bull elk have begun their rut. Sounds that resemble everything from a loud squeaky hinge to a human scream fill the air as the bulls announce that the urge to reproduce is upon them and that they are ready to defend their turf.
Not all elk are below the snow line. Early on Thursday morning, as a heavy wet snow gathered on the meadow grasses of Whitegrass Meadow in the park, the trumpeting of a bull elk echoed eerily in the air while his harem of a dozen cow elk quietly grazed. At the other end of the meadow, near the boarded-up log cabins of an abandoned guest ranch, two bulls locked antlers behind an ethereal veil of white falling snow, struggling for dominance. Each fall the bulls' necks swell with the strength that allows them to battle more effectively with antlers than can weigh up to 60 pounds.
It is still too early for the elk to descend all the way to the National Elk Refuge. "I imagine we'll see the first of the bull elk showing up here any day," said Barry Reiswig, manager of the refuge, which the United States Fish and Wildlife Service operates. "This is a place where they know they're safe."
In the coming months, as many as 18,000 elk will make their descent through the winter clouds that cling alongside the mountains to the long grassy valley of the refuge.
The herds are at the center of an elk economy that has grown in recent years in town and in Jackson Hole, as the valley here is called. On Saturday orange-jacketed hunters will swarm to the region to cull the herd.
Tourists also travel to see one of the great wildlife migrations, especially in the park and the refuge, where hunting is forbidden. Elk are most active this time of year. "Bachelor bulls are breaking into harems," said Greg Winston, an outfitter in Jackson who takes people on wildlife photo safaris. "When they're evenly matched, they get into a shoving match. It's never deadly, but I've seen bulls shoved over onto their back. It's pretty impressive."
A bull elk can also be dangerous. This week, a German tourist in Yellowstone National Park was pinned to her automobile by a sexually aroused bull elk, park officials said, but the woman was not injured.
In December, after the deep snows have arrived, migration is complete, and visitors can take horse-drawn sleigh rides through the extensive herds. Last year more than 25,000 people took rides.
Occasionally elk leave the refuge and wander downtown, browsing on shrubs in yards or standing in roads and highways. Refuge employees sometimes herd the animals back to their area on horseback, but that is no easy task. A fully grown elk can weigh 800 pounds and stand five feet tall at the shoulder. "Elk can only be moved into the wind," apparently so they can sense what's ahead of them by smell, Mr. Reiswig said. "If the wind is blowing the wrong way, they can't be moved."
Antlers are also part of the economy. Each spring, before the herds make their journeys back to the mountains, they drop their antlers.
In May, as the snow retreats, Boy Scouts assemble at the refuge to gather thousands of antlers. Artisans here fashion the branches into items like candelabra, chairs, tables, knife handles, belt buckles and buttons.
Dixie Sowards of Elkhorn Designs, a home-furnishings store, said elk-horn chandeliers were extremely popular. "That one right there," Ms. Sowards said, pointing to a nearly five-foot-tall pyramid of antlers with lights, "is very hot right now."
It costs $5,600.
But the biggest consumers of antlers are dealers, who buy them for $8 or $9 a pound to sell to a lucrative Asian market. There they are made into tea that is believed to have medicinal properties.
The sale of antlers last year fetched nearly $100,000. Eighty percent goes to the refuge; the Boy Scouts keep the rest.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Each May, local Boy Scouts collect antlers for sale at auction. It is the season of the elk in Jackson, Wyo., and that means bull elk try to show each other who's boss. Each fall the bulls' necks swell with blood, strengthening them to battle with antlers that can weigh up to 60 pounds. "I've seen bulls shoved over onto their back," one outfitter said. HEADLINE: Academics and Labor Leaders Pulling in Tandem Once More

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
After a 30-year estrangement in which union leaders shunned academics as too far to the left and the liberal intelligentsia scorned big labor as part of the establishment, the two sides have begun efforts to forge a new alliance.
Academics are counseling students to become union organizers and are donating time to teach courses to union officials. Cornell University professors held a conference with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on how labor can do more organizing, while many sociology professors are revamping their courses to focus more on labor's role in society. 
 In early October, several dozen professors will join union leaders at Columbia University for a 1960's-style teach-in intended to give the academic world's imprimatur to labor's new leadership and to explore how intellectuals can advance the goals of organized labor. Similar events will be held at a dozen other schools, including the University of Wisconsin, the University of Florida, Eastern Illinois University, Wayne State University in Detroit and the University of Texas at El Paso.
"We want to lend the support of a large number of academics and intellectuals to the revitalization of labor," said Eric Foner, a history professor at Columbia University who is helping to organize the teach-ins. "From our point of view, there is no real hope for progressive social change in this country without a strong labor movement, and without a strong labor movement the conservative tendency of things is never going to be reversed."
This labor-intellectual alliance is intended to put an end to three decades in which liberal academics and unions were at loggerheads over Vietnam, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s obsession with the cold war and labor's foot-dragging on allowing more women and minorities into unionized jobs.
Labor leaders hope that historians, economists and sociologists will not only help them in union organizing drives, but will also help change the public's perception of labor.
The alliance is being pursued by John J. Sweeney, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, at a time when he is trying to build coalitions with other segments of society, including the clergy, women's groups, students, environmentalists and Hispanic people.
"As part of our effort to rebuild the progressive coalition in this country, it's important that progressive academics play a major role," said Robert Welsh, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s chief of staff.
The new ties are still minuscule, compared with the alliance between intellectuals and unions in the 1930's, when academics ran labor colleges and union newspapers and wrote pro-labor polemics. Still, academics have promised that their current support will besubstantial.
"What we're talking about is not just a few intellectuals providing some ad hoc advice, but about some significant potential shifts in research time and thinking," said Tom Juravich, research director for the labor relations school at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
Some conservative intellectuals heaped scorn on this effort. Roger Kimball, managing editor of The New Criterion, a conservative journal, called labor's academic allies "a rogues' gallery of politically correct intellectuals who have a very serious case of Marx envy."
He added: "They are infused with an incredible nostalgia for a kind of political activism which they hope can infuse a higher purpose to their lives. They look to the 60's and to the 30's for models for this kind of militant activism, safe though they are in their ivied groves of academia."
The new effort comes at a time when professors at private colleges, like Bennington, and public universities, like the City University of New York, are facing some of the same pressures that other workers face, like downsizing and pay freezes.
Officials with the American Association of University Professors acknowledge that they hope the A.F.L.-C.I.O. will back their fights to preserve tenure, win raises and reverse cuts in education spending.
At a news conference in Washington on Wednesday, James A. Perley, president of the association, said, "We've come to realize that we need to reach out to make connections to others who are experiencing the same kind of difficulties."
Professors, writers and intellectuals say they have embraced the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s leadership because it is seeking to transform labor into a broad social movement, and, they say, dropping its focus on helping the relatively well-paid union elite. Many academics say they are pleased that Mr. Sweeney has focused on organizing more workers and raising the wages of low-paid workers.
"In the 1930's, many intellectuals supported labor because it represented not just an interest group, but a social movement whose activities promised much to not only its immediate members, but to the whole society," said Steven Fraser, co-chairman of the teach-ins and author of a biography on Sidney Hillman, the clothing workers' leader. "The social movement character of labor began to decline in the 1950's and was pretty much dead by the end of the 1960's. That's what had originally attracted intellectuals. Now, I'm happy to say, that social movement character is returning."
For their part, labor leaders found it hard to forgive liberal academics for opposing the Vietnam War. And in the 1980's, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. hierarchy made common cause with some neo-conservative intellectuals in opposing leftist movements in Central America. In a hierarchy that was forever seeking to root out Communists, many labor leaders were squeamish about associating with academics who they feared were closet Communists.
In recent weeks, professors at U.C.L.A. have advised the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on setting up its Union Summer program, in which more than 1,000 students volunteered to work for unions, and on carrying out an organizing effort at small factories in Los Angeles.
At Sarah Lawrence College, Priscilla Murolo, a history professor, has encouraged some students to become union organizers. And at Eastern Illinois University in Charleston, Gretchen Knapp, a history professor, is setting up a teach-in and film festival about the labor movement.
"A lot of our students, after they leave here, will be encouraged to join unions or will deal with unions in some way, shape or form," Professor Knapp said. "These students know little about unions, and we're trying to show them what the labor movement stands for."
The teach-in speakers at Columbia on Oct. 3 and 4 will include Cornel West, professor of Afro-American studies at Harvard; the feminist author Betty Friedan, and Richard Rorty, a University of Virginia philosopher.

HEADLINE: Little-Noticed Cut Imperils Safety Net for the Poor

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 20

 BODY:
A little-noticed provision in the nation's new welfare law that will immediately cut Federal money for safety-net services like soup kitchens and child protection programs has set off a struggle by state officials to preserve what they can.
As of Oct. 1, the Government will chop 15 percent, or $420 million, from the $2.8 billion it distributes annually to the states in no-strings-attached money under a program known as the Social Services Block Grant. 
 States use the appropriations for hundreds of purposes, typically to help the elderly poor stay out of nursing homes, to pay for shelters and day care, to rehabilitate juvenile criminals and to rescue children from parental abuse or neglect.
States say the cuts, which began in June, come at the worst possible moment, when they expect the welfare law to start increasing the demand for the services by people like legal immigrants, mentally disabled children and single adults who stand to lose food stamps or other assistance under the law's other provisions.
"It's not welfare reform," said Greg Vadner, director of the Division of Aging of Missouri's Department of Social Services. "You just have less money. It's purely a funding cut."
Like many states, Missouri is asking managers of local safety-net programs to prepare to accommodate the reduction. Steve Renne, deputy director of the Department of Social Services in Jefferson City, said the Legislature would consider a special appropriation to offset the cuts, using savings from the decrease in the welfare rolls because of the healthy economy.
But some services will be cut, too. "It will be some combination of all those options," Mr. Renne said. "Within the next 30 days, we will have to decide. Our legislative folks don't want to be in the position of picking up the loss when the Federal Government cuts a program."
Mr. Vadner said that in his division, the cuts meant that new applicants for home-delivered meals would be turned away. "We will reduce the number of people we serve," he said.
The concern intensifies at the community level, where social workers, teachers, counselors and local charities come face to face with the poor. The Salvation Army in Columbia, which receives only 2 percent of its money from public agencies and none under the block grant, is already reeling from the effect of the stiffer welfare regulations that Missouri, like most states, adopted in the months before the Federal law was enacted.
"We're getting more and more families," said Capt. Max Grindel, commanding officer here. Through mid-September, he said, he had served 25,000 meals, up from 16,000 at the same time last year. Every night, all 50 beds in the shelter are taken, he said, and he hopes to expand. "We're in need of a new shelter," he said.
Lynn Cole, children's services supervisor for Boone County, of which Columbia is the hub, said: "Some of these people won't be able to care for their children, so their children will be coming to us. What I see is more children coming in for care and less resources to help them."
The cuts, she said, could halt the expansion of services like Althea Harris's. Ms. Harris, 45 and single, has degrees in social work and law, but she has chosen to work as a career foster parent under a four-year-old program dedicated to helping Columbia's most neglected or abused children.
The state pays her $45 per child a day to rehabilitate up to two severely troubled children and prepare them for adoption or return to their parents. She has adopted four of her foster children, now 8 to 17 years old.
"It's just fun," she said of her work. "A van load of kids. Going to the library. Taking them to swimming lessons. We work real intensively with them and their families. We show the parents whatever behavioral techniques work best. What's gratifying is when the kids can go back home."
The state also uses the Social Services Block Grant to help pay for the average $110 daily cost of caring for youngsters ages 12 to 17 in closely supervised group homes after they had turned to crime. Demand for that service, too, is growing, said Terry Finn, regional administrator for the Division of Youth Services.
"We're behind the eight ball," Mr. Finn said. His budget has not yet been cut, but he has been warned that it is likely to be. "We do not have sufficient resources now," he said. "Our beds are filled, and we have a waiting list."
Missouri is not at all unique in wrestling with maintaining these services. Some states with healthy treasuries, like Iowa, say they expect to accommodate the cuts at least through next year by using more of their own money and savings from sharp declines in their welfare caseloads. But others, including California, Arizona, Tennessee and North Carolina, have already reduced some grant-subsidized services. In New York, a task force is evaluating the situation.
Under the principal financing provision of the welfare law, Congress is giving the states a total of $16.4 billion annually to 2002 in the form of different and much larger block grants separate from the Social Services Block Grants. The states will partly match the new block grants and use the money for welfare checks for poor families and training for jobs.
Because the total amount is fixed, the new grants do not take account of the rising cost of living or an eventual recession, when workers would lose jobs and come looking for aid. But the initial grants will be more than the states would have received under the tightly regulated cash-assistance program called Aid to Families With Dependent Children because they are based upon years when the economy was weaker and caseloads were larger. So many states say it could be a couple of years before they begin to feel a pinch in the block grants.
But the effect of the change in financing the Social Services Block Grants, Title 20 of the Social Security Act, is swift and immediate. The 15 percent reduction is an actual cut, not a cut in expected future spending under the old system. That grant is fixed at $2.38 billion a year until 2003, when it would rise to $2.8 billion again.
The cut has already begun to bite. Congress ordered it initially in last April's budget agreement, and the states began seeing a drop in financing in June. At the time, it was a temporary, deficit-reducing measure. But in the new welfare bill, Congress extended the time the cut will be in effect. For Missouri, the grant has dropped to $48.1 million from $56.7 million.
Paradoxically, these grants served as a model of the change the states sought from Congress in overhauling the welfare system, especially the much larger A.F.D.C.
Under the social services program, unlike A.F.D.C., states are allowed almost total flexibility in spending to help the needy, so much so that Congress and the Department of Health and Human Services do not require them to submit breakdowns of their use of the money.
Congress, however, decided not to permit such flexibility with its successor to A.F.D.C., Temporary Assistance for Needy Families. It loosened some strings, for example, in letting states determine a family's eligibility for welfare, but attached new ones, like one requiring that 25 percent of the adults be working by the next year.
In the welfare law, Congress did allow states a way out of the cut in the social services grant. It said they could shift 10 percent of their temporary-assistance money to the services. But that, the states say, forces them to choose which groups of the poor they will serve.
In Columbia, the elderly, like children, are seen as likely to suffer. Jean Leonatti, executive director of the 19-county Central Missouri Area on Aging, said that during the year through June, her staff brought meals to 5,023 homebound old and disabled people.
It also provided 3,498 rides to doctors' offices and pharmacies and sent aides to the homes of 217 area residents, many with Alzheimer's disease, to provide respite care, freeing spouses or other care givers to leave the house.
Ms. Leonatti said the social services block grant had provided about 10 percent of her $3.2 million budget but about 50 percent of the $450,000 of her gasoline costs. A cut in the subsidy in June has meant a cut in service. "We can only travel some of those routes one day a week now," she said, "so we'll bring them one hot meal and four frozen meals."
One of Ms. Leonatti's drivers is Lena Cheathum, 24, a single mother of three children who stays off welfare by delivering meals 40 hours a week and working 50 more in two part-time jobs. She delivers 58 meals a day. Her vehicle is a 1983 Dodge Colt, with 91,000 miles, a torn-out radio and a choking muffler.
Ms. Cheathum is a vital link to the homebound elderly and disabled, but the cut means her visits could become less frequent, even though she is the only regular visitor for some of them. As such, Ms. Leonatti said, she is often the first to spot a client whose health has taken a turn for the worse and needs help.
"I love this," Ms. Cheathum said, as she stopped at the small brick home of Willmetia Armstrong with a warm box containing a pork chop, mashed potatoes, green beans and a cup of tapioca pudding. "The people on my route, they have a fit when I'm not there and somebody else comes."
Ms. Armstrong, who said she was born in 1908, calls Ms. Cheathum "hon." She said: "She lets me stay here by myself and keep out of an institution. They have a girl who comes in to clean, too. I get to stay here as long as I can."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lena Cheathum, who takes meals to the homebound elderly under a welfare program that is being cut, prepares food for deliveries. (Jeff Roberson for The New York Times) (pg. 1); Althea Harris, who has degrees in social work and law, prefers to be a career foster parent of some of the most neglected or abused children in Columbia, Mo. "It's just fun," she said of the trips she takes with the children. (Jeff Roberson for The New York Times) (pg. 16)

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Florida Stuns 107,608 in 20 Explosive Minutes

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

DATELINE: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 21

 BODY:
Defying convention, the laws of etiquette and the largest crowd to see a college football game in 66 years, the Florida Gators streaked to 35 consecutive points in the first 19 minutes 54 seconds on the way to a convincing, if misleadingly narrow, 35-29 victory over Tennessee.
The fourth-ranked Gators (3-0) defeated the No. 2 Vols for the fourth consecutive time in their 14th straight Southeastern Conference victory. Florida's triumph became an essential step toward a possible fourth straight S.E.C. championship, ended Tennessee's 11-game winning streak and all but finished any Tennessee hope for a first national championship since 1951. 
 Florida's high-powered victory, built upon calculated risks, odd formations and the time-tested foundation of a solid running game, quieted a passionate standing-room crowd of 107,608 at Neyland Stadium. The crowd was the largest since an estimated 110,000 at Soldier Field in Chicago saw Notre Dame beat Army in 1930.
Tennessee (2-1) outgained Florida, 501 yards to 304, and yet the Gators were never close to being in danger. Peyton Manning set Tennessee records with 37 completions, 65 attempts and 492 passing yards. Manning threw four touchdown passes, three of them in the last 17:21 including one with 10 seconds to play.
Manning had a Heisman-like second half -- 25 of 39, 277 yards, 3 touchdowns, no interceptions -- but the damage was already too much to overcome. The desperate reliance on Manning's passing was a result of a distorted approach caused by six Vol turnovers -- including four Manning interceptions -- in a nightmarish first half. The harsh-sounding proclamations of two Florida sophomores, Johnny Rutledge and Tim Beauchamp, that Tennessee's offensive line was error-prone and that Manning could be pressured into mistakes, became prophetic.
Danny Wuerffel of the Gators was economical: 11 of 22 for 155 yards. Sixty-five of those yards produced four touchdown passes. Wuerffel's career total increased to 82, fifth best in major-college history, two behind Jim McMahon of Brigham Young.
Wuerffel did not throw an interception, as Florida lost just one fumble and converted three of the six Vol turnovers into 21 Gator points. Florida produced 149 rushing yards -- 86 by Terry Jackson -- and held Tennessee to 9 net rushing yards, a factor that allowed Florida to establish control.
At the end, the scoreboard said this game was the closest between Florida and Tennessee in 20 years. But Florida's victory, over the highest-ranked opponent any Gator team has ever defeated, was built upon a dominance in two categories that was established from the start.
The more aggressive Gator defense, reconstructed by a new defensive coordinator, Bob Stoops, held the Volunteers to the sixth-fewest rushing yards in Florida's S.E.C. history. "We have a big package," said James Bates, a linebacker who had one of the interceptions. "It was frustrating to come into spring camp and have it all thrown out at us. It was like, 'Are we ever going to learn it?' "
Tennessee had rushed for at least 100 yards in 20 of the previous 21 regular-season games. Today the single-digit Vol total included 3 yards on 14 carries in the first half, a limitation created in part by injuries that thinned an already inexperienced offensive line. Jarvis Reado, a junior right tackle, fractured his right fibula and suffered ligament damage. Brent Gibson, a senior center and the line's leader, sprained his left ankle.
Florida's rushing game produced 149 yards, enough to sustain a pace that remained in its favor until the outcome was no longer in doubt. "There was no pressure on us at all," said Elijah Williams, a tailback who gained 51 of his 74 yards on Florida's first three offensive plays. "They were ranked higher, at their place, a hundred and something thousand. It was just us against them."
Tennessee's six turnovers, which tied a school record, equaled Manning's total for the entire 1995 season. Anthone Lott's 27-yard run on a fumble recovery, Florida's school-record sixth defensive touchdown of the season, gave the Gators a 35-0 lead with 10:06 to go in the second quarter.
"That's the darnedest first quarter I've ever been through, ever seen," said Phillip Fulmer, the Tennessee coach.
The Gators, with the resolve of an experienced gambler, chose to go for it on five fourth-down plays. They were successful four of the five times, a pattern that began with an incomprehensible fourth-and-11 attempt from the Vol 35, in the rain, on the first offensive series of the game. The result was a 35-yard touchdown pass to Reidel Anthony, the first of four for Wuerffel.
"When you go for it on fourth down," said Steve Spurrier, the coach of the Gators, "we look real stupid if we don't make it."
Manning's first interception, grabbed by Teako Brown after it deflected off the right hand of Marcus Nash, set up a 10-yard touchdown pass from Wuerffel to Terry Jackson for a 14-0 lead.
At that point, going back to the bizarre comeback victory over the Vols last season, Wuerffel had led the Gators to nine consecutive touchdown drives against Tennessee. The lead was just two touchdowns, but already, the Vols were being pushed into a corner.
Tennessee reached the Florida 46, was faced with a fourth-and-7 situation, and Spurrier's successful gambles lured Fulmer into a trap. The Vols kept their offense on the field, Manning threw toward Joey Kent, and Brown delivered a hit that created an incompletion.
The next time the Vols were in Gator territory, they were behind by 35 points.
"I thought we had a chance to win in the second half," Manning said. "It took us a while to get going in the third quarter. We finally got things rolling, but it was too late."

HEADLINE: Missiles Aimed at Iraq Are Armed With Failure

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, Sept. 18), asserting that President Clinton had to launch missile attacks against Iraq unilaterally, says that's "why God created cruise missiles -- for operations without allies." This reflects a dangerous arrogance of power.
The current generation of cruise missiles was developed by the Pentagon, not by God. In the late 1970's and early 1980's the Defense Department accelerated the development of cruise missiles to overcome the Vietnam syndrome and to augment United States superiority over the Soviet Union. 
 Cruise missiles were seen as a means to conduct massive aerial bombardments without immediately risking American casualties, as highly accurate vehicles to deliver nuclear warheads and as handy devices for destroying Soviet warships.
Mr. Friedman's claim of unilateral military action as "the price of leadership" obscures reality and undermines democracy. In fact, since 1944 when the United States replaced Britain as the hegemonic power in the Middle East, Washington has used "any means necessary" (in the words of the Carter Doctrine) to insure ultimate control over Middle East oil.
These means have included repeated threats to initiate nuclear war, subversion of elected governments by the Central Intelligence Agency, devastation of the Iraqi infrastructure in the Persian Gulf war, and the subsequent embargo, which the United Nations says may have cost 500,000 civilian lives.
Not incidentally, control of Middle East oil has provided the United States with influence over the economies and politics of Japan and our European allies, among others.
Mr. Friedman correctly describes the paucity of Washington's vision for the Middle East. Would that he had written what he must surely know: Neither cruise missiles nor military action will bring peace or justice to Iraq or the Middle East.
The old cliche is right. War reflects the failure of policy. The United States should be working through the United Nations and other diplomatic forums to address the dangers inherent in Saddam Hussein's brutal rule and to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
 
JOSEPH GERSON
Cambridge, Mass., Sept. 18, 1996
 
The writer is New England regional program coordinator, American Friends Service Committee.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
