HEADLINE: The Truth About Gentle Ben

BYLINE: By T. H. Breen; T. H. Breen's most recent book is "Imagining the Past: East Hampton Histories."

 BODY:

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN AND HIS ENEMIES
By Robert Middlekauff.
Illustrated. 255 pp. Berkeley:
University of California Press. $24.95.
Benjamin Franklin calculated the advantages to be derived from friendship. It was important, he thought, to appear genuinely likable in public. Unlike most people who have achieved great success, Franklin described exactly how he did it. If one wanted to win friends and gain followers, for example, one avoided argumentative words such as "certainly" and "undoubtedly." Instead, one employed more modest language, advancing topics of self-interest in terms like "I conceive," "I apprehend" or "I imagine." Franklin mastered these strategies, and contemporaries of all classes and backgrounds -- women as well as men -- testified to his extraordinary charm. 
 Franklin had less to say about making enemies. In public affairs, personal animosity slightly puzzled him, as if he could not quite comprehend why others might detest such a genial man. Quite a few people accepted the challenge. They interpreted as guile what others saw as charm. A Pennsylvania political rival once claimed in print that Franklin had a "wicked and virulent spirit," an "inflammatory" character and a "foul" mouth, and concluded that Franklin was "a very bad man, or one delirious with rage, disappointment and malice," bearing "the most unpopular and odious name in the province."
Venomous attacks on Franklin are not the stuff of popular mythology. Modern historians have generally found Franklin as likable as most of his contemporaries did. Robert Middlekauff, a historian at the University of California, Berkeley, also holds him in high regard. His purpose is neither to vilify Franklin nor to defend him against scurrilous attack, but rather to understand better how human passions have powerfully shaped public events. The past, he argues, is not simply a narrative of "objective" social and economic conditions. It also involves strong personal feelings, like disappointment and envy, hatred and scorn. Countering the dominant interpretive currents of recent social history, Mr. Middlekauff declares that his "central assumptions are that emotions are as important as objective circumstances and that they are usually inseparable from what can be counted and measured and seen."
He reviews Franklin's long battle with Thomas Penn, an irascible man who was the son of the founder of Pennsylvania, as well as the proprietor of the colony. The colony's charter gave the younger Penn extraordinary powers over local affairs. Not only did he hold popularly elected government in contempt; he refused to pay taxes on huge tracts of land he owned. Such disdain for the colonists' welfare was bound to put him at odds with a man like Franklin.
But it was not political issues that ultimately sustained the controversy. Penn truly disliked Franklin, seeing him as a duplicitous and manipulative social leveler. "I should be very Glad he inhabited any other Country," Penn said, "as I believe him of a very uneasy Spirit." The proprietor's aristocratic condescension stung Franklin's pride, and as the contest developed, he gave as good as he got, charging Penn with gross insensitivity to the concerns of the ordinary people of Pennsylvania. In 1757 the Pennsylvania Assembly, or legislature, sent Franklin to London to negotiate with Penn. After one heated meeting, Franklin called Penn "a low Jockey," confessing that he "conceived that moment a more cordial and thorough Contempt for him than I ever before felt for any Man living -- a Contempt that I cannot express in Words."
So the exchanges might have continued, except, as Mr. Middlekauff observes, extreme anger began to cloud Franklin's normally clear judgment. He lost self-control and his passion overruled reason, the failing he disliked most in other people. Hatred for the proprietor persuaded Franklin to ask King George III to strip Penn of his charter powers and to declare Pennsylvania a royal colony. But Franklin discovered that the King and his ministers had no more interest in promoting popular government in America than Penn had. Franklin endured a humiliating public defeat, one he might have avoided had he reflected more dispassionately about the political situation.
Later Franklin acquired other enemies during the long Revolutionary crisis. These people annoyed him, often making it difficult for him to carry out his responsibilities effectively as an American diplomat. Whatever the reasons, Franklin refused to engage these antagonists in public. Perhaps his standing as an international celebrity enhanced his self-confidence. He never again allowed personal rancor to divert attention from the nation's tenuous claim to independence. The same could not be said for John Adams, a bright, able lawyer, who grew to hate Franklin. The two men were thrown together in Europe during the war. A vain man, Adams envied Franklin's social skills as well as his fame. Within months of his arrival in Paris, Adams had convinced himself that Franklin was withholding vital diplomatic information and toadying up to French ministers. He could never quite fathom Franklin's ability to charm beautiful and intelligent women. At a particularly delicate moment in the peace negotiations with England, Adams sulked in his lodgings, telling others that "he could not bear" to "go near him." On his part Franklin concluded that Adams meant well for his country, but that he was "sometimes and in some things, absolutely out of his Sences."
At the end of the day, such bitter rivalries did not count for much. Franklin and Adams put aside their differences long enough to achieve a peace far more generous than anyone at the time could have anticipated. To his credit, Mr. Middlekauff manages to explore the darker side of human relations without thereby diminishing the real achievements of the people he studies. He reminds us that truly gifted political leaders have had a capacity to rise above personal animosity and work for the common good.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Franklin in 1777, an engraving from "Benjamin Franklin and His Enemies."

HEADLINE: Goodbye, Ozzie and Harriet

BYLINE: By Carol Tavris; Carol Tavris is a social psychologist. Her most recent book is "The Mismeasure of Woman."

 BODY:

SHE WORKS/HE WORKS
How Two-Income Families Are Happier, Healthier, and Better-Off.
By Rosalind C. Barnett and Caryl Rivers.
260 pp. San Francisco:
HarperSanFrancisco. $24.
 
IN THE NAME OF THE FAMILY
Rethinking Family Values in the Postmodern Age.
By Judith Stacey.
194 pp. Boston:
Beacon Press. $22.
 At the recent wedding of my stepson, my husband sat companionably between his former wife (the mother of the groom) and me. The groom, in his toast, warmly acknowledged the bride's ex-husband (the father of her son), who was there with his longtime partner, who sat next to the lesbian couple with their new baby. The new husband of my husband's ex-wife introduced us to the daughters of his two previous marriages, one of whom described the difficulties of living with your ex-husband in the apartment right above you. All in all, a typical post-modern family -- one typical of Republicans as well as Democrats, conservatives as well as liberals, rich as well as poor and, in this case, England as well as America. 
 The dizzying speed of changes in family configurations has made many nostalgic for a simpler time; but the correct response to bouts of nostalgia should be the same as the classic response to the desire to exercise -- lie down until the impulse passes. Instead, many people are busily trying to reinstate a family structure that lasted for less than a decade: the postwar blip when American families could afford to consist of one breadwinning husband and a wife who stayed home minding babies. This pattern now accounts for 3 percent of all families. Yet conservatives have so dominated the political conversation about the family, wailed so noisily about the allegedly catastrophic consequences of change, and persuaded so many liberals and moderates to join the choir that it seems impossible to construe the issues in any other way.
 Now two bold books do just that. The methods and language of their authors differ significantly: Rosalind C. Barnett's research, reported in "She Works/He Works," is based on quantitative studies of dual-income couples, and her argument is framed in Caryl Rivers's cheerful journalistic style; Judith Stacey's research, the basis of "In the Name of the Family," primarily involves free-ranging interviews with single mothers and working-class families, and her argument is framed in an impassioned sociological style. Yet both books come up with surprisingly similar and optimistic conclusions.
 Ms. Barnett, a psychotherapist and scholar in residence at the Murray Research Center at Radcliffe College, and Ms. Rivers, a writer with whom she has collaborated on previous books, report findings from a study of 300 dual-income couples. These couples are not typical of all American households, but they are representative of a large and growing segment of the population: full-time-employed, dual-earner couples. These families, Ms. Barnett shows, are thriving, contrary to the worries of many parents and the claims of some psychologists that children need the full-time ministrations of their mothers. For one thing, these couples "do not feel the gut-wrenching vulnerability" of economic disaster if one partner loses a job. For another, as studies repeatedly have found, employed wives are not as depressed and anxious as 1950's homemakers were, nor do their children suffer. The major source of stress for working women, the study found, is sexual harassment, followed by efforts to "mommy track" mothers out of their jobs.
 Just as wives aren't the selfish careerists of media stereotype, Ms. Barnett and Ms. Rivers say, neither are husbands "brutish, uncaring, lazy slobs who are dead set against change." Today's fathers, they find, are "not the distant, work-obsessed fathers of the 1950's"; most are closely involved in all aspects of their children's care, and when they don't get enough time with their children, their levels of distress rise. Also contrary to stereotype, men's participation in household chores has risen dramatically. Judith Stacey found this in her working-class sample too: "Almost all of the men I observed or heard about routinely performed domestic tasks that my own blue-collar father and his friends never deigned to contemplate," she writes.
 Of course, not all families are as secure as two-income couples. Ms. Stacey, a professor of sociology and women's studies at the University of California, Davis, recognizes that liberals, like conservatives, are concerned about the instability of families, about absent fathers and poverty among single mothers. But she argues forcefully against what she regards as the punitive and mean-spirited solutions offered by conservatives, such as efforts to get men back into the home by restoring their dominance there.
 Ms. Stacey's book is a collection of five previously published essays, and what it suffers in repetitions it more than makes up for in its unflinching attack on the "rhetoric of moral panic and the politics of backlash" in the United States, which she contrasts with Sweden's pragmatic solutions to the realities of family change. The first essay is a synopsis of the ethnographic work with working-class families that she did for her previous book, "Brave New Families." The next three dissect the premises, data and results of the campaigns for "family values" in popular culture and social science. The last essay examines the transformation of attitudes among many gay men and lesbians. Once opposed to marriage as a repressive, heterosexual, patriarchal institution, many are now enthusiastic supporters of marriage and family. Ms. Stacey regards such families neither as marginal nor exceptional but as models of ingenuity and flexibility.
 Together, these books bring us good news that "collaborative couples," who are now the norm, are healthier and happier than those constrained by the segregation of the past. But, these books warn us, we won't find ways of coping with the bad news until we face the economic and social facts. Women who need and enjoy their jobs aren't going to give them up. People who are unhappily married aren't going to stay together. Teen-agers aren't going to have a mass conversion and choose abstinence until they marry -- if they do marry. And members of the impoverished underclass, denied opportunities for work and training, and now being denied even the basic humane supports of life, aren't ever going to be able to live like Ozzie and Harriet; to tell them they should is not only delusional but cruel.

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2358 words

HEADLINE: Solicitations Rising for Costlier Galas

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LUTZ 

 BODY:
WITH government financing declining and competition for private charitable contributions on the rise, Long Island's nonprofit institutions are stepping up their fund-raising activities.
Galas are growing costlier, golf outings are proliferating, and, as more organizations hire one of the growing number of fund-raising specialists, solicitations of all types are multiplying. 
 Some of the efforts have proved successful. But as the number of solicitations grows, so do fears among the fund raisers that they may be putting too much pressure on potential contributors.
"Institutions are investing more time, effort and resources in fundraising, so the competition has grown very fierce," said Jack J. Sage, the the chief executive officer of United Way of Long Island.
"There's been so much consumer complaint about how many times the same organizations and people are asked to pitch in," he added "In fund-raising circles, this is a major issue people do worry about."
Others in the field concurred.
"Charities are developing more and more event-type solicitation," said Ronald Cooper, a managing partner at Ernst and Young in Melville and the vice president for development at the Long Island Philharmonic.
Many arts organizations, hit hard by cutbacks in government support, are hoping that events like galas pick up some of the slack. "The Philharmonic is one organization that has really utilized its annual gala to help offset some of the lost grant money that came out of government," Mr. Cooper said.
In the Philharmonic's case, its share of financing from an important state program has declined to $15,000 from $150,000 in the last three years. At the same time, prices for attending the orchestra's gala have risen incrementally, and will increase again this year, to $395 per person, said Karen L. Barnes, the executive director.
"We just edge it up quietly," she said.
The Philharmonic, whose operating budget is $1.5 million, hopes to raise $300,000 at the April event next year, she said.
At the Tilles Center in Old Brookville, prices for the annual gala have increased by about 20 percent over the last five years, said Nan Gerson, director of development. The increases have helped make up for the loss of financing from the New York State Council on the Arts, which has been declining by about 9 percent a year, she said.
Government financing accounts for a smaller portion of Tilles's budget than it does for most arts groups, she said.
At a top price of $600, the gala, to be held on Oct. 12, will cost the same to attend as last year, she said, adding that the organization, whose operating budget last year was about $5.4 million, hopes to attract 2,200 people and raise $500,000. The center will pay about $100,000 to the scheduled entertainers, the Boston Pops Orchestra and the television performer Jason Alexander, she said.
Asked whether ticket prices will increase next year, she said, "My board would like to do it."
At a gala for the Cinema Arts Center in Huntington next month, prices that averaged $100 a person in the past will rise by nearly two-thirds, largely because of the expected drawing power of the actors John Mills, Janet Leigh and others who are scheduled to appear, said Mr. Cooper, who also advises the cinema.
The event, expected to attract 600 people and bring in $100,000, marks "the first time that the Cinema Arts Center has been raised to this level of fund raising," he said.
A study released last week by a coalition of business leaders and arts organizations created by Friends of the Arts indicates that arts spending in the not-for-profit sector has a significant impact on the region's economy and that arts spending generates jobs, earnings and revenues in many other Long Island industries.
For every dollar of direct spending, the study found, an additional $1.39 was generated throughout the economy. Direct spending by arts organizations generates an additional $45 million in total output on Long Island, according to the report.
Like many arts groups, social service agencies are also using gala events to raise more money. The National Center for Disability Services in Albertson, whose budget is about $18 million, is holding a celebrity sports night this year at which it expects to raise more than $1 million, according to Edmund L. Cortez, the group's president and chief executive officer. That money will be used partly to offset cuts in Federal funds for research.
Other types of events are also popular.
"There are a huge number of charity golf tournaments on Long Island," said Gene Bernstein, vice chairman of Northville Industries in Melville, who oversees operations at the Northville Long Island Classic, which was held last month at Meadowbrook Country Club in Jericho.
Gate receipts from the tournament, an event on the Professional Golfers Association senior tour, go to Schneider Children's Hospital of Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park.
More than 1,000 charity golf tournaments have been held on the Island this year, up as much as 30 percent in the past year or two, said John Glozek, editor of Long Island Golfer magazine. The publication helped coordinate 700 tournaments this season, double last year's figure, he said.
"There are more fire departments having them," he said. "There are more Kiwanis clubs having them. There are still the not-for-profits, and they're always doing it; I think more of them are doing it now."
Some organizations that had never thought about holding a golf tournament are now doing so. One is the Interfaith Nutrition Network, a Hempstead group that collects food for emergency shelters. The group scheduled its first golf tournament this month, said Anthony E. Childs, a fund-raising expert in Smithtown who advises the network.
He said that four factors entered into the decision to hold the tournament: "Expenses are going up, more people need the services, there's less government funding, and there were people who were willing to undertake and organize a golf outing."
While golf tournaments are nothing new for educational institutions, some are considering expanding their events. Dowling College in Farmingdale, which expected to raise $40,000 from its tournament at the Crescent Country Club in Huntington last Thursday, may reserve two courses next year, said Stanley Henry, chairman of the board.
Beyond staging events, organizations are focusing on a variety of different solicitations. At Dowling, the picture has shifted dramatically in the past three years since the college development office heightened its fund-raising efforts, said Mr. Henry, who is also owner of This Week Publications in Farmingdale.
In part because of heavily staffed "phoneathons" and mass mailings, he said, the number of donors has almost quadrupled, to 4,000, and the proportion of alumni who contribute has increased to 15 percent from 3 percent in the last three years.
At the Philharmonic, the number of foundations being solicited has quadrupled to 100 in the last three years, Ms. Barnes said, adding that she considered the campaign a success because three or four foundations had responded positively. One, the Sanford C. Bernstein Foundation, has provided money for ticket subsidies to students, she said.
Like the Philharmonic, religious organizations are developing long-term fund-raising strategies to build interest among young people. Many such organizations are now seeking professional help in putting these strategies into effect, said George Holloway, who for 25 years has published a fund-raising newsletter for the National Catholic Development Conference. The newsletter, based in Hempstead, has 1,000 subscribers nationwide.
"We have had tremendous growth in our membership," he said, "because religious groups traditionally, while receiving the bulk of the dollars given by the American public, have not had in the past professional development people.
"But now that the number of vocations to religious groups has declined in recent years, they've hired more and more laypeople to help run their operations," he added.
The Long Island Council of Churches, for example, has retained Mr. Childs to help raise funds. On his advice, this year the council has doubled the amount of mail it sends to potential donors, he said.
With the increased demand for fund-raising help, membership in the Long Island chapter of the National Society of Fund Raising Executives increased last year by 80 to 200, said Steve Levy, the president of the chapter.
The increased activity in fund raising reflects an overall increase in the size of the nonprofit sector, which is growing more rapidly than the economy as a whole, according to Pearl Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association.
In 1994, employment in nonprofit organizations on Long Island increased by 3.5 percent over 1993, while total employment grew by 1.4 percent, Ms. Kamer said. Payrolls generated by the nonprofits rose by 5.4 percent, compared with 3.2 percent for the Island as a whole, she said, adding that the growth likely continued last year.
Ms. Kamer's analysis identifies nearly 2,500 nonprofit groups on the Island. They are divided into 13 categories that range in number up to 507 -- the number of religious organizations.
In addition to these established groups, Mr. Holloway said, "Charities are springing up literally overnight for all kinds of causes. On the East End in the summer, every weekend there appears to be another charity having some benefit."
The increasing number and variety of groups asking for money has been noted at the offices of some of the largest contributors, like European American Bank in Uniondale, which finances about 12 programs and contributes to many more.
"There are more requests coming in," said Linda Strongin, a vice president, who manages the bank's community-relations program. "I'm seeing requests from nonprofits I didn't even know existed."
The negative side of all the activity is that the solicitations are beginning to test contributors' patience. One problem is the volume of requests to attend special events.
"There are an enormous amount of complaints from donors asking how many golf tournaments can they go to, how many dinners can they go to," Mr. Sage said. "The encouraging thing is that they still seem to go. But the organizations that depend on special events all seem to be telling me that it's a great struggle."
Mr. Henry said that he rarely finds a Monday on which he is not playing in a charity golf outing, and sometimes in the same week on a Thursday.
"It has definitely increased dramatically," he said. "I literally cannot open my mail without finding one or more invitiations for a golf outing, sometimes three or four in a single day. It's ridiculous."
A major source of irritation to corporate contributors is multiple aid requests from different parts of the same organization, Ms. Strongin said. Recently she received four requests from the same organization for the bank to support a charitable walk.
"By the time I got the fourth request," she said, "I finally said, 'please get your act together. I know you're volunteers, but look at all the money you've wasted.' It gets aggravating after a while."
Corporations are also finding that many of the requests lack an explanation of how the companies will benefit by giving, Ms. Strongin said.
She contrasted two recent requests: one from a local fire company to buy a piece of equipment and another from a New York City agency to pay for computer training. Both requests seemed worthy. But the first proposal, which included an illustration of how the bank gift would be acknowledged, was looked on favorably; the second, which made no mention of the bank's benefiting, was not, she said.
In its written guidelines for evaluating requests for contributions, the bank states that, in addition to the proposal's effectiveness in improving employee morale and fulfilling the company's social responsibility, "our determination should be based on advancing the business goals of the bank." The guidelines also state that the programs that are paid for largely by the bank are, among other things, "designed topromote the bank's image." Organizations seeking contributions often fail to realize that "the profit people are dealing with tighter budgets," said Sharon Grosser, manager of community development programs at Northrop Grumman Corporation in Bethpage.
Ms. Grosser said that it is the consensus of community-development executives with whom she meets that virtually all companies are looking anew at their charitable giving.
"Everyone has suffered," she said. "If they haven't reduced their budgets, they are certainly re-evaluating where the money is spent."
Others agree. "No one likes to say it," Mr. Sage said, "but corporate giving as a phenomenon is plateauing."
At charity dinners, he said, "the constant complaint is that companies that used to take a table or several tables now might take one or two people."
No one knows how much money was donated to nonprofit groups on Long Island last year. Nationally, contributions increased 11 percent, to $144 billion, according to the American Assocation of Fund-Raising Counsel in Manhattan.
At the United Way of Long Island, which acts as an umbrella organization that funnels money to 160 groups, pledges for the 1995-96 fiscal year, which ended in June, increased about 4 percent over the year before, to $9.4 million, Mr. Sage said.
He said that over the last seven years, the portion of the total United Way pledges that come from individuals has doubled to 10 percent. All 21 people who give at least $10,000 per month to the organization have been recruited during this period, he said.
Last year the United Way started a department devoted to seeking major gifts and bequests from wealthy people, an area that Mr. Sage expects to be extremely fruitful over the next decade. With most of the assets on the Island in the hands of people over age 60, he said, most charities will be spending more time, effort and resources on this so-called planned giving.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: A Postrevolutionary Man

BYLINE: By Douglas Brinkley; Douglas Brinkley is the director of the Eisenhower Center and a professor of history at the University of New Orleans. He is completing a biography of Jimmy Carter.

 BODY:

The President We Deserve
Bill Clinton: His Rise, Falls, and Comebacks.
By Martin Walker.
Illustrated. 360 pp. New York:
Crown Publishers. $27.50.
Over the past four years publishing contentious books about Bill Clinton -- most of them highly unfavorable -- has become something of a cottage industry. Although a few, such as David Maraniss's excellent biography, "First in His Class," Ernest Dumas's illuminating study, "The Clintons of Arkansas," and Elizabeth Drew's two indispensable analyses, "On the Edge" and "Showdown," have been fair minded, the bulk read either as tabloid partisan potshots or as investigative tracts on Whitewater. As Leslie H. Gelb put it in a column in The New York Times, "My colleagues and I, like journalistic Dr. Strangeloves, are ready to nuke Mr. Clinton at the slightest provocation." 
 Indeed. Ever since 1988, when the Republican strategist Lee Atwater picked the young Arkansas Governor as the most potent likely Democratic challenger to President George Bush in 1992 and unleashed a "bleed Clinton" campaign, poison right-wing pens and Republican opposition researchers have had a field day investigating "F.O.B.'s." Indictments have been handed out and jail sentences levied to dozens of Friends of Bill, but President Clinton is still working through the briar patches essentially unscathed.
Unlike the hordes out to "get" Clinton, Martin Walker, Washington correspondent for Britain's newspaper The Guardian, has taken it upon himself to try and make sense out of post-cold-war America by studying the life and career of our 42d President, bringing to the task the dispassionate perspective of a foreign reporter awed at the carnival of American Presidential politics in an age when the medium truly has become the message. The result is "The President We Deserve," a shrewd, stylishly conceived narrative that distinguishes itself as the most comprehensive book on Mr. Clinton to date. In unadorned but sprightly prose, Mr. Walker takes the reader on the 50-year roller coaster that William Jefferson Blythe 4th rode from 1946 in Hope, Ark., to early 1996, when, as President of the United States, Bill Clinton "blunted, diverted and finally defeated the surging momentum of the new Republican majority." Much in "The President We Deserve" is familiar, yet by telling it as a balanced, chronological, warts-and-all story, Mr. Walker lets readers judge for themselves whether Mr. Clinton is the best candidate to lead America into the next millennium. Unfortunately, his erudite effort lacks the documentary evidence to make it more than an interesting campaign-year biography.
If there is an overall thesis to "The President We Deserve," it's that Bill Clinton is the archetypal postwar American, his life having unfolded in the eddies of the vast social revolution that swirled around him. Mr. Walker sees Mr. Clinton as the perfect symbol of the great American meritocracy that blossomed after 1945 thanks to the G.I. Bill, the sexual revolution and the civil rights movement: "The first in his family to go to college, he was also the first in his family to go abroad in anything but military uniform, the first Governor of his state to go abroad to open trade missions, the first President whose summits were on trade pacts rather than on arms treaties." As Mr. Walker tells it, Mr. Clinton's story is dizzying, peppered with the contradictions we've come to expect from the Razorback who went bowling dressed like Elvis Presley, but who is also the Rhodes Scholar who "developed a fondness" for the "Meditations" of Marcus Aurelius.
Yet his embrace of pop culture is just the clearest manifestation of how much Bill Clinton has always been in sync with his times; there is also his dismissal of military service as a prerequisite for an ambitious American politician. In his generation, service was for those who lacked either the smarts or the means to avoid the draft by attending college. Now he holds the distinction of being the only postwar President not to have served in the armed forces. But unlike Dick Cheney, Newt Gingrich and Phil Gramm, who also skirted service the academic way, Mr. Clinton is proud of his conscientious dissent against Vietnam. And, as Mr. Walker repeatedly makes clear, it is his lack of repentance that still raises the greatest ire.
"No government really rooted in limited, parliamentary democracy," the young man wrote the commander of the Reserve Officer Training Corps at the University of Arkansas, "should have the power to make its citizens fight and die in a war they may oppose, a war which even possibly may be wrong, a war which, in any case, does not involve immediately the peace and freedom of the nation." At the time, however -- and also because his college friends, including Hillary Rodham, Strobe Talbott and Robert Reich, were anti-Vietnam Democrats too -- Mr. Clinton assumed, correctly, that supporting L.B.J.'s war would someday be seen as a severe political handicap. "Clinton was with the majority," Mr. Walker writes. In fact, he was never "violently against the war," only calculatingly against it. Out of the 27 million Americans of draft age between 1965 and 1972, only 2.2 million were actually drafted. As America's first postconscription President, Mr. Clinton naturally has taken heat.
Mr. Walker offers a unique perspective on Bill Clinton's two years at Oxford, for he attended the university himself then, and his firsthand descriptions are illuminating. Mr. Clinton comes across as likable for his infectious enthusiasm and constant drive, making friends wherever he went -- hitchhiking all over the Continent, reading Gunter Grass in Germany and George Orwell in Spain; visiting Czechoslovakia just months after Prague Spring and touring Moscow at a time when few Americans dared. In his first year at Oxford alone, he also found time to read 300 books thoroughly, Mr. Walker tells us, on an impressive number of varied subjects.
As for the infamous marijuana cigarette, Mr. Walker insists that Mr. Clinton really didn't inhale: he was allergic to smoke. Besides, Mr. Walker asserts, marijuana was not readily available in Britain during the 1960's; what Mr. Clinton actually put to his lips was a hand-rolled cigarette laced with crumbled hashish. "His Oxford acquaintances were amazed at the mockery Clinton inspired for saying 'I didn't inhale' during his campaign," Mr. Walker writes. "Technically, it was true."
A t times "The President We Deserve" reads like a primer for Europeans who can't keep up with American scandals or comprehend where the hard politics diverges from innuendo. And here Mr. Walker is at his journalistic best, assessing Clinton Administration policy making by meticulously following its downs and ups, from the withdrawal of Zoe Baird's nomination as Attorney General two days after the Inauguration to the signing of a free-trade treaty of intent with the European Union on Dec. 1, 1995. In his highest note, Mr. Walker credits the Clinton Administration with charting "America's new international role in the aftermath of the cold war, as the linchpin of a free-trading global economy." According to Mr. Walker, Mr. Clinton's greatest historical achievement has been to expand what George Bush first envisioned: a central United States role in forging a new world order of open-market democracies. Refreshingly, Mr. Walker gives more consideration to Mr. Clinton's summit meetings with President Boris Yeltsin of Russia than he does to his $200 haircut on the runway at Los Angeles International Airport. This constant focus on substance casts a more favorable light on Mr. Clinton; the "character issue" begins to look feeble next to his handling of the Oklahoma City terrorist bombing, Congress's passage of the North American free-trade pact, his response to Mexico's economic collapse, peace talks in Northern Ireland, the threat of $1 billion in sanctions against China and the Bosnian peace agreement.
In the end, the political portrait that emerges is not so much that of a "New Democrat" as that of a traditional liberal Republican President. "In setting the course for the new international consensus of free-trading internationalism, and for the new domestic consensus around leaner and meaner government," Mr. Walker believes, Mr. Clinton "had strong grounds to claim his right to reelection." Reading "The President We Deserve" leaves the voter with a renewed understanding that only a second term will tell whether he can make that leaner government acceptable for most Americans. "Having acquiesced in the great shrinkage of the New Deal and Great Society," Mr. Walker concludes, "he had still to show that activist government could be made to work."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 23, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 268 words

HEADLINE: Why Pour Money Into Failed Amtrak System?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Trains Are Leaving" (editorial, Sept. 20) concludes by endorsing a failed strategy: Amtrak's decades-long effort to maintain a "national rail passenger system." 
 A strategy that makes sense would recognize that high-speed passenger rail is economically viable only in high-density corridors, and over relatively short distances (under three hours).
Longer distances are served at half the cost or less by the world's best air passenger system and bus systems.
To accomplish such a strategic shift, we need to change the model. Amtrak must become a holding company. Its mission would be to develop a 20-year plan to build the right-of-ways, to purchase rolling-stock technology from Europe or Asia and to arrange to have it manufactured and/or assembled here.
When each route system was complete, a long-term operating lease with a private company would be negotiated.
We can assume that the airlines would bid on these routes, since they already have the reservation systems, personnel and training programs to be a low-cost provider.
The public sector would get a return on the capital employed and the traveling public would get the benefits of a first-rate system operated by the private sector for profit.
This approach would reduce congestion at the airports serving these corridors as well as reduce noise and air pollution.
Financing would have to come from the Highway Trust Fund and the monies saved from the reduced demand for airport expansion. It can be done, but it will take a fresh approach.
 
CHARLES H. GESSNER
Marblehead, Mass., Sept. 20, 1996

HEADLINE: In America;
Families on the Edge

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The navy blue sweater of 3-year-old Timothy Dixon was saturated from the steady rain. No one paid much attention. Soggy clothing is one of the hazards of being homeless. Timothy was with his mother, Kim Dixon, his brother, Byron, 10, and his sister, Keisha, 8, in a downpour outside the city's Emergency Assistance Unit, a chaotic place in the Bronx where homeless families go to seek shelter and eventually, they hope, a subsidized apartment.
The wind was blowing in strong, cold gusts from the direction of the Triborough Bridge. Less than a dozen blocks away fans were heading toward Yankee Stadium for a game that would be rained out. It was an ugly afternoon, and you could tell by the eyes of the people milling about the E.A.U., some with their belongings in black garbage bags, that the prospects for the evening were no better. 
Timothy did a little dance on the sidewalk. Then he darted several yards away from his mother. Then he ran back.
"Trying to keep warm," somebody said.
Kim Dixon held a cigarette in her hand. "We've got no place to go now," she said. She gestured toward the E.A.U. "They got roaches in there and you have to sleep on the hard floor but what else can we do? Can't stay out here."
She said she fled with her children from their home in Atlanta after her daughter was molested by a relative. The family stayed with a sister-in-law in the Bronx for a while, in a grossly overcrowded apartment, but that situation became untenable.
"She put us out," said Ms. Dixon.
Timothy darted off again.
"Come here, son!"
Byron and Keisha stood quietly beside their mother. Ms. Dixon took a drag from her cigarette. Byron kept an eye on his brother. He looked around quizzically from time to time, but he didn't say anything. Keisha's gaze never seemed to move. She stared without expression down the rainy street.
Quietly, disastrously, the number of homeless children in New York City is growing. A study by researchers at the University of Pennsylvania showed that family homelessness in New York increased from 1990 to 1995, and that the largest increase by age group -- 9 percent -- was among children 9 years old and younger.
"These are families that have used up all of their resources," said Gretchen Buchenholz, executive director of the Association to Benefit Children. "They have been sleeping on floors with friends or relatives, or they are fleeing domestic violence. These are very, very poor families and their kids suffer terribly from being homeless. They lag developmentally. Their language skills can be delayed. They don't get enough to eat. They suffer physically, cognitively and emotionally."
"Basically," said Steven Banks, who heads the Homeless Family Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society, "we are creating a lost generation of children who simply do not know what it is like to be in stable housing circumstances."
Most of these worn-down, nomadic and nearly worn-out families are black, and most are refugees from the daily combat of Harlem, the South Bronx or Bedford-Stuyvesant/ East New York.
The main reason they end up doubled and tripled up in apartments with relatives and friends is that they have been unable to earn enough to bring rents in even those devastated areas within their reach. The first problem is finding any work at all. The second problem is that entry-level work does not pay enough to cover Harlem, South Bronx or Bed-Stuy rents for a family of four or five.
These are crazy-making problems. The families exist on the edge. There is nothing to cushion their fall. A fire, or a broken water pipe, or a collapsed roof, or a physical injury, or the loss of a job, or a bout with depression can hurl everybody into the abyss. Moreover, families that live doubled or tripled up with relatives in apartments crammed with a dozen people or more have, by definition, overstayed their welcome. They are always just one argument, just one fight, just one ill-conceived comment away from the sidewalk.
Employment is the essential issue here. There's an economic depression in the inner cities.
But that's old news. No one is paying much attention.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
In Service Of Amazon, Composers Of Brazil

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
The Amanakaa Amazon Network, which takes its name from the Tupi Indian word for rain forest, has been raising money to preserve 150,000 square miles of Brazilian rain forest since 1990. One of the network's activities is an annual Amazon Week in New York, the seventh of which began on Saturday evening.
Most of the events are lectures and panel discussions about the ecology and economics of the region, and are to be held at the National Museum of the American Indian. But the series is framed by music. The Brooklyn Philharmonic played an opening concert of Brazilian classical music at Alice Tully Hall. And the week is to end with a folk music and dance festival at the World Trade Center on Saturday from noon to 8 P.M. 
 The Brooklyn players were led by Silvio Barbato, a Brazilian conductor in his mid-30's, who compensated for the lack of program notes by speaking briefly about each work. It was a surprisingly staid affair. Only last spring the American Composers Orchestra demonstrated the variety, scope and distinctive character of Brazilian concert music in its Sonidos de las Americas series, but works presented here did little more than pay homage to European and North American models.
The bright coloration and complex rhythms that contemporary Brazilian composers have used to create a national style were nowhere in evidence, and where folk themes were used, they were subordinated entirely to the warm textures of conventional string writing.
Claudio Santoro, for example, was described as a composer intent on giving Brazilian music its own voice, yet his 1954 "Canto Amor e Paz" says more about the international neo-Classical movement of the 1950's than about Brazil. Most of Heitor Villa-Lobos's "Bachianas Brasileiras" find common ground between Bach themes and Brazilian folk music, but the one offered here -- No. 9, a Prelude and Fugue -- is the most straightforwardly Bachian of the series.
The final two works on the program were by Antonio Carlos Gomes, a composer who flourished in the second half of the 19th century, a time when the notion of a Brazilian style was hardly a twinkle in composers' eyes. And indeed, in his Sonata in D, a string orchestra work from the 1890's, his writing draws uninhibitedly on Mozart and Beethoven, with a touch of Puccini in its slow movement. Gomes had studied in Milan and composed operas for La Scala and other Milanese houses.
To close the concert, Aprile Millo brought a measure of slightly wobbly intensity to "Quale Orrible Paccato," a pretty but unremarkable aria from Gomes's 1873 "Fosca."
Mr. Barbato worked hard to bring out the spark in this music. The Brooklyn players cooperated intermittently, producing a lovely, rounded sound in the Gomes works, but letting their intonation slip occasionally in the Santoro and Villa-Lobos scores.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Silvio Barbato, a Brazilian, conducting the Brooklyn Philharmonic at the opening of Amazon Week. (Chris Lee for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: College Skyboxes Curb Elbow-to-Elbow Democracy

BYLINE: By ROBERT BRYCE 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 22

 BODY:
College football teams have long relied on marching bands, cheerleaders and winning teams to sell tickets and generate revenue. While nothing will ever take the place of a winning record, colleges across the country are adopting a more reliable, and more controversial, source of cash: those exclusive enclosed seats in the stratosphere of sports stadiums known as skyboxes.
Once the ultimate status symbol of professional sports, skyboxes are proliferating in the college game. Nearly three dozen universities in six conferences now have the private boxes, and half a dozen more are planning to add them. 
 "It's a creeping and disturbing trend," Edward J. Blakely, dean of the planning and development school at the University of Southern California, said recently in a telephone interview. Mr. Blakely, who is writing a book about exclusive communities with restricted access for the Lincoln Institute of Land Policy, said that sports stadiums had been one of the last places where Americans shared a common space.
Skyboxes, he said, are the sporting equivalent of residential communities that rely on gates and security fences to keep nonresidents out. "It used to be the regular guy at the ball park could sit next to the corporate C.E.O.," Mr. Blakely said. "Not anymore. This is the privatization of public space."
The private boxes are popular at colleges for the same reason they are popular at the professional level: money. A college stadium skybox that seats from 8 to 50 can cost $8,000 to $80,000 a season.
"The ability to raise additional revenue is the main and only reason" for skyboxes, said Dave Heeke, an associate athletic director at the University of Oregon, which put 11 of the boxes in its football stadium in 1991. Mr. Heeke pointed out that the miniature suites offered a college's supporters more than a comfortable vantage point. The amenities may include catered meals and color television. And most of the cost of a skybox is tax deductible because it is classified as a contribution to a college athletic program.
Numerous state-supported schools known for their football prowess have installed skyboxes, including the Universities of Florida, Georgia, Iowa and Arizona. In the last few months, the University of Texas here, a member of the new Big 12 Conference, announced that it would build 64 skyboxes in its football stadium. The University of Nebraska, another member of the Big 12, which has won two consecutive national football championships, announced plans to build 40 of the boxes.
The private boxes above the common seating at college sports events are not limited to football. Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C., and the University of Nevada at Las Vegas have the private suites at their basketball arenas. Texas Tech University in Lubbock has skyboxes in its new baseball stadium.
Bill Dorsey, executive director of the Cincinnati-based Association of Luxury Suite Directors, said no one should be surprised that skyboxes were playing a bigger role at the amateur level. "College sports are big business," said Mr. Dorsey, whose association of about 350 members is made up of concerns that lease the boxes as well as the caterers that serve them.
"In certain states, the colleges are bigger than the pro teams," Mr. Dorsey said. "For instance, the University of Nebraska takes the place of a pro team. It's what the whole state of Nebraska focuses on."
The University of Nebraska is planning to charge a minimum of $75,000 a year for a skybox, with 20 seats. At that price, with six home games, a seat in one of the boxes at a Nebraska football game will cost $625. By comparison, a ticket in the stands is $28 to the public and half that for students.
In some cases, college skyboxes cost as much as or more than those in professional sports. According to figures from Mr. Dorsey's association, the most expensive skybox at Lambeau Field, home of the National Football League's Green Bay Packers, leases for $25,000 a year.
The most expensive skybox at the Thomas & Mack Center, where the University of Nevada at Las Vegas plays basketball, costs $80,000 a year. Students, however, are admitted to home games free.
Robert Baade, an economics professor at Lake Forest College in Illinois, testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee last year about the problems associated with financing new sports stadiums. Like Mr. Blakely, he questions the trend toward the exclusive boxes.
"Stadiums have a finite amount of space," Mr. Baade said in a recent telephone interview. "If you devote more and more seating to preferential customers, what do you have left for the ordinary public? I think it means sports spectating is becoming a far less democratic activity."
The president of the student government at the University of Texas, Jeff Tsai, said that he would oppose the private boxes if they result in the loss of student seats. But he added, "Skyboxes are an alternative that could benefit students because they could alleviate the burden they pay for athletics."
Texas A&M University was one of the first major colleges to build skyboxes. The university, also a member of the Big 12, built 48 of the boxes in its football stadium in 1980. "This is just another way to provide good seats to our alumni and corporations," said Wally Groff, the university's athletic director, who added that revenue from the skyboxes had been used to build and refurbish other sports facilities. "We just approved a $3.6 million tennis center, and the funds for that are coming from the suites," Mr. Groff said.
He dismissed the notion that skyboxes had created economic segregation in the stands. "The good seats have always gone to the biggest contributors," he said.
Harry Edwards, a sociology professor at the University of California at Berkeley, said that wealthy boosters had always been a "privileged class" at university sporting events. "I don't see it as that big a deal," Professor Edwards said. "The only change is that the athletic programs have devised a way to get more money by moving these people off the 50-yard line in row 12 to skyboxes around row 75."
While other colleges are embracing skyboxes, the University of Michigan and the University of Notre Dame, two universities renowned for their football programs, have decided against them.
"We have had many people come to us and ask if they can build skyboxes for us," said Bruce Madej of the University of Michigan's athletic department. "And there have been unbelievable offers on the table. But we are trying to make sure that this is a college atmosphere and not a professional atmosphere."

HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
Companies Reach Investors Via the Net

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE 

 BODY:
Bell & Howell's management found a new way of getting out information about its annual shareholder meeting last May in Ann Arbor, Mich.: broadcast the proceedings live on the World Wide Web.
The company's decision is an example of the way the Web is becoming a new venue for investor relations. Investors come to learn not only about a company's profits and press releases, but also its strategies and culture. 
 The model is still sketchy, and many company sites focus exclusively on consumer information and have not caught on to the basics of investor relations. But innovations are quickly emerging that undoubtedly will become the standard.
Colgate-Palmolive, for instance, offers the daily highs and lows of its stock's price over the last five years, a valuable help to shareholders at tax time. And Campbell Soup allows Web users to sign up to receive news releases by E-mail. First name, last name and E-mail address, boom, that's it.
After Bell & Howell's shareholders were told about the May meeting, "hundreds of extra shareholders" were able to attend "by remote," said Henry A. D'Ambrosio, vice president at Bell & Howell for administration. "In the Q. and A. period, we got 15 E-mail questions including 2 from overseas, from London and Tokyo."
Bell & Howell's site also is unusual in listing the names and telephone numbers of investment analysts who follow the company.
Hewlett-Packard, although it is a leading technology company, offers a more routine but fairly complete service, including its stock price, updated throughout the day, quarterly and annual reports, speeches by the chairman, recent remarks that management made to securities analysts and descriptions of the company's businesses, segment by segment.
Many companies link their Web pages to their financial filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission at the Edgar data base and offer an E-mail form for requesting printed shareholder information like an annual report. And often there are corporate histories, sometimes earnest, often leaden. AT&T offers its annual reports going back five years and shows a graphic of its stock price over the last 180 days (generally sagging).
Companies typically distribute their news releases to the financial news agencies and public relations wire services to meet strict S.E.C. requirements for the timely and fair dissemination of important corporate news. But the Web provides a new wrinkle in the democratization of news, "giving the common guy a bit of an edge," said John Williams, senior vice president of PR Newswire, which is available on the Web.
"The information is open to the public at large, at no charge, 24 hours a day and seven days a week."
Anne Crawford, the director of investor relations at Colgate-Palmolive, said her company was striving "to keep our investors supplied with current information about company releases as well as strategies, and the Web offers another tool to do that." The company's site answers many routine questions about stock prices and a dividend reinvestment program.
But more than that, Ms. Crawford said, "we are probably getting inquiries about the company that we might not otherwise have gotten, for instance from investment clubs that saw our site." There are inquiries from as far away as Hong Kong and Malaysia. And the site also fits in with the growing trend of younger investors doing their own research, she said.
Also, updating the information on the site is inexpensive and quick, she said, so much so that many Colgate-Palmolive employees find out company information on the Internet long before a news release reaches their desks.
A handy way for an investor to do corporate surfing is to go to the Web sites of the main exchanges. The New York and American stock exchanges offer links to their members' home pages, making it a simple process to check out companies and industries.
Investors can also turn to brokerage houses for corporate data and special reports. Merrill Lynch & Company, for example, offers selected research reports on line. And Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers, publishes market and economic analysis and lets users search for data on many companies.
 Smaller companies on the Web must be alert to keep their information timely and answer queries promptly, warns Robert Amen, of Robert Amen & Associates in Greenwich, Conn., which is part of the Ketchum public relations group. People who send in electronic queries about a company expect an answer within a day or so, not weeks, he said.

HEADLINE: Appalachia Family Reunions on Wane

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAZARD, Ky., Sept. 22

 BODY:
Alma Watts Waddell surveyed her annual family reunion recently with the kind of tender smile she might bestow on an ailing relative.
Four score of her cousins sat at long tables at the community center in the nearby Appalachia town of Hindman, eating potluck food and talking about old times. The Watts family gathering is still among the most cherished weekends of the year for Mrs. Waddell, 60, but she has been watching it wither for years. 
 "Family is just so important," Mrs. Waddell said, "but so many of the younger people just don't get involved anymore."
Mrs. Waddell's lament has been shared this year by reunion organizers all over eastern Kentucky, many of whom report the lowest attendance ever at their family gatherings. The decline is a sign that the Appalachia culture, based on the importance of family, may be fading, said Ron Eller, director of the University of Kentucky's Appalachian Center in Lexington, which is devoted to study of the area.
Americans everywhere have family reunions, but few relish the gatherings the way Appalachian residents do, the experts say. Every summer, reuniting families flood parks and cram cemeteries. Many newspapers in eastern Kentucky have special reunion sections to announce the gatherings. Signs pointing to reunions sprout like kudzu on major highways.
The reunions were born in part because so many in the area were forced to leave because of the decline of the coal industry. In the three decades after World War II, more than three million people left the mountains to find work.
Taught to cherish even distant family connections, the migrants did not forget their roots, returning yearly to the mountain hollows. But their children are not as interested in their heritage. Hundreds once attended the Watts family reunion, but this year there were 85.
"The older people that was so close are dead and gone," said Dr. Gene T. Watts of Hindman, the family patriarch. "And so much of the rest of the clan are scattered in so many different directions."
The children are not only scattered, said Ron Crouch, director of the Kentucky State Data Center in Louisville. "The reality is that the youngsters aren't Appalachians," he said. "They are Chicagoans or Detroiters or Cincinnatians."
Leslie Larson, 39, was one of the dwindling number of cousins of her generation who attended the Watts reunion. Born in Lexington while her father attended the University of Kentucky, Mrs. Larson was reared in Battle Creek, Mich. When she talks, her mouth forms the rounded vowels of Midwesterners. Her accent has none of the soft lilt of the mountains.
"Appalachia is my heritage," Mrs. Larson said, "but it's not me." When Mrs. Larson was a child, her family returned to the mountains for three weeks each summer. She grew close to a brace of cousins and developed a deep fondness for the area. But the trip became harder to schedule. She had not been to a Watts reunion in the previous 13 years.
"The heritage of where my parents grew up really draws me," she said. "I wanted to show it to my kids. And I wanted them to meet their cousins." But even if all the cousins in far-off places returned, the Watts reunion would still be smaller than it was 20 years ago because many of the cousins who still live in eastern Kentucky no longer attend. This is the trend that worries so many reunion organizers.
"It's really the locals you have trouble getting there," said Creda Isaacs, who helps organize her family's reunion in the area.
Appalachian clanishness was born in the 1700's and 1800's when the region's economy was based on subsistence farming, said Mr. Eller, of the Appalachian Center.
With transportation confined to farm animals and the roads poor to nonexistent, families formed their own communities for the farming, teaching and preaching. And when industrialization roared into the mountains at the turn of the century in the form of railroads and coal mining, displacing many farms, people clung to their families for support.
This emphasis on family ties was not always helpful, a fact rarely mentioned in the current national political mania for "family values." When the region's coal economy first nose-dived in the 1920's, residents were reluctant to leave because they wanted to remain with their extended families, Mr. Eller said. They stayed behind and became hopelessly poor. By contrast, many mining areas in the West were almost abandoned when industry moved out.
Since family was more important than ideology, family networks controlled eastern Kentucky's politics for decades, often leading to nepotism and corruption. A member of the Watts family, Ruben Watts, who relied on the family for political support, pocketed thousands of dollars while judge-executive of Letcher County by engineering bogus sales of road-building supplies to the county. He pleaded guilty in 1994 to theft.
Mr. Eller said industrialization brought better roads, better communication and a different set of values to Appalachia. "So it's not surprising that the family structure in the region is also looking like the rest of the country," Mr. Eller said. "Some of us don't see that as progress."
Still, Mr. Eller and those at the Watts family reunion say family ties are still important here. "You can take us out of the mountains," said Aggie Smith, a Watts cousin whose family left for Indiana in the late 1940's, "but you can't take the mountains out of us."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CONGRESS;
Parties Bicker Among Themselves Over How to Divide Their Money

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton's dominance in the polls and the fierce battle for control of Congress have set off tensions between the Presidential campaigns and their political parties over how best to divide a limited financial pie in the crucial last full month of the campaign.
Some top aides to Bob Dole, the Republican nominee, say they are concerned that Republican Party officials are diverting an excessive proportion of available money to helping House and Senate candidates because they fear that Mr. Dole will lose. 
 Democrats face the question in reverse: with Mr. Clinton comfortably ahead in the polls, many advisers to Democratic Congressional candidates criticize the White House for not freeing up more resources to help them. Mr. Clinton, these officials argue, can afford to be more generous.
While the Presidential campaigns are supposed to be financed solely with Federal subsidies, the parties have amassed well over $100 million this year -- often through their state party organizations -- to be pumped into things like generic television commercials, polling and campaign workers that can benefit both Presidential contenders and other candidates on the ballot.
But not all spending helps all candidates equally. A Presidential candidate may not want his party to spend much in a state where he is well ahead or behind, yet such help could make the difference for House candidates in the state.
"The competing geographic imperatives naturally set up some degree of conflict," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster with several clients running for Congress. "Money is a scarce resource in politics, and the priorities of people who want to capture the White House are different from the priorities of those who want the House and Senate."
Over the next six weeks before the election, the parties have to make decisions about whose priorities govern the spending of tens of millions of dollars. Some skirmishes are inevitable, but they have been unusually intense this year because the stakes are higher. Both sides view this as a pivotal election that could decide whether the Republicans retain control of the House and Senate for years to come, or whether the Democrats wrest it back.
As is usually the case, the incumbent is firmly in command not only of his own campaign strategy but also of how his party allocates resources. The Dole campaign has no such control over how much help it receives from the Republican Party, whose attention is divided between winning the White House and hanging on to Congress. Mr. Dole appears to have even less leverage because of his relatively poor standing in the polls.
Some of Mr. Dole's aides complain that the Republican Party has diverted significant resources to states where Mr. Dole does not need extra help (like Kansas and Texas) or has already written off to Mr. Clinton (like Iowa and Rhode Island) just to benefit Republicans seeking state or Congressional office.
"There's a sense that the party has not shown its enthusiasm for Bob Dole in a manner that we would expect," a senior Dole aide said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "I suspect they're trying to keep the House majority, and we're second priority. There's a general level of frustration."
In one example, aides to Mr. Dole complained that the national party should be directing the Ohio Republican Party to send out more mailings highlighting Mr. Dole rather than leaving the Dole committee to have to pick up the cost -- as much as $1 million in that important swing state.
"For every dollar that the state committees don't kick in, the Dole campaign has to pick up the slack," said one Dole campaign official.
Craig Veith, a spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, which raises money for Republican House candidates, said he had not heard of such complaints, but argued that his committee's candidates could help Mr. Dole.
"Congressional races are entities among themselves," Mr. Veith said. "They can turn out voters in large numbers that will in turn help the Presidential campaign."
On the Democratic side, Congressional leaders were so concerned that the White House was hoarding resources that several met recently with Harold M. Ickes, the deputy chief of staff -- and later with the President himself -- to argue that they could retake Congress if given adequate resources to further remind voters that the unpopular Newt Gingrich is Speaker.
"The President is mainly concerned with getting himself re-elected, and each member of the House in concerned with taking back their respective body," said one Democrat consultant who is close to the House leadership and who spoke on the condition on anonymity.
"Everyone understands that. But what distresses people is that when the President is doing so well, why do they keep the money flowing to them and not redirect it when he doesn't seem to need it?"
Another senior-level Democrat, also speaking on the condition of anonymity, echoed the complaint: "There's a frustration that there has not been more of an effort to help the Congress piece, particularly as Clinton sits with a 15-point lead. It all comes down to what markets they're playing in."
Some Congressional officials said the White House should free up more money to help Congressional candidates in Kansas and Alabama, where Mr. Clinton is not seriously competing, but where there are important House races. They also say the White House should do more for House candidates in Massachusetts and Washington State, where the President is particularly strong but where House seats are at risk.
Some Democratic Congressional officials complained that the White House insisted on taking too large a portion of the proceeds when Mr. Clinton travels around the country as the featured speaker at joint fund-raising events that are intended to raise money not only for the national party but also for local candidates. For many candidates, the money is much more important than whether Mr. Clinton mentions them in a speech or campaigns in their area.
Responding to such concerns, the party announced last week that Terry McAuliffe, the chairman of the Clinton-Gore finance effort, would lead a drive to raise several million dollars more for Congressional races.
David Eichenbaum, the communications director for the Democratic National Committee, said: "This move should put to rest any of those concerns. I know that there have been some complaints, but there always are. People always feel that you can do more -- and we are trying to do more."
Publicly, top officials of both campaigns insist that there are no conflicts. Referring to the $12 million Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton are allowed to take directly from their national parties, Scott Reed, the Dole campaign manager, played down any tensions, saying: "What do I care about? We're getting our $12 million."
Douglas Sosnik, the White House political director, said, "We've been much more engaged in Congressional races than the last two incumbents to run for re-election without facing a primary: Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan."
But one White House official, speaking on the condition that he not be identified, was less patient as he dismissed complaints of Democratic Congressional candidates.
"There's a situation that no matter how much you do it's not enough," he said. "It's a constant drumbeat -- they want as much help as they can get."

HEADLINE: Essay;
No Pol Will Tell You

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Only a couple of months ago, it seemed to be such a political masterstroke.
First, move left to repay heavy-spending union labor by raising the minimum wage. Make the Republicans look like skinflints with their murmuring about job losses at the entry level. 
 Simultaneously, move rightward to embrace welfare reform, which, like the minimum wage, had been ignored when Democrats controlled both Congress and the White House. That stole the G.O.P.'s big issue.
The one-two of raising entry-level wages and requiring the welfare recipient to go to work was a combo of political genius, everybody said. Clinton's popularity soared.
But nobody stopped to think what would happen in the real world when you pushed people into the labor force and -- at the same time -- made it more expensive for employers to hire them. Taken together, the two guarantee big trouble.
Last month, the consequence of the left-right combination to the welfare-laden District of Columbia dawned on the Clinton White House. Political strategists panicked, swung left, and granted D.C. a "waiver." But by assuring 20,000 welfare mothers that the work requirement would not apply to them, Clinton in effect repealed welfare reform in the nation's capital.
One trouble with that maneuver was that it was against the new law. Worse, repealing welfare reform by fiat as soon as it took effect would make Clinton look like the old, liberal Democrat. Worst of all, it would signal that if re-elected, Clinton would promptly bring back the era of big government.
That prospect sent Clinton scurrying back again to the right. Last week, he rescinded most of his unlawful waiver and now those 20,000 mothers will have to start looking for jobs.
But not half of these people have high school diplomas, and most can hardly read. What's one big advantage these potential workers offer prospective employers? To gain entry, they could lower costs by working cheap.
And what is the wrongest-headed thing that government can do? To make it more expensive for an employer to give them a chance to work, especially in a city that is losing 10,000 jobs a year. But raising the cost of entry-level workers, of course, is precisely what the minimum-wage increase does. When combined with welfare reform's work requirement, making cheap labor more expensive is public-policy stupidity.
Nobody -- certainly not the bludgeoned Republican House leadership -- points this out because political strategists turned the minimum wage into the equivalent of motherhood. 'Twas a famous victory.
This came on top of another liberal victory: the Family Leave Act. Beyond abortion rights, the new law mandating time off work for familial behavior at home is the centerpiece of the Clinton appeal to women. He boasts of it every day to widen the gender gap.
Bob Dole makes no attempt to argue, because polls show that mandated time off to meet family problems is a big winner with women. Occasionally you hear a peep from some business type that such government intrusion into the workplace makes a company less competitive in global markets, but that's a lot of abstruse economic talk. That battle is over.
Few stop to think of the unintended consequences to workers, female and male, in real life. The popular notion is to force employers to grant leave for family crises, then extend that to taking the family dog to the vet, then to paying for that time off.
But reality is sure to intrude on this politically rosy social engineering. If one worker takes full advantage of his entitlement of family leave time, and another shows up for work every day, which one is likelier to get ahead?
The worker who is on the job regularly will do better (and be a better provider) than the one who takes full advantage of the new entitlement to stay home. The unintended consequence of "family leave" will be to force many breadwinners into more frequent work-family conflicts.
No politician will tell you that. But ultimate decisions about hours and wages will be made between workers and managers, by the law of supply and demand, not by the meddling of politically sensitive politicians.

HEADLINE: Longer Years, Better Schools

 BODY:
The idea of year-round public schools is suddenly getting attention in New York City. Putting children on a staggered schedule over 12 months would allow each school to handle up to 25 percent more students. That would reduce much of the overcrowding problem. Money now targeted for new buildings could be used instead for repairs, computers and new science labs.
A recently released report by the Citizens Budget Commission provides some compelling arguments for doing away with the standard school schedule. Building enough new space to meet increased enrollment, and repairing the existing schools, would take about 90 percent of the city's capital funds through 2003, and still not provide computers, labs and other needed technology. 
 The C.B.C. paints a tempting vision of a New York City in which all the schools are in a good state of repair, with plenty of classroom space and up-to-date technology. But to get there, parents would have to accept a school schedule in which some students take their vacations in the fall or spring instead of summer. The nonprofit research group also envisions double sessions, in which some youngsters start class at 7:30 A.M. and leave for home by noon. Only that kind of dramatic change would allow the city to close its most rundown schools and concentrate economic resources on making the remaining buildings up-to-date.
One of the great advantages of any change that frees up space through scheduling reform is that it can be implemented quickly. Chancellor Rudy Crew is right to be planning a pilot program for extending the year in one school district by 1997.
The change would be a burden on parents who have painfully patched together after-school child care arrangements and would have to start over again. But even that problem must take a back seat to the fact that youngsters packed more than 40 to a room meant to hold 30, or having classes in the hallways, are not getting an adequate education.
The district that agrees to try the year-round school experiment should also be targeted for fast-track building repairs and technological updating. Parents who accept sacrifices and inconvenience should be able to expect rewards in the form of smaller classes, better maintained buildings and more classroom computers.
Meanwhile, the city and state must understand that scheduling innovations are not a panacea. Although some high schools are already operating on double sessions each day, the city does not have the will to put elementary school students on four-hour days that end at noon, no matter how much it will help solve New York's budget problems. Some new schools will still have to be built, and the existing ones must be repaired at a rate faster than present funding allows. But experimenting with year-round schools must be part of the mix. The city could profit mightily if the experiment is a success.
