HEADLINE: Drugs, Guns and Just Don't Do It

 BODY:
After dwelling for weeks on the economy, Bob Dole has begun attacking President Clinton on drugs and crime. As a tactical matter, Republicans may be right to try to add to Mr. Dole's central proposal, a 15 percent tax cut that has failed to excite voters. Mr. Clinton, however, has moved shrewdly to pre-empt criticism on these two social issues no less than everywhere else. The Republican candidate's poor gun-control record makes it unlikely that he can reclaim the crime issue for his own. As for drugs, both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole are right to call for more leadership, and right to accuse each other of ignoring the problem until fairly recently.
A debate about two such emotional issues is certainly welcome. Crime has been generally on the decline, especially in many big cities, but there is much that can still be done to help local police departments combat crime and curb the use of guns. The rise in drug use among American teen-agers over the last few years is also a cause for concern. Drugs are less prevalent than they were in the 1980's, and substantially less than in the 1970's, but a national survey showed recently that 10.9 percent of teen-agers used drugs at least monthly in 1995, up from 5.3 percent in 1992. 
 When Mr. Clinton took office, drug programs seemed like they would be a good place to cut spending, especially in the new era of budget stringency. That was before the upsurge in drug use among teen-agers. As a result, funding is now headed back up to record heights. What is missing is an elevated discussion about priorities. Two-thirds of the money spent by the Federal Government is still concentrated on interdiction, including stepped-up border policing and aid to drug crackdowns in other countries. Unfortunately, neither Mr. Dole nor Mr. Clinton is calling for a redirection of efforts to promote education, prevention programs and treatment in communities where drugs flourish.
For Mr. Dole to accuse President Clinton of responsibility for the increase in drug use is no surprise, but surely it is a stretch. True, some experts say that after the favorable trends of the last two decades, many Americans have become complacent about the danger of drugs. In addition, a survey by the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University has found what its chairman, Joseph A. Califano Jr., calls "an air of resignation" among parents who came of age in an era of greater tolerance toward drugs.
These attacks, however, are not so much about drugs as about Mr. Dole's attempts to invigorate the character issue. They allow the Republican campaign to run commercials recycling Mr. Clinton's clumsy comments about not inhaling and joking that he would inhale if he had the chance to try marijuana again. Mr. Clinton's comments never inspired much confidence, but neither has Mr. Dole's clunky repetitions of "Just don't do it!"
Mr. Dole's legislative record on guns, meanwhile, undercuts his campaign effort to depict himself as tough on crime. The former Republican Senator has done little to take guns out of the hands of criminals. It was hardly a surprise that the Fraternal Order of Police, a 270,000-member union that had never before endorsed a Democrat, came out for Mr. Clinton last week, following earlier endorsements by the National Association of Police Organizations and the International Union of Police Associations.
Mr. Clinton's solid record on guns includes standing up to the gun lobby to help enact the assault weapons ban and the Brady bill, which requires a waiting period for handgun purchases. As the Senate's Republican leader, Mr. Dole was in a position to help but instead voted against the Brady bill and opposed the assault weapons ban. Lately, he has withdrawn his support for repealing the ban on assault weapons, but he has not matched Mr. Clinton's unequivocal pledge to veto repeal legislation.
Crime and drugs are highly charged subjects that involve asking voters which candidate they trust in their hearts to come down on the right side of the issue. Americans would do better to evaluate the records that both candidates have compiled.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Takes Note of a Clinton Anniversary

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: GRAYSLAKE, Ill. Sept. 22

 BODY:
Bob Dole noted the three-year anniversary of the introduction of President Clinton's failed health-care overhaul measure today by denouncing it as a symptom of the President's "liberal agenda." He ridiculed "Liberal Bill Clinton" as an advocate of higher taxes and bigger government.
Mr. Dole was introduced here today by Elizabeth Dole, who came to the front of her husband's Presidential campaign for the first time in five weeks to portray Mr. Dole as a "workhorse, not a show horse." She said her husband was far more trustworthy than his opponent. The decision by Mr. Dole's campaign to put Mrs. Dole back out front came as Dole aides continued to worry over his lagging standing with women in voter polls. 
 Mr. Dole flew 1,000 miles to this heavily Republican community north of Chicago to use the anniversary of Mr. Clinton's introduction of the health-care bill to bolster his assertion that "our opponents have this outdated liberal vision of bigger government and higher taxes on working families."
"That was just three years ago today," Mr. Dole said of the anniversary of Mr. Clinton's health speech to a joint session of Congress. "So don't forget this liberal in the White House who now talks like a moderate or a conservative or a Republican."
"He won't talk about it at the debates," Mr. Dole said of the health-care plan, referring to the coming Presidential debates. Mr. Dole stopped and smiled. "Oh, I'll talk about it in the debate."
Mr. Dole's speech today was noteworthy both for its repeated use of the word "liberal" to describe the President -- it was reminiscent of President George Bush's description of Michael S. Dukakis in 1988 -- and for its signals that Mr. Dole plans to refocus his campaign this week on to the economy.
Today's rally, in this wealthy community 40 miles north of Chicago, was filled with visual reminders of Mr. Dole's 15 percent tax cut proposal. In the spot on the lectern where the White House hangs the Presidential seal for Mr. Clinton, Mr. Dole's campaign hung a circle with the word "TAXES," and a red line through it. The crowd held up yellow circular signs reading "15 percent."
Mr. Dole greeted his crowd by joking about his fall in Chico, Calif., last week, which came after his staff failed to nail down a decorative railing on the stage. "Like I said, it's a pleasure to drop in -- maybe I shouldn't use that word. Good to be here."
But Mr. Dole's campaign continued to exhibit logistical difficulties today. When Mr. Dole reached the climax of his address -- warning of attempts by the White House to use "scare" tactics about his tax cuts to win votes -- the red, white and blue balloons that were supposed to be released at the end of the rally came tumbling down, obscuring the line of sight between the candidate and the television cameras, and supporters began bursting them. Mr. Dole attempted to ignore to the barrage to deliver his peroration, but finally made note of the tumult in front of him and ended his speech.
Mr. Dole's remarks today seemed less intended to attack Mr. Clinton's health-care plan itself, than to use it as proof that Mr. Clinton was actually a liberal in moderate clothing.
Mr. Dole initially supported the concept of expanding health care insurance, but as Mr. Clinton's program lost favor with voters (and as one of Mr. Dole's Republican Presidential primary opponents, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, took to attacking it) Mr. Dole turned completely against the proposal.
He asserted today that it would put Government between families and their doctors, and would be financed by a new round of taxes.
Still, in attacking Mr. Clinton as a liberal, Mr. Dole is attempting something that Mr. Bush sought to do, without success, in 1992. Mr. Clinton's election that year was in large part the result of his having drawn lessons from the failures of other Democratic Presidential candidates through the 1980's -- Walter F. Mondale and Mr. Dukakis. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, throughout his years as Governor of Arkansas and then as a Presidential candidate, used language and adopted positions that allowed him to present himself as a moderate, from supporting the death penalty to calling for cutbacks in welfare.

HEADLINE: A Focal Point for the Well-Heeled;
In New Canaan, Prominent Residents Fight a Subdivision

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 22

 BODY:
When a housing developer appeared before the town's Environment Commission here last month, he was armed with a landscape architect, three engineers, two wetland scientists, two lawyers and his own court reporter.
When neighbors who oppose the subdivision had their say at the panel's meeting on Monday, they had their own lawyer, an engineer, a landscape architect and a couple of wildlife experts. They had already attacked the plan in full-page ads in the local newspaper. 
 All this for a proposal to build six houses.
Meet the rarefied real estate world of one of New York's most exclusive suburbs, an executive preserve where four-acre zoning endures, and million-dollar houses are being demolished to make way for bigger ones as the price of choice building lots exceeds $800,000.
The economics of housing at this level leaves the concept of shelter far behind. An $800,000 lot -- particularly a four-acre one -- does not acquire a home; it becomes an estate. And one man's estate may be another man's dressed-up oversized box, a pretentious violation of the landscape as well as the environment. Neighbors have no esthetic guarantees, only the certainty that whatever is built will be big.
"We all know that with this project we're not going to get just houses," Briggs Geddis, New Canaan's environmental officer, said at the recent hearing. "With each house, there's going to be tennis courts, swimming pools, who knows what."
This subdivision, for only half a dozen houses, involves millions of dollars, the largest remaining parcel of undisturbed forest in New Canaan, and on either side, some of Fairfield County's most prominent names.
The developers are James G. Lucchesi, a businessman turned real estate entrepreneur, and Thomas J. Watson 3d, grandson of I.B.M.'s founder. They have contracted to buy 40 acres of water company land that has long been a buffer to the New Canaan Reservoir, in a valley below the high crown of Oenoke Ridge.
The opponents, in keeping with the businesslike ways of the corporate executives who dominate New Canaan, formed the Committee to Save the Oenoke Wetlands. Its president, David T. Kearns, is the retired chairman of Xerox and a former Deputy Secretary of Education.
Mr. Kearns, like all but one of the committee's officers and most of its members, lives next to the water company property, land behind their backyards that they had assumed was protected from development.
"Most of us always felt that the property back there would remain open forever," Mr. Kearns said.
In newspaper ads, the committee has both called on the public to "Stop Watson," and has urged Mr. Watson himself to reconsider his plan to develop "one of the last large nature preserves in New Canaan."
But while his grandfather had an estate here and a number of cousins live in town, Mr. Watson lives not in New Canaan but in nearby Wilton and is not even known by any of the opponents. As the presumed money behind the plan, his famous name has been used as a target.
"The personalization is clearly out of place and offensive," said Mr. Lucchesi, speaking for Mr. Watson and himself. "We are surprised that some of the noted and respected members of the committee would link their names and reputations to such a campaign."
The neighbors, he said, are "motivated by the desire to protect a private preserve in their backyard that they don't own and that they don't pay taxes on."

A Dwindling Supply Of Available Land
In some ways, the dispute over this 40 acres may say more about the value of buildable land as it grows more scarce in wealthy suburbs like New Canaan, where owning acres around your house is part of the point, than about the environment or the developers or the neighbors.
Many people were surprised to learn that the water company property was being sold, not only because they thought it was protected, but also because it seems an awkward, if not impossible, piece of land to develop.
On a map, the outline of the 40 acres zigzags like a gerrymandered voting district, as on one side it follows the odd lot lines of the neighbors' properties, and on the other it follows a ridge line that separates it from the reservoir and the water-company's 173 other acres.
In addition, the property is inaccessible, a slice of woods surrounded by the water company land and private property. The developers had to buy a strip of land several hundred feet long from a neighbor just to provide access.
Until now, for most people the land existed only as a glimpse of woods far below when they drove along Oenoke Ridge Road. None of the watershed is open to the public, though Audubon Society birders are allowed, and deer hunters -- some approved by the utility, some poaching -- roam it.
The people most familiar with it were the neighbors, who could walk into it from their backyards, with or without permission. William Mulvey, a retired advertising executive who organized the committee, recalls his children exploring its hills and valleys. Ruth Swanberg, a neighbor who is a director of the Garden Club of America, accompanied her children.
"We used to walk back into this property here, with the permission of the manager, looking for wildflowers," she said. "Now today, I've been taking my grandchildren to the same spot looking for the same thing. I'd hate to think that's going to go."

Little Opposition, Then a Public Fight
It is because of the ridge line that the land is for sale; since the rain and snowmelt coming off its side of the ridge do not run into the reservoir, the state classifies the land as nonessential.
Several years ago, the State Department of Public Utility Control ordered the New Canaan Water Company, since bought by the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, to sell the land to reduce its debt. In 1995, after public hearings, the agency approved the sale to Mr. Lucchesi and Mr. Watson for $1.95 million, pending local approvals for building on it.
But it is because of the price of land in New Canaan that Mr. Lucchesi agreed to buy the property, after several other developers passed. His target was the $2 million to $3 million market. His first house in New Canaan, built on spec to showcase his work, sold to a corporate chairman for $2.95 million.
"I build Rolls-Royces," Mr. Lucchesi said. "I don't build Lexuses." There is not much vacant land left in New Canaan for more Rolls-Royces -- particularly land protected forever on one side by a reservoir.
Each of the six lots, he estimated, could sell for more than $800,000. In addition, he hopes to build at least some of the houses.
Mr. Lucchesi expected opposition at the state's hearings, but there was none. And neither the town nor any nonprofit group exercised its right, under state law, to buy the land for preservation.
When the neighbors realized that the sale was going through, there was one place left to make a stand: the local Environment Commission, which is charged with protecting wetlands.
Running through the property, covering 9 of the 40 acres, is a band of spongy ground through which rain and snowmelt drain into a pond on Mr. Mulvey's lot, then into the Five Mile River and Long Island Sound. To get to five of his six lots, Mr. Lucchesi had to cross the wetland.
Besides providing a habitat for many species, wetlands serve as a buffer against flooding by absorbing rain runoff and then draining gradually, their soil also cleaning the water of pollutants like pesticides and fertilizer chemicals.

Wetlands Become The Primary Focus
Still, the wetlands are an issue mainly because Mr. Lucchesi needs permission to cross them. The greater concern expressed by Mr. Kearns and his neighbors is that the scale of development, when $2 million houses are being built, will necessarily destroy a large tract of forest. And they question whether a developer's profit, and a home buyer's need to make a grandiose statement, justifies that destruction when so little open land is left.
They are urging Mr. Lucchesi to reduce the scale by building fewer houses, or imposing deed restrictions limiting, for example, the size of lawns.
"I'm not directly affected by this," Ned Swanberg, Mr. Kearns's longtime neighbor, said. "We won't see the road behind us. My concern is that, of the 40 acres, 30 to 35 will be destroyed, the woodland and the wildlife and the wetland."
Mr. Swanberg's wife, Ruth, said: "There has been a need for some development, for the medium-income people to live in, and I think that's fine. But these are $2 million houses, and I don't think we need another one in New Canaan, to be perfectly honest."
In New Canaan, however, the general state of the environment is not the business of the Environment Commission, only that of wetlands is. And certainly the esthetic question of what is more beautiful, undisturbed second-growth forest, or the kind of giant boxes that are increasingly being built here, is beyond its view.
"You have to have very good reasons to say no," the commission's chairman, Sven W. Englund, said of wetland applications. Courts are protective of property owners' rights to use their land, and in this case, if Mr. Lucchesi can't cross the wetland, the property is basically worthless.
Mr. Lucchesi and Mr. Watson, meanwhile, have spent several hundred thousand dollars on architects, engineers, lawyers and other experts. They paid $12,000 for a surveyor to count every tree that would be cut down for the road. They paid an agricultural scientist $1,800 for a study on the most environmentally sound way to maintain a lawn. They are prepared to plant shrubs along the road that will provide habitat for more species of animals and birds than are there now.
Where the road crosses the wetland, engineers have designed a weir to let water drain from one end of the property to the other; its floor will be paved with rocks taken from the land, to make it a natural passageway for animals.
The road, they say, will not harm the wetlands or change the drainage. And much of the runoff, they note, comes not from the 40 acres, but from the neighbors.
"I would hope the opposition would realize that despite their passion, this is an environmentally sensible and reasonable use of the land," Mr. Lucchesi said. "But if they want to spend tens of thousands of dollars on an appeal, that's fine with me."
Fine, as long as the market for multimillion-dollar houses stays strong. "If another Black Monday occurs before I get approval and sell the land," he said, "I've got a very big white elephant."

HEADLINE: Does America Love or Hate the U.N.?

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 20

 BODY:
How alienated from the United Nations are the American people? That question is on many minds here as the United Nations prepares for a visit on Tuesday by President Clinton.
The President, who is to address the General Assembly and sign a treaty banning nuclear test explosions, has declined a lunch with other heads of government and Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, whom Mr. Clinton has vowed to block from a second term. 
 Inside the organization and the missions of 185 member countries scattered around New York City there is intense fascination about how this visit, taking place in the midst of a presidential campaign in which both major parties have attacked the United Nations, can be made to look cordial but not too friendly.
But while American political candidates are distancing themselves from the United Nations, there is mounting evidence that the American public takes a much more generous, international view.
This summer, when more than two dozen religious leaders representing most major Christian denominations in the United States wrote to senators urging more spending on global social and economic development, relief organizations that backed the appeal pointed to numerous opinion polls showing considerable support for foreign aid and the work of international organizations.
"Average Americans understand that somehow foreign relations impinge on their daily lives now in a way that the cold war issues did not," said Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American delegate at the United Nations. "There clearly was potential terror from nuclear weapons, but the world was held at bay." Now concerns about global epidemics, crime and terrorism make them aware that they are not alone, and they look for international solutions, she said.
"Of course there are people who will always object to the U.N. because they think it's a world government, which is nonsense, and then those who object to it because it is filled with foreigners, which cannot be helped," Ms. Albright said.
Such critics have had a disproportionate effect on Congress, but do not represent public sentiment, said Steven Kull of the University of Maryland's School of Public Affairs, who has conducted a series of polls on international issues.
"Clearly members of Congress have a perception that the public is more resistant to participation in the U.N. or has a more negative attitude about the U.N. than the polls show," he said.
"It does seem that people who call and write to members of Congress, just based on what they say, are wont to have more concerns about the U.N. being too powerful," he continued. "But this is a very small population, but they are more verbal about it, more active, and belong to organizations that mobilize people."
Representative Eliot L. Engel, a Democrat from the Bronx who recently led a successful campaign to restore some money cut from Administration requests for the United Nations Development Program, said that when members of Congress are made aware that assaults on the United Nations can actually undermine American economic or security interests, they can be persuaded to be more supportive of the organization.
He said that New York would lose jobs and revenue if the United Nations Development Program left the city, perhaps for Bonn, which is wooing it. The development program assists poor nations, often helping them create free-market economies.
"We can either have an aid program that insures that there is stability in the world, democracy and the kind of free markets we want to see," Mr. Engel said, "or we can be very shortsighted and in 10, 20, 30 years from now, God forbid, we can fight another major war, or have to pick up the pieces of one."
When Mr. Kull began sampling American public opinion about the United Nations more than three years ago, his findings were greeted with a good deal of skepticism.
Americans, his polls showed, were neither isolationists nor proponents of a go-it-alone style of world leadership. Instead, they wanted greater involvement in the United Nations, including in peacekeeping operations, and more spending on foreign aid.
These and other researchers' polls have also shown that Americans would support a standing United Nations peacekeeping force and taxes on arms transfers to pay for operations.
When some opinion surveys began to show that these attitudes could affect how people vote this November, critics often zeroed in on what they saw as the bias of the groups conducting the polls -- for example, the United Nations Association of the United States, an independent, nonpartisan group, but one that is close to the United Nations -- or how the questions were posed.
Charles Lichenstein, a former deputy permanent representative of the United States at the United Nations and now senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative organization in Washington, questioned whether respondants understood the issues involved.
While most Americans are generous and want to help solve world problems, he said, there are few who know enough about the United Nations to judge how effective it is.
"If you ask another set of questions: Should American forces be put under the command of the U.N. or some other international body in which the U.S. has no decisive authority, I suspect most Americans would say, 'Of course not,' " Mr. Lichenstein said. "If you ask them, should you throw good money after bad, they would say 'No.' "
At the United Nations Association in New York, Jeffrey Laurenti, executive director of policy studies, says criticism of the United Nations can come from either the right or the left in Washington because until very recently, foreign policy was the preserve of an elite drawn from both Republican and Democratic camps. It was a world of security specialists and establishment pundits where "international affairs was assumed to be high diplomacy, not town hall politics."
"Think tanks also had an investment in power politics and cold war alliances," Mr. Laurenti said. "The public doesn't have these same personal or emotional investments," he said. He says this is why opinion polls are reflecting a far greater public awareness of changing global concerns than the guardians of opinion want to recognize.
"The old priesthood cannot keep the unwashed laity from the altar of international relations any longer," Mr. Laurenti said. "The public at large tends to see international affairs increasingly as something from which they cannot be disengaged. They see international problems as something the whole world needs to be involved in."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Democrats Ponder New Clinton Term

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Bill Clinton could very well be on his way to becoming only the third Democrat in this century to win re-election as President. That feat alone would give him a place in history.
Yet as Election Day draws nearer, even many Democrats say they are hard-pressed to describe a second Clinton term: Who would serve in an Administration that is expected to undergo vast turnover? And what kind of reputation would Mr. Clinton build for himself and for a party that has largely run this election by capitalizing on the unpopularity of Speaker Newt Gingrich? 
In broad strokes, Mr. Clinton has said he would devote another four years to emphasizing education, to somewhat expanded coverage of health care and to deficit reduction as levers to move the country further along in a post-industrial information age.
He has accompanied his speeches with small-scale family-centered proposals that might be said to make up a Nouvelle Deal of fat-free Government activism in a time of strained resources. In some cases, he has proposed tax incentives instead of spending programs to foster social goals, offering tax cuts, for example, as an incentive for obtaining higher education. And sometimes his stands are simply hortatory.
But a debate is already starting inside the Democratic Party over whether such a modest agenda is needed to restore faith in a party too often associated with big government, or whether it leaves a policy vacuum that ignores the nation's true challenges.
"Whether you have a Democratic Congress or not, there will be a furious debate about where Democrats go," said Robert. L. Borosage, co-director of the Campaign for America's Future, a new research group set up by some Democrats to counter the centrist Democratic Leadership Council. "Everyone's agreed that this election is a referendum on the Gingrich agenda."
Mr. Clinton has been far less specific about how he would grapple with what many analysts consider to be the serious policy questions: what programs to trim or eliminate to balance the budget, how to insure that there will be jobs for the millions forced off welfare, and what to do about impending crises in the Social Security and Medicare systems as the nation's population ages.
Robert D. Reischauer, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said, "We are at a point in our history where the New Deal has to be rationalized and consolidated if it's going to be preserved in the second and third decades of the next century when the baby boom generation's retirement puts immense pressure on the system."
How Mr. Clinton tackles these problems could depend on the Congress he has to work with. When he faced Democrats in his first two years in office, Mr. Clinton tacked leftward, raising taxes to combat the Federal deficit and trying to sell universal health care coverage.
When the Republicans took charge of Congress after the 1994 elections, Mr. Clinton moved to support a seven-year plan to reach a balanced budget and signed into law stringent limits on welfare benefits. His aides now say they expect to face a centrist Congress no matter which party prevails in November.
"Whatever happens, the governing majority is going to be very narrow," said Bruce Reed, a domestic policy adviser. "That means that the two parties will have to work together to get anything done."
Other Administration officials wonder whether Mr. Clinton could persuade a Democratic House to approve his plan to balance the budget, particularly since it reserves the hard choices for the future.
"The question is," one official said, "will the Democrats -- if they come into power -- follow him?"
Assuming that no recession is on the horizon, Mr. Clinton's budget plan envisioned $279 billion in savings from entitlement programs, including Medicare and Medicaid, and $167 billion in other domestic programs. Most of those cuts have yet to be made. And the Democrats have run hard against the House Republican attempt to rein in Medicare spending by $270 billion, raising the question of whether either party will try to overhaul a program that has such a committed constituency.
Some liberal Democrats are mobilizing to cut military spending to free resources for domestic programs.
Beyond identifying immediate savings in Medicare, Mr. Clinton must decide whether to take the politically risky step of revising Medicare and Social Security before the retirement of the baby boom generation early in the next century breaks the systems.
The President has said that bipartisan commissions should be set up to make recommendations for both programs, and he has suggested that he is open to ideas like raising the retirement age or lowering the automatic cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security.
More broadly, Mr. Clinton could be expected to seek some small steps toward his formerly consuming quest to insure health coverage for all Americans. He has said he wants legislation to allow laid-off workers to be able to keep their health insurance for six months. And many aides predict that Mr. Clinton might seek health coverage for all children.
One large question is how far Mr. Clinton would go to modify the new welfare legislation, which imposes a lifetime limit of five years on benefits for any family and requires most adult recipients to work within two years. The President, who signed measure last month, has said he wants to remove provisions barring assistance to legal immigrants who are not yet citizens and to modify some cuts in food stamps.
He has also proposed $3.4 billion in grants and tax incentives to create jobs. And he has recently implored churches and businesses to hire workers who leave the welfare rolls. But members of his Administration are ready to push him to further guarantee the availability of work.
The gap between rich and poor has continued to grow in the last four years, and Mr. Clinton has said the answer to wage inequality is education. He proposed a tutoring program to insure that all children are literate by the third grade, a school construction fund and a $10,000 tax deduction and a $1,500 tax credit to help pay for college tuition.
Aides predict that Mr. Clinton, with an eye to history, would be likely to burnish the peacemaker role and seek a comprehensive role in the Middle East. He has also called for summit meetings on the expansion of NATO and on improving relations with China.
One clue to Mr. Clinton's policy direction would be the appointments he makes in a second term and the balance he strikes between his party's liberal and moderate wings.
Among those exected to leave are Leon E. Panetta, the chief of staff, and George R. Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser. Friends say the deputy chief of staff, Harold M. Ickes, may return to New York.
In the Cabinet, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, 70, is considered likely to leave as well. Some officials say they believe that the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, may also move on. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich may return to academia, and Attorney General Janet Reno, who has Parkinson's disease, may step down for health reasons, officials said.
No matter what Mr. Clinton would do in a second term, a victory after the depths of 1994 would be considered an extraordinary comeback. And he would join the ranks of Woodrow Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt as the only Democratic Presidents to be re-elected in this century.

HEADLINE: Case Study: When Busing Works, but Unease Persists

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
The move seemed logical enough.
A Brooklyn school district decided to make a dent in the overcrowding of one intermediate school by busing sixth graders to an undercrowded school in the same district. Empty spaces in East New York could be filled with children from Cypress Hills, just a 15-minute bus ride away. 
 But the parents in Cypress Hills did not like the idea from the start. Not long after the busing began three years ago, rumors began to crop up. One parent, Maria Perez, heard that her daughter Evita's sixth-grade class had to get down on the floor one day when gunshots were fired in the housing project across the street. Last year, another mother, Sonia Perez, said her son, Maximino, was nearly an hour late getting home because the bus had to detour around the scene of a shootout between the police and a man they said was the Zodiac serial killer.
Whether or not these stories were true, the perception that East New York is a risky and undesirable place to send their children sticks in the minds of many Cypress Hills parents when they are asked about busing. And there are other things they do not like: They say the school is too far away, and since few of them have cars, it is difficult to drop in on classes or deliver something a child left at home. And ethnic differences divide Cypress Hills, a mostly Hispanic neighborhood on the north side of busy Atlantic Avenue, from East New York, a mostly black neighborhood on the south side, making parents worry that their children will feel uncomfortable or that the usual hallway pushing and shoving could erupt into something more serious.
Even with these concerns, parents acknowledge that their children have had few difficulties socially or academically at the East New York school. On a recent visit, the school seemed safe, orderly, calm and insulated from neighborhood violence and crime. And the school, which is 60 percent black and 38 percent Hispanic, is actually more diverse than the Cypress Hills parents might have expected.
Because busing can successfully spare students from many of the problems of overcrowding, it would be an obvious answer to easing the worst overcrowding in the New York City schools in decades. But as the emotional reactions and practical concerns of parents -- some of them who even have other children in overcrowded schools -- indicate, it is not only a matter of matching students with seats.
With 91,000 more students than the system can adequately handle and not enough money for new schools, Chancellor Rudy Crew is exploring options like year-round schooling and busing to fill the 67,000 empty seats throughout the system, some in classrooms that have been turned into lounges or offices. New York City already buses some 159,000 children to school each day.
But the experience of a single Brooklyn district, where the bureaucratic and geographic hurdles to busing are minimal, suggests why even moving children a relatively short distance -- never mind across district lines -- can be much more complicated than it seems. "There ought to be a way to reconcile those, to fill up what you have, rather than build new schools," said Robert E. Riccobono, the superintendent of District 19, which includes Cypress Hills and East New York. "But you can't just plug in the holes. Neighborhoods are psychological and physical barriers. Kids have to cross a line that is regarded as a community line. Is it distance or safety or a neighborhood with a different ethnic composition? It's all of those."
He and other school officials say that busing can have practical disadvantages. They say that parents become less involved with their children's schooling when they cannot walk down the street to meet with a teacher or guidance counselor. They say that busing often makes it hard for a child to participate in extracurricular activities. And some say moving children to other schools can make it tricky to plan certain classes and curriculums, especially those that mix grade levels or use the same teacher in several classes.

Problems of Space, Money and Attitude
The story of District 19, which lies along Brooklyn's western border with Queens, is an intricate web of the issues that, in one way or another, afflict many school districts.
There is the recent surge of immigrants, mostly from Latin America and the Caribbean, to the district's north side. And while Cypress Hills has its share of violent crime, parts of it are considered the safer areas of Brooklyn's 75th Precinct.
There is East New York, a neighborhood that has only recently begun to make up for a series of scourges: the white flight of the 1960's, the drug devastation of the 1970's and 1980's, and a murder rate that until a few years ago was the city's highest.
There are the economic circumstances of the district's poor and working-class families, which lead many teachers and parents to feel that the closer the school to home, the better. Some families, for example, rely on older children to walk the younger ones home from school.
There is the issue of new school buildings, in this case a proposed intermediate school in Cypress Hills that, to the bristling anger of many parents, has been held up for four years because of a dispute between the city and a food processing plant over the land. And there is the district's Mason-Dixon line, Atlantic Avenue, the wide, divided thoroughfare with elevated train tracks down the middle and heavy trucks rumbling in both directions. North of Atlantic Avenue is Cypress Hills. South is East New York.
"Atlantic Avenue is a community line psychologically as well as physically because it is a dangerous street to cross," Mr. Riccobono said.
All of these factors have contributed to a diametrically unequal distribution of schoolchildren. The most recently available figures show that last year, schools on the north side had about 1,000 too many children, while schools on the south side had 1,200 spaces.
"It's almost a wash," Mr. Riccobono said. "You would say that, pretty easily, through rezoning, you should be able to resolve the picture. But you can't. If you do that you might be providing an effective baby-sitting service, but you may not be taking into consideration the best education and you're not taking into consideration the concerns of the parents, and why else are we here? They see a school building across the street or a few blocks away from home and they want the kid to go there. It's an American tradition."

A District Strains To Cure Imbalance
District officials have tried many things to rid the imbalance.
They have moved kindergartners among schools throughout the district, a step that they say is easier to take because school districts are not legally required to provide kindergarten classes and can therefore move the children without public hearings or changes to school residence boundaries.
They have tried to attract more children to several East New York intermediate schools by turning them into magnet schools, with special programs dealing with health care, computers or legal affairs that are open to students who live anywhere in the district.
They have leased space for annexes in places like a Y.M.C.A. And they have moved other sixth-grade classes to undercrowded schools. There were complaints, "but it was closer and people didn't view it so much as going from Cypress Hills to East New York," Mr. Riccobono said. "It wasn't as blatant."
Reconciled to the limited city and state money for building and leasing new classrooms, Mr. Riccobono said he would like to move fifth and sixth grades in overcrowded schools to "any school that's underutilized."
That would be schools like Intermediate School 292 in East New York, which has turned some of its 500 spaces into offices and a moot courtroom. A nearby elementary school, Public School 190, has classes with only 20 to 22 children. Ten minutes away are the bulging classrooms of Public School 7 and Intermediate School 171, which share the same 85-year-old building on Ridgewood Avenue in Cypress Hills.
Some classrooms are packed with 50 children taught simultaneously by two teachers who say they can devote little time to each child. There is no cafeteria -- it has been turned into three classrooms. Children eat in the gym and the auditorium.
"It's a terrible situation," said Victor Rodriguez, the principal of I.S. 171. Every classroom and storage closet is filled with people from either the intermediate school or the elementary school.
"All of a sudden, his gym class is in our lineup," said Teresa Moser, the principal of P.S. 7. "Our children are eating lunch in his assembly."
The school, built for 1,100 students, has more than 1,750 this year. Officials bus about 320 children to other schools. More than half of them are kindergarteners. About 140 are sixth graders, who board a bus at 7 a.m. bound for Intermediate School 218 in East New York and are dropped off by bus at the Cypress Hills school at the end of the day.
That move was begun in September 1993, over the heated objections of many parents.
"The thing is that we were going to be using a school that didn't belong to us," said Sonia Perez, whose daughter, Yamaris, was in the first batch of sixth graders and whose son went to East New York last year.
Maria Perez, whose youngest daughter, Jessenia, has 50 children in her first-grade class at P.S. 7 this year, said she was concerned about the overcrowding in Cypress Hills. But, even though three of her children have been bused to I.S. 218 without incident, she is still not comfortable with the arrangement. She said she has trouble getting to the school to see how they are doing.

The Toughest Task: Pleasing the Parents
School districts are entitled to make zoning and busing decisions without parental approval, but public hearings are required and no school official wants unhappy parents.
"There were meetings and screaming," Mr. Riccobono said. "It totally made sense, but the parents didn't like the idea."
Even Mr. Rodriguez, the principal of I.S. 171, is not fond of the idea.
"It looks good on paper," Mr. Rodriguez said. "But what good is it to splinter a school? The kids have no identity with who they belong to."
Ultimately, the district worked out an arrangement that would keep the Cypress Hills sixth graders as separate as possible from the East New York students.
Their classrooms were grouped together in one wing of the intermediate school with its own administrative office. The Cypress Hills children would eat lunch earlier than the other students. And to keep the Cypress Hills children out of the hallways as much as possible, the students would stay in a single classroom all day and the teachers would move from room to room.
"I think they were very concerned because the word out in the community is that this particular area in East New York is not the same as where they are, with the homicide rate," said Ron Attivissimo, the principal of I.S. 218.
Mr. Attivissimo said the East New York parents have not protested the busing. And despite their fears, Cypress Hills parents like Maria Perez and Sonia Perez concede that the switch to the school has gone rather smoothly.
Mr. Attivissimo said the school's worst problems are occasional skirmishes that do not necessarily involve students from the two neighborhoods. Mr. Riccobono said there have been shootings in the nearby housing project, but he said the school, like others in East New York, is protected from violence and drugs.
But now that many parents have become accustomed to having the sixth grade in East New York, something else is happening to I.S. 218. Busing, magnet programs and other district changes have brought hundreds more students into the school.
"It's created the problem of overcrowding in my school," said Mr. Attivissimo. "We're going to have to talk about another site for I.S. 171."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sixth-grade students in Cypress Hills are bused to Intermediate School 218 in East New York at 7 A.M. each day. The busing began in September 1993 over the objections of many parents in Cypress Hills. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: Rural Life Gains New Appeal, Turning Back a Long Decline

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Iowa, Sept. 19

 BODY:
After graduating from college a few years ago, Marty Beanblossom did something that would once have seemed remarkable for an ambitious young man from this Midwestern prairie town. He came back.
George Schaefer, a local farm boy, lived in San Francisco for 15 years, traveled the world and became a Zen Buddhist. Now he has returned to work the family farm overlooking the English River in Washington County. 
 New young professionals in town, Bridget Quinn Carey, a librarian from Long Island, and her husband, Jim Carey, a lawyer who grew up in Buffalo, recently bought a turn-of-the-century house on a shady street in this little town of rambling porches and picket fences.
And a fledgling Hispanic community, though still small, has grown large enough for the Washington State Bank to need a Spanish-speaking teller.
Ten years after the nightmare of a collapsing agricultural economy, when many family farms went broke, stores closed, suicide rates soared and young people fled the countryside, rural America is growing again.
It is what a new study labels "The Rural Rebound," and economists explain it by citing a big jump in the number of small-town manufacturing jobs, a stronger farm economy, quality-of-life concerns among baby boomers, especially those with young children, and the technological advances that allow many people to do their work wherever they wish.
Reversing a longstanding rural-to-urban trend, 1.6 million more people moved to rural areas from cities and suburbs from 1990 to 1995 than went the other way, according to a study by Calvin Beale, a demographer with the United States Department of Agriculture, and Kenneth M. Johnson, a sociologist at Loyola University in Chicago.
Many rural counties continue to hollow out, especially in the Great Plains. But 50 percent of farm-based counties have seen a population increase in the 1990's, according to the study. Virtually all agricultural counties in the Midwest, including Washington County, lost population in the 80's. In general, a county was classified as rural if it had no population center of at least 50,000.
"It's fun to be living in Iowa these days," said Bill Reha, the vice president of the Washington State Bank. He talked about the diversity of the newcomers in town, the optimism of bright young college graduates moving back, rising property values and a resurgent Main Street.
Small towns like Washington, with its Victorian-style homes and a town square shaded by towering trees, have an unmistakable appeal, at least esthetically, compared with the now-dominant American motif of strip malls and suburban sprawl.
Plenty of young people are looking at rural areas, ignored for years by the up-and-coming, as places rife with opportunity.
On the first day of his law practice, Mr. Carey, 27, was seeing clients. "And within six months, I had a jury trial," said Mr. Carey, who surprised himself after law school at the University of Iowa by settling in the state. "Meanwhile, my friends are still filing in the basements of major law firms."
Mr. Beanblossom, who returned to his hometown to be a funeral director, has found it possible to become a civic leader in a small town without having to wait for gray hair. At age 27, he is a member of the School Board, president of the Community Chest and on the board of directors of a local advocacy group for the developmentally disabled.
"I shrug my shoulders at classmates who wonder what there is to do in a small town," Mr. Beanblossom said. "There aren't enough hours in the day to do all the things I want to do."
Iowa, which hemorrhaged population in the 80's at a rate worse than any other state, losing 5.1 percent of its population, has started to grow, with a population gain of 62,000 since 1990. But the state, with a population of 2.86 million, still has 137,000 fewer people than in 1980.
The growth in rural areas has been achieved largely through economic diversification. In 1995, for the first time, Iowa exported more non-farm goods, which were worth $4.1 billion, than crops and livestock, worth $4 billion.
For the first time in 100 years, Washington County looks as though it will reach a new population high -- about 21,000 -- by the end of the decade.
It helps to have the University of Iowa just 30 miles away, in Iowa City, a city of 60,000 with a growing employment base and a robust cultural and arts community.
But farming is still the dominant economic force in Washington County, and times for farmers are much better. Interest rates have stayed relatively low, corn prices have lately hovered at record highs, and land prices, which plunged to $1,000 an acre from $3,500 an acre in the 80's, have climbed back to about $3,200 an acre.
Two big, empty commercial shells that once housed a discount store and a builder of metal barns have come back to life as the homes of new companies, Bazooka Farmstar, which makes agricultural equipment, and Engineer Building Design, which builds roof trusses.
Virtually all of the town's businesses have been growing, including McCleery-Cummings, a maker of calendars; Modine Inc., a water company, and the Crane Company, a maker of valves.
Iowa has a large number of older residents, after a long exodus by the young, and two retirement homes here cater to them, the United Presbyterian Home and Halcyon House.
"When they come to us, they might not have lived here for 50 or 60 years," said Ann C. Williams, the administrator at Halcyon House. "But they'll say: 'This is where my roots are. This is where I belong.' "
People like Ms. Quinn Carey are finding that it is where they belong, too. After growing up on Long Island, she said, she would never have dreamed of living in Iowa, especially with the childhood memories she had of visiting a relative who was a farmer.
"Two weeks on a hog farm was not a Long Islander's idea of a summer vacation," she said.
When her husband was accepted into law school at the University of Iowa, she said, she decided that she could bear three years in Iowa City, "as long as it was three years and out."
But after landing a part-time job in Kalona, the center of an Amish and Mennonite settlement, she gave small-town life a closer look. Then she and her husband decided to have a family.
"Having a kid changes everything," she said. "It's safe here. It's pretty. And the people are there for you. What's important is different in this culture, and I like that."
But it takes some adjusting to a life with little privacy and no anonymity. When Mr. Carey moved here, he said, it took him forever to walk down the street to get to work. Everybody wanted to stop to talk to him, shake his hand and find out about him and his business.
"I guess that's what makes it a safe and secure place, though," he said.
Mr. Schaefer, who is probably the only Zen Buddhist farmer in Washington County, is not quite sure why he came home to stay. He interrupted a trip to South America four years ago to come back for the wedding of his brother, Steve, and decided to stay, at least for a while.
Now he and his wife, Anne, a commercial interior designer, are planning to build a house on the farm, which has been in his family for nearly 150 years.
"It wasn't a real conscious decision to come back," Mr. Schaefer said. "But I guess it's been a conscious decision to stay. It takes some getting used to. But I like it, probably 90 percent of the time."
As an insurance broker in San Francisco, he had earned a high salary, but he did not like the work. "I told my boss, 'You know, I hate what I do,' " he said. "And he answered, 'Yeah, well, so do most people.' "
Mr. Schaefer quit his job and set out on an 18-month journey, spending a lot of time in India and New Zealand.
At his farm, on a bluff overlooking the English River, he ruminated about a journey that stretched from Iowa to San Francisco and around the world, and finally back home to Iowa.
"I'll be pulling out a fence," he said, "and I'll think, 'My great-great-grandfather stood here one day and put this in.' "

HEADLINE: Sharpton's Candidacy Has Democratic Leaders Stewing Over Strategy

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
As the Rev. Al Sharpton formally announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday, Democratic leaders said that his surprise entry into the race would complicate their efforts to regain City Hall next year.
Mr. Sharpton announced his candidacy to a packed congregation during the morning service at Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem, issuing a blistering attack on the stewardship of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and presenting himself as a potent municipal voice for black New Yorkers. 
 But his entry into the race was seen as a possible boon to the Republican Mayor, complicating efforts among Democrats to unite behind an electable alternative to Mr. Giuliani. In fact, Mr. Sharpton said he had not even determined whether he would run in the Democratic primary, holding out the possibility he could run as an independent, siphoning black votes from the Democratic candidate.
Should Mr. Sharpton run in the Democratic primary and lose, many Democratic leaders and elected officials suggested that black voters might be too disenchanted to return to the polls for the November general election and vote for the Democratic nominee.
"In order to defeat Rudy Giuliani, we're going to need every African-American vote possible, plus others that are part of the Democratic Party," said Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., the Brooklyn Democratic leader. "If he siphons off African-American votes, it would guarantee Giuliani's re-election."
Mr. Norman said that his major concern about Mr. Sharpton was whether he would accept the outcome of the Democratic primary and stand behind the nominee. "If he runs in the general election as an independent," Mr. Norman said, "it creates a major problem for those of us who want to see Giuliani dislodged from City Hall."
Mr. Sharpton has always been an unpredictable and flamboyant presence in New York City politics. And the news of his latest candidacy has hit many in political circles like a bombshell.
Mr. Sharpton captured 26 percent of the vote in the Democratic Senate primary against Daniel Patrick Moynihan two years ago, and his entry into the mayoral race has forced many political leaders and mayoral hopefuls to reassess their strategies.
"Given how Sharpton did in his two Senate races, there's a good chance he could get a quarter of the primary vote," said Public Advocate Mark J. Green, now the highest-ranking citywide elected Democrat. Mr. Green said that, under those circumstances, Mr. Sharpton might "directly influence who would end up in a runoff, if not possibly get in a runoff himself."
Former Mayor David N. Dinkins said that he had not talked to Mr. Sharpton and was therefore reluctant to comment. However, Mr. Dinkins said that "obviously this has to have an effect on the effort to unseat Giuliani." Mr. Dinkins added, "Perhaps that will be a negative effect."
Mr. Giuliani had no comment on Mr. Sharpton's announcement, his press secretary, Colleen Roche, said. She said that the Mayor had also withheld his opinions of other declared or presumptive candidates.
Speaking to reporters after the church service, Mr. Sharpton said he had formed an exploratory committee that would determine many of the details of his candidacy. One day earlier, an aide to Mr. Sharpton had said the minister expected to run in the Democratic primary.
Yesterday, several people close to Mr. Sharpton, who ran twice for the United States Senate as a Democrat, said that he would most likely run in the Democratic primary.
In his remarks yesterday, Mr. Sharpton discounted any suggestion that he could not win. "The fact of the matter is that I got 33 percent of the city vote," he said, referring to his candidacy for the Senate two years ago. He said that once he files his papers to make his candidacy official, "I'm the front-runner already."
Mr. Sharpton told hundreds of cheering worshipers that he considered Mr. Giuliani's tenure to have been a failure, citing problems in the public schools, police brutality and insensitivity toward black New Yorkers. "So it is on that basis that I have said I will run," he said.
Before Mr. Sharpton entered the race, the only announced candidate in the Democratic primary was Sal F. Albanese, a City Councilman who represents the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. But Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, and Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, have already raised substantial campaign funds and have hired consultants in preparation for their mayoral races. Also, Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, has said he was deliberating whether to enter the race.
Mr. Albanese said he would not alter his strategy because of Mr. Sharpton's candidacy. But he said that "there is no doubt that the Reverend Sharpton will garner a majority of the black vote. But that will not affect my strategy of trying to appeal to voters across racial lines on economic themes."
Many political consultants suggested that the candidate most likely to be affected by Mr. Sharpton's candidacy was Ms. Messinger, who has made black voters a cornerstone of her election strategy. Over the last year, she has campaigned in black churches and has appeared before a wide range of black organizations.
Ms. Messinger was observing the Jewish holiday yesterday and was unavailable for comment. Her spokesman, Leland T. Jones, however, said that the Manhattan Borough President believed that the Sharpton candidacy posed no difficulty for her campaign.
"The Reverend Sharpton can be the equivalent to a shot in the arm for the Democratic Party," Mr. Jones said. "He will bring a series of issues to the fore and energize his base to vote. And that will be to the benefit to all in the Democratic primary and, ultimately, for the Democratic nominee. She is not worried about this."
In the Senate race four years ago, Mr. Sharpton got 15 percent of the vote in a contest that drew a strong turnout among black voters, who delivered 70 percent of their vote for him. In that race, he unexpectedly finished ahead of Elizabeth Holtzman, then the City Comptroller, in a four-person Democratic primary. The results broadened his reputation beyond street militancy to demonstrate that he could be a politician with some level of following.
Two years ago, Mr. Sharpton won 26 percent of the vote in a Democratic primary against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, with a large percentage of votes coming from black voters in New York City.
But Mr. Sharpton has a host of critics and has drawn criticism for some of his political positions and causes, including accusations of anti-Semitism during the Crown Heights racial disturbances in 1991. He also was sharply criticized for racially charged statements last year before the torching of a white-owned store in Harlem.
Mr. Sharpton and Mayor Giuliani have a history of tense relations, with Mr. Sharpton frequently accusing the Giuliani administration of racist policies and the Mayor of being insensitive to black New Yorkers.
Much of that sentiment was in evidence in Mr. Sharpton's comments yesterday, as he attacked Mr. Giuliani for not doing more to solve the problem of overcrowded schools and "police brutality that's getting worse and worse." He added: "In the middle of this, the Mayor tells us that the quality of life has gotten better. Better for whom?"
Mr. Sharpton also focused on the dearth of black elected officials in city government. "We are approaching the end of the 20th century and there is not one black citywide elected official in the city of New York," Mr. Sharpton said.
Mr. Sharpton came to prominence in the mid-1980's during the Howard Beach case, in which a black man, Michael Griffith, was killed by an automobile after being chased onto a Queens highway by a group of white youths. As an adviser to the Griffith family, Mr. Sharpton successfully pressed for the appointment of a special prosecutor in the case.
He again took center stage during the racial tensions that swirled around the death of Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black youth killed by a white mob in the summer of 1989 in Bensonhurst. Mr. Sharpton staged angry protest marches in Bensonhurst accompanied by busloads of supporters. It was during one such march that a 27-year-old man stabbed Mr. Sharpton with a five-inch steak knife.
Mr. Sharpton faced possibly his greatest criticism for his involvement in the case of Tawana Brawley, a 16-year-old Dutchess County girl who claimed she had been raped by a band of white men. Mr. Sharpton took on the State Attorney General's office, accusing officials of a cover-up in the case and suggesting that law enforcement officers carried out the sexual attack, but a special grand jury later dismissed the case as a hoax. To this day, Mr. Sharpton maintains that Tawana Brawley was raped, then abused by a judicial system that would not believe her.
Born in Crown Heights, Mr. Sharpton recounts often in stories that he was a loud child who learned early that "you've got to holler like hell sometimes to get what you want." He preached his first sermon at the age of 4 at the Washington Temple Church of God in Christ in Brooklyn and became known through radio broadcasts and sermons as the Wonder Boy, a fiery prodigy in the pulpit.
As a teen-ager, he attached himself to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., minister of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. And then in 1973, a year after Mr. Powell's death, he began to work for the soul singer James Brown, whom he met after Mr. Brown's son died in an automobile accident. He worked with Mr. Brown through the 1970's, helping promote his concerts and even styling his hair similarly.
Mr. Sharpton's income comes mostly from public speaking and cash donations at his weekly Saturday rally for the nonprofit National Action Network, a political group of which he is president.
He and his family divide their time between an apartment in Crown Heights and a house in Englewood, N.J., where they spend most weekends.

HEADLINE: MOST STATES FIND GOALS ON WELFARE WITHIN EASY REACH

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
State officials are discovering that the work requirements of the new welfare law are much less onerous than they first believed.
The work requirements will be substantially reduced for any state that reduces the number of families receiving welfare, compared with the total in the 1995 fiscal year, and that number is already way down in most states. Thus, a state can comply with the law by putting some people to work and by simply removing others from the rolls, regardless of whether they find jobs. 
 In the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, at least 25 percent of the adults on welfare in each state are supposed to be working, the law says. But if, for example, a state reduces its caseload by 10 percent, compared with the 1995 fiscal year, its work target will be reduced by 10 percentage points, so only 15 percent of the adults on welfare will be required to work.
Since the welfare caseload is down an average of 9 percent nationwide from last year and still falling, that means many states will face a far smaller task in meeting the Federal requirements. If a welfare recipient moves to a job or simply ceases to receive aid, the state gets the same credit toward the work requirement.
That worries some welfare advocates. Mark H. Greenberg, a lawyer at the Center for Law and Social Policy, a research and advocacy group, said the "caseload reduction credit" was troubling to him because it rewarded states for reducing the welfare rolls even if they did not put more people to work.
"Under this provision," Mr. Greenberg said, "states will be equally rewarded if their caseload goes down because more people are working or simply because the state has has made it more difficult for families who need help to receive it."
The welfare law ends the 60-year-old Federal guarantee of cash assistance for the nation's poorest children, sets a five-year limit on payments to any family and gives states vast new power to run their own welfare and work programs with lump sums of Federal money.
The caseload-reduction credit will prove useful to most states. In June, the last month for which Federal data are available, the number of families on welfare was less than the monthly average for the 1995 fiscal year in 47 of the 50 states -- all but Alaska, Hawaii and Minnesota.
New York State faces the prospect of a dauntingly large jobs program, but the state will need to get only 18 to 20 percent of its adult welfare recipients into jobs because of declines in its welfare rolls, which were down nearly 7 percent in June, compared with the fiscal 1995 average.
Drops in welfare rolls are striking in Maryland (26 percent), Wisconsin (24 percent), Indiana (21 percent), Oklahoma (18 percent), Louisiana (15 percent) and Michigan (14 percent). For the nation as a whole, the number of families on welfare has declined 14 percent, to 4.4 million, from a peak of 5.1 million in March 1994.
Evelyn Ganzglass, director of employment and social services policy at the National Governors' Association, said: "It's staggering how much change there has been in caseloads. It's incredible."
Officials attribute that to a strong economy, aggressive efforts to put people to work, restrictive new state laws and a new political climate that discourages people from seeking or staying on welfare.
Many state welfare officials say the provisions mean that they will probably be able to meet the requirements without making major changes in their programs. In New York, however, city and state officials are scrambling to prepare for the largest public jobs program since the Depression, and some experts say it will be extremely difficult for New York to find employment for the thousands of unskilled people now receiving welfare.
But the number of families on the Federal welfare rolls in New York State has dropped nearly 7 percent, to 425,370 in June from a monthly average of 456,929 in the 1995 fiscal year. That reduction means New York will need to put 18 to 20 percent of its welfare recipients to work, and aides to Gov. George E. Pataki said last week that the state was well on its way to meeting that goal.
In Connecticut, the number of families on welfare has dropped 6 percent, to 57,120 in June from an average of 60,985 in the 1995 fiscal year, while in New Jersey, the number is down 7 percent, to 110,700 from 118,883.
In Mississippi, Larry E. Temple, deputy director of the state Department of Human Services, said, "Our caseload is going through the floor." As a result, he said, the state will easily meet the new work requirements.
From 1990 to 1993, more than 60,000 Mississippi families were on the welfare rolls. That number declined to 52,500 in 1995 and then declined a further 10 percent, to 47,300, in the first nine months of the current fiscal year.
So under the new law, Mississippi will have to put about 15 percent of its adult welfare recipients to work, and that goal is well within reach, Mr. Temple said. He said 10 to 15 percent of the recipients were already working.
Mississippi, like other states, is emphasizing work. "When a client comes in to apply or be recertified," Mr. Temple said, "we have job placement people on site trying to find them a private-sector unsubsidized job as a first priority."
In Indiana, Cheryl Sullivan, the Secretary of Family and Social Services, said, "We don't anticipate any problem meeting the work requirements set by the Federal Government." Twenty percent of Indiana's adult welfare recipients are already working, Ms. Sullivan said, and Indiana will get credit for for having already made sharp reductions in its rolls. Thus, Indiana is already satisfying the work requirements imposed on it by the new law.
The Republicans who devised the caseload-reduction credit acknowledge that they do not know what happens to all the parents and children leaving the welfare rolls. Democrats say many of these families sink deeper into poverty. Republicans say the adults will find jobs and will ultimately be better off.
Even without changing eligibility criteria, Mr. Greenberg said, a state can reduce its welfare rolls in many ways -- for example, by closing some welfare offices, by imposing new paper-work requirements or by demanding that an applicant produce additional records as proof of identity or income.
Gary J. Stangler, director of the Missouri Department of Social Services, closely followed the Congressional debate on welfare legislation, but he said he had been pleasantly surprised to learn of the caseload-reduction credit just last week.
Because of this credit, he said, "we're within striking distance" of the new work requirements and may already have met them.
Rose Masure, the welfare director in Maine, said: "The credit is a reward or recognition for something we've already done. We've already reduced the caseload." The number of Maine families on welfare totaled 20,590 in June, down 5 percent from 1995 and 14 percent from 1992.
Republicans like Representatives James M. Talent of Missouri and Tim Hutchinson of Arkansas were determined to set stiff work requirements. They did this in two ways. They established a much stricter definition of work, which excludes many types of education and training that were previously counted as work. At the same time, they made more welfare recipients subject to the work requirements. In the past, many welfare recipients were exempt from the requirements and excluded from the calculations.
States that do not meet the work requirements of the new law face financial penalties. They may lose 5 percent of their Federal welfare money in the first year, and penalties would grow in subsequent years.
The work requirements became even more stringent under pressure from President Clinton, who denounced the Republicans as "tough on kids and weak on work." By that, he meant that the Republicans did not provide enough money for child care and other services that welfare recipients need to enable them to work. The work requirement rises to 50 percent of the adults on welfare in the fiscal year 2002.
Like much of the new welfare law, the work requirements are based on an assumption that the economy will remain strong. No one can be sure what will happen in a recession. If the economy softens, the demand for welfare will almost certainly increase, and fewer states will qualify for the caseload-reduction credit. But jobs will be harder to find in a soft economy, so the work requirements will be harder to meet.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

FBI Enlisted in Effort To Investigate Leak at Fed
The Federal Bureau of Investigation has agreed to assist in the inquiry into last week's release of information on interest rate policies. Reuters had quoted a "senior Fed official" saying that 8 of the Fed's 12 district banks were in favor of raising the discount rate and that a consensus was forming for a quarter-point increase in the more important Federal funds rate. 
 The Fed's senior policy makers are scheduled to meet tomorrow. [Page D2.]
 
Omnicom Invests in Interactivity
The Omnicom Group, the world's second-largest advertising company, is planning to invest more than $10 million to create a division to specialize in interactive marketing and media. The move reflects the intensifying interest in interactivity among agency giants. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]
 
News Magazines Focus on U.S.
The three news magazines have been devoting fewer covers to international news. Part of this development can be attributed to a proliferation of domestic news. But editors at the news magazines and foreign policy experts say that since the end of the cold war, there has been a significant lessening of interest in foreign affairs. [D2.]
 
Children's Network Leaving Nest?
The News Corporation has decided to spin off its Fox Children's Network, combining it in a new company with the Saban Entertainment Company, producers of hits like "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers." [D2.]
 
Lloyd's Seeking New U.S. Business
This summer, collapse seemed just over the horizon for Lloyd's of London. But now, Lloyd's chairman is on a tour of the United States to make a pitch for new business. [D3.]
 
Dole's Role in Rail Merger
Questions have arisen about actions that Bob Dole, as Senate Majority Leader, took when the Union Pacific-Southern Pacific railroad mergers came before Congress. [A13.]
 
Echelon Reaches for the Top
Echelon, a vendor of computer "control networks" for the home, used to monitor such items as electricity use, could become a household name. But there are risks. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. [D5.]
 
InterJim? JimLink? NetJim? No, Jim!
Naming a new business has become an exercise in patience. Like baby names, high-tech business names follow the fashion of the times. Log on to the Internet today, and you'll meet InterNIC and Interspace, Netopia and Netlogic, MagicLink and MindLink. [D5].
 
Newspaper Rivals and Partners
Newspaper business managers are huddling together in joint, cooperative ventures like printing delivery agreements that would have been unthinkable a decade or two ago. Iver Peterson: Publishing. [D7]
 
G.M.'s Present for Detroit
General Motors is effectively giving its old headquarters building to Detroit to serve as a new City Hall. [A10.]
 
Calling Long Distance, for a Song
A pop singer, Jaye Muller, and his company have combined existing technologies that enable customers to reach out and touch someone far away for the cost of a local call via the Internet. Mr. Muller's JFAX system appears to be the leader. But competition is bound to grow. [D5.]
 
Radio Unleashed in Cyberspace
The regional restraints on radio are coming off, thanks to the Internet. Audionet carries real time broadcasts of 85 stations. [D7.]

HEADLINE: F.B.I. to Aid Fed in Inquiry Of Sensitive Rate Data Leak

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The Federal Bureau of Investigation has agreed to assist the Federal Reserve in a highly unusual internal inquiry into a leak last week of sensitive information that some members of the Fed were pushing for an increase in interest rates, law enforcement officials said tonight.
Brent Bowen, the Inspector General for the Fed, has asked for the Justice Department's help in finding the source of the disclosure. Last Tuesday, a Reuters news agency report from Chicago Tuesday quoted a "senior Fed official" as saying that 8 of the Fed's 12 district banks were in favor of raising the largely symbolic discount rate. The report also said a consensus was forming for a quarter-point increase in the more important Federal funds rate. 
 At the time, Fed officials would not comment on the report. But the effort to investigate it, along with the request for assistance by the F.B.I., strongly suggested that the Reuters report might have accurately reflected the internal deliberations within Government and indicated that Fed officials have decided to aggressively search for the person who disclosed the information.
Many investors who had expected the Fed to leave monetary policy unchanged sold bonds based on the report, sending prices lower and pushing up interest rates.
The Reuters report said the Minneapolis, Richmond and San Francisco district banks had been pushing hard for a tighter policy by calling for a half-point increase in the discount rate, while five others had sought a quarter-point increase.
It was uncertain how the disclosure of the information would affect Tuesday's meeting of the central bank's senior policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee. Analysts said the group might be under greater pressure to make a change, even if members have misgivings about such a move.
The Fed's committee, which includes the presidents of the 12 district banks along with the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board, sets the target for the Federal funds rate, which is how much financial institutions charge each other for overnight borrowing.
The Federal funds target is 5.25 percent and some analysts have said that the Open Market Committee is deeply divided over whether to raise the rate to 5.5 percent. At each meeting of the committee, only 5 of the 12 district bank presidents vote on interest rates along with members of the Fed board.
The investigation is under the direction of Mr. Bowen, the Fed's Inspector General. The investigation is aimed at discovering the source of the information provided to Reuters and whether any criminal laws or administrative confidentiality regulations were violated. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
