HEADLINE: POLITICS: FOREIGN POLICY;
A Once-Crucial Issue Languishes in the Campaign

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The mini-crisis in United States relations with Iraq in the last few weeks has only emphasized how meager a role foreign policy has played during this long campaign year, especially when compared with past Presidential contests.
For decades, the cold war and how to win it colored domestic politics. And there were always specific flash points: Korea, Cuba, Quemoy and Matsu, Berlin, Nicaragua, the Middle East, the Persian Gulf and, of course, Southeast Asia. Dwight D. Eisenhower's wartime exploits reassured Americans made nervous by the Nuclear Age, Barry Goldwater lost because voters considered him too trigger-happy for the Presidency, Lyndon B. Johnson was driven from office by failure in Vietnam, and Ronald Reagan rode to a second term on a tide of anti-Soviet rhetoric. 
 The rule was, foreign affairs could not win you the Presidency but it could cost you the Presidency. George Bush encouraged the reunification of Germany, helping to calm what might have been a chaotic period in Central Europe, and he assembled the coalition that expelled Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. But because he neglected the economy at home, his exploits abroad availed him little.
On the other hand, Jimmy Carter looked inept in dealing with the Iran hostage crisis, and he, like Johnson, was brought down by the widespread feeling that he was incapable of defending the interests of the United States.
Despite some rough spots during the last four years -- Somalia and Haiti, for example -- and despite the contention of scholars and diplomats that the Clinton Administration, depending too much upon improvisation, has failed to develop a coherent foreign policy, Bill Clinton has escaped any significant political damage from crises overseas.
Indeed, in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, completed earlier this month, the President's approval ratings for foreign policy reached 53 percent, the highest of his Administration. Almost the same number of people, 52 percent, said they felt confident of his ability to handle an international crisis.
Unchallenged in the primaries, he watched as potential Republican rivals fought it out almost entirely on the basis of domestic policy. Patrick J. Buchanan accused him of selling out to the Japanese and the Mexicans on trade and of ceding too much authority to the United Nations but was unable to convince more than a small minority of Republicans. Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana had even less luck with a campaign built partly on the dangers of nuclear proliferation.
There have been only the faintest echoes of these issues in the general election so far. Ross Perot still criticizes United States trade policy, and he chose as a running mate a man who made his reputation doing so, Pat Choate. In his speech accepting the Republican nomination, Bob Dole had some harsh things to say about the United Nations and its Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
But taxes and crime and other domestic policy questions have remained at the heart of the campaign. Once American forces were committed to action in Iraq, Mr. Dole pulled back from criticism of the President's dealing with Mr. Hussein.
The Helms-Burton Act, which would penalize countries that profit from properties confiscated by the Cuban government, has stirred heated political discussion in Canada, Mexico and Western Europe, but no one bothers to mention it in the American political campaign.
At least some of Mr. Dole's advisers think he could profit from discussing foreign policy. It is an area where his experience considerably exceeds Mr. Clinton's, and where Mr. Clinton's record has been spotty, if far better late in his term than earlier. One who believes that is Robert Ellsworth, the former Representative from Kansas, who cut his political teeth under Richard M. Nixon, a President who always argued that foreign policy lay at the very center of politics.
But Republican strategists and pollsters, like their Democratic counterparts, insist that the voting public does not care about foreign affairs.
Does this all-but-exclusive preoccupation with matters close to home make any difference? Even among those whose work centers on foreign policy, there is nothing approaching consensus.
Morton I. Abramowitz, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, is one of those who is not perturbed in the slightest. "No foreign policy in the campaign?" he asked earlier this year. "Good. Keep politics out of it, and the experts can do a more constructive job."
Allan E. Gotlieb, a former Canadian Ambassador to the United States, sees peril in the gradual "marginalization," as he calls it, of foreign affairs.
"If you have no discussion in campaigns, and relatively little in Congress," Mr. Gotlieb said this week, "you establish no context for policy. So when trouble comes, it is harder for a President to build support for his policies in the electorate, and it is harder for your allies to understand what is happening."
Relatively calm though the world may seem at the moment, there is certainly ample potential for disruption, either during the final stages of the campaign or in the next four years. The odds are strong, for example, that by the beginning of the next millennium there will be new leaders in Russia, China, India and Saudi Arabia. Each change will pose fresh questions for the United States (What to do if the transition in Hong Kong goes badly?) but there is no disposition to chew them over in advance this fall.
Politicians naturally shy from formulating positions on issues that no one is pressing. They have enough problems carrying voters with them on the issues they cannot avoid.
But it seems unlikely that the next President, whoever he is, will be able to avoid hard decisions on such questions as the future of the Middle East peace process, the timing of expansion of the NATO alliance to the east and the succession to Boris N. Yeltsin in Russia in light of the rise of the aggressive former general, Aleksandr I. Lebed.
Only in national elections does the American public have much influence over the course of American foreign policy. As things now stand, voters will forfeit their limited leverage this time because they will hear little to enable them to choose between varying approaches to the problems that surely lie ahead.

HEADLINE: Once Bitter Enemies, Now Business Partners;
South African Blacks Buy Into Industry

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 23

 BODY:
It wasn't the usual handshake on a deal. One hand, white, belonged to Nicholas Oppenheimer, scion of the family that controls much of South Africa's gold- and diamond-mining. The other, black, belonged to Cyril Ramaphosa, a prominent foe of the old, white-ruled South Africa and leader of a crippling 1987 miners strike.
The $900 million deal that the two men signed last month sells a large piece of the Anglo American Corporation, the Oppenheimer flagship that by some estimates accounts for 25 percent of South Africa's gross domestic product, to a consortium of blacks led by Mr. Ramaphosa. 
 Both sides got a bargain. Blacks bought a big share of the nation's best-known company at 11 percent below market price. Anglo hopes it bought a shield against the potential hostility of a new black Government for the decades it supported apartheid and profited from a cruel system using migrant labor.
As Anglo American joins a growing number of white-dominated corporations courting black investors, both sides are also helping to assure the political future of the country by bringing blacks into the mainstream economy; many here agree that if majority rule does not lead to a growing black middle class, and if black citizens do not feel that they live in a land of opportunity, the nation's survival is at risk.
For that reason, black economic empowerment may be the most important trend in South African business today. The Anglo American deal, the largest yet, brought together investors ranging from black-owned holding companies to union pension funds, a small-business group and the National African Chamber of Commerce.
The Anglo American deal is so big that blacks now have control or major influence -- meaning the power to appoint board members -- over companies representing almost 10 percent of the capitalization on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. They include holding companies, medium-size manufacturers, cellular phone companies, publishers and insurers.
"It's astonishing how quickly black business is getting in," said Robin McGregor, an analyst who tracks the murky world of corporate ownership here. "I keep a file of clippings on it, and I'm reaching for my scissors every day now."
In many cases, these deals create instant millionaires. In some, the investor groups are now operating the businesses. In others, the profits have financed black investors' entry into other industries, without conferring management control.
Empowerment reflects the new truth that this is a black African nation and that the privileged whites running its economy have become a nervous minority. In the United States, such efforts are largely limited to affirmative-action hiring, loans to small business and public contracts set aside for minority businesses. Here, affirmative action and set-asides exist, but huge conglomerates also search the country for black investors, to sell them valuable assets at discount prices. In some cases, they lend the purchase money.
"There's no guilt complex in America," declared Themba Sono, a professor of business economics at the University of the Witwatersrand here. But many of the biggest companies, he continued, "can't refuse. They'd be branded racist."
Black empowerment, South African style, has critics. Some say that in a nation where black unemployment is about 40 percent and laborers may earn $12 a day, the deals mainly enrich well-connected businessmen. Others call the deals cynical efforts by big business to buy the friendship of those in power.
Those tensions are evident in the group buying into Anglo American, the National Empowerment Consortium -- in which the miners, rail, textile and food-service unions, wary of the holding companies, insisted that no member could buy more than one-eighth of the total.
Anglo announced two years ago that a major subsidiary, the Johnnies Industrial Corporation, often known as Johnnic, was for sale -- if the right group of blacks could be found. Other buyers made inquiries.
"We told them they were wasting their time," an Anglo American spokesman, Michael W. Spicer, said. It waited for a black group to assemble. This spring, Mr. Ramaphosa became the group's negotiator when he retired as executive secretary of the African National Congress.
Reserving an offer for black buyers, and selling at prices lower than others pay, would presumably be illegal under American law. "If we were doing this sale in the States, we would be liable for a shareholder suit," Mr. Spicer conceded. "But for obvious historical reasons, South Africa is not Manhattan."
Anglo offered the consortium its 48 percent stake in Johnnic, a holding company worth 8.5 billion rand -- $1.88 billion at current exchange rates -- that owns big stakes in other large companies including South African Breweries, Premier Milling, Omni Media, and Toyota South Africa. Three insurance companies also have stakes in Johnnic.
When the deal was announced, Johnnic was trading at 56 rand a share. The consortium has until July 1 to buy a 20 percent stake in the company for 50 rand a share. Then it has 18 months to buy 15 percent more at 5 percent below the average market price.
Small businesses and investors can also buy in at the 50 rand price -- and if they need cash, Anglo will lend them 90 percent at low interest, keeping the shares as security and repaying the loans from dividends and capital appreciation.
"The indications are now that we will find the money," Mr. Ramaphosa said, borrowing from South African banks, insurers and union pension funds.
The consortium will appoint half of Johnnic's board. In return, insiders said, it agrees not to fundamentally change the company or sell its shares for three years, so management effectively remains as is. Johnnic is a holding company, so the deal will not affect the daily management of the companies it invests in.
The next target is another Anglo American subsidiary, JCI Ltd., that owns gold, coal and chrome mines. Mr. Ramaphosa -- who once joked on a visit to JCI that "the next time I drop in, it will be as chairman" -- seems confident of success.
The biggest empowerment deal before Anglo American's was in 1994, when Sanlam, the Afrikaner-dominated South African National Life Assurance Company, sold its $220 million subsidiary for black policyholders to a group led by Dr. Ntatho Motlana, a longtime Soweto community leader. "We do not want guilt offerings or handouts," Dr. Motlana, who has founded a chain of clinics, said then. "At the same time, our goal is not a gradual, bottom-up approach to advancement."
Sanlam accepted, as payment, low-dividend preferred stock in a holding company formed by Dr. Motlana, New Africa Investments Ltd. It now has interests in a cellular phone network, a bank, a television movie channel and The Sowetan newspaper. It also co-founded an investment house, DLJ Pleiade.
"Now they're so big, they have no problem getting bank loans," said Sven Lunsche, business editor of The Sunday Times of Johannesburg. "They don't need to seek out white partners any more."
The founders of black-empowerment vehicles are often coy about the source of their seed money. It is widely reported, for example, that one group, Thebe Investments, began with $2 million given to the African National Congress in exile by Scandinavian countries, Japan and others who wanted to help the liberation struggle but not buy guns.
On a smaller scale, Magnus Heystek, an investment adviser, says he helps medium-size manufacturers sell stakes to black investor groups. Buyers, he said, range from middle-class professional women to the owners of formerly illegal bars and shops in black townships.
New Africa Investments, however, has been criticized by Sam Shilowa, secretary of the Congress of South African Trade Unions, as a "front for white investors" that "steals public resources and puts them in the hands of a few black individuals."
Dr. Motlana, in response, pointed out that he had created a foundation to help small entrepreneurs and added that no one criticized white magnates for getting rich.
His business partner, Dikgane Moseneke, said that New Africa Investments has 19,000 shareholders, "who've put in anything from a hundred bucks to a couple of thousand," and that 14 percent of the company is held by black unions' pension funds.
Some critics see another side to the movement, contending that corporations are co-opting people close to the Government to make sure no anti-business legislation is passed. The A.N.C. has stopped talking about nationalizing the economy, but South Africa businesses benefit from practices including price-fixing cartels and secret corporate ownership that are illegal in other countries.
Such tactics were used by the National Party, when it came to power in 1948. Its conservative Afrikaner constituency detested the English-speaking whites who ran business. With the Government threatening to nationalize the mines, businessmen invited well-connected Afrikaners onto their boards. In 1963, Harry Oppenheimer, Nicholas's father, engineered the sale of the General Mining Corporation, which had gold interests, to a small coal-mining company run by Afrikaners. The result, Gencor, is now one of the country's most powerful mining houses.
"After that, the only trouble for the English mining houses was from the black miners," Dr. Motlana said, laughing. Business and government developed a cordial, if strained, relationship; business leaders defended apartheid and boasted of South Africa's cheap migrant labor.
Twenty years later, when Anglo American came to the forefront in opening relations with the African National Congress, more than conscience was involved again: international sanctions were beginning to hurt. Mr. Ramaphosa said Anglo American had been motivated by "both guilt and fear." The company's spokesman, Mr. Spicer, was circumspect.
The decision to sell Johnnic was "not pure altruism," he said, "but we think it's enlightened self-interest."
A former Anglo executive who heard some of the discussions two years ago that led to the Johnnic deal was blunter, saying co-opting the new Government had been the goal. The executive said the deal was discussed in crude racial terms, with talk of throwing the blacks "a bone."
Asked about that, Mr. Moseneke of New Africa Investments sighed and said:
"When we started talking with Anglo, their level of arrogance was just frightening. They came to appreciate us as people with skills -- perhaps greater than their own. And to understand that but for apartheid, they wouldn't have the money they do."

HEADLINE: Mayor Who Loves to Hate His City;
Utica's Leader Relishes His 'Lousy' Job in a 'Lousy' Place

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

DATELINE: UTICA, N.Y.

 BODY:
One of the inexplicable things Edward A. Hanna did when he was Mayor here 20 years ago was to declare that Utica was "a lousy place to live." Another was to construct the Tower of Hope outside City Hall in honor of Bob Hope, who has no particular connection to Utica.
So it has not surprised people here that now, back in office after a hiatus longer than many careers, Mayor Hanna seems to be relishing the fact that Utica is in a financial crisis. 
 The crisis has given him, at age 74, the chance to again provoke people with unorthodox ideas, like proposing to close the city government entirely. And the crisis is helping Mr. Hanna prove his main point, which seems to be that Utica has needed his quirky leadership since he lost a bid for re-election in 1977.
"Everything I've touched since the day I took office has been corrupt, stupid and wrong," he yelled in his office one morning in September. "I've yet to find anything I can say, 'Somebody did something right.' "
The city avoided default in August only because the state stepped in to buy its notes; also in the summer Utica received the lowest bond rating of any city in the country from Standard & Poor's: CCC. "We got just what we deserved," Mr. Hanna said.
Some here said Mr. Hanna's return to the Mayor's office in January was a sign of just how desperate Utica, like many older cities across the state and nation in recent years, is for solutions to intractable financial problems.
But even they said their Mayor's yelling, bickering and obsession with detail are just what Utica needs to force itself to confront the financial facts.
"We've got a Mayor who whatever his faults and flaws, is unwilling to sweep under the rug the problems Utica faces," said John H. Johnsen, a professor at Utica College who is chairman of a citizens' committee that urges regional financing for services in Utica and its suburbs.
There are, however, people here who say the Mayor's faults and flaws are worthy of note. For example, it struck some people as unusual that Mr. Hanna, a Democrat who has sometimes run as an Independent, made it a top priority to rebuild Hanna Park outside City Hall with Federal and state funds while the city teetered near bankruptcy and while he was cutting police and fire services.
Hanna Park, built during the first Hanna administration from 1974 to 1977 and named for him later, is near Hanna Park Drive, also named for him, and not far from Ellen Hanna Minipark. The Mayor built the minipark with his own money in honor of his wife of 49 years, known to residents here from the Mayor's greeting during his folksy long-running weekly radio show: "Ellen, were you at bridge game today or casino?"
Some critics thought it odd, too, how, in the midst of municipal chaos, Mr. Hanna had time to worry about getting the carillon in the Tower of Hope to play again after years of silence. Once again, as it did in the 1970's, the Tower of Hope is bonging out the Mayor's favorite song on the half hour, "I Did It My Way," made famous by Frank Sinatra.
"These are the crazy, nutty things Ed Hanna is noted for," said Michael Cerminaro, the president of Utica's Common Council and a Republican who is mentioned as a potential mayoral candidate in four years.
But it is also true that Mr. Hanna loves the details of governing and thrives on exposing other people's misdeeds. A millionaire entrepreneur who made his fortune by perfecting a photo developer that went into use around the world, Mr. Hanna returned to public office two years ago as city comptroller, after an absence of nearly two decades. He acknowledges spending more than $250,000 of his own money in his effort to revive his political career in the last few years. The Mayor's salary is $60,000.
As comptroller, Mr. Hanna warned that years of mismanagement, a declining tax base and a shrinking population had broken the city's finances. He also revealed less momentous developments. In a report to the public, he detailed how a staff member had used a city fax machine for an urgent personal matter. He forced the employee to pay $2. "I, as always, am on top of every expenditure of taxpayers' money," Mr. Hanna wrote.
After winning a close three-way race for Mayor last fall in which a Republican incumbent and a Republican Councilwoman split the anti-Hanna vote, Mr. Hanna turned his prodigious energy to the task at hand. He cut city jobs, although because of ongoing fights over cutback plans, exact numbers are hard to come by. He has also closed one of six firehouses and partly shut another and proposed a budget that would have eliminated city funds for the library and zoo.
Many of his plans were rejected by the Common Council. But his frustration with local politics has not slowed him down.
He has been pressing ahead on various fronts. He speaks often about his main proposal to solve Utica's problems. "City government should be closed down," he said.
There are many supporters in this area for a regional approach that would rescue the city by having governments throughout the Utica area share the cost of services. Mr. Hanna has become a champion of that idea and appointed one of his opponents in the mayoral campaign to serve as a regionalization coordinator. But when asked about the Mayor's suggestion that the city government could be closed soon, several leaders of the regionalization efforts said that seemed implausible.
Mr. Hanna remains undeterred. He said he hoped the city would go out of business before the end of his term so he would not have to complete it.
"It's a lousy job," he said. "You inherit all these problems. You inherit a bankrupt city. Am I going to say it's a beautiful job?"
Mr. Hanna, a 5-foot-7-inch man with a craggy face and a booming voice, has always insisted that his motives are altruistic. And there are many here who agree. "He's blunt, he's not very tactful, he's not a very good salesman and yet he's right about a lot of things," said Robert Fowler, president of the Utica Area Chamber of Commerce.
Many in the business community have been enthusiastic about the Mayor, who has aggressively pursued new business for Utica, which has continued to lose residents, with the population declining to 64,000, from 68,000 in 1990.
Mr. Hanna said that after he was turned out of office in 1977, he returned to running his business and lived in Florida and Paris. But when he sold his own company six years ago and moved back to Utica, he said, he wanted to get involved in business again. And he said he viewed governing this city as a business where he can help people.
Some who have watched Mr. Hanna for years say public spiritedness is not the total explanation for his involvement in politics. "He loves to be the center of attention," said John O. Lindell, a political science professor at Hartwick College in Oneonta who was Mr. Hanna's aide during a single term as an assemblyman 30 years ago and has watched his career since.
Mr. Hanna's interest in the spotlight was evident one September morning. After ushering a reporter with a 9 A.M. appointment to a seat at the side of the Mayor's desk, Mr. Hanna proceeded to "run city government" for nearly three hours before he said he had time to be interviewed.
He summoned more than 30 city employees and cross-examined them about matters large and small. In what seemed to be a very loud version of a stage whisper, he railed about this "stupid law," that "overloaded payroll" and the immorality of political contributions, which he said he has never accepted.
A subject he often returned to was the terrible shape the city was in when he returned as Mayor and the good job he was doing. "That's another big mistake they made," he said as he told two befuddled-looking workers about how he corrected mismanagement and waste.
At one point, eight worried-looking aides surrounded his desk while six city employees waited in chairs. By the time some employees arrived, Mr. Hanna appeared to have forgotten why he had shouted out for his secretary to get them. Some employees were the objects of tantrums. "Don't come in and treat me like a damn fool," Mr. Hanna screamed, his eyes watering in rage, at one city engineer.
Some of the city workers seemed uncertain what the purpose of the audience was. One young man wearing a T-shirt and a Giants cap turned out to be the person responsible for removing discarded trees.
It soon became clear that Mr. Hanna wanted to remind the young man of the Hanna policy that discarded logs should be made available to the citizenry. "You're saving the pieces people can use in their fireplaces, Joe?"
"Yes," Joe said.
"Good," the Mayor said.
When Mr. Hanna did finally have time to be interviewed, he was asked about the fact that he seemed to be enjoying himself.
"It's a lousy job," he said. "That doesn't mean I don't like it."

HEADLINE: Greek Premier Begins Shuffle Of Cabinet

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ATHENS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Prime Minister Costas Simitis, who won strong support from voters in parliamentary elections over the weekend, moved today to assemble a new ministerial team to push through changes in foreign and economic policy.
Mr. Simitis, who succeeded Andreas Papandreou in January and called for the early elections in the hope of gaining a mandate for his reforms, has vowed to turn Greece's sprawling and inefficient bureaucracy into a "hands-on" meritocracy. 
 Officials now say he is almost certain to replace Defense Minister Gerassimos Arsenis, who has pushed for a $10 billion military buildup. And his Foreign Minister, Theodoros Pangalos, was also considered likely to leave, but perhaps for another ministry, like transportion.
Since taking office, Mr. Simitis has worked hard to convince the United States and the European Union that a new era in relations was at hand. And Western diplomats seemed pleased that Mr. Simitis had come through elections on Sunday with 162 deputies in the 300-seat Parliament, saying it meant stability.
European Union diplomats expected Mr. Simitis to be more active in pushing for economic reforms, and have applauded him for a style that is less confrontational than his predecessor's.
Mr. Simitis joined the Socialist party in 1974 when it was set up after a brutal seven-year military junta fell. He has served in every Papandreou Cabinet but remained largely in the shadows until his one-time mentor fell ill last year.
Then Mr. Simitis, 60, replaced the ailing Mr. Papandreou as Prime Minister in January, scored a leadership victory to run the party after Mr. Papandreou died in June, and finally cemented his grip on power on Sunday by leading the Socialists to a solid election victory.
"With such a strong victory, all leadership battles are finished in our party," a former senior Socialist party official said.
Mr. Simitis is an intensely private man who seemed ill-at-ease with the public attention of campaigning. He has turned his back on the histrionics and unpredictable shifts of Mr. Papandreou. Instead, Mr. Simitis, who trained in Germany and Britain as an economist and lawyer, has called for a "new era" of sacrifice and work to earn the respect of European Union partners.

HEADLINE: For Kuwaitis, Self-Reliance Proves to Be an Elusive Goal

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: KUWAIT, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Exultant but also bitter after the Persian Gulf war, Kuwait sought to settle scores, deporting tens of thousands of foreign workers whose leaders had backed Iraq in the conflict. The new Kuwait, its leaders declared, should be run by the Kuwaitis.
But today Egyptians, Pakistanis, Filipinos and others have filled the void that the foreign workers, mainly Palestinians, left behind, and Kuwaitis are as much a minority in their own land as ever before. 
 And as the United States vows anew to defend this country, with a total population of two million and vast oil reserves, many Kuwaitis now say they feel no qualms about relying on others.
"The Kuwaiti, he does not like to work," Falah al-Rashidi, a 23-year-old Kuwaiti assigned to the National Guard. "The foreigners have experience that we lack, and they work for lower salaries. This does not mean that the Kuwaiti does not contribute. But this way, the Kuwaiti can stay safe and rested."
More than six years after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, nearly every sign of the seven-month occupation that followed has been erased.
Luxury American cars hum along modern highways. Futuristic architecture adorns the downtown skyline. And voters like Mr. Rashidi are flocking to nightly political gatherings as they prepare to elect a new Parliament, a ritual still unknown to Kuwait's Persian Gulf neighbors.
Despite the promise let loose by liberation, Kuwait -- whose own citizens pay no taxes, account for just one-sixth of the work force and are guaranteed high-paying jobs in Government ministries -- has yet to set a clear course for the future.
And the most visible indicator -- a demand by Parliament last month that young men and women be segregated at the Government-financed Kuwait University within the next five years -- is regarded by liberals and intellectuals as particularly troubling. On a campus where clingy T-shirts have become almost as common on young women as more modest Islamic dress, it is regarded as a move away from the postwar spirit that has left Kuwait relatively tolerant of Western ways.
"Culturally, it is a step backward," said Moudi Bou-Resli, a professor of zoology at the university, who herself attended mixed classes at the university soon after it was founded in 1967.
Parliament, disbanded in 1986 and restored in 1992 only under American pressure, has proven aggressive in investigating allegations of corruption in the Government, which answers to the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. His family has wielded supreme power in Kuwait for 200 years.
The Emir and his family retain the final decision on most matters, however, and Parliament has veered away from central issues, including democracy, the economy and national defense.
"All their ideas are still in the drawers," said Abdullah al-Rashidi, a 46-year-old Kuwaiti who sported a thick gold and platinum bracelet under his cream-colored full-length gown and holds a sinecure in a ministry he would not identify. "Maybe they're afraid that if they decide anything, they won't have anything new to talk about."
This reluctance has troubled not only voters and political rivals, who have filled newspaper columns with denunciations of a do-nothing legislators, but also many outsiders, who assert that Kuwait has done too little to address human and economic inequities.
"Significant problems remain," the State Department said in its most recent human rights report on Kuwait, which pointed out that women still do not have the right to vote and that the Government continues to be hostile to more than 100,000 stateless people known as the "bidoon."
Under Kuwait's restrictive electoral laws, only 107,000 among the country's 720,000 citizens -- all of them men able to prove Kuwaiti ancestry back at least one generation -- will be eligible to vote on Oct. 7.
In 1992, most of the members of what was then the new Parliament said they favored extending the vote to women. But that movement has languished, complicated by debates over whether women should also be permitted to hold office and by the fears of some political moderates that Kuwaiti women might emerge as a particularly conservative political force.
Kuwait has also managed to reduce the number of bidoon (the word means "without") to about 117,000 from a prewar level of 220,000. Most are of Iranian or Iraqi origin, and some have lived in Kuwait for generations. But it has shown no hint of granting citizenship except to a tiny minority, and it has purged the Kuwaiti military of nearly all the bidoon within its ranks.
But the Government continues to shower benefits on its own citizens, who benefit from cradle-to-grave medical care, free education and subsidies on electricity and water so generous that both the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have registered complaints.
Every Kuwaiti is also assured of a job, and of those who work, 93 percent are Government employees, earning wages far higher than those in the private sector. By law, Kuwaitis receive a minimum wage more than double that paid to foreigners, and their workday ends by 2 P.M., creating an early-afternoon rush hour as parents hurry to collect their children from school.
"A lot of people still think that all of this is their due -- that it's their share of the oil revenue," a Western diplomat said.
For now, with Kuwait pumping two million barrels of oil a day -- its prewar level -- and oil prices higher than predicted, such generosity may be sustainable. Having dipped deeply into its cash reserves, cutting them from $100 billion to $35 billion, and borrowed another $5.5 billion to cover the costs of the gulf war and reconstruction, Kuwait has already weathered extraordinary burdens.
And since the gulf war Kuwait, with a per capita income of about $23,000 and an estimated 10 percent of the world's oil reserves, has ended its once-generous aid to the Palestinians and Jordan.
But of the money that Kuwait still spends, fully half is devoted to Government salaries alone, Western diplomats said, while another third that is set aside for defense is used largely to buy advanced weapons for the Kuwaiti Army, still just 19,000-strong, even smaller than it was before the gulf war. In the fiscal squeeze that has resulted, Kuwait has run a budget deficit for each of the last five years.
At the same time, Kuwait's one-dimensional economy -- oil accounts for 90 percent of all revenue -- and its high rate of population growth have left planners nervous.
With the support of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, many officials argue that Kuwait must either cut benefits to its citizens, as Saudi Arabia did two years ago in the face of greater financial strains, or sharply reduce the number of foreign workers, who drain capital from the economy.
But even the much-touted postwar effort to shift jobs to Kuwaitis never got far off the ground. Kuwait's population, about 2.1 million before the war, plunged as Kuwaitis and foreigners alike fled Iraqi occupation. It fell to just 1.3 million by 1992, but even then Kuwaitis never held much more than one-fifth of the jobs.
The ouster of most Palestinians, Jordanians and Yemenis emptied Kuwait of some of its most numerous and best-educated groups of foreign workers. But as Egyptians, Pakistanis, Indians and others flooded here to take over neighborhoods and jobs as teachers, engineers, waiters, drivers and ditch-diggers, the population soared, and in 1993 it exceeded the 1.5 million figure the Government set as its postwar target.
Today, Kuwait's population stands at 2 million, 1.3 million of whom are non-Kuwaitis, according to the most recent Government statistics. Of a total labor force of 1.1 million, only 176,000 are Kuwaiti citizens.
"They treat us like servants," said Lal Hettige, a 33-year-old Sri Lankan accountant employed by a car distributor who is one of 16,000 residents of Bachelor City, a compound of cement-block units 12 miles north of the capital where foreign workers not permitted to bring their families to Kuwait usually sleep three to a room and work six days a week.
"No Kuwaiti would put up with what we put up with," said Mr. Hettige, a university graduate whose wife and child remain in Sri Lanka and whose salary of about $650 a month is as much as eight times what many other residents of the compound earn. "But the money is much better than anything at home."
At the nightly outdoor gatherings, known as diwaniyas, that are a staple of election campaigning here, political talk flows fast and furious, but it often focuses more on local issues like highways and sewers than the path ahead for Kuwait.
Near the end of one such discussion the other evening at a thickly carpeted headquarters that, like scores across the capital, was lighted with long strands of bulbs as if for a carnival, a Kuwaiti man fixed an American reporter and his Palestinian interpreter with a smile and stated what he said was the inevitable.
"The Palestinians and Egyptians teach us and the Americans defend us," said the Kuwaiti, who insisted on anonymity. "That's the way it's been, and that's basically the way it will always be."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Sets Record, As Broader Market Slips
The Dow Jones industrial average rallied from a 53-point deficit to finish at a record 5,894.74, up 6.28, but declines in oil and semiconductor shares hurt the broader market.
Trading was sluggish, partly because of Yom Kippur and partly because investors were reluctant to take positions before the Federal Reserve meeting today to consider interest-rate policy. [Page D14.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose in lackluster trading ahead of the Fed meeting. The benchmark 30-year bond rose 8/32, to 965/32, sending its yield down to 7.02 percent. [D21.]
 
The Fed policy makers appear sharply divided. It is their last chance to alter rates before the Presidential election, and several Fed regional presidents are agitating for an increase of at least a quarter point in the closely watched Federal funds rate, the interest rate charged among banks for overnight money. [D4.
 
Goldman Plans New Positions
Goldman, Sachs & Company is said to be planning managing director positions that would confer status and probably higher compensation on some ambitious younger executives without substantially expanding its 127-year-old partnership. [D4.]
 
Big B Rejects Revco Bid
Big B Inc. rejected a $330 million takeover bid from Revco D.S. Inc. as financially inadequate. Many on Wall Street foresee a bidding contest for Big B, the nation's 10th-largest drugstore chain, whose stock is already trading above Revco's offer of $15 a share. [D4.]
 
Bellcore Negotiations Reported
Science Applications International, the largest privately owned research and engineering company, is said to be seeking to buy the Bellcore research organization from the Bell communications companies for $700 million. Neither company would comment. [D2.]
 
Hilton Buying All of 4 Hotels
Hilton Hotels is paying $267 million to acquire four big hotels in New York and Washington that it now owns jointly with the Prudential Insurance Company of America, furthering the expansion plans of its new chief executive, Stephen F. Bollenbach. [D9.]
 
Seymour Cray Injured in Crash
The supercomputer pioneer Seymour Cray, 70, was critically injured Sunday afternoon in a three-car crash near Colorado Springs. [D2.]
 
Europeans Raising Cashmere Goats
With the huge European textile industry consuming about 60 percent of the world's annual cashmere production, Europeans are fighting to develop goat herds to supply the soft wool, in competition with China, the world leader. [D6.]
 
This Bud's for Europeans
Anheuser-Busch, which adopted the Budweiser name of a small Czech brewery, Budejovicky Budvar, more than a century ago, said it had broken off trademark negotiations with the Czech Government. Anheuser's beer is selling under the compromise name "Bud" in some European markets. [D6.]
 
A Bold Campaign From Ford
Ford Motor plans an oversized and bold campaign from J. Walter Thompson Detroit for its nine-seat, $28,000 Expedition sport utility vehicle. Advertising. [D10.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1560 words

HEADLINE: Notion of Year-Round Schooling Is Slow to Win Over Los Angeles

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23

 BODY:
They have seen lingering confusion and knotted-up schedules. They have been through broken friendships and canceled vacations, dropped classes and abandoned activities, sweltering classrooms and even hassles with the police.
The seasoned students of Los Angeles High School, who since sixth grade have been on the kind of year-round schedule that New York City is contemplating, predict that their East Coast counterparts will see much of the same -- but will eventually learn, as they have, to cope. 
 "It will be chaos at first," said Ileana Vasquez, 17. But "time heals; you adapt."
If students and parents interviewed here are any indication, the adapting to staggered vacations can take years, cost nerves and require contortions to calendar-juggle day care, off-time and activities. As soon as enrollment drops, Los Angeles schools tend to switch back immediately to the traditional year with a three-month summer vacation.
More than 40 percent of public schools in Los Angeles are on year-round programs. The year-round academic calendars "are seen as medicine you swallow to address overcrowding," said Mark Slavkin, a former president of the Board of Education of the Los Angeles Unified School District, which is second in size only to New York's system and has used the year-round calendar in some schools since the early 1980's.
But the year-round system has provoked accusations of economic-based injustice here because it is mainly the crammed schools in the city's poorer areas that have had to adopt it, Mr. Slavkin said.
Rudy Crew, Schools Chancellor in New York, has proposed a dose of the same medicine for some schools in his city, saying that crowding and budget shortfalls had made year-round scheduling inevitable. An experiment with year-round schooling could begin as early as next fall.
Angelenos say the medicine might be bitter, especially in the beginning. But they say year-round scheduling has pluses as well, like the smoother rhythm it gives to the year and the space it saves. The 180 schools on year-round schedules last year allowed Los Angeles to accommodate a student population that grew by 12,000, to about 640,000 -- and is still growing -- with far less busing and bungalow building than would have been needed otherwise. And the added costs of keeping air-conditioning and offices running all year were much less than busing or the building of annexes would have been, administrators said.
But the complications of the year-round system, under which typically two-thirds or three-fourths of the students are in school at any one time, can prove daunting.
Consider the experience of Yolanda Guerra, a private nurse in Culver City with three children in the Los Angeles school system. The three were all on different "tracks," meaning each had four months of vacation at a different time. "It was driving me nuts," she said. "We're from Belize, and we never had a vacation because of that. I used to have to go home by myself because if I took two it wasn't fair to leave one."
Backers of the year-round program say such conflicts can usually be avoided, and when Mrs. Guerra found out that the high school could put all her children on the same track this year, she successfully requested a uniform schedule for them.
Putting children all on the same track is not necessarily easy. At Los Angeles High School, where students have slightly longer school days to make up for the four full months each track has off, most of the sports tend to be oriented toward the A track, which has July, August, January and February off. The home economics and technical-vocational students are somewhat concentrated in the B track, which has September, October, March and April off. And the high-powered academic classes are geared toward the C track, which is off in November, December, May and June. Students whose tracks are different from their favored areas of study or activities either have to come in to school during vacation for things like band practices and football games, or miss out.
The splintering of the student body also leads to splintered relationships, some students complained. Alonzo Salazar, a Los Angeles High School senior, attributed the demise of a two-year romance in part to the fact that he and his girlfriend were on different tracks. Their separation, a much longer version of the usual "see you in September" mooning of high school sweethearts, amounted to eight months a year when they could see each other only after school. "You grow apart after a while," he said.
Even cross-track friendships tend to wither to the point that "you don't want to get acquainted with people not on your track because you won't see them," Ms. Vasquez said.
The six seniors interviewed said the staggered vacation schedules caused problems for communities, which must cope with loose students floating around all year, and led to encounters with the police, who tend to stop young people on suspicion that they are skipping school. "When you're off on vacation and you want to go to a park or something, they're always checking up on you because they think you're ditching," said Teresita Guerra, 17, Yolanda Guerra's daughter.
Then there is an obvious pitfall: hot classrooms. Charles Ballinger, executive director of the National Association for Year-Round Education, which lobbies for year-round calendars, said the best determinant in California of whether year-round classes would work at a given school was whether the building had air-conditioning. In New York, only about 60 of 1,100 school buildings have it.
But such transition pains do not deter believers like Mr. Ballinger from promoting year-round schooling even when crowding is not a problem. He, along with many teachers and administrators, see it as the calendar form of the future, once the country finally abandons the outmoded schedule that was tailored to a time when children were needed to help in the fields.
The principal of Los Angeles High School, Anne L. Felatico, sees year-round education as "the only way to go." She said parental concerns, be they football or vacation plans, could be accommodated, though "you have to work at it a little." Mr. Slavkin of the Board of Education said that businesspeople and taxpayers tended to agree, believing that using schools all year was common sense.
And Lloyd Houske, the principal of the Cahuenga Elementary School in a mainly Latino and Korean area of Los Angeles known as Wilshire Center, said that, given a choice, he would not go back to the traditional calendar after more than a dozen years on the year-round one.
"In a year-round school you can skip much of the review" that is needed to restart rusty students after the long summer break, he said. "And for teachers to have more than one vacation a year is kind of refreshing. There's less burnout."
Irma Munoz, mother of three children all on the same track at the Cahuenga school, said that she liked the year-round system because she could reinforce what her children learned at school during their more frequent long intervals at home. But she said she also knew many working parents who suffered trying to find baby sitters for the awkward two-month periods.
Mr. Slavkin, a longtime supporter of the year-round system and still a Board of Education member, said that the city did have many die-hard backers of year-round education but that they tended to be at schools where the system had been in place for 10 years or more.
More often, schools have switched back before new time routines have sunk in, and parents have often tried frantically to fight off the introduction of the year-round system in the first place.
There were also considerations of class, Mr. Slavkin said, because crowded schools in poorer neighborhoods protested that they were the only ones that had to suffer the inconvenience of year-round schedules.
"The equity argument was that it's not fair that some kids in mostly minority and poor neighborhoods are on year-round calendars, while kids in more affluent suburban areas are not," he said. The shift to year-round schedules has often drawn hundreds of incensed parents to public meetings and threatened the seats of school board members.
In 1993, a new policy allowed schools to choose their schedules, and more than 300, mainly in wealthier areas, went right back to the traditional schedule of having summers off. "The first chance they got, some of the schools, when they had the option to go back, they did, even if only for the year," said Mary Toma, president of the 10th District Parent-Teacher Association, which covers most of the Los Angeles Unified School District.
These days, only severely crowded schools, which are mainly in poorer areas, tend to be on the year-round schedule, and parents there tend to be resigned to it, both because they can see the crowding problems and because they prefer it to the only ready alternative -- busing some children elsewhere.
More schools may adopt the year-round calendar with new legislation signed by Gov. Pete Wilson this summer awarding schools an incentive of $650 per student to keep class sizes below 20 in primary grades. But opposition is expected to continue.
"I think the traditional calendar is just this incredibly enduring institution that people are reluctant to change," Mr. Slavkin said.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Fear And Shopping In Queens

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
ON the peninsula of two-story houses known as College Point, jutting into the East River, people refer to their part of Queens as their "town," as though it were independent.
"It's a nice quiet town," said Richard Calabro, owner of a shoe store on College Point Boulevard, the main commercial strip. A few doors down, another shop owner said: "People don't say they're from Queens. They say they're from College Point." 
 These days, they also say they're worried. Along the boulevard, merchants have their ears to the ground, listening for a loud sucking noise that will confirm fears that business is being drawn from the community's traditional center to vacant land less than a mile away. There, beside the Whitestone Expressway, giant discount chains are looking to establish a beachhead in College Point, familiar names like Price Costco, Staples and Toys "R" Us, the on-the-march empires of modern commerce.
"They're going to kill the main street, or what's left of it," said Fred J. Mazzarello, president of the College Point Board of Trade, whose member stores are already beleaguered by high rents and fast-changing ownerships. At an office-supply store, Diane Bux sees her business being strangled by the behemoths. And like many of her neighbors, she dreads an influx of cars and trucks (even beyond the increased traffic expected from other newcomers, like a printing plant The New York Times plans to open in College Point next year).
If all this sounds familiar, it is. College Point's agonizing over megastores is not new, there or in other parts of the city. But the matter has a sudden urgency because of land-use proposals from the Giuliani administration that are to be debated publicly before the City Planning Commission tomorrow and taken up by the City Council later in the fall. It is a complex issue with dizzying arrays of statistics, from both free traders who say the marketplace should take care of itself and preservationists who call the giant stores predators that should be stopped cold before they destroy neighborhoods.
Basically, the Giuliani camp would throw out a welcome mat for the big guys, allowing stores as large as 200,000 square feet (20 times the present limit) to move onto wide streets in zones now set aside for manufacturing. This no-muss, no-fuss approach is intended to sidestep resistant community boards.
UNLESS megastores find havens in town, says the City Planning Commissioner, Joseph B. Rose, New Yorkers will keep driving out to Home Depots and Kmarts in the suburbs, taking $3 billion a year in retail sales with them. As matters now stand, the city is "under-retailed," and old industrial areas sit there unused, he argues, adding that the administration's plan would create thousands of retail jobs without destroying neighborhoods or fouling the air.
That, opponents say, is bunk.
First, the $3 billion figure is exaggerated, they say, arguing that nothing will keep certain New Yorkers from driving to Long Island for shop-till-you-drop entertainment at the malls. Small stores in the city would suffer the most, they warn. As for the cumbersome review procedures of community boards, which indeed can keep projects bottled up longer than it took to build the pyramids, that's life. Neighborhoods, the opponents say, have a right to a voice in their future.
In this debate, New Yorkers seem deeply ambivalent, judging from a report by the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger (admittedly not a neutral observer, as a likely mayoral contender who denounces City Hall's "come-and-get-it approach"). Interestingly, her study notes that most people cherish mom-and-pop stores for giving their neighborhoods character, yet they are also charmed by the megastores' siren call of easy shopping and low prices.
MR. ROSE says they can have it both ways. But College Point fears winding up with neither -- that the giants will squash the little stores and then, as their shareholders see fit, move on. "We're afraid we will be left a ghost town," said Clara Spero, a Board of Trade official.
People remember the touted tax relief offered to real estate developers in the booming 80's. It seemed like a good idea, until an oversupply of office space produced neither tax revenues nor tenants in parts of Manhattan. To many in College Point, the megastores represent the same sort of economic Trojan Horse.
While City Hall waves off their fears as overblown, it might bear in mind that fear has a way of becoming a strong political force.

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Coping With Year-Round School
Faced with school overcrowding and budget shortfalls, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has proposed an experimental program of year-round school. A similar program has been used since the early 1980's in Los Angeles, where 40 percent of the public schools now use a year-round calendar. If students and parents interviewed there are any indication, adapting to such a change can take years, cost nerves and require contortions to calendar-juggle day care, off-time and activities. [Page A1.]
 
In Albany, Talk of a Raise
Many members of the State Legislature strongly believe that they will return to Albany after the Nov. 5 elections to give themselves a raise. Many adamantly feel they deserve a raise because their current base salaries were set in 1989, because fewer of them hold outside jobs than ever before and because New York City Council members are paid more than they are. But in an election year, many challengers around the state have recognized the toxic quality of the pay raise issue. [B1.]
 
Equal Opportunity Rejections
Getting into a co-op, always an excruciating experience, has become even more so, as co-op boards reject more and more applicants. The rejections, which have nearly tripled since 1987, are not limited to multimillion-dollar apartments on Park and Fifth Avenues, but are also occurring in less exclusive buildings across Manhattan, where prospective buyers were rarely treated as supplicants. [B1.]
 
Relishing a Crisis in Utica
One of the inexplicable things Edward A. Hanna did when he was Mayor of Utica in the 1970's was to declare that the city was "a lousy place to live." Another was to construct the Tower of Hope outside City Hall in honor of Bob Hope, who has no particular connection to Utica. So it has not surprised people that now, back in office after a hiatus longer than many careers, Mayor Hanna seems to be relishing the fact that Utica is in a financial crisis. [B1.]
 
Fear of Superstores in Queens
Beside the Whitestone Expressway, giant discount chains are looking to establish a beachhead in College Point, Queens. Less than a mile away, merchants along College Point Boulevard have their ears to the ground, listening for a loud sucking noise that will confirm fears that business is being drawn from neighborhood's traditional center. The agonizing is not new, but the matter has a sudden urgency because of land-use proposals before the City Planning Commission. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Early Jockeying in Manhattan
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, has made no secret of her aspiration to run against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani next year, and the contest for her seat is already turning out to be a spirited one. Already, five of Manhattan's elected officials say they are serious about a campaign to replace her, and several others are deciding whether to enter the race for the Democratic primary in September 1997. [B3.]
 
Inquiry Into Peeping Complaint
Police officials were investigating accusations that some male officers secretly watched their female counterparts through a two-inch hole at a women's locker room in a Manhattan police station. [B3.]
 
Cornell Wins Housing Complaint
The United States Department of Education has ruled that Cornell University is not in violation of Federal civil rights statutes by maintaining two dormitories that attract mostly minority residents. [B2.]
 
New Focus for Adelphi Critics
In the campaign to oust the trustees of Adelphi University, the dual roles of its board chairwoman, Ernesta G. Procope, have loomed large. The board's critics have accused her of a conflict of interest for serving simultaneously as Adelphi's chairwoman and as owner of the brokerage handling the university's insurance. Now they have placed a price tag on the Long Island university's relationship with her company, the E. G. Bowman Company of Manhattan. [B5.]
 
An Arsenal on Long Island
Police officers responding to reports that shots had been fired on a residential street in Woodmere, L.I., said they made a surprising discovery in a two-story house: pipe bombs, machine guns and assorted rifles and explosives in a vast arsenal. [B5.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
New Charges for Ex-Fugitive
Alex Kelly, a former high school wrestling star awaiting trial on charges that he raped two girls in 1987, faced new charges after a car crash near his parents' home in Darien, Conn. The Darien police said Mr. Kelly was driving the white Nissan that zoomed past a radar post, speeded up when officers gave pursuit and then flipped over, injuring a young woman. Mr. Kelly, who fled to Europe after the earlier arrest, pleaded not guilty. [B5.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Potential Buyer for Bellcorp
The Science Applications International Corporation is said to be negotiating to buy the Bellcore research organization in Morristown, N.J. The regional Bell companies have been seeking a buyer for more than a year. Business Day. [D2.]

HEADLINE: War on Drugs Urged at U.N. By Colombian

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
With the audacity that has made him the scourge of Washington, President Ernesto Samper of Colombia -- minus the American visa he lost in July because the Clinton Administration accused him of having ties to narcotics traffickers -- came to the United Nations today to propose a new global campaign against drugs.
Portraying himself as a victim of drug lords and the leader of a country that had been "demonized" by outsiders, Mr. Samper struck a third-world chord and received a sustained ovation. 
 In Washington, a senior official said today that Colombia needed to think less about international solutions and more on its internal mess.
American officials say 80 percent of the world's cocaine comes from Colombia, as does 25 percent of heroin now sold on the streets of the United States. Drug money has made corruption "endemic" throughout Colombian society, an American official said.
The Clinton Administration, with the public corroboration of some former senior Colombian officials, has said Mr. Samper accepted political donations from notorious traffickers in his 1994 campaign for the presidency. He has denied knowingly accepting drug money. In June, the Colombian Congress saved his presidency by dropping charges that his election campaign had been financed by the Cali drug cartel.
Since March 1, in part because of the charges against Mr. Samper, Washington has listed Colombia along with Afghanistan, Burma, Iran, Nigeria and Syria as countries failing to cooperate in the drug war. The designation meant an end to much of Colombia's foreign aid.
Although there have been well-publicized arrests of drug lords during the Samper administration, Washington continues to question the effectiveness of Colombia's efforts.
Mr. Samper came to New York on a diplomatic visa and said in an interview that he was under no special restrictions. He will also attend a commemorative conference on Tuesday marking the 35th anniversary of the founding of the nonaligned movement. He holds the rotating presidency of the group.
The Colombian President left home in a blaze of publicity after more than eight pounds of heroin were found in his official plane on Friday night, forcing him to take a chartered aircraft on Saturday. Today, the State Department announced that 11 members of the Colombian Air Force had been arrested in connection with the heroin.
Addressing the General Assembly today, Mr. Samper proposed a six-point plan against "narco-terrorism," saying drugs and terrorists were now inextricably linked and asking for economic aid for replacing illegal crops with legal ones.
Mr. Samper, who has a graduate degree in economics from Columbia University, also asked for controls on the sale of chemicals and weapons to drug producers and traffickers, for worldwide application of a European agreement against money-laundering and for an international intelligence center for narcotics information and eventually an international tribunal for drug cases.
Turning to the countries of high demand, he urged better programs to stop consumption.
"One cannot place the entire burden of drug fighting on drug-producing countries, which are the weakest link," he said, echoing a theme that resonates in other countries where narcotics are grown or manufactured.
American officials, who still cooperate with Colombia in crop eradication, say they have urged Colombia to impose stiffer sentences, freeze the assets of convicted drug traffickers and strengthen laws on money-laundering and extradition.
In the interview before his speech, Mr. Samper, who survived one attack on his life, said he was still the object of death threats. Some officials here said they believed that Mr. Samper might in fact be trapped in a vicious cycle, to some extent beholden to narcotics money and unable to come down harder on Colombian traffickers, even if he wanted to, without risking his life.
"The President of Colombia is always in danger," he said.
Mr. Samper argued that the Colombian Army had been fighting a war on two fronts, against narcotics trafficking and against guerrillas who are increasingly receiving money from drug traffickers.
He remains defiant about his relations with Washington. Taking away his tourist visa, he said, "raised my popularity in Colombia by 15 points."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Ernesto Samper, of Colombia, left, embracing Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali yesterday at the United Nations. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Heating Oil Hits 5-Year High As Europe Draws U.S. Supply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Heating oil surged to a five-year high as soaring prices in Europe drew supplies away from the United States at a time when stockpiles are lean and refiners are running close to full capacity.
On other markets, crude oil, gold and copper rose. 
 Heating oil prices in Europe, which have surged 40 percent the last three months, also reached a five-year high yesterday. The rally has outpaced gains in the United States, reducing European exports and attracting heating oil from the United States, where inventories are running 16 percent less than stocks in the similar period last year, the American Petroleum Institute said.
Adding to the concerns, the Coastal Corporation said that it had shut a 20,000-barrel-a-day unit at a Texas refinery on Friday after finding a crack in a pipeline.
Heating oil for October rose 2.21 cents, to 69.69 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the highest since Nov. 7, 1991. October gasoline surged 2.76 cents, to 62.83 cents a gallon. November crude soared 70 cents, to $24.07 a barrel.
Crude also rose after Iran yesterday warned against the American military buildup in the Middle East since early September over hostilities with Iraq.
Gold jumped after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged at its meeting yesterday. The decision by the Fed's Open Market Committee may allow inflation to accelerate, traders said.
December gold jumped $1.30 to settle at $385.70 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Copper surged after inventories fell more than expected, causing optimism that demand may be strong enough to absorb some of the increased production anticipated next year. The London Metal Exchange said its stockpiles fell 9,728 tons, to 282,881 tons, between Friday and Monday, the biggest drop since July 2. Copper supplies at the exchange are down 7 percent since August.
Copper for December delivery rose 1.5 cents, to 89.15 cents a pound, on the Comex.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Critics Were Wrong

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
O.K., it's safe to say it now: The 1995 U.S. bailout of Mexico's economy with a $12.5 billion loan worked. Mexico has now repaid $9 billion of that loan, including $1.29 billion in interest, and the Standard & Poor's credit agency just upgraded Mexico's government bonds from "negative" to "stable." You may recall the Mexican bailout was fiercely resisted by most of Congress, but a few brave legislators (including Bob Dole) supported President Clinton when he essentially took personal responsibility for the Mexico loan by getting the money from a special Treasury Department fund, instead of Congress. If Mexico had defaulted, Mr. Clinton, and his top Treasury officials Robert Rubin and Larry Summers, would have been skinned alive. But it turns out they were right. Their critics -- Al D'Amato & Co. -- were wrong. So what have we learned?
Lesson 1. Thank goodness nobody did a focus group before President Truman announced the Marshall Plan. At a time when Congress is increasingly populated by nativist, anti-foreign-policy types -- who think that representative democracy is about accurate poll-taking, not exercising judgment -- it's a good thing the executive branch can still operate in a crisis without them. 
 Lesson 2. As in war, so in economics, without U.S. leadership nothing happens. Without a U.S. commitment of cash to rescue Mexico, the I.M.F. and the Europeans never would have joined in. In other words, without the G-1, there is no G-7. Unless America is ready to act unilaterally, it will never have allies with whom it can act multilaterally.
Lesson 3. Markets are important, but central banks still matter. The Mexican crisis was the equivalent of a bank run on an entire country, and the only institutions that could stop it were not the markets but the major central banks and the I.M.F. The global markets cannot just take care of themselves. "In the absence of the U.S. and I.M.F. the outcome for Mexico would have been much worse today," Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, told me. "We would have had to declare a moratorium on debt repayments. There would have been lawsuits. It would have been a mess."
Lesson 4. Culture matters even more than central banks. To pay for the bailout, Mexico cut the standard of living for most of its people by 20 percent. There should have been a revolution, but there was barely a demonstration. In part this was because Mexicans were too busy just trying to survive, but mostly it was due to the strength of the Mexican family. "The family was a terrific social absorber here," said Antonio Madero Bracho, chairman of Sanluis, the Mexican mining conglomerate. "People moved in with each other, and the family really took the place of social security and unemployment insurance."
Lesson 5. The advocates of Nafta oversold Mexico. Yes, there is substantial political and economic reform happening here, but alongside it are still substantial graft, drug-running, political assassinations, weak police and Robin Hood guerrilla groups. The U.S. rushed into Nafta in response to the Europeans getting together and the Japanese walling themselves off. But Mexico was never our economic equal. Nafta will hasten the pace that it becomes one, but that moment is a ways off. Mexico reminds us that there is still a reason we call places "developing countries." "We oversold Nafta short term," argued Mr. Ortiz. "But in the long term Nafta will help consolidate Mexico's economic institutions and its place in the global economy."
Lesson 6: Diplomats prefer to do shuttle diplomacy in airplanes, not taxi cabs, but it's the taxi shuttles, inside countries, that now matter most. The increasing challenge of U.S. foreign policy is going to be dealing with the internal workings of allies and neighbors -- to help them make the transition from state-dominated, regulated economies to more open systems linked to global markets, without triggering social explosions.
Lesson 7: Yes, some investors on Wall Street benefited from the Mexico bailout. But sometimes governments have to do the right thing despite the fact that Wall Street benefits. (Wall Street also profited from the New Deal.)
Lesson 8: Mexico has undergone a lot of remarkable changes in this century, but one thing hasn't changed: its geography. It's still 100 million people on the U.S. border. What happens in Mexico still matters more to America than what happens in its own state of New Mexico.

HEADLINE: GONE FISHING WITH: Hoagy Bix Carmichael;
One Generation's Haunted Reverie Is Another's Pot of Gold

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

DATELINE: BREWSTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
UP a lazy river, Hoagy Bix Carmichael watched the brown water slide by and said nothing. While he was at it, he also did nothing, if you think that watching insects dance over the water and following the dimples poked into the surface by feeding trout are nothing.
At his side on a leafy bank of the east branch of the Croton River, his son, Ben, 13, chafed for some action. 
 "Can't we just try?" he asked.
The father regarded him indulgently. "You can try, Ben," he said. "But the trouble is that trout, unlike salmon, don't like a lot of thrashing around." He watched some more, then opened a small box of flies, picked a Tricorythodes stygiatus, hardly bigger than a dewdrop and perhaps half as heavy, and tied it to a diaphanous filament of leader just twice the thickness of a human hair. Now, he said, the boy could start fishing.
If fishing is, as Mr. Carmichael likes to say, a jerk on one end of the line waiting for a jerk on the other, it is owing to the prolific genius of his own father, the songwriter Hoagy Carmichael, who died in 1981, that he can indulge his obsession around the world and back in his own backyard (not a Hoagy Carmichael song) in northern Westchester County.
At the same time, the legacy takes a lot of tending, and the 58-year-old scion, who has something of the long face of his father, spends a good part of his time on what he calls "the Carmichael industry." (His younger brother, Randy, dabbles at the piano and is also busy managing a golf course that he owns in Cleveland and boating in Florida, leaving music management to the older brother.)
On Sept. 11, he took part in a ceremony in Shubert Alley to mark the Postal Service's issue of a 32-cent stamp honoring Hoagy Carmichael, the composer of "Stardust," "Georgia on My Mind," "Rockin' Chair," "Up a Lazy River" and other classics, as part of an American songwriters series.
He has been trying for years to produce a musical about his father and his father's circle, particularly the jazz cornetist Bix Beiderbecke, who died of overliving at 28 in 1931, and whose name the adoring Hoagy Carmichael merged with his own and gave to his firstborn.
Mr. Carmichael also serves as president of Amsong, an association of songwriters and heirs seeking to extend copyright protection for songs. He has produced television shows, including some years of the children's public television classic "Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood."
Otherwise, if he is not out fishing, he is in his workshop, hand-building fishing rods as one of the leading craftsmen in the small trade. His custom rods made of bamboo from a small area of southern China take about 70 hours to make, and sell for thousands of dollars.
"I'm so lucky that in this world I get to do so many things," he said later after fishing, rocking in his father's old rocking chair in a stone house he is having rebuilt in nearby North Salem.
Mr. Carmichael grew up in California (or rather, he says, "I tried to"), where his father gravitated when fame catapulted him out of Bloomington, Ind., and the days of playing in the epochal jazz group called the Wolverines. Where the elder Hoagy Carmichael once lived in Hollywood, on Sunset Boulevard off Doheney Drive, is now part of the Dreamworks SKG entertainment conglomerate.
The father's first success was perhaps his greatest: As he told it in "The Stardust Road," his lyrical-Dadaist autobiography, published in 1946 and now out of print, it was 1927, and he was a young, unsuccessful lawyer crossing the campus of Indiana University one hot night, "sweet with the death of summer," when he paused to remember a passing love. A line came to him: "The memory of love's refrain."
"I looked up at the sky," Hoagy Carmichael wrote, "and whistled 'Stardust.' " Then, he said, he ran for a friend's piano. It took several years to get it on a record, but once lyrics were added by Mitchell Parish it became what has been called the most recorded song of all time, with perhaps 1,500 renditions and prodigious royalties. They would bestow economic freedom on the songwriter's son, even without other lucrative creations like "Georgia on My Mind," which was ubiquitous at the Olympics this summer in Atlanta, and which one year generated as much as $1.4 million in royalties.
But such riches are anomalous in an industry more known for penury. "There are 48,000 songwriters, and 46,000 aren't making money," said the younger Mr. Carmichael, who recently took over as president of Amsong from Mary Rodgers, the composer and teacher and daughter of Richard Rodgers, who wrote his songs with Lorenz Hart and Oscar Hammerstein 2d.
To protect their legacies, he said, the heirs of celebrity songwriters in Amsong have been pressing Congress for years to extend the copyright on songs composed before 1978 from the current 75 to 95 years after composition. For works composed after 1978, the group is seeking a copyright extension from the current 50 to 70 years after the death of the composer.
The way it is now, Mr. Carmichael said, writers of hit songs could live to see their creations pass into the public domain, costing them a livelihood. Opponents, however, have portrayed the campaign as an effort by wealthy heirs to protect their pocketbooks. He and Amsong are also fighting to turn back a challenge by restaurants now compelled to pay royalties for canned music.
Mr. Carmichael considers it only just that they pay. He asked, "Can I walk in and get a free steak?"
There are thorny new copyright questions as well, he said, adding, "I'm told there are 500 references to Dad's songs on the Internet."
For years, in a kind of payback to his father, Mr. Carmichael has been working to produce a musical based on Hoagy Carmichael songs. The work, once tentatively titled "Hoagy and Bix" is being recentered more on Hoagy, his son said.
He said a version was recently previewed at the Playboy mansion of Hugh Hefner, a friend, in preparation for anticipated tryouts in Cincinnati, Baltimore and Beiderbecke's hometown of Davenport, Iowa. Mr. Carmichael's hope is to get it to Broadway in time for the 1999 centennial of Hoagy Carmichael's birth.
Trout fishing was not something he learned from his father, whose interests ran more to the great indoors. "He drank a bottle of Scotch every other day and was never tipsy," recalled Mr. Carmichael, who said he himself could barely function after a glass of wine at dinner. He discovered fly fishing while on a trip to Canada for Expo 67. "I couldn't catch a thing, but I really caught the bug," he said.
And so it was on this late summer morning, with the fishing season in its waning days, that Mr. Carmichael put lesser cares aside and headed for the Croton with Ben, who was visiting from Maine, where he lives with his mother, from whom Mr. Carmichael is amicably divorced.
"Speaking of Grandpa's book," Ben said on the way, "next month, we have to read a biography."
His father was happy to oblige. "I have one copy of 'The Stardust Road,' " he said. "I'll give it to you."
"Cool," Ben said.
Wearing hip waders, they forded the shallow river to the opposite shore. "It always fishes," Mr. Carmichael said optimistically. "I'd hate to tell you how many fish I caught here." A few years ago, he recalled, he caught the biggest trout of his life here, a 24 1/4-inch brown, and someone he knew once came away with an eight-pounder. He scanned the water for a good while, watching little insects called spinners zig and zag, listening for the telltale pop of a trout's rising. "This is a patience game," he said.
He looked for signs of flying ants, which can drive trout into a feeding frenzy. "Don't ever go out without flying ants," he counseled. "If they're hatching, and you don't have them, you might as well get the keys to your car and go home." Alas, there were no flying ants to be seen.
"They're taking the spinners," he decided, tying a reproduction of the minuscule fly to a stretch of maddeningly snarlable 7x leader. "You prefer a male or a female?" he asked, straight-faced.
Despite his best efforts, however, all he managed after a few abortive strikes was a darling little brown trout of about 11 inches. "I don't like to have the fish I catch called 'cute,' " he pretended to grumble, promptly releasing it, as he does with all the fish he catches. His visitor then took one of about the same size, which, naturally, looked much larger.
"Well," Mr. Carmichael countered, "mine will be much larger by tonight."
