LENGTH: 1025 words

HEADLINE: In Catholic School, Shared Values Include Rigor and Decorum

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
Along a wall of Sister Mary Scanlon's seventh-grade homeroom at St. Elizabeth School are two bookcases, one for the World Book Encyclopedia, National Geographics and biographies, the other for Bibles, catechisms and the "Saints Alive" series.
Sister Mary's students get the nuts and bolts of decimals, cell development and subjects and predicates, and they say prayers three times a day, starting with the Hail Mary and Our Father, and they attend a daily religion class. But like the books, belief and knowledge coexist with clear boundaries. 
 In New York City, 182,000 children attend schools like St. Elizabeth's, which is in Washington Heights. The city's Roman Catholic schools teach more children than the entire public school system of Detroit.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a graduate of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn, has long championed the academic rigor and decorum offered by Catholic schools. Now, he is promoting a $2 million effort, backed with money from businesses and philanthropies, to send 1,000 struggling students from the city's school system to parochial schools.
A day with St. Elizabeth's seventh graders helps answer the question that proposal raises: Exactly what kind of education would those 1,000 students get?
Sister Mary's 29 students use textbooks approved for public schools by the State Department of Education. Outside of religion class, the closest to a religious reference came last week during a geography lesson when Sister Mary exclaimed "Holy Toledo!" after one boy said Iceland bordered New York State.
Across the city, about 1 in 4 Catholic school students is from another faith, but St. Elizabeth's, at 612 West 187th Street, has a higher concentration of Catholics: 98 percent of the 620 students, an overwhelming majority Dominican. In Sister Mary's homeroom, everyone is Catholic.
In her midmorning religion class, Sister Mary devoted 10 minutes to the first five books of the Old Testament, writing the word Torah on the blackboard in big letters.
Then, from the New Testament, she had a student read several verses from the end of Matthew 11 aloud: "Come to me, all you that labor and are burdened, and I will refresh you. Take up my yoke upon you and learn of me, because I am meek and humble of heart: and you shall find rest to your souls. For my yoke is sweet and my burden light."
Sister Mary, her usually clipped voice softening a degree, offered an interpretation. "Very often we are in a situation where we feel we're the only ones who are feeling the way we do," she said. "Did you ever have an experience when a friend knew exactly how you were feeling?"
After class, she acknowledged that a student from another faith might feel alienated.
"As much as we talk about guarding against anti-Semitism, the children still see it all over the place, so their question is: Didn't the Jews kill Jesus?" Sister Mary said. "And I say, 'Well, no, actually the Romans put Jesus to death.' But they still ask questions like that, so I think sensitivity to those sorts of issues would be really important."
Across the hall from Sister Mary's religion class, Ricardo A. Mendoza teaches science. On a recent day, he divided the class into groups, gave each cluster a brown bag with an object in it -- tea strainer, egg slicer, cinnamon stick, sea shell -- and told the students to pretend it was the year 6000. What kind of people would have left these artifacts? Mountain people, said one group. American Indians, said another.
The textbook Mr. Mendoza usess, "Life Science" (Silver Burdett Ginn, a division of Simon & Schuster), includes evolution, and Mr. Mendoza said that like most Catholics, he easily reconciles the science with the Biblical creation story by explaining Genesis as a metaphor.
"Possibly seven days does not mean seven days," he said, "but maybe centuries or millions of years, figures of speech. I'm progressive. It's a matter of giving the kids a very wide perspective."
The archdiocesan Superintendent of Schools, Catherine Hickey, elaborated. "Science and religion coexist very nicely because we believe in natural law, and cause and effect," she said. "We believe natural law was put in place by God."
While Bible lessons are confined to the religion class, values -- respect, honesty, tolerance and nonviolence -- are everywhere. "Religion is not spoken of in every class," said Mary Ellen Eichmann, the school's associate director of development, "but there is this implied value of respect for one another, and that value is lived out here."
Research suggests that it is the emphasis on shared values and individual achievement that leads to the academic success of inner-city Catholic schools. Students of similar economic background usually outperform public-school counterparts in test scores, graduation rates and college entry.
"We very firmly believe in integrating things," Ms. Hickey said. "We're not just a brain or a body. We're an intellect, a social being and a spiritual being."
Across the city, in poor and middle-class neighborhoods where many parents worry about the public system, Catholic schools have a loyal following. St. Elizabeth's is in a neighborhood where gunfire punctuates the night, but the school recorded only one fight last year.
When the principal, Sister Noreen Nolan, walks the hallways, which she does frequently, she usually has her arm around a youngster. Instead of buzzers to signal the end of classes, one teacher on each floor is designated to ring a big brass bell by hand.
Teachers almost never have to quiet a class. Textbooks are covered. Homework is done on time. Led by a teacher, the students walk wordlessly in the halls, the boys on the one side, the girls on the other.
Nairobi Rodriguez, a sweet-faced 12-year-old with a ponytail and hoop earrings, did not want to go to St. Elizabeth's from Public School 189 last fall. "I was so mad at the beginning," she said. "I said, 'Why a Catholic school, with those ugly uniforms, and they're too strict.'
"But now I like this school. In public school, some of the kids cursed at the teacher, but here everybody listens."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The new Pan Am is rolling out an unusual frequent-flier program with an old name.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
WHEN Pan American World Airways is reborn tomorrow, with a daily nonstop between New York's Kennedy International Airport and Miami, and between Kennedy and Los Angeles, passengers can enroll in an unusual frequent-flier plan, named World Pass.
Economy passengers on the two-class carrier will receive one and one-quarter frequent-flier miles for each actual air mile flown, rather than the usual one mile, while first-class passengers will receive one and three-quarter miles. In addition, all passengers will receive 1,000 miles as an enrollment bonus. Members can earn a free flight after 20,000 miles, rather than the more common 25,000, while elite status -- with priority check-in privileges -- will kick in at 15,000 miles, instead of 25,000. 
 An unusual aspect of World Pass -- named after the former Pan Am's frequent-flier program, which was subsequently honored by Delta Air Lines -- is that up to three members, whether family, friends or foes, can pool mileage for free flights.
The drawback, of course, is that Pan Am's limited route structure means its frequent fliers have few destinations to choose from. But Martin Shugrue, a co-owner of the new airline, and a vice chairman and chief operating officer of the former Pan Am, said the new carrier would expand slowly but steadily. In two weeks it will add two more daily nonstop flights between New York and Miami, and it plans eventually to add routes between New York and San Francisco, Chicago and San Juan, P.R., as well as between Miami and Los Angeles.
The new carrier will fly wide-body Airbus Industrie A300's.
 
Air Fare Update
Fall air fares are not dropping like autumn leaves, as airline advertising might suggest, but for purchases through next Monday, it is still possible to find bargains on domestic flights and flights to Canada, the Caribbean and Europe. While travel dates differ by carriers, most domestic travel must be completed no later than Feb. 13, 1997.
For example, all the major carriers offer a $408 round-trip fare between New York and Los Angeles, based on a seven-day advance purchase and a Saturday night stay, with certain holidays blacked out. And the round-trip Chicago-San Juan fare is $338 on any of the seven major carriers that fly that route, based on weekday travel, a three-day advance purchase and a three-day minimum stay. A round-trip ticket from New York to London is as low as $298; New York to Paris is as low as $346.
 
Check That Battery
For the millions who plan to travel by car this winter, the American Automobile Association has some advice: Have the car battery checked, especially if it is more than two years old and even if it carries a warranty of four or more years.
 
Keeping in Touch
An independent survey for Marriott International found that 56 percent of all business travelers carry a personal computer and 80 percent of the computers are equipped with a built-in modem. Slightly less than half of the travelers (48.6 percent) carry cellular phones, while 7.6 percent carry pagers.
 
Hotel Update
Travelers bound for South America will receive a complimentary upgrade when they pay with the American Express Card at one of the nine participating hotels in a marketing alliance called Leading Hotels of the World: Alvear Palace and Caesar Park in Buenos Aires; Caesar Park and Maksoud Palace in Sao Paulo, Brazil; Hotel Carrera in Santiago, Chile; Hotel Bogota Royal in Bogota, Colombia; Hotel Oro Verde in both Guayaquil and Quito, Ecuador, and Eurobuilding Hotel and Suites in Caracas, Venezuela. The offer is valid through the end of this year.
When Hilton Hotels' Conrad International Centennial Singapore Hotel opens Nov. 8, it will offer introductory rates ranging from $142 (United States) for a single room to $985 for the Presidential Suite. After March 31, 1997, the rates will rise to $257 and $1,785, respectively. Tax and service charge will add an additional 14 percent to the bill.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Climb On Relief Fed Does Not Act

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices moved higher yesterday on relief that Federal Reserve policy makers left interest rates unchanged.
Expectations among market participants had been divided on what the Fed would do, with many anticipating a rate increase of about a quarter-point, while others expected the Fed would take no action. When the Fed made its announcement at 2:15 P.M. yesterday, prices, which had been rising, surged further. 
 While the decision by the Fed to take no interest rate action gave the credit market a lift, it could add to the volatility of the market in the weeks ahead.
If new economic data -- starting with the September employment report on Oct. 4 -- show that the economy is not slowing, then investors and analysts could decide that the Fed may have to raise short-term interest rates by half a percentage point or more when the policy makers meet again on Nov. 13.
Such an outlook, would surely send interest rates higher and could undermine the stock market.
By the close of the New York market yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond was up 15/32 , to 974/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.98 percent, from 7.02 percent on Monday.
The market experienced a mild selloff in the morning yesterday after the Conference Board's September consumer confidence numbers showed confidence at a six-year high. The 111.8 reading in the confidence index for September might have had a more pronounced effect on the market had the previous months reading not been increased to 112 from 107.
Prices were bolstered after the weekly Redbook survey of chain store sales, released in the afternoon, showed that sales were down three-tenths of 1 percent for the week ended Sept. 21. The report, along with a decline in the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi retail sales report, confirmed a view that retail sales continued to moderate through September, encouraging expectations that the economy might be slowing enough on its own to avoid a future rate increase. The reports bolstered the market before the Fed news.
Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management in Washington, said the fact that the Fed did not ease rates increased the chances that the Fed will not raise interest rates this year. By the time the Fed policy makers, the Federal Open Market Committee, next meet, "the economic slowdown will statistically have been documented and that would preclude a tightening," he said.
There are several factors that may have persuaded the Fed to postpone a rate increase, Mr. Carpenter said. Fed policy makers typically look to the bond market for wide swings in yields.The bond market has been confined to a narrow trading range in the last six months, with the long bond yield moving in a range of between 6.90 percent and 7.20 percent, he noted.
The central bank also tends to be concerned about the dollar, which has been stable, and the price of gold, which is substantially lower than its early year peak of $415 an ounce, he noted.
By November, Mr. Carpenter said, the Fed should have all the information it would need to determine what kind of momentum was being transferred from the third quarter into the fourth.
The market will now likely turn its attention to coming supply, with the prognosis improved for the Treasury auctions this week, starting with today's $18.25 billion sale of two-year notes.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.13 percent, 12 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- lower than the previous day. The five-year note, which will be auctioned tomorrow, was being offered at a price to yield 6.50 percent, 9 basis points lower.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RUNNING MATE;
In New York, Kemp Accepts Support of Police Union and Conservative Party

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
Jack Kemp brought the Republican Presidential campaign to New York yesterday, accepting the endorsement of the city's police union and telling the New York Conservative Party convention that he and Bob Dole would step up their pressure on the Senate to overturn President Clinton's veto of a ban on late-term abortions.
In a move to counter the endorsement of Mr. Clinton earlier this month by Fraternal Order of Police, the national umbrella organization for police unions, Mr. Kemp appeared at a gathering of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the largest of the big-city police unions, and pledged that a Dole Presidency would restore the nation's respect for the law. 
 Mr. Kemp offered no specific anti-crime programs before the police group, which had endorsed Mr. Dole before the New York primary in March. The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has supported Republicans since 1976, when it supported Jimmy Carter after President Gerald R. Ford told the then-financially strapped city, in the words of a tabloid headline writer, to drop dead.
"If we are to protect our cities, like this great city, this great nation, our families, our wives, our children, and restore this country's respect for the law, we've got to have it embedded in our schools, inculcated in our children and families and churches and synagogues all over America," Mr. Kemp said.
"We've got to restore respect for the man and women who enforce the law," Mr. Kemp said. "We need to give our law enforcement agencies, those men and women on the front line, out there on the cutting edge of the war against crime and drugs, the tools with which they can combat this very serious challenge here on the eve of the 21st century."
Mr. Kemp said that one place to start was to place the Ten Commandments "in every public school, every private school," adding, "It ought to be on the desk of every child."
After hearing complaints from New York Attorney General Dennis Vacco about liberal judges appointed by Mr. Clinton, Mr. Kemp first said, "We need judges who will stand up not only for the rights of the victim, but for the rights of someone accused" of a crime, but later in his speech reversed his wording to say judges needed to respect not just the rights of the accused but those of victims as well.
The New York Conservative Party, which is closely allied with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, one of Mr. Dole's most powerful backers, formally nominated Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp as its Presidential ticket today.
Mr. Kemp told the party that he and Mr. Dole would be pressing every Senator to vote to override President Clinton's veto of a ban on late-term abortions when the Senate takes up the issue on Thursday.
"Whether people happen to be pro-choice or pro-life -- and we happen to be pro-life -- no one can agree with the destruction of human life as that baby is just seconds away from what Moses said should always be chosen, human life," Mr. Kemp said. "I'm going to pledge to you, Bob Dole and Jack Kemp are going to ask every United States Senator to examine their conscience, to put this not to the test of politics -- right or left matter little when it comes to that precious human life -- to override President Clinton's veto of the ban against partial-birth abortion."
Mr. Kemp's visit here seemed aimed less at wooing New York voters, who are overwhelmingly Democratic, than in finding platforms to stay with the themes like crime and abortion that the Republican campaign has been weaving into its main message of tax cuts.
Earlier yesterday, speaking to factory workers in Grand Rapids, Mich., Mr. Kemp seemed to acknowledge that the strong economy had left many voters feeling that the country was already on the right track. But he argued that it would take the Republican policies of lower taxes and less regulation to create an economy with opportunities for everyone.
"The problem with this economy is not that we are not doing a little better -- we are," he said. "But it's not working for everyone."

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE MAKES NO CHANGE IN INTEREST RATES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
After weeks of speculation that the Federal Reserve would launch a pre-emptive strike against inflation, its monetary-policy officials met today and decided against raising interest rates, apparently in the belief that the economy is likely to cool off enough to keep prices in check.
Following its tradition, the Federal Reserve gave no explanation why it chose not to act. But the stock market soared briefly on the news, as did the spirits of the Clinton Administration, which had feared that a rise in interest rates just weeks before the election could undercut the Administration's claim that its handling of the economy had brought steady growth in the number of jobs while at the same time keeping interest rates relatively low. But the market, after the early afternoon rally, closed with a loss for the day. 
 The Federal Reserve's silence today concealed what appears to be a sharp split within its powerful Open Market Committee. The central bank has kept short-term borrowing rates steady since late January but agreed in July to lean toward an increase in those rates, its only weapon against inflation.
Last week, in an unusual news leak, Reuters news agency reported that 8 of the 12 presidents of the regional Federal Reserve Banks -- who are usually viewed as particularly hawkish about inflation -- were urging an increase in rates.
That leak was seen as something of a public challenge to the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, who has supported an unusual experiment: keeping interest rates stable even as unemployment has dropped to 5.1 percent -- a level low enough that many economists think it means that wage pressures are going to start to spread through the economy, causing an increase in prices. So far, inflation has stayed under 3 percent a year.
Mr. Greenspan asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to look into the leak. But more important, in refusing to act today he appeared to demonstrate his power to stamp down any effort by the regional bank presidents to mount a threat to his own authority.
Some analysts also contended today that Mr. Greenspan was reluctant to raise rates this close to an election. Such increases have occurred only twice, most recently before the 1980 Presidential election.
Whether or not that consideration was a factor today, President Clinton was clearly happy with what had happened. "I just think it shows we've got a strong economy with no inflation," he said. "I'm glad about that."
Indeed, a report today -- which came out after the Federal Reserve panel began its meeting -- indicated that the economy remained on track. The Conference Board, an independent research group, said that consumer confidence held nearly steady, at a six-year high, in September. Its index was 111.8, close to a revised reading of 112 for August.
The Republican response to the Federal Reserve's decision was both complicated and in some respects contradictory. Before it was known, Jack Kemp, the Vice Presidential candidate, argued forcefully against an increase, saying he would "bang on" the Fed if it squelched the forces of growth. Bob Dole and Mr. Kemp have made the need for faster economic growth a centerpiece of their campaign, and this afternoon Mr. Kemp cheered the Fed, saying it had acted properly because "this economy is not overheated."
"It's in need of capital and credit, oxygen and seed corn, and now we need a tax-rate cut like Bob Dole and Jack Kemp want," he said during a campaign stop in Manhattan.
But at the same time, Mr. Kemp appeared to acknowledge that the nation's low unemployment rate was one of the biggest obstacles to the Dole camp's message that the economy is on the wrong track. "Inflation is not caused by too many jobs, too many people getting jobs, and too many people working," he said.
Mr. Dole did not address the Fed's decision directly. Asked if it represented a victory for the President, he said only, "Interest rates are higher in every category under Bill Clinton."
Before today's meeting, slightly more than half the Wall Street analysts who regularly proffer predictions had said that they expected a modest increase in interest rates, probably a raise of a quarter of a basis point, or 25-hundredths of a percentage point. They pointed to the tightness of the labor market and recent rises in hourly wages as potential warning signs of future inflation.
But a jumble of factors -- some economic, some political -- argued against a change now, and in the end those won out. "This was a case where it was too close to call in substance," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers. "So there was a heavy dose of psychology, of waiting for more data, and some guesswork."
The statistical evidence that the Fed had to work with pointed in different directions. Poor retail sales numbers for the summer suggested that the economy was slowing, but some experts suspect those figures will be revised upward in coming months. Job growth has been robust, but the numbers for the summer are not always reliable because of the waves of young people moving in and out of the labor force.
"The risk was that if the Fed tightened and then the economy slowed down, the board would take the blame," said Paul Kasriel, the chief domestic economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Mr. Greenspan has argued for much of the year that the economy will slow down in the second half, and his track record of predictions, while hardly perfect, has been good enough to give his view even more weight than the chairman traditionally enjoys when policy makers meet.
"He's been right a lot more than he's been wrong," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy, a New York securities firm. "And this decision truly shows that he is still in charge."
Though he is known as an inflation hawk, Mr. Greenspan appears to have been influenced by an argument advanced by the White House and many big-business leaders that the American economy has undergone a profound change, and that tight labor markets do not necessarily assure rising inflation.
Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, has argued repeatedly that competition -- both domestic and global -- is far more intense today than it ever has been, making companies far more reluctant to raise prices. At the same time, American workers are less likely to press for wage increases because they know that manufacturers who are unhappy with wage rates in the United States are freer than ever to move operations abroad.
But that is an untested argument, and many mainstream economists say that inflation has been delayed, not evaded. Many of them suspect that the Fed will move to tighten monetary policy -- that is, to raise interest rates -- at the committee's next meeting, a week after the Nov. 5 election.
On balance, Mr. Clinton seems likely to benefit from today's nonaction more than Mr. Dole will. The Administration can make the case that the Federal Reserve, an independent body, has ratified its view that the economy is neither too hot nor too cool.
That is a sharp contrast to the first few years of the Administration, when the White House barely contained its anger at Mr. Greenspan. The central bank raised rates seven times between February 1994 and February 1995, pushing the target rate for Federal funds -- the most important of two rates the Fed controls -- to 6 percent from 3 percent. Some of Mr. Clinton's advisers feared that those increases would choke off the economic expansion. They did not.
Then the Federal Reserve reduced rates three times -- in July and December 1995, and then again in January of this year. The Federal funds rate is now 5.25 percent and the discount rate is 5 percent.

HEADLINE: A Reckless Tax Cut

 BODY:
Bob Dole wants to cut everyone's income tax rates by 15 percent and throw in an extra $500 cut for every child up to age 18 -- a startling 70 percent reduction for a family with two children earning about $30,000. But, says a group of more than 500 economists, including seven Nobel laureates, the tax gift would be economically reckless -- crowding out valuable public programs and private investment that the economy needs to grow. President Clinton was cornered by Mr. Dole into offering his own tax-cut plan -- for families with young children, for college students and for employers who hire welfare recipients. These tax cuts are also tantalizing, but they too make little economic sense, as some of his own advisers admit in private. Yet there is a major difference between the two plans. The President's is too small to do great harm.
The Dole plan specifically names numerous tax cuts. But he is vague where he will cut spending to pay for his generosity. He mocks critics who say his huge spending cuts are implausible by claiming that his plan requires cutting only a nickel out of every dollar of Government spending. But combined with the cuts that Congress has promised, Mr. Dole's budget would require cutting almost 40 percent out of discretionary spending by 2002. 
 Mr. Dole's second defense is that his budget plan would spur growth. But as Paul Samuelson, Robert Solow, Kenneth Arrow and the four other Nobel winners made clear, the impact would instead be barely noticeable. Mr. Dole has his own stable of more than 100 economists, including four Nobel laureates, in support of his plan. But their case is weak.
Tax cuts can lift an economy out of recession. But the economy is now operating at full bore. For tax cuts to spur growth in this circumstance, they would have to encourage Americans to work harder and save and invest more. The Reagan tax cuts did not achieve these goals. Neither will Mr. Dole's. Another stain on the Dole plan is its unfairness. Poor families who owe no tax cannot take advantage of a child tax credit. But affluent families would profit from a tax cut on capital gains -- another Dole idea that he claims is the key to growth but that most economic analysis says is an economic afterthought.
Mr. Clinton's cuts are only a fifth as large as Mr. Dole's, putting that much less pressure on public programs. But Mr. Clinton makes plenty of small mistakes. He too fritters away money on a consumption-oriented child credit. He proposes a tax subsidy for students who enroll in college or job training and maintain a B average -- wasting money on families that would pay tuition without Washington's help, encouraging colleges to boost tuition and, eyeing Lake Wobegon, raise every student's grades above average. Nor will Mr. Clinton's proposal to enlarge a tax credit for companies that hire welfare recipients atone for his signing the Republican welfare bill. In the past, these tax credits have not worked well and have sometimes backfired -- signaling employers not to hire what must be a troublemaker if the Government is providing a bribe.
It is sobering to compare the 1992 and 1996 versions of Mr. Clinton. Then he proposed investing $50 billion a year in education, training, mass transit and national service. Now he proposes sprinkling inconsequential tax cuts. Campaign platforms are best read as declarations of priorities, not blueprints to policy. Read that way, Mr. Clinton's plan would do no harm even if he cannot figure out, with a Republican-controlled Congress, how to do much good. Mr. Dole's priorities risk damage.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CONGRESS;
Lawmakers' Shift to Full-Time Politicking Won't Mean a Change in Routine

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
There is serious legislative work going on as Congress hurries to adjourn, but not so much of it that it gets in the way of politicking.
Leaders negotiated today over provisions to drop from the immigration bill and additions to the spending measure intended to keep the Government running after Congress goes home to campaign full time, maybe as early as this weekend. 
 But for many senators and representatives, the transition from part-time to full-time electioneering may pass unnoticed.
First, the leaders guaranteed that there would be no votes until after 5 P.M. today in either house, allowing a long weekend of campaigning. That was more than five days since the House ended its last roll-call at 3:03 P.M. Thursday. The Senate, where only 19 senators are running for re-election, stayed around to vote on Friday morning at 10:30.
While many of them were arriving after four or five days on the stump, there were still enough members around today to do this sort of work:
*Hold a pseudo-hearing in which Democrats, who cannot call real hearings because they are in the minority, denounced Bob Dole's tax reduction proposals as a threat to farmers, education, law and order and the National Weather Service.
*Hold real committee hearings. One featured Republican attacks on Boutros-Boutros Ghali, the United Nations Secretary General, who was accused of exceeding his authority, as Mr. Dole himself says frequently. Others concentrated on complaints that naturalization proceedings were being speeded up to produce more Democratic votes or that Agriculture Department workers were being hounded to contribute to political action committees.
*Vote without dissent, but without a roll-call, either, in the House to denounce persecution of Christians. No partisanship was involved.
*Vote to kill another resolution demanding that the House ethics committee release its counsel's report on charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich. The vote was 225 to 173, with 9 members voting present.
*Attend one or more of the 21 fund-raising events for House members and candidates to be held tonight, out of 100 planned for this week.
The lines are not always clear. There is politics in some of the substance, and substance in some of the politics.
The immigration bill, which would increase border enforcement and restrict benefits to legal immigrants, is a major piece of legislation with enormous political appeal in states with large alien populations and large numbers of electoral votes and seats in the House, like California, Florida and Texas.
So Republicans have been in constant touch with Mr. Dole, their party's Presidential nominee. Today they distributed a letter urging support for dropping a provision that he had previously backed intensely, one allowing states to bar illegal immigrants from schools. The intent was to make it look as though he was behind the change of course, but the letter arrived at the Capitol after Congressional aides had told reporters the decision had been made.
The politics in the Gingrich motion was obvious. It was designed to embarrass Republican incumbents in districts where Mr. Gingrich is unpopular and where the race is close..
But the Democrats, and the four Republicans who joined them, also believe that the House is better off when its dirty linen is hung out to dry in public. And many believe that Republicans on the committee are stalling. They think they are covering up something serious in the report on the September 1994 accusation that the Speaker had violated tax laws and misused foundation money for partisan purposes.
And there were no nonpolitical distractions in the "forum" the Democrats held on Mr. Dole's tax plan. Democrats had Larry W. Mitchell, a Texas farmer, saying the spending cuts the plan calls for would decimate child nutrition, agricultural research and food inspection programs. David Glover, a special-education teacher from Red Wing, Minn., complained that Mr. Dole's program "would divert $5 billion per year in public tax dollars to private and religious schools."
A Washington police sergeant, Marty Pfeifer, said the cuts would hurt the Border Patrol, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the prison system. And Bob Sheets, former director of the National Hurricane Center in Miami, said, "Even a 10 percent cut would basically do away with the Weather Service as we know it."
Nor was there much doubt about the purpose of a hearing that Representative Mark E. Souder, Republican of Indiana, held on naturalization proceedings.
"The evidence suggests," Mr. Souder told the Government Reform and Oversight Subcommittee on National Security, International Affairs and Criminal Justice, "that the naturalization push may have resulted from direct order of the White House to naturalize new citizens to register them as likely Democratic voters."
There is nothing original about any of these ways of doing business in the last days of a Congressional session six weeks from Election Day. But, with relatively little legislation to debate and vote on, these devices were what was left to them when the motive was "let's get out of Dodge," as Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, described the House's mood.
"People want to load the wagons and roll them out," Mrs. Schroeder said.
It was obvious, to anyone standing outside the Capitol Hill Club or the Democratic Club, a few hundred yards from the House floor, what they wanted to load the wagons with. Tonight's 21 House fund-raising events, 6 for Democrats and 15 for Republicans, were only a start.
Before this week ends, the National Republican Congressional Committee will have run 80 such events, bringing in $50,000 or more, House Democrats will have held 20, Republican Senate candidates another 17, and Senate Democrats a dozen.
The Republicans have the edge on inviting names, too, with events like a New England-Style Fall Reception for Representative Peter I. Blute of Massachusetts. But the biggest haul of the week is expected to be the $3 million the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee plans to raise at Union Station on Thursday.
No wonder Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, got confused this morning when he was talking about leftover legislation in "the remaining days of this campaign -- er -- session."

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 20.71 as Fed Holds Rates Steady

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks ended lower yesterday as the Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates steady drew a classic buy-on-the-rumor and sell-on-the-news market response.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.71 points, to 5,874.03, just one day after closing at a record of 5,894.74. The Dow was also weighed down by a selloff in the stock of AT&T, which tumbled 5 5/8, to 51 1/2, on an earnings warning. 
 "We had a negative surprise from one of the bellwether stocks of all time," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines, 1,238 to 1,081, on heavy volume of 460.2 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Adding to the market's mixed character, the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 3.80 points, to 1,215.27, reflecting strength in technology shares, attributed to a positive reaction to an Intel presentation and to industry upgrades by Morgan Stanley and Hambrecht & Quist. Intel rose 3/4, to 96 1/2, in Nasdaq trading. In active Big Board trading, Micron Technology rose 3 1/4, to 31 1/4; Texas Instruments rose 5 5/8, to 57 3/8, and LSI Logic rose 1 5/8, to 24 5/8.
But other market indicators slipped. The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 0.87, to 685.61. The American Stock Exchange index dipped 0.22, to 563.40. The Big Board's composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.28, to 365.23, with the average share down 3 cents.
Several initial public offerings drew strong buying yesterday. Cross-Continent Auto, which operates six franchised automobile dealerships, climbed 6 to 20 in its debut. Hot Topic Inc., an apparel maker, rose 8 1/8 to 26 1/8 on its first day.
Apparel designer Mossimo extended its losses, falling 3 1/2 to 30 1/2 after sinking 6 7/8 Monday on its warning that its earnings would fall far short of analysts' expectations.
GMIS Inc. soared 6 3/16, to 23 5/16, after agreeing to be acquired by HBO & Company. The Fed's announcement in midafternoon initially set off a rally, sending the Dow up more than 30 points. A wave of selling soon followed, sending the Dow sliding more than 40 points before it reversed course yet again just moments before the close.
The Fed's decision, which had been anxiously awaited amid concern that inflation was building up, left the key Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans unchanged at 5 1/4 percent. The central bank also held the discount rate, which the Fed charges banks, at 5 percent.
Some analysts had expected the central bank to lift rates by a token one-quarter percentage point, which would have been the first rise in one and a half years.
Analysts said the market interpreted the Fed's inaction as a delay of an inevitable increase after the November elections.
Analysts cited a number of reasons for the choppy finish.
"The rally in stocks and bonds pulled back partly due to the dollar," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers.
Much of the afternoon seesaw activity in the Dow index was driven by a series of huge program trades.
According to Birinyi Associates Inc., a buy program initiated just after news of the Fed's vote added about 30 points to the Dow. That program was followed almost immediately by a sell program that wiped out those gains.

HEADLINE: In Clear-Cutting Vote, Maine Will Define Itself

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: ASHLAND, Me., Sept. 20

 BODY:
In Maine this political season, everyone is talking about one thing: The 10 million-acre North Woods, most of it owned by multinational paper companies, that help define the state's economy and its psyche.
They are talking about how far to go in redressing what everyone -- including the environmentalists, the Governor and the paper companies -- now agree has been years of industrial abuse. The spruce and fir forest that stretches across the northern part of the state was so dense 150 years ago that Henry David Thoreau, who hiked there, described it in his journal as "a standing night." Now it is crisscrossed with thousands of miles of logging roads, which run between vast clear-cuts where not a single mature tree remains standing. 
 Though the land is privately owned, the public has long enjoyed access to the North Woods for hunting, fishing, hiking and camping. Just as the state regulates hunting and fishing and development along lakes and streams in the woods, so has it for years established forest practices.
Now, a group of grass-roots environmentalists, led by a former gubernatorial candidate for Maine's Green Party, wants to ban clear-cutting altogether and severely restrict other logging practices in the North Woods. After collecting 58,000 signatures on Election Day last fall in favor of the ban, the group won the right to put a referendum on the November ballot.
But industry has countered with an alternate referendum that would restrict clear-cutting without banning it. Voters will get a chance to choose one of those proposals in November or to reject them both.
The stakes are high. Jonathan Carter, the former Green Party gubernatorial candidate, who lives with his family on a farm at the edge of the North Woods, said: "This is the last vestige of a great forest that is being destroyed. This is as important as saving the ancient forests of the Northwest."
With polls showing 70 percent of the voters favoring the ban last spring, the timber companies joined with environmentalists that are more friendly toward industry -- like the Maine Audubon Society and the Natural Resources Council of Maine -- and the Governor to propose their less stringent regulations. That alternative referendum, worked out in months of private negotiations between environmentalists and large forest landowners, is called the Compact for Maine's Forests. With the support of the Legislature, the compact was put on the ballot.
Each side says its referendum is the way to insure the health of both the forest and industry. The referendums would amend the state's 1989 Forest Practices Act, which is widely seen, even by many in the industry, as not stringent enough.
"This will be the first time the industry has allowed the public to come in and discuss their management with them in Maine," said Bob Perschel, the Boston-based regional director of the Wilderness Society, a national environmental group. The Wilderness Society has not taken a position on either referendum.
Maine's forest-products industry employs 32,000 people and generates pulp for paper and lumber valued at $5.5 billion a year. The state is the country's second-biggest paper producer, after Wisconsin. It makes paper for Time and National Geographic magazines and for The New York Times Magazine, as well as for lottery tickets.
Gov. Angus King, an independent who campaigned two years ago on a pledge to bring more jobs to the state, acknowledges that some restrictions are necessary, but he calls the referendum that would ban clear-cutting "a gun to the head of the Maine economy." He estimates that if it is passed, more than 15,000 jobs will be lost in the short term.
But Mr. Carter argues that the compact referendum "is a political document that virtually does nothing." Mr. Carter said the intention of the clear-cutting ban was not to stop logging, but to change it to a pattern of selective cutting that would keep the industry healthy. "We want the paper companies here," he said.
William Vail, who is executive director of the Maine Forest Products Council, the industry's trade group, and co-chairman of Citizens for a Healthy Economy, the political group formed to fight the clear-cutting ban, said the changes called for in the compact would "benefit the health of the forest, but they don't shut the industry down."
Recent polls have shown support flagging for the referendum to ban clear-cutting, and a poll last week in The Bangor Daily News indicated that 60 percent of the voters surveyed favored the more moderate compact referendum. The clear-cutting ban is backed by the Sierra Club on the national and state level.
Most Americans are familiar with logging debates about Federal land in the Pacific Northwest, where President Clinton ordered a reduction in logging in old-growth national forests in 1994 as part of a plan to protect the spotted owl. In Maine, the debate is over land that is private: the vast and uninhabited core of the North Woods, which stretches from north of Moosehead Lake and Millinocket to the Canadian border.
The debate can be found in places like Dean's restaurant in Portage Lake in northern Maine, where loggers gather for lunch; paper-mill towns like Rumford in the west; the state Capitol in Augusta, and cosmopolitan Portland, in the south. It dominates the front pages, the editorial columns -- which are unanimous in their support of the compact -- and the letters to the editor.
"You'd hardly know we have a Senate race," said Governor King, referring to the hotly contested race for the seat of Senator William S. Cohen, a Republican who is retiring. That race pits Susan M. Collins, a Republican who is the former New England director for the Small Business Administration, against Joe Brennan, a Democrat who is a former Governor.
The debate over the woods even takes place in the sky: The timber companies and the group advocating a ban on clear-cutting have been giving flying tours of the North Woods to politicians and reporters. The flight paths are different, of course. The timber companies show off expanses of green regrowth, while trips by those who favor a ban on clear-cutting feature miles of ugly brown swaths where clear-cutting has occurred.
Carole Haas, a computer programmer who lives in Cape Elizabeth, says she does not need to go up in a plane to see the damage. She has hiked through the woods near Millinocket. "It's hard to believe you're looking at something that used to be forest," said Ms. Haas, who is a volunteer in the campaign to ban clear-cutting.
"We're not tree huggers," she said. "We're not saying don't work the woods. The woods are the lifeblood of Maine. We're just saying work them in a responsible way."
Massive clear-cutting began in the mid-1970's to combat an infestation of spruce budworm.
The timber companies have one of the state's most powerful lobbying groups, and they have spent $1.8 million so far, much of it on television commercials fighting the proposed clear-cutting ban. The group seeking a total ban on clear-cutting has not had the money to put a single commercial on the air, Mr. Carter said.
While the debate has divided environmentalists, it has brought together paper company owners and mill workers, who are now fighting for the compact referendum. Maine has lost thousands of jobs in recent years as textile and shoe mills have shut down. Jobs in the paper mills, which pay $43,000 a year on average, including overtime, are prized.
"If we're not going to cut down any trees, we're not going to have any jobs," said Scott Grassette, a 30-year-old mechanical maintenance worker at the Boise Cascade mill in Rumford who followed his father and grandfather into work at the mill.
Thousands of logging jobs have been lost in Maine in the past decade because of mechanization. But the supporters of the clear-cutting ban say their referendum will create jobs. "The irony is that we're trying to save the industry from itself," said Jamie Sayen, the editor of The Northern Forest Forum, a bimonthly journal that covers issues related to the North Woods and the rest of the northern forest. "The referendum will mean more jobs for loggers' children and grandchildren."
If Maine sometimes seems like two states -- north and south -- then the debate has underscored the separation. The forest is largely in northern Maine. The votes, and most environmentalists, are in the more urban south, often viewed as more closely connected to Massachusetts than to remote northern Maine.
"We are not down to our last tree in northern Maine," said Robbie McKay, the leader of a group of property rights advocates in northern Maine who have been fighting bitterly against both measures. "When you have a clear-cut up here, trees grow back." She added, referring to southern Maine, "They have clear-cuts down there, but they call them shopping malls."
Near Ashland, Matt Libby's family has operated a sporting camp on a lake in the woods for more than a century. The land, which Mr. Libby leases, is owned by Great Northern Paper, part of Bowater Inc. Mr. Libby and his wife, Ellen, live in a log cabin made of spruce that Mr. Libby cut with a chain saw, and peeled and notched by hand.
"It was pristine wilderness 40 years ago, when I was a kid," Mr. Libby said. "The biggest change is the roads. If you go in a straight line, you'll hit a road."
He is leaning toward the compact. "It's not a park," he said. "It's a working timberland. Development is a lot worse than clear cutting."
The Lincoln News, meanwhile, has been crusading for the compact referendum in a series of editorials. One last week argued: "Although the 13 colonies that became states in George Washington's time may have done just fine without any regulation of their forests, it's a recipe for disaster in a nation of more than 250 million people consuming natural resources that are not infinite."

HEADLINE: The Joy of Deconstructing O.J.;
At a Symposium, Deep Thoughts and Cheap Thrills

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The crowd that filled the auditorium on the Upper East Side of Manhattan one evening last week was stellar indeed -- writers, academics, lawyers, publishers, a judge, a Pulitzer Prize winner and assorted other thinkers of big thoughts.
What was on their minds was, by contrast, rather earthy -- violence, celebrity, money, sex, race. They had come to find meaning in the one soap opera (now in reruns) that mandarins are not afraid to admit they watch. 
 The O. J. case, that is.
Cabdrivers may claim to have lost interest in O. J. Simpson. His civil trial may be making miserable TV. But in certain circles, some of them rather erudite, the subject of Mr. Simpson remains a big draw.
Professors at Cornell University are putting together an O. J. research archive. There have been conferences among legal scholars about the Simpson case. New O. J. books pour into bookstores month after month.
The most recent, "The Run of His Life: The People v. O. J. Simpson" (Random House) by Jeffrey Toobin, who covered the case for The New Yorker, appeared on the best-seller list this month within days of going on sale.
Toni Morrison is scheduled to co-edit a book of essays on the case by the likes of A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., the retired Federal judge; Ishmael Reed, the poet and critic, and the scholars Patricia J. Williams and Andrew Ross.
And the 92d Street Y in Manhattan, that venerable bastion of edification known for lectures on subjects like neurobiology and the world economy, has put three separate evenings of O. J.-related events in its 1996-97 program.
So what's the attraction? Social significance, or cheap thrills?
"Intellectuals are people, too," said Dr. Bruce Lewenstein, an associate professor at Cornell who is working on the Simpson archive with the help of a National Science Foundation grant. "We need excitement just like everybody else. We need good stories to hook our interest and tie our tables to."
Or, as Mr. Toobin put it: "It's a tabloidy guilty pleasure but it's also an important historical event at this point. To put it another way, this case has everything that obsesses the American people. It has sex, violence, race, Hollywood, sports. And the only eyewitness is a dog."
Let the record reflect: the panel discussion at the 92d Street Y last Wednesday was not, not a frivolous event. "The Law According to O. J.," read the topic printed on the cream-colored invitations mailed out by Random House and The New Yorker. "How the Simpson Trial Changed the Legal System."
The assembled panel was also impeccably august. (No talk show hosts without last names.) There was Randall Kennedy, the Harvard Law School professor; Judge Kimba M. Wood of Federal District Court in Manhattan, and Linda A. Fairstein, who heads the sex crimes unit for the Manhattan District Attorney.
Also on the panel were Mr. Toobin and Barry C. Scheck, the former Simpson defense team member who is a faculty member at Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School. The moderator was the impressively credentialed Fred Graham -- television anchorman, lawyer, award-winning journalist, Fulbright scholar.
But the big picture proved an elusive target. Much of the evening ended up being spent obsessing, yet again, over the blood on the socks, the bloody glove, whether Marcia Clark blew it, whether the police conspired, whether the defense went too far, what to make of those jurors.
If the trial had changed anything, it began to seem, it had changed the idiom. Obscure O. J. references whizzed by without translation. References to "the Bundy blood drops" and what juror No. 8 said on "Nightline" seemed to have acquired all the currency of Ross and Rachel's romance on "Friends."
So what had drawn this well-educated lot, some of whom had left their chauffeured black town cars idling by the curb? Harold Evans, the president and publisher of Random House, was asked in an interview: Was it their earnest interest in legal implications, or was it the titillating nature of the case?
"Well," Mr. Evans said matter-of-factly, "I think the latter would be predominant."
As for Mr. Evans, he had another agenda. By co-sponsoring the event with the 92d Street Y and The New Yorker, Random House was using the Y to help promote Mr. Toobin and his book. Just as Mr. Evans's wife, Tina Brown, the editor of The New Yorker, was using the Y to help promote The New Yorker and Mr. Toobin.
Ushers dispensed free copies of the current issue of The New Yorker to audience members as they left the auditorium after the discussion. And in a reception room next door, Mr. Toobin's book was on sale. The author himself briefly settled in behind a table to sign copies.
Upstairs, Random House and The New Yorker held a private dinner party in honor of Mr. Toobin with 150 invited guests including the lawyers Floyd Abrams and Ronald L. Kuby; the television personalities Chuck Scarborough and Jane Pauley, and Garry Trudeau, the cartoonist, who is married to Ms. Pauley.
Ms. Brown described the O. J. Simpson panel discussion as a "positioning event" to "reinforce links" between the magazine and a natural audience, the kind of people who attend talks at the Y. "It's a more subliminal approach," she said. "You get a lot of return on a small investment."
Mr. Evans, who at Random House has enlisted publicists from the film industry to experiment with new ways of promoting books and reading, said it would be accurate to describe his motivation in co-sponsoring the Simpson discussion as enlightened self-interest.
"Would I do it if I wasn't running Random House?" he said. "No.
"Would I attend such a function if I wasn't connected to Random House? Yes."
The subject of Mr. Simpson is, after all, more than simply provocative, several academics who have thought or written about the case insisted in recent interviews. They suggested that high-profile dramas, not unlike catastrophes, have at least the potential to shed new light on broader public concerns.
For example, the researchers at Cornell said their new Simpson archive -- legal papers, trial videotape, cartoons and other material relating to the use of DNA fingerprinting in the case -- is intended for the use of researchers interested in the issue of how society accommodates new technology.
And Dr. Christopher B. Mueller, a professor at the University of Colorado School of Law who helped organize a conference on the case earlier this year, said the spectacular nature of it simply insures a level of familiarity with the facts that makes it possible to examine deeper issues.
Not that the mere facts have lost their appeal, either.
Sylvia Cutler of Fort Lee, N.J., who attended the discussion at the Y, described herself as still "absolutely obsessed" with the case -- more obsessed than she had been with anything since Adlai Stevenson's Presidential campaign in 1952.
Miss Cutler said she had become absorbed almost immediately after the murder of Mr. Simpson's wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend, Ronald Goldman, on June 12, 1994. She had followed every new development, through Mr. Simpson's arrest on murder charges, his trial and his acquittal.
Now she was tracking the trial of the wrongful-death suit filed against him by Mr. Goldman's family and Mrs. Simpson's estate. Miss Cutler said she was heading straight home from the Y to catch a rerun of Geraldo Rivera's regularly scheduled O.J. post-mortem.
She said a friend, equally mesmerized, recently asked her: "When are we going to let go?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed Leaves Rates Steady, Cheering Administration
After weeks of speculation that the Federal Reserve would take a pre-emptive strike against inflation, its monetary policy officials decided not to raise interest rates, apparently believing the economy is cooling enough.
The inaction cheered the Clinton Administration, which had feared that a rate rise just weeks before the election could undercut the Administration's claim of success in handling the economy, creating record employment. [Page A1.]
 
Treasury prices moved higher. Traders were relieved by the inaction, and the yield on the 30-year bond fell below 7 percent. [D16.]
 
Stocks were mixed, with blue chips dragged down by AT&T's slide. The Dow industrials fell 20.71 points, to 5,874.03, but the Nasdaq Composite rose 3.80, to 1,215.27, on strength in technology shares. [D6.]
 
Paper Industry In a Political Storm
In Maine, where the forest-products industry employs 32,000 people and generates pulp for paper and lumber valued at $5.5 billion a year, this political season, everyone is talking about one thing: The 10-million-acre North Woods and how far to go in redressing years of industrial abuse. [A1.]
 
I.B.M. to Introduce Revised OS/2
I.B.M. plans to introduce the latest version of its OS/2 software, code-named Merlin today. But even I.B.M. executives concede that the new program lacks the legerdemain to make Microsoft's popular Windows disappear. [D2.]
 
Sun-Diamond Found Guilty in Gifts
Sun-Diamond Growers of California was found guilty of illegally giving more than $9,000 worth of gifts to former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy when his department was considering action on issues important to the group. Mr. Espy, who resigned under pressure in December 1994, was not charged. [A17.]
 
Loewen Rejects $3.1 Billion Bid
The Loewen Group, striving to remain an independent competitor, rejected a $3.1 billion stock offer from the Service Corporation, the world's largest chain of funeral homes. Analysts expected a new Service bid. [D3.]
 
Suit Against H. B. Fuller Dismissed
A wrongful death lawsuit filed against the H. B. Fuller Company of St. Paul, a leading adhesive manufacturer, was dismissed by a Federal judge in St. Paul, who said it should be tried in Guatemala. The suit was filed by the family of a Guatemalan teen-ager who died in 1993 from the effects of sniffing glue. [D5.]
 
Investment Advisers Watch Suit
If the Thompson family of Knoxville, Tenn., succeeds in an unusual lawsuit against Glenmede Trust of Philadelphia, lawyers say big changes could ensue in the way investment advisers do business. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Pro-Bono Campaigns to Fight AIDS
Peter Rogers, creator of the Blackglama mink campaign, is producing a series of celebrity-filled print ads for Gay Men's Health Crisis. More than 20 magazines have agreed to donate more than $1 million worth of space. Also, a print campaign, created pro bono by Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York will promote the Race to Deliver, a four-mile footrace through Central Park on Sunday to raise funds for God's Love We Deliver, which feeds homebound AIDS patients. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Pan Am Flies Again
Pan American World Airways, which is to be restarted today with daily nonstops between New York and Miami and New York and Los Angeles, is offering a generous frequent-flier plan. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D5.]

HEADLINE: No Sympathy for Ex-Wives

 BODY:
To The Living Section:
God forbid ex-wife Susan Wexler shouldn't be able to afford a housekeeper ("Ex-Wives of the Rich and Famous See a Film and Pronounce It Fact," Sept. 18). After 51 pampered years it would be extremely cruel to suddenly force her to start living like an ordinary person.
I plan to see "The First Wives Club" because I'm a fan of the three lead actresses and the premise seems like a very rich one. As an underemployed intellectual, I have my own source of resentment toward plutocrats who feel that their money exempts them from ordinary standards of decency. But don't think I have any particular sympathy for the women who marry them. 
 And why did you make no mention of the middle- and lower-class women who suffer real economic hardships after divorce? The Op-Ed piece on gender gaps from the day before ("Misreading the Gender Gap") had the story of a divorced woman forced onto welfare. Were you afraid an anecdote like that might have compromised the white-shoe tone of your story?
 
ANDREW DABROWSKI
Bloomington, Ind.

HEADLINE: Career Changers, Beware!

 BODY:
To The Living Section:
It was with great amusement that I read about professionals moving into the kitchen and the reaction of others ("Out of the Rat Race and Into the Kitchen," Sept. 11).
This month is my ninth anniversary as a culinary professional, after having been an executive recruiter in the data processing and financial fields for 11 years. 
 I welcome all of you career changers and dreamers. I hope you have the passion and the love of food and the industry that I do. Long hours and nights, sometimes 14 hours a day (10 to 12 in a row). Poor working conditions, poor equipment, inarticulate employees, inconsistent/incompetent management, cutthroat suppliers, etc. Just like the "real world."
Great money, if you have deep pockets, or know of them. Otherwise, you find yourself being shortchanged with mediocre benefits. Guess what: you, too, can be laid off! There are plenty of jobs out there. But for some reason the offers seem to be 15 percent to 25 percent below what you are making (sound familiar?).
So, after four months of unemployment, I am going back to work, this time in sales. No desk for me, and no one asking, "Why are there red threads in the saffron rice?"
 
DAVID GLAZER
Somerset, N.J.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Rise in Income Tops Inflation

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Per-capita income in New Jersey grew faster than inflation last year but slightly slower than the national average, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. The state's per-capita income -- total annual income divided by population -- went up 5.1 percent in 1995, to $29,848. The national rate of per-capita income growth was 5.3 percent. New Jersey's status as the second-wealthiest state (after Connecticut) was unchanged.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 919 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
U.S. Economy Is Off Track, Dole Declares

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 24

 BODY:
In an hourlong address today, Bob Dole stepped up his attacks on President Clinton and signaled that he was returning full-bore to his economic message.
"In every state I visit, every talk show, at every rally I address, I will be saying to the American people that you know how to spend your money better than the Government," the Republican Presidential nominee said to more than 500 people at the Economic Club of Detroit. "I will be saying that this economy is not good enough and not on the right track." 
 He said that in families with two wage earners, "one spouse works full time for the family, and the other spouse works full time to pay taxes to the government."
Mr. Dole suggested that President Clinton's inclination toward "activists meddling in expansive Government," as revealed in his failed health-care plan, resulted not from his being "a finger-in-the-wind politician who is waiting for the polls," but from a deep-seated, liberal predisposition to tax and spend.
Citing Mr. Clinton's 1993 tax increase and his "pork barrel" stimulus package, Mr. Dole declared, "These are the actions of an old-style, dyed-in-the-wool, big-spending liberal committed to a government that spends and spends and taxes and taxes." And he warned, "These are the actions of someone who, once the spotlight of the campaign has turned off, will take every opportunity to increase the size of Government even as he decreases the size of your wallet."
Mr. Dole said that as a percentage of gross domestic product, "Federal taxes are now at the highest level in history, the Government is taking more out of our economy than ever before in history, and families are working longer and harder but taking home less."
As an example of a tax increase that Mr. Dole said lurked in a second Clinton term, he said that Bruce Babbitt, Mr. Clinton's Interior Secretary, had just last week proposed a tax on outdoor equipment, including binoculars and bird seed.
But Mr. Babbitt did not propose this tax. It evolved over the last several years from state environmental and parks officials who said that because their state governments were too strapped for cash to maintain wildlife and conservation projects, they wanted a user fee on outdoor equipment. Hunters have paid such fees on guns and ammunition since the 1930's to help restore wildlife.
Naomi Edelson, the wildlife diversity director for the International Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies, which heads a bipartisan coalition of 1,200 organizations that support the fee, said she informed the Dole campaign a week ago that Mr. Dole's characterization of Mr. Babbitt's role was not accurate. She said Dole aides had asked for more information, which she faxed to them.
"It has nothing to do with the Clinton Administration," she said in a telephone interview today from Washington.
Whatever the source of the proposal, Mr. Dole drew chuckles from his Detroit audience today as he ridiculed it as an example of the Administration's tendency toward excessive taxation.
"If they get their way," Mr. Dole warned, in a waltz into unscripted terrain, "you won't even be able to escape the I.R.S. when you're hiking. They'll suddenly be walking along with you, somebody from the I.R.S., saying: 'You having a good time? Have you paid your taxes? Have you fed the birds? Have you looked in your binoculars? If you haven't, you don't have to pay the tax. You don't feed those birds, you're all right.' "
Mr. Dole cited several statistics in his comments on the state of the economy, including those on the trade deficit.
"Just the other day," he said, "the President's own Department of Commerce reported that the U.S. goods and services trade deficit in July reached a four-year
 high, $11.7 billion, an incredible 43 percent jump from June.
"That represents another slice out of U.S. economic growth, which is the disaster for American workers and their families."
 After spending most of his time lambasting Mr. Clinton and his policies, Mr. Dole outlined his own economic proposal -- including a 15 percent cut in Federal income taxes, a $500-per-child tax credit and a halving of the capital gains tax rate, to 14 percent from 28 percent -- as a sound way to restore economic growth.
Recommending his book, "Trusting the People," which describes how he would simultaneously cut taxes and balance the budget, Mr. Dole said: "The bottom line: Under our plan, a family of four making $30,000 will save $1,261 on their Federal tax bill."
Joe Lockhart, a spokesman for the Clinton campaign, said that despite Mr. Dole's "negative attacks, the economy is on the right track." Mr. Dole's plan would lead to cuts in Medicare and Medicaid, education and environmental programs "even deeper than last year's Dole-Gingrich budget," Mr. Lockhart said.
Meanwhile, a battle over endorsements was escalating between the Clinton and Dole campaigns.
The Dole campaign ran an advertisement on Monday in USA Today boasting that more than 100 economists and 4 Nobel laureates had endorsed the Dole economic plan.
Today, the Clinton campaign countered by pointing to a statement by the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research institute in Washington, denouncing the Dole plan as "not credible" and saying it would lower future living standards. It was signed by 546 economists, including 7 Nobel Prize winners.
The Dole campaign also released a list of 195 executives from high-tech companies in Silicon Valley who endorsed Mr. Dole's plan.

SECTION: Section C; Page 21; Column 1; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 878 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Muzzling a Vicious Pit Bull: Debt

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE INDEBTED SOCIETY
Anatomy of an Ongoing Disaster
By James Medoff and Andrew Harless
Illustrated. 241 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.
 
Most people juggling their multiple credit-card accounts might blame their mounting debts on a general failure of character, or at least on the late-20th-century mushrooming of too-easy ways to run up bills.
But James Medoff and Andrew Harless, respectively a professor of labor and industry at Harvard and a financial consultant with a doctorate in economics from Harvard, offer a kinder, less judgmental explanation in "The Indebted Society: Anatomy of an Ongoing Disaster," a study that looks deeply into the comings and goings of money, mostly the goings. 
 Mr. Medoff and Mr. Harless write that the slower productivity growth and stagnant wages of the 1970's placed American wage earners in a squeeze, and that by putting ourselves in debt we were partly trying to maintain our standard of living and partly trying to comfort ourselves with possessions.
Besides, we consumers weren't the only ones to sin, the authors add. Debt was general all over the economy. The Federal Government sinned, too, with the help of Reaganomics's attempt at a supply-side solution to our malaise. And corporations, too, thanks to the United States Tax Code and "a changing ethos in the American boardroom."
As a result, the American economy descended into a hell of "interlocking vicious circles": in one of them, corporate debt and reduced productivity nip at each other's heels; in another, low savings and slow productivity growth bite each other's tails. The authors love a metaphor. "This vicious circle, this pit bull foaming at the mouth, what damage has it done so far?" they ask. "It will take more than rabies shots to resuscitate growth in U.S. living standards!" So as well as the dismal science, as Carlyle named economics, we get a dismal sense of the mess we're in.
Yet Mr. Medoff and Mr. Harless identify culprits and a possible way out of the morass. The culprits are the people who lend, much swollen in number and wealth these past few decades; not menacing sharks or top-hatted men with gold chains, but ordinary citizens who invest in bonds and live on the interest. And they are supported by the members of the Federal Reserve Board, who put too much stock in "the NAIRU -- the 'non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment' (also known as the 'natural rate of unemployment')," which the authors characterize as a damnable chimera.
If only the Fed would realize that the evidence for this concept is shaky at best, the authors lament. Then it would stop worrying that unemployment below a certain point is inflationary, and it would take the productive step of lowering interest rates as the economy heats up, instead of raising them and strangling the economy, as it now tends to do. The authors grant that pushing for lower interest rates may seem illogical in a book "about the ill effects of debt." Yet their evidence is that "low interest rates don't really encourage borrowing," but stimulate the economy in various other ways.
But the Fed won't cut interest rates, they conclude, because its members aren't accountable to anyone or anything except a theory that appears objective yet isn't. So the hope the authors see lies in building a broad political consensus in favor of tapping the "slack resources" of the economy through "smart" Government spending and in reducing the Federal deficit by, um, raising taxes. Or if taxes are unacceptable in the present climate, then try tax-sheltered savings, because "a policy that successfully raises the U.S. private-saving rate is just as good as a policy that reduces the deficit."
One striking thing about "The Indebted Society" is how defensive and apologetic its authors seem for offering a liberal, Keynesian solution to the ills of indebtedness. As if to forestall criticism, they call themselves "bleeding hearts" for sympathizing with the poor and chronically unemployed. "Call us communists, if you must," they write elsewhere, "but we think that people who make a lot of money should pay most of the new taxes."
They are loath to call anyone a real villain, stressing that the lenders are often the borrowers as well and emphasizing the good intentions of the members of the Fed. And they mention several times the value of the police and military defense to the American polity, as if eager to distinguish themselves from old-line, leftward-leaning liberals.
All the same, their anatomy of the indebted society is clear and precise, and full of sensible proposals for measuring even more accurately our economic blood pressure and pulse. If you agree with even half their logic, the proposal of a tax cut now will seem altogether ridiculous. "Cutting taxes has the effect of raising government borrowing and reducing government investment, so as to intensify the vicious circle," they conclude. "In a democracy, tax cutting is the natural part of the vicious circle of undersaving and underinvestment."
Their book even makes you believe that if we were free of debt, we might not need the naughty thrill of running up our credit-card accounts. Just think, a month without unpayable debts! It might not be so boring.
