HEADLINE: French Stir Up a Boulle Run

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MASON 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
FOR five days, a chateau-hopping gaggle of prosperous Americans had savored the best Paris had to offer, ogling its Gobelin tapestries, inspecting its tortoise-shell Boulle cabinets, sampling the finest Champagnes and sating themselves on foie gras.
No less a personage than Bernadette Chirac, the wife of the French president, had personally escorted the group including Anne Cox Chambers, the communications heiress; Martin Gruss, the prominent investment banker, and his couture-clad wife, Audrey, through the Elysee Palace and into the garden to inspect her prized ducks. 
 And now it was time for the payback. "So," Mrs. Chirac asked, with a fearsome smile, "did you buy anything?"
Lured by an aggressive marketing campaign, a record number of wealthy Americans have been drawn to the city for the Biennale Internationale des Antiquaires, the world's ritziest antiques fair, at the Carrousel du Louvre. And suddenly Parisians renowned for their Gallic hauteur have been engaged in the delicate art of courting Americans, the better to liberate them from their millions.
Clearly the strategy has been successful: Two weeks after the biennial's opening, Americans had accounted for half of its sales, and 60 percent of its gross.
Why travel all the way to Paris to pay a hefty premium for pieces of "F. F. F." (as fine French furniture is known in the trade), many of which could have been bought more cheaply, and conveniently, in New York? Clearly, the French franc is an infinitely more chic currency to be relieved of.
"Anyone can have English," said Roger Prigent, a New York antiques dealer. "For me, it shows that the super-rich want 18th-century French furniture from the golden age. It's about real quality."
Princess Laure de Beauvau-Craon, the president of Sotheby's office in Paris, observed, "Many Americans feel that when they buy French objets d'art in Paris they are purchasing something that is somehow more authentic." Will Iselin, who is the head of the international furniture department at Christie's, described the biennial, which opened Sept. 12 and ends Sept. 29, as "pure theater, and the only thing that can rival the drama of the auction room." Referring to its 120 exhibitors, he said: "What else are they going to do? Just sit back in their shops and wait for customers?"
Hardly. So dramatic is the contrast between the rarefied atmosphere inside the biennial and grim daily reports in Le Monde about the economy, strikes and general malaise that one expected Marie Antoinette herself to burst forth any moment with a cry of "Let them buy Boulle!"
And French dealers are racing against time: the international auction world is coming to town, thanks to a change in French law that will permit Sotheby's and Christie's to begin holding auctions in France for the first time in January 1998, breaking a national monopoly established by Henri II in 1522.
"Sotheby's and Christie's will cause an earthquake in the French art market," said Herve Aaron, an exhibitor at the biennial. "It's our job to be strong and aggressive."
A further thorn in the side of the organizers of the 40-year-old event was its move two years ago from the opulent Grand Palais to the Carrousel du Louvre, a subterranean sprawl beneath I. M. Pei's glass pyramid. "It's a high-rent shopping mall," complained one dealer who pulled out.
"I think it has a very beautiful ambiance," said Bambi Felberbaum, a collector who traveled from Park Avenue and was taking photographs home for her husband's approval. "It's not easy for me to make purchases without him," she confessed.
Top Parisian decorators were enlisted to design the booths, some of which looked like ancien regime salons. Six were designed by Francois-Joseph Graf, known for his restoration work at Versailles and the redesign of a certain triplex on Park Avenue.
And whose triplex might that be? That of Henry and Marie-Josee Kravis, whose arrival to shop for their 26-room penthouse was awaited with predatory glee.
"Has anyone seen Monsieur Kravis?" was the plaintive cry of countless French dealers envisioning all the museum-quality wares it would take to fill the 68-foot-long ballroom he is converting into a library.
But he had shopped discreetly before the biennial officially opened, darting among recamiers and chenets de fer with Mr. Graf and ultimately buying palace-quality pieces from seven leading dealers. Though no one would say exactly what he bought, Mr. Kravis was said to be keen on a gold-threaded 17th-century tapestry, believed to be a Gobelin. Zut! Dominique Chevalier, the dealer, is committed to selling it as part of a set of four, priced at 14 million francs (about $2.8 million). Close to paradise for Mr. Chevalier, but not quite.
Prices at the show ranged from 500 francs ($100) for a French 19th-century coin to 20 million francs ($4 million) for a platinum-card-busting Picasso painting.
Were objets d'art eligible for frequent flier miles, an awesome number would have been accrued. Trans-Atlantic peregrinations included a set of nine Louis XVI painted landscape wall panels purchased in March at Christie's in New York, then resold in Paris to a mystery client of Mr. Graf's back in the United States. One Louis XV desk that sold for 250,000 (almost $395,000) in London this spring was for sale at $1 million in the biennial.
"Everything I've sold so far has been to Americans," enthused Ariane Dandois, who even sold the floor of her booth, to Juan Pablo Molyneux, the New York designer known for having paid $48,875 for Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis's tape measure at Sotheby's in April.
Organized by the Syndicat National des Antiquaires, a trade group of 400 elite dealers, most of whom are French, the biennial is highly self-interested. This year, with the help of Loving & Weintraub, a Madison Avenue marketing firm, the syndicat identified 162 "American patrons" who could, in turn, bring along deep-pocketed friends. Among those targeted were Anne Cox Chambers and the Kravises.
"I was very aware that I was being asked to join the Patrons Council as part of a marketing ploy," said Sharon S. Hayslip, an interior designer in Dallas whose clients include Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Jones, the owners of the Dallas Cowboys. "But I have to admit it was fun to be singled out. I hadn't even thought of going before."
But did she buy? "I have several things on reserve," Ms. Hayslip said. "With objects of that caliber you rarely make a split decision." (Another strategy, called "The Biennale Prestige Tour," offered up the visit with Mrs. Chirac and an assortment of dukes, marquises and baronesses for a $5,000 contribution to the American Friends of Blerancourt, a chateau museum founded in 1931 by Anne Morgan, the daughter of the banker J. P. Morgan.)
Pamela Harriman, the United States Ambassador to France, pausing to admire an English 1837 silver chandelier priced at $1.9 million, seemed puzzled by the presence of so many Americans. "I wonder if they're really here to buy," she mused. "Life has changed so much. It's hard to imagine many Americans today having a taste for all this formal French furniture."
One American who loves gilt to the hilt is Tina Turner, who was in town but unable to attend the biennial because of rehearsals for a series of sold-out Paris concerts. Stephen Sills, her New York-based interior designer, said that Ms. Turner's house at Villefranche, in the South of France, already includes a 21-piece suite of gilded Louis Philippe furniture, including a particularly ornate bed whose twin is in the Louvre.
Asked whether he detected a leap in the American taste for French furniture, Herve Aaron said, "I'm not crazily optimistic."
"It's true that most of the major collections in the world of great French art and antiques are in America," he added, "but there's always been a select few of very rich Americans who appreciate the quality of our antiques and can afford them."
He doesn't see that group growing. "America has become a society of sneakers," he said.
Sneakers have their virtues, however. They don't punch holes in Savonnerie carpets. But to judge by the number of Americans spotted in high heels at the biennial, formality isn't entirely passe.

HEADLINE: Banking Bill Retains Consumer Protections

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Sept. 21 editorial "Honesty in Banking" urges the Senate, and me as the Banking Committee chairman, to reconsider any contemplated rollback of the 1991 Truth in Savings Act. I agree with your position and oppose any extreme revisions to this law. 
 Last fall the committee unanimously passed legislation that retains the requirement that banks uniformly advertise an annual percentage yield. The final Senate spending bill does not do away with the disclosures that consumers might use in deciding where to deposit their money. It is to be hoped that the bill will also contain provisions that will protect taxpayers from having to finance another savings and loan bailout and that will improve credit report accuracy and privacy.
In recent years I have fought against high credit-card interest rates, double automatic teller machine surcharges and mortgage scams directed at elderly and working-class homeowners. Maintaining consumer protections and reducing consumer costs have always been a top priority for me, and I am confident that the final package will be true to these goals.
 
ALFONSE M. D'AMATO
Washington, Sept. 24, 1996

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Urges a Tighter U.S. Monetary Policy

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund called today for tightening of American monetary policy to avoid more drastic and disruptive action later.
At the same time, the fund urged Germany to continue interest-rate reductions it has made this year. 
 The call for tighter monetary policy in the United States and some further loosening in Europe came in the lending agency's spring review of the global economy called the World Economic Outlook.
The I.M.F. expects economic growth in the industrial nations of around 2.5 percent a year, with inflation remaining subdued at about the same level until the year 2000. This would leave unemployment in the United States, now 5.1 percent, substantially unchanged, while only a modest cut of perhaps two percentage points was seen in the high rates of European countries, now in the area of 11 percent.
Continuing fast growth was forecast among emerging economies, in the 6 percent annual range this year and next, which would increase the global average to around 4.4 percent a year during the rest of the century. Mexico and Argentina are expected to recover from their financial problems, African growth to accelerate, but expansion to slow in such Asian boom economies as Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia -- where, the I.M.F. said, recent growth rates had been unsustainable, creating a growing inflation risk.
And the I.M.F. said that nations in transition from socialism to capitalism had the potential to reach annual growth rates of roughly 4 percent. Eight countries -- including Poland, the Czech Republic, Albania, Croatia and Slovakia -- were expected to register growth rates of 5 percent or more.
Growth in the United States, after slowing to 2 percent in 1995, rebounded early this year and was forecast to reach 2.4 percent for 1996 and 2.3 percent in 1997.
Though the underlying American inflation rate has remained fairly stable at around 3 percent so far -- indeed, the report was released a day after the Federal Reserve decided there was no reason to raise interest rates for the time being -- the I.M.F. said the recovery now threatened to exceed the level "consistent with low and stable inflation."
"Some firming of monetary policy over the next few months would seem prudent," Michael Mussa, the fund's chief economist, said at a news conference today. He added that American unemployment had now fallen close to a rate at which inflation might start to accelerate, implying that any further reduction would be dangerous. "The risks are on the side of inflation in 1997," Mr. Mussa said.
In Europe, the monetary fund said it expected economic growth to accelerate next year, rising from only 1.6 percent this year in the 15-nation European Union to 2.5 percent in 1997, with German and French growth rates climbing in tandem from 1.3 percent to 2.4 percent.
Still, the I.M.F. suggested that continuing low inflation and a strong currency left the Bundesbank room for further cuts, calling it "still too early to conclude that the recent round of interest-rate reductions has run its course."
While European growth might in time cut a couple of points from the current 11 percent unemployment level, the I.M.F. warned that any further fall risked reigniting inflation unless governments did more to loosen their labor markets.
Japan's modest recovery was expected to accelerate, after two lean years, with growth reaching 3.4 percent in 1996 and 2.7 percent next year. But the I.M.F. warned that the Japanese must aim for a budget surplus to meet the costs of an aging population.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shakes Off Earlier Fall, Rising Against Yen and Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen and German mark yesterday, shaking off its plunge of a day earlier, when the Federal Reserve disappointed many currency traders by leaving interest rates unchanged.
In late New York trading, the dollar stood at 110.44 yen, up from from 109.00 yen on Tuesday. This was the biggest one-day jump for the dollar against the yen since Aug. 7, when traders responded to the strength of the United States economy and tensions in Korea. 
 The dollar also rose to 1.5156 marks from 1.5011 marks, the biggest one-day jump since April 9. The British pound fell to $1.5610 from $1.5655.
Analysts attributed the dollar's gain against the yen to Japanese investment managers buying higher yielding investments, and the dollars needed to purchase them, to improve balance sheets in time for Monday's halfway mark in that country's fiscal year.
The dollar rose against the mark as the German currency gave way to other European currencies on renewed confidence in plans for a single European currency.
Yesterday's currency moves reversed those of Tuesday, when traders dumped the dollar broadly after the Fed decided it did not need to raise rates now to cool off the economy.
"It's hard for market participants to be bearish on the dollar even if the Fed didn't raise rates, with the mark being weak in Europe and with sizable outflows from Japan," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, an investment advisory firm in Essex, Conn.
Even as the dollar fell Tuesday, many analysts pointed to the fundamental strength of the currency, especially with the United States economy stronger than other major economies.
Another bit of speculation in the markets has the Fed raising rates at its Nov. 13 Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which would give the dollar a boost since higher interest rates make United States assets even more attractive.
"Everyone's of the opinion that the Fed will tighten before the Bank of Japan does," said Martin Ely, head of spot trading at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in London.

HEADLINE: Sales Rate of Existing Houses Dropped Slightly Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Sales of used houses fell modestly in August, the National Association of Realtors said today. It was the third straight monthly decline as the housing market showed signs of leveling off.
The board said sales of existing, or used, houses fell one-half of 1 percent in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.13 million. That followed a revised estimate of a two-tenths of 1 percent decline, to 4.15 million, in July and a sharper 2.8 percent drop in June sales. 
 The August drop was not quite so sharp as forecast by Wall Street economists, who had expected sales to fall to 4.09 million a year.
The lobby group's new estimate for July, 4.15 million, was slightly higher than the 4.14 million it announced a month ago. The average price for a house resold in August was $149,900, up from $149,600 in July.
Despite three months of weakening business, August sales of used houses were 2 percent higher than a year earlier, when they were selling at a rate of 4.05 million a year.
The August falloff occurred despite cheaper long-term mortgage rates, and the combination seemed to suggest that some steam was going out of a robust housing market.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, said the average rate for a 30-year mortgage in August was 8 percent, down from 8.25 percent in July.
"The nation's housing market is easing in for a soft landing," said John Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. He added that after surging earlier this year, "it's only natural that the market will correct itself."
Sales peaked in May at a record annual rate of 4.28 million.
A waning housing market would be consistent with what appears to be the Federal Reserve's belief -- that the overall economy is slowing. On Tuesday, the Fed decided against raising interest rates, a sign that it believes the economy is likely to cool on its own and keep inflation in check.
During August, sales of used houses fell 9.5 percent in the Northeast, to 570,000 a year, while in the South, the nation's biggest regional housing market, they were down 1.9 percent, to a rate of 1.53 million. In the Midwest, August sales edged up nine-tenths of 1 percent, to a rate of 1.07 million a year, and in the West they increased strongly by 5.6 percent, to 950,000 a year.

HEADLINE: College Tuition Rates Show Steady Growth, Report Says

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
College tuition continues to rise by more than the nation's inflation rate, a situation that is likely to keep pushing more of the cost of college onto the shoulders of students and their families as government support shrinks.
The College Board, in its annual survey made public yesterday, reported that tuition for the current school year increased an average of 6 percent at public four-year colleges and universities and 5 percent at private four-year colleges and universities. 
 The change in who bears the cost of college has been especially pronounced at public colleges and universities, where more than four out of every five students are enrolled.
"We have made a major shift in cost from the taxpayer to the student," said David W. Breneman, an economist and dean of the Curry School of Education at the University of Virginia.
The shift has been steady. In 1992, tuition already accounted for more than a third of the revenue of colleges and universities, up from just a fourth in 1969, according to data compiled by Michael S. McPherson, president of Macalester College in St. Paul, and Morton Owen Schapiro, dean at the University of Southern California. Mr. McPherson said he expected the shift to continue.
"We're going to have to face up to the fact that states are no longer willing or able to continue to provide the across-the-board access that they provided 20 years ago," Mr. McPherson said, adding that the states were the engine in financing higher education.
Even with the higher tuition increases, however, public colleges and universities are still a bargain compared with private ones. In the 1996-97 academic year, tuition and fees for public four-year colleges grew by an average of $155, and reached an average of $2,966. At private four-year colleges, tuition rose an average of $607 to an average of $12,823, the survey showed. Two-year colleges showed average tuition increases of 5 percent, with public colleges rising to $1,394 and private colleges to $6,673.
The College Board survey involved 1,601 public and private four-year institutions with a total full-time enrollment of more than five million undergraduates.
Even as college tuitions have increased, college enrollments have increased to about 15 million, and educators said yesterday that college remained within reach.
"For most Americans, the fact remains that college is still accessible." said Donald M. Stewart, president of the College Board.
At the same time, financial aid is also up, the board said, although most of the growth is in loans rather than grants.
While many elite private colleges and universities now set their tuition at $20,000 and more, the College Board said that more than half of all full-time undergraduates at four-year institutions paid tuition of less than $4,000, and three quarters paid less than $8,000. Fewer than 5 percent pay $20,000 or more.
College graduates continue to earn considerably more than those who have not gone to college.
"College participation rates have been up through this whole period because the returns are so high," said Lawrence Gladieux, executive director for policy analysis at the College Board.
The emphasis on how people benefit from college, rather than on how the nation benefits from a better-educated society, may be one reason taxpayers have been willing to reduce their support for public higher education, some educators say. But Mr. Stewart and others stressed that higher education was an investment for society as a whole.
Private college tuition rates began climbing faster than inflation in 1980, as colleges tried to make up for inflationary increases they faced in the 1970's. But in recent years those increases have slowed.
David L. Warren, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, said this was the eighth consecutive year that the rate of increase in tuition for private colleges and universities had held steady or declined.
"There has been a very tough-minded approach by presidents, faculty and trustees to say what is central and critical to the mission of the institution and what is peripheral and can be eliminated," Mr. Warren said. "Making those choices has allowed the rate of increase in tuition to decline steadily."
The tuition at public universities, which saw smaller increases in the late 1980's than private colleges, began to rise more sharply in the 1990's, and showed double-digit increases in 1991 and 1992 as the economy slowed and states cut their support. Since then, their rate of increase has either equaled or exceeded the private colleges, although the dollar amounts remain smaller.
"The public colleges are struggling to maintain quality through price increases, given the tax revolt they have faced," said Gordon Winston, chairman of the economics department at Williams College and co-director of its project on the economics of higher education.
But state legislatures have begun to encounter resistance to their budget-cutting for higher education. New York State, for example, made sharp cuts in its financing of higher education a year ago, but pared appropriations only slightly this summer. As a result, neither the State University of New York nor the City University of New York raised tuition this fall, after making sizable tuition increases last year.
One small note of comfort to college students and their parents is the continued rise of financial aid.
The College Board said that $50 billion in financial aid was available to students last year, but that most of the $3.3 billion increase this year was in loans rather than grants.
The College Board said that living costs, which at some public institutions can amount to more than the cost of tuition, had also risen this year. Like tuition, living costs rose faster at public colleges than at private ones this year, although on average they are still somewhat lower at public colleges than at private ones.
The average cost of room and board at four-year private colleges rose 4 percent, to $5,361 for the 1996-97 academic year, while the average cost at public four-year colleges rose 6 percent, to $4,152.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Problems may be ahead for the world's vaccine program.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
YOU probably know the pitch: a few pennies collected for the United Nations Children's Fund by trick-or-treaters at Halloween can protect a child against a killer disease. In this case, the claim is only slightly exaggerated. For merely a dollar -- make that $15 if you include delivery to some of the least accessible places on earth -- Unicef can immunize an infant against diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough, measles, polio and tuberculosis. No surprise, then, that the World Bank estimates that the Expanded Program of Immunization-Plus, a package with the basic six vaccines, "has the highest cost-effectiveness of any health measure available today."
The catch is that the wide diffusion of vaccines depends on multitier pricing in which the wealthy markets bear the enormous development costs while poor markets cover only their share of the manufacturing costs. The "State of the World's Vaccines and Immunization," a largely celebratory report issued yesterday by Unicef and the World Health Organization, hints at serious political and economic problems ahead in keeping Robin Hood in charge of the game. 
 The focused immunization effort by W.H.O. and Unicef, begun in 1974, is a roaring success. Vaccination coverage against the six target diseases has risen from 5 percent of the world's newborns to 80 percent today, cutting childhood deaths by about three million a year. Polio will probably follow the way of smallpox into extinction within a decade, relieving developed countries of the need to spend hundreds of millions of dollars annually to immunize their own young.
So, too, is the system for keeping costs manageable in the third world. Vaccines are bought in bulk from private manufacturers at rock-bottom prices. A "cold chain" delivery network, developed over the years by Unicef and W.H.O. in coordination with local authorities, maintains vaccine quality with minimal use of high-priced foreign personnel.
But strains are showing. Vaccine sales at high markups in rich countries, needed to sustain variable-cost pricing in poor ones, is a continuing source of political tension. The issue made headlines in 1993 when President Clinton attacked discriminatory pricing against America, proposing as a remedy that the Federal Government act as a monopoly buyer of basic vaccines for the nation. And the new report suggests that such strains will grow.
For one thing, some 14 vaccines have entered the market since 1980 and dozens more are in the pipeline. Research costs, the report estimates, are running from $50 million to $200 million for every vaccine. And while most of the new vaccines are likely to prove cost-effective when the development outlays are averaged among wealthy and needy populations, nobody is rushing forward to foot the overhead.
"We've built up the expectation that antibiotics are expensive and vaccines are cheap," said Amy Batson, a senior official at W.H.O. "It's easy to justify high prices for medicines that save people, once they have a disease. It's a lot harder to underwrite the costs of prevention."
For another, ownership of the "intellectual property" in vaccines is growing more tangled as the research effort spreads from the old-line pharmaceutical houses to universities and private labs. This complicates the process of negotiating low or zero-royalty charges on behalf of customers who cannot possibly afford more than pennies a dose.
Perhaps most important, the lines between rich and poor consumers are becoming blurred. Rapidly growing economies like China and Brazil have far greater capacity to absorb the overhead in creating vaccines than subsistence economies like Bhutan and Somalia. One could also argue -- as President Clinton, in effect, did -- that poor Americans have a greater moral claim to vaccines at cost than, say, middle-class citizens of Brazil.
W.H.O. and Unicef offer a two-pronged fix. They want to divide the countries they now serve into four categories ranging from Laos and Mozambique, which will be asked to pay only a token share of vaccine costs, to Turkey and Malaysia, which will be asked to bear a substantial portion, to Russia and Mexico, which "would be left to their own devices."
Less specifically, they want decision-makers to get more serious about priorities. Vaccines that can be manufactured cheaply (like the yellow fever vaccine) should be delivered where they are needed as quickly as possible. But costs must be weighed against benefits for more expensive vaccines, like the one against Hib bacterial meningitis now widely used in the industrial countries.
Walter Vandersmissen, a spokesman for SmithKline Beecham in Belgium, agrees "as a matter of global principle" that most of the overhead in vaccine development should be assigned to consumers with deep pockets. But vaccine manufacturers are uneasy about opening their pricing policies to public debate, the likely consequence as the armory against infectious diseases expands along with costs and life-death choices became stark. "Everyone likes multitier pricing as long as the price they pay is the lowest," Mr. Vandersmissen said.

HEADLINE: New U.S. Bonds Could Prove To Be Tax Trap for Unwary

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
What could be more enticing to the long-term investor than a promise to protect returns from inflation's corrosive effect?
But the inflation-proof Government bonds announced today by President Clinton do not banish risk so much as exchange one kind of risk for another, experts say. As a result, they are likely to appeal mainly to highly conservative investors and could even prove a tax trap for the unwary. 
 "To herald them as a great investment for education and retirement may be a bit misleading," contended John R. Ziegelbauer, a senior manager at Grant Thornton, the accounting firm. "If you're going long term, you really should look for a mix of stocks and bonds."
Still, the novel securities will fill an important niche for both individual and institutional investors, analysts said. They will also benefit the Government -- and thereby taxpayers. The Treasury will get an additional tool for managing its huge debt that could save it money as long as inflation remains under control, while the Federal Reserve will get a pure gauge of inflation expectations that will aid its formulation of monetary policy.
Every investment represents a balancing of acceptable risk and potential rewards. Stocks go up and down by the minute and are worth whatever they will fetch when you want to sell. Bonds, which also fluctuate in price, generally give a lower rate of return over time. And while that rate is guaranteed in dollars, an unanticipated rise in inflation would mean that these dollars would not buy as much as the investor had hoped.
The trade-off for buyers of the inflation-proof bonds is that they accept an even lower stated rate of return in exchange for a guarantee that their buying power will not be diminished by inflation alone. Following up the May announcement of its intention to issue bonds that protect buyers from inflation, the Treasury said today that it would conduct its first auction in January and would offer the securities quarterly.
Yields will be determined by those bidding in the market. In Canada, Britain and other countries that have offered such bonds the real interest rate -- that is, the rate after inflation -- has fluctuated between 3 and 5 percent, experts said.
Initially, the Treasury will sell 10-year notes but other, so far unspecified, maturities will be added within a year. The amount will not be set until the close to the auction day but the Government pledged to sell enough to support a liquid trading market. Some private specialists believe the Government eventually hopes to have 15 percent of its roughly $5 trillion debt in what it calls "inflation protection" bonds. One official noted today that even 2 percent of today's debt would mean the Government would have to sell $100 billion worth.
From various choices, the Treasury decided to structure the securities like those that Canada began issuing in December 1991. These are so-called bullet instruments, whose principal amount is adjusted for inflation while the interest rate remains fixed.
Inflation will be measured by the most popular yardstick -- the Consumer Price Index for urban areas -- without any adjustment for recurring seasonal variation. There will also be a lag so that, for example, the rate to be applied on Dec. 1 is the C.P.I. for September.
The security is tailored with pension funds and Wall Street's traders particularly in mind.
"We think they work well," said Dan Bernstein, director of research at Bridgewater Associates, a Wilton, Conn., firm with experience in indexed Canadian bonds and whose pension fund clients will find their risk of mismatched assets and liabilities "completely erased."
Treasury officials said they delayed the first auction to give Wall Street time to develop a market for stripped versions of the securities, which will resemble today's zero- coupon bonds. They will be split into their principal and interest components and marketed separately. Money managers are already creating mutual funds based on inflation-proof securities.
The officials would not say whether the second maturity to be offered would be shorter or longer than 10 years. Private analysts predicted it would be a two-to-five-year issue, which they said would have greatest appeal for individual investors. A 30-year issue, by contrast, is most attractive to institutions.
The bonds will be sold in denominations as low as $1,000, mostly for 401(k)'s and other tax-deferred accounts, but others who bid for them were cautioned about adverse tax consequences should inflation surge.
With the new bonds paying the real part of their interest on a semiannual basis -- the inflation adjustment comes only at maturity -- it is possible that the bond will not generate enough cash in a given year to cover the tax liability it creates.
But that only happens at sharply higher inflation rates, Barbara J. Moore, a managing director of the SEI Corporation in New York, said. The break-even inflation rate for a taxpayer in the 28 percent bracket is 8.5 percent.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, promptly denounced the Administration for what he said was a failure to consult Congress about inflation-proof bonds. Mr. Archer argued that the bonds would create a "new level of uncertainty" about budget projections and asked the Administration to defer implementation.
A Treasury spokesman, Howard Schloss, said that Treasury officials had repeatedly discussed inflation-protected bonds with the Ways and Means Committee staff since April.
The Administration also announced today that it will offer by January 1998 a new inflation-protected savings bond to be sold in denominations as low as $50.
It also said it would propose legislation to expand the tax-exempt use of savings bonds to include vocational and other schools not now qualified and to eliminate the current requirement that buyers of bonds for this purpose be at least 24 years old.


GRAPHIC: Had inflation-indexed notes been sold in November '85, buyers would have been losers because prices rose less than expected. The notes, selling at an estimated real yield of 4 percent, would have paid $49 less than conventional Treasury notes and most of the payout would have come later.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Is Becoming 'National Spokesman' on Immigration

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Having received widespread attention for his outspoken positions in favor of immigration and against parts of the new Federal welfare law, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has recently found a new avocation: becoming what an aide calls the "national spokesman" for these issues at forums around the country.
In the last few months, the Mayor has received more than 100 invitations to speak on these topics, said his communications director, Cristyne F. Lategano. Most have been turned down, but he has accepted at least three, including a speech he gave earlier this month at the Georgetown University Law School in Washington, where he announced plans to file suit against the Federal Government over part of the welfare law. 
 On Monday, he will deliver the keynote address at a conference on "The New Immigrants" at the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. Next month, he is scheduled to give a similar speech at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. (He will not receive a speaking fee for the appearances.)
The Mayor has also made several nationally televised appearances on the subjects.
The burst of speaking trips represents an unusual departure for a mayor who almost never leaves New York City, even for a vacation. But he has warmed to his new-found role, which allows him to stress his distance from the right wing of the Republican Party -- still a political anathema in the city -- while becoming one of the party's more visible moderates.
"When he gets these invitations, what they tell us is that he's really become the national spokesman for these issues, the leader on these issues," Ms. Lategano said. "He views it as his responsibility to spread the word and go to other parts of the country to tell them firsthand the devastating effects of this anti-immigrant legislation."
Mr. Giuliani misses few opportunities to make these points at home as well, delivering similar speeches on Tuesday to the Manhattan Institute and yesterday to St. Francis College in Brooklyn. His remarks generally follow the same pattern: praising the industry and innovation of immigrants while criticizing the welfare law and other proposals that restrict benefits to legal and illegal aliens.
On welfare, he speaks highly of almost every major provision in the welfare law -- touting the workfare program he has built, the country's largest -- but attacks the law as an unfinanced mandate, saying it fails to provide enough money to cities and states.
"I'm a very big supporter of immigration because I think immigration is the principle that has been at the core of New York City's success for 200 years," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday, speaking to about 200 students and others at St. Francis, a small Catholic college in downtown Brooklyn. "It's the reason why this city is the wealthiest city in America, the reason why this city is the best-known city in the world. And there's the reason why this city constantly finds ways of renewing itself."
By cutting off food stamps and other benefits for legal and illegal immigrants, Mr. Giuliani said, the welfare law is hurting a group of people who actually work and own businesses in greater proportion than American citizens. This week, under orders from the state, the city began dropping some legal immigrants from the food stamps program, citing the new law.
"The Federal Government is saying, 'Come in, we'll take your tax dollars, but then if you get in trouble, and the job you thought you had, you lose, or you get sick, we're not going to give you anything,' " he said. "You, however, just stay here, and what's the city and the state of New York going to have to do about it? They're going to have to pay for it."
On Tuesday, speaking to members of the Manhattan Institute at the staid Union League Club, Mr. Giuliani, in response to a question from the audience, made a joke about the English-speaking deficiencies of New York City taxicab drivers but then quickly launched into his defense of immigrants. "I am the biggest supporter of immigrants left in the United States of America," he told the crowd, which did not applaud that particular part of his remarks.
Those who have invited Mr. Giuliani to speak say they find it remarkable that a Republican mayor is making such a strong case in favor of further immigration, particularly when the opposite sentiment is so frequently heard in party circles.
"We thought at a time in which people were kind of skeptical about immigration, we wanted to hear from someone who was going to speak enthusiastically about the contributions of people from all over the world to America," said Robert Kudrle, professor of public affairs at the Humphrey Institute and one of the organizers of next week's conference, which coincides with the Year of the Swedish Immigrant celebration at the university. "Mr. Giuliani has been celebrating immigration, and I guess it makes sense for a mayor of New York to do that."
Frank J. Macchiarola, president of St. Francis College, said that as a "good Democrat," he would not normally be a political supporter of Mayor Giuliani. But he said Mr. Giuliani's positions resonated well with his student body of 2,000, which is 20 percent foreign born.
"Let's give credit here where it's due," said Mr. Macchiarola, a former city schools chancellor. "In large measure, he has been outstanding in that regard, and it demonstrates a real understanding of what this city is all about."
On his radio programs and at his "town meetings," the Mayor has often received questions that are critical of immigrants, and he has wondered aloud whether his position represents "political suicide" locally. But having fallen from grace with the national Republican Party for endorsing former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, in 1994 and failing to endorse Bob Dole, a fellow Republican, so far this year for President, Mr. Giuliani has suddenly found a new doorway onto the national stage.
"He's the Mayor of a large city that serves as the economic engine of the country," said Ms. Lategano, denying that any political calculation was involved. "When he sees the value and importance of an issue like this, he believes it's going to benefit not only New York City but the entire country if there's an understanding of that issue."

RIFT IN DOLE'S IMAGE

SECTION: Section B; Page 15; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1101 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE PLAYERS;
For Its Stretch Drive, Dole Campaign Turns to a Turnaround Artist

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The G. D. Searle Company was a sluggish purveyor of Metamucil in an otherwise booming drug industry when Donald H. Rumsfeld became its chairman in 1977. By the time he left in 1985, its stock had quintupled. He repeated the trick at General Instruments Inc., a slumbering electronics business whose stock leapt to $51 from $15 a share during his stint there in the early 1990's.
Mr. Rumsfeld, in short, is a proven turnaround artist. 
 He says that is unrelated to his recent ascension to national chairman of Dole for President Inc., a struggling concern in which even some Republicans place little stock.
"I am a nonexecutive chairman," Mr. Rumsfeld said in an interview. "Scott Reed is the executive of this campaign, and every piece of it operationally reports to him. I have no line operating functions."
Nor does he need any. At 64, Mr. Rumsfeld is the campaign's eminence grise: a former fighter pilot, Congressman, Cabinet member, White House chief of staff, Secretary of Defense, diplomat, corporate czar and onetime Presidential aspirant who is Mr. Dole's peer and chief troubleshooter.
"He's strategic, he's substantive, and he's grown up," said Kenneth Duberstein, President Reagan's former chief of staff. "He makes the trains run on time."
He also is demanding, blunt-spoken in private and more than a little driven. He has often said he finds crises invigorating rather than daunting. Fortune magazine named him one of the nation's toughest corporate bosses in 1980; he addressed a cash crisis at General Instruments, a multibillion-dollar corporation, by shrinking its headquarters staff to 23, including clerks and a temp.
Mr. Rumsfeld says somewhat vaguely that his new job is "to do things, to look at things and give my thoughts" whenever Mr. Dole or Mr. Reed requests them. Others say that not only means assisting in daily organization and policy decisions but helping shape whatever long-term strategy can be executed in the six weeks of politicking left.
"The most important thing is what Dole's talking about on a daily basis," one campaign official said. "That's Rumsfeld's franchise."
His impact is hard to measure. Mr. Dole has nudged slightly upward in some voter-preference polls since Mr. Rumsfeld took on his new job on Aug. 27, and he has avoided any major gaffes. But both were to be expected as Mr. Dole gained experience and voters began to pay attention to the race.
Mr. Rumsfeld says his chief value is bringing an outsider's perspective to a Washington campaign.
"I think like a businessman, a noninside-the-Beltway person. And I have the kinds of passions and concerns and views that are very strongly held from having dealt with the Government," he said.
Mr. Rumsfeld joined the campaign in June as a senior policy adviser, helping to flesh out Mr. Dole's positions. He expected the job to take a couple of days a week.
He was wrong. As it became apparent that Mr. Dole needed bold proposals to define his candidacy, policy became the keystone of the campaign's strategy, and Mr. Rumsfeld's visits turned into a six-day-a-week job.
One obvious product of that was Mr. Dole's signature issue, his proposed economic package with its 15 percent cut in income taxes and other breaks for families and investors. Mr. Rumsfeld said he and Mr. Weber were "intimately involved" in that process, mostly by overseeing the experts who prepared a menu of economic proposals for Mr. Dole.
Donald Rumsfeld's resume is one long, virtually uninterrupted climb upward.
Mr. Rumsfeld -- friends call him Rummy -- was born in 1932 in Evanston, Ill. He was an Eagle Scout. He wrestled and played football in high school and later at Princeton University. He married his high-school sweetheart. In 1954, he joined the Navy, became a jet-fighter pilot and All Navy wrestling champion, and moved to Washington after his discharge in 1957.
Mr. Rumsfeld later returned to Chicago, decided in 1961 to run for the House, and won overwhelmingly in a campaign that left experts marveling over its grass-roots fervor. Back in Washington, he drew Suite 241 in the Cannon House Office Building; his neighbor in 243, Representative Bob Dole, became a family friend. So did Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan.
Mr. Rumsfeld quit Congress in 1969 to run what seemed a Nixon Administration backwater, an anti-poverty agency called the Office of Economic Opportunity. His deft performance, in which he shrank the popular agency without dismembering it, won him a job as counselor to Mr. Nixon and later as United States Ambassador to NATO.
When Watergate washed Mr. Nixon from office in 1974, Mr. Rumsfeld was overseas, isolated from its taint. The new President Ford brought him home, first as his chief of staff and then as Secretary of Defense. Newspapers called him the Republican Party's hottest ticket, a sure-fire Presidential prospect.
Instead, Mr. Ford lost the 1976 Presidential campaign, and Mr. Rumsfeld took a U-turn to private business at Searle. "I could very well have stayed around, been a butterfly waiting to land," he said earlier this month. "But I decided that isn't how I wanted to spend my life."
At Searle, he slashed headquarters jobs, sold off money-losing divisions and focused on consumer products and drug research, then the company's weak spot. The firm rebounded, and the Monsanto Company bought Searle in 1985 in part on the strength of its rebuilt pharmaceutical business.
After five years as an investor and consultant, he moved to General Instrument, this time concentrating the company's resources on cable and high-definition television. When the privately owned firm went public in 1993, Mr. Rumsfeld reaped $23 million from stock sales.
Most recently he was chairman of the board of Rand Corporation, the private, nonpartisan research organization, from which he has taken a leave of absence.
In 1988, Mr. Rumsfeld considered making his own run for the Republican Presidential nomination but dropped the effort, in part because of the money-raising that an all-out campaign demanded.
That campaign may have been hopeless. Mr. Rumsfeld says he does not feel that way about Mr. Dole's candidacy. In 1976, he says, he saw another Republican Presidential candidate -- his boss, Gerald Ford -- make up a 15-point deficit in a matter of weeks, only to lose to Jimmy Carter by a tiny fraction of the vote.
"The President is known to the American people; they're aware of him," he said. "The other candidate is not yet known to them, or to the extent he's known at all, it's as a senator. This campaign is just beginning."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald Rumsfeld, a switch-hitting star in politics and industry. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)
